HEADLINE: CHINESE, IN A MOVE TO ALARM TAIWAN, FIRE TEST MISSLES

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Friday, March 8

 BODY:
China began a series of ballistic-missile tests just off the coast of Taiwan this morning to discourage aspirations for independence on the island and to intimidate its 21 million people in the two weeks before its first presidential election.
This morning the Ministry of National Defense confirmed that two Chinese M-9 missiles had landed inside previously announced target areas off Taiwan's coast, one due west of Kaohsiung and the other east of Keelung. The Ministry said that it believed the missiles were unarmed and that the Taiwan military "would continue to monitor the situation." 
 Later, officials in Washington and in Taipei said a third missiles had been launched into the area off Kaohsiung. China did not say where the missiles had been launched from.
In recent weeks China has been increasingly combative toward Taiwan, denouncing what it said were relentless efforts by Taiwan's leaders to move the island toward independence. China regards Taiwan as a renegade province and has said repeatedly that it would take military action to prevent the island from asserting independence.
The Chinese Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, said today that the people of Taiwan should not panic over the missile tests, but he warned of a "real disaster" if they supported independence for the island.
"The Taiwan compatriots don't have to panic over the pending military exercises by the People's Liberation Army," the New China News Agency quoted Mr. Qian as saying at the National People's Congress. "What they should really worry about is that the 'independence' seekers, with support from some international forces bent on splitting China, continue on their wrong path. That will be a real disaster."
Here in Taiwan, the Mainland Affairs Council, which plots the country's policy toward China, the missile tests.
"By firing missiles at us, Beijing is clearly using military means to attain political ends," Kao Koong-liang, the vice chairman of the council, said at a news conference. "It is attempting to influence popular morale and to obstruct the development of our constitutional democracy.
"This kind of brutal intimidation and provocation creates feelings of extreme antipathy toward the Beijing authorities among the people of Taiwan and also seriously harms relations across the Taiwan Strait and delays national unification."
In Washington, the State Department called the tests "unnecessarily provocative" and "reckless."
The missile tests, clearly intended to shock the people of Taiwan, were the most aggressive Chinese actions toward Taiwan since the 1950's, when Beijing shelled some offshore islands under Taiwan's control.
This morning's tests are the third time China has fired test missiles into the waters around Taiwan, a tactic it adopted after a visit by President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan to the United States last June. But the tests this morning were far closer to Taiwan than previous ones, just 22 miles from Keelung, a northern fishing port, and 32 miles from Kaohsiung, one of Asia's busiest container-port terminals.
Major shipping companies announced on Thursday that they would continue to use the port at Kaohsiung but said they would skirt the target zone. In Japan, the Transport Ministry announced that it was rerouting all commercial flights away from Taiwan.
In the past week Taiwan has been swept by rumors of war and has witnessed runs on the American dollar, some hoarding of food and a blizzard of pronouncements from the three candidates for president.
"Everyone is worried," said Hsu Lu, the general manager of the Voice of Taiwan, an independent radio station here. "People are talking about this on the streets, on the radio of course, everywhere."
Taiwan's Government has sought to reassure the island's 21 million citizens with a stream of declarations about the country's military preparedness.
The China News quoted an unnamed Defense Ministry official as saying that while Taiwan was not able to intercept any wayward missiles from the mainland, the Taiwan Air Force was prepared to bomb missile bases in China "under the right circumstances."
At a campaign rally on Thursday, President Lee said the tests were intended to undermine Taiwan's democracy and to dissuade people from voting for him. "Don't be afraid," he declared. "Let's unite together and show our strength to the Chinese Communists."
Mr. Lee's opponents were preoccupied with the tests as well. Chen Li-an, an independent candidate, demanded that the President apologize for "bringing the country to the brink of war," according to The China News. And Peng Ming-min, the candidate of the Democratic Progressive Party, which seeks complete independence for Taiwan, called China a "bully, uncivilized, barbarian."
On Thursday, even before any missiles were fired, many banks were experiencing heavy buying of American dollars, according to local newspaper reports. The New Taiwan dollar was hit hard by heavy selling and lost three cents; a further fall was prevented only by the intervention of the Central Bank. Stock prices, which were rocked earlier this week, recovered strongly today.
Many supermarkets around the capital reported heavy buying of toilet paper and rice. "I told my sister to stock some toilet paper and food at home just in case there was a war," Pei Mei-kuei, a housewife in her late 50's, told Reuters on Thursday. "It probably won't happen, but it will be difficult to buy necessities if there is a war. It's better to get prepared."
Gold dealers were reporting that the sale of gold bars, a traditional haven in times of trouble, were running 20 to 30 percent above normal.
In Washington, the White House was "deeply disturbed," said its spokesman, Michael D. McCurry. He said the national security adviser, Anthony Lake, would meet today with his Chinese counterpart, Liu Huaqiu, a Deputy Foreign Minister, to talk over the sharply elevated tensions in the Taiwan Strait.
Hours after the tests, Secretary of State Warren Christopher sought to "get a dialogue going" over dinner with Mr. Liu, who was on a private visit to Washington. But Mr. Liu, like other Chinese diplomats, was not listening very closely to American concerns about human rights, trade deficits, copyright violations and Beijing's sales of missiles and nuclear-weapons technology.
Mr. Liu wanted most of all to air China's grievances over Taiwan, officials said. Chinese officials expressed fury today over the elections, and the refusal of Taiwan's leaders to discuss reunification with China.
They also lashed out at the State Department's criticism of Beijing's human rights record in a report issued on Wednesday.
A State Department official stressed that the missile tests were not acts of war or terror. As long as the missiles hit the target areas and do not strike Taiwan, the tests are no more than political theater, he said -- "but a little too close to the edge of the stage."
"The view here is that these tests, while clearly meant to make a political impact, do not constitute an economic blockade, or an attempt to mess Taiwan up commercially or economically," he said.
In Beijing on Thursday, the Foreign Ministry spokesman rejected criticism from the United States Defense Secretary, William J. Perry, and from Mr. Lake, the national security adviser.
"Actually, it is China who should be protesting," Mr. Shen said, "because the question of Taiwan is entirely China's internal affair in which no other country has the right to interfere."

HEADLINE: Dairy Legislation Takes Inclusive Approach

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Francis W. Rodgers (letter, March 5) is wrong in his assessment of my dairy proposal. Instead of criticizing me, he should thank me. 
 Mr. Rodgers's contention that my proposal would adopt nationwide the California practice of fortifying the milk we drink, resulting in a price jump of 30 to 40 cents a gallon, is backward. My legislation repealed that idea. Mr. Rodgers's beef should have been with the Agriculture Committee, which put forth the idea, rather than with the 258 of us in the House who emphatically rejected the costly suggestion.
Yes, my amendment has the support of New York's hard-working dairy farmers, who every year contribute tens of thousands of jobs and millions of dollars to New York's economy and tax revenues. My amendment also received the support of major consumer organizations and taxpayer groups. That is because this legislation prepares the dairy industry for competition in the 21st century.
How did we accomplish that? By getting the Federal Government permanently out of the practice of subsidizing the production of butter, powered milk and cheese within five years. By fully financing dairy export initiatives to create more markets for America's dairy products. And by requiring the Department of Agriculture to take the regional dairy pricing system, which does not cost taxpayers a nickel, and consolidate its 33 regions into 10 to 14.
This inclusive approach to achieving workable reform of the dairy industry is what guaranteed passage in the House of Representatives, not any amount of campaign contributions.
 
GERALD B. SOLOMON
Member of Congress, 22d Dist., N.Y.
Washington, March 5, 1996

HEADLINE: Always Busy, Seemingly by Accident

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW 

 BODY:
Onstage, Brian Murray communicates a certain verity and an authenticity, whether he is playing Falstaff or a shady character in a Joe Orton black comedy. This is, of course, both a key to his virtuosity and also a reason he is not more celebrated. It is not easy to define a Brian Murray role, which is why he can seem so infinite.
In less than one year's time, he has been acclaimed in leading roles in three plays in New York. With witty precision, he is currently playing an unscrupulous entrepreneur of no fixed profession in Orton's "Entertaining Mr. Sloane" at the CSC. Earlier this season, he was a deeply compassionate homosexual Anglican priest driven from his parish in David Hare's "Racing Demon." Before that, he transformed himself into nine different characters, including the flamboyant title role, in a freewheeling adaptation of Graham Greene's "Travels With My Aunt." 
 For Mr. Murray, this is simply his latest halcyon year, but the hyperactivity is, as always, a coincidence. Despite four profitable decades as an actor, most of them on the New York stage, he continues to be vulnerable to the vagaries of the profession. He never knows where his next role -- or his next directorial assignment -- will come from.
Over an iced tea after a recent student matinee at the CSC, he said, "The best thing about being on a roll: you keep working out, working all the muscles at once." When he was asked if he had ever been out of work, he replied in the negative, but superstitiously knocked so hard on the cafe table that, for a moment, the table seemed to be in danger of collapsing.
That response is characteristic of the man, who by his own description is highly emotional on stage and off. "I'm what's known as a spendthrift soul," he said, adding that his quest as an actor has been "to learn economy." Even as an older actor -- he is 58 -- he still conveys a youthful exuberance on stage.
Mr. Murray is one of a small band of highly accomplished actors who are consistently employed in the New York theater. One difference between him and his peers (like Philip Bosco) is that he was born in South Africa and received his early acting training in England. He is an American citizen, and his approach to roles could be considered American. Only a slight English accent, accentuated when needed in performance, is a giveaway of his background.
Culturally, he is mid-Atlantic, which is not to suggest that he is at sea playing either Americans or Englishmen. In England he has played Arthur Miller and Tennessee Williams. Here, he has been called upon to play Hugh Leonard ("Da"), David Rudkin ("Ashes") and Michael Frayn ("Noises Off"). Along with his compatriot Brian Bedford, he is one of the American theater's favorite transplanted Englishmen. (Mr. Bedford's distinction is that he often plays Frenchmen, in adaptations of Moliere.)
Encouraged by his mother, who had been a dancer, Mr. Murray had his first taste of theater as a child actor in Johannesburg. Moving to England, he soon began playing "lower-class hoodlums" in films and on television. Both he and Mr. Bedford were Teddy boys in the 1959 movie "The Angry Silence."
In 1961, Mr. Murray began the first of four years with the Royal Shakespeare Company at Stratford-Upon-Avon. With only five days notice, he was moved up from a small role to play Romeo. It was a turning point for him, but in an unexpected way. Performing with Edith Evans and Dorothy Tutin, he realized that until then he "had gotten away with being cocky and facile," and that there was an abyss between what he had been doing and "real acting."
His education had begun, but he decided to continue it in the United States. After coming here first in Peter Brook's historic "King Lear" (he played Edgar to Paul Scofield's Lear), then in the Broadway premiere of "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead," he stayed on, studying at the Actors Studio and other New York workshops. With only a brief period as a leading man, he quickly made the transition from juvenile to character actor.
If he had stayed in London, he said, he would have become a member of the acting establishment and he might have been honored with a C.B.E. or even a knighthood. Instead he chose to emigrate, attracted by the opportunity and the vitality of the American theater.
He remains a most ardent admirer of Mr. Scofield for his "simplicity, stillness and integrity," while also having a great affinity for American actors. "They tend to dig a little more into roles," he said. "They don't take things for granted, particularly when playing English parts." Looking back on his days in England, he said: "I felt too big and clumsy and not witty and elegant enough for England. I always felt my elbows were in everybody's way." In an emotional sense, he said, he "couldn't hold back."
Although he has not acted in England since 1970, several years ago he returned to South Africa to do "Shadowlands," the first time he had performed there since he was a child. It was the year after his mother died, and the experience was, he said, therapeutic because his character in the play "can't show tears, except in the little scene at the end." He recalled, "I was able to find my way through the pain I was feeling at being an orphan, at a ripe old age."
When he was asked how he is able to cry onstage, he said, "As a kid, I used to do it by yawning, and holding down the yawn." He demonstrated, and tears clouded his eyes. Now, he said, he can cry by feeling the emotion of the scene, which is what he did in "Shadowlands" and "Racing Demon." More often he is called upon to win laughs. Comedy of all varieties is his specialty.
Turning to his sharply sardonic role in "Mr. Sloane," he compared Orton to Noel Coward as a writer of high comedy, despite the fact that Orton wrote from a lower-class perspective. "I can't help feeling that he was influenced by Coward," he said. "What did they call him: the working-class Wilde? I think this play is closer to Coward. Coward's people always seem to inhabit a nonworld of actors and artists. They never seem to have a proper job. When it comes to that, neither do the people in Orton."
Mr. Murray works with equal frequency on Broadway and Off Broadway (and also acts in regional theater), and finds only one major difference in the stages: "In a small space like the CSC," he said, "you have to be careful not to push it, not to mug. It's a danger because I've got a very expressive face." Then with a look of fervent commitment, he added: "I can't live without the other character: the audience. I don't know how one can survive as an actor without sharing the same experience in the same room."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Price of Orange Juice Takes Off As Cold Snap Threatens Florida

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Orange juice prices surged to their highest levels in nearly four years on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday as cold weather threatened Florida's crop.
On other commodities markets, copper prices advanced on signs of increased demand and a sharper drawdown in supplies. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodities gained 0.92 point, to 245.37. Falling crude oil prices drove the energy-weighted Goldman Sachs Commodity Index down 0.63 point, to 194.11. 
 Florida's weather will be unseasonably cold this weekend through Wednesday, with temperatures close to freezing, according to the Weather Services Corporation in Lexington, Mass.
Prospects of crop damage or reduced juice yields heightened concern that already-low supplies of orange juice were getting smaller, traders said.
"Any time you have weather like this, it puts pressure on the market to go up, especially now with the market so tight," said Ken Shoop, vice president of operations at the Peace River Packing Company, an orange cooperative in Fort Meade, Fla.
May orange juice soared 8.6 cents, or 6.6 percent, to $1.3775 a pound, the highest price for the active contract since April 23, 1992.
Brisk demand, particularly for fresh juice, has helped drive Florida's stockpiles of frozen concentrated orange juice down 17 percent from last year, according to the Florida Department of Citrus.
Copper surged to a 10-week high after reports of a strengthening construction market and falling stockpiles signaled robust demand.
The Labor Department said the economy added 705,000 new jobs in February, including a rise of 121,000 in construction employment, while the Commerce Department said construction spending rose three-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $537.6 billion in January.
"The huge employment number, which was a much larger gain than expected, propelled copper higher," said Monica Chitnas, a vice president of J. P. Morgan Commodities in New York.
Copper for May delivery on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange rose 2.7 cents, to $1.199 a pound, the highest since Dec. 29.
Falling stockpiles also indicated a healthy copper market. The London Metal Exchange said copper stockpiles fell a larger-than-expected 4,250 metric tons, to 343,525 tons, between Tuesday and Thursday.

HEADLINE: THE DOWNSIZING OF AMERICA;
On Wall Street: For Richer, for Poorer?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Is Wall Street really to blame?
In some ways, the answer is yes.
In recent years, investors have put pressure on companies to slim down, to be more competitive. And the takeover wave of the mid-1980's showed many corporate bosses that if they did not put their shareholders first, they might themselves be unemployed after a takeover. 
 Moreover, pressure from money managers has helped reshape the compensation system for chief executives. A large part of the pay of top management these days is in stock options, which are valuable only if the share price goes up.
But who is Wall Street? Increasingly, it is us.
"We're all shareholders now," said Byron Wien of Morgan Stanley, the big brokerage firm. "What happens on Wall Street is not just the concern of some wealthy investors in New York. There is a broad range of people owning stocks and mutual funds for themselves, or for their retirement funds."
Those owners are, of course, primarily the middle class and rich. But a 1992 New York Stock Exchange study estimated that households earning less than $100,000 a year owned slightly more than half of all shares held by individuals. More than 51 million people owned stock then, up from 30 million in 1980 and just 12 million in 1959. And 31 percent of American households owned mutual funds, a mutual fund industry group estimated last year, up from fewer than 10 percent two decades ago.
Mutual fund managers and pension fund managers are often the ones who squeeze companies the hardest. The California Public Employees Retirement System, known as Calpers, has picked out numerous underperforming companies, demanding that they shape up.
Patricia Macht, a Calpers spokeswoman, said the fund, with nearly $100 billion in assets held for a million active and retired beneficiaries, prefers that companies improve shareholder returns without layoffs. But, Ms. Macht added, "There are companies that are fat, that have not taken a good look at the number of employees they need."
Most pension funds are not as outspoken, but all of them are seeking good returns. Indeed, that is the primary focus of their money managers, as it must be under Federal law. The conundrum is that there is no way to ask the fund's investors if they would prefer less emphasis on profits and more on keeping people like themselves employed.
Take the case of First Interstate Bancorp, a large California bank, which sought to fight off a takeover attempt from a rival, Wells Fargo, by merging with a Minneapolis bank. The deal would have given shareholders a windfall of at least 30 percent and saved nearly all the jobs at both banks. But Wells Fargo -- which vowed to close 400 overlapping branches and layoff upward of 9,000 employees -- prevailed, mostly because investors wanted its slightly better offer.
Americans always had a bigger stake in the stock market than they knew, because pension funds owned stocks as well as bonds. But in most cases the performance did not directly affect the payout of the traditional defined-benefit plans, which effectively promised to make up any shortfall in investment results.
That was before the rise of defined-contribution plans, in which the employee controls where the money goes, and benefits or suffers depending on how the investments perform. In 1984, only 27 percent of the assets in pension plans were in defined-contribution plans. Today, that number is more than 40 percent.
Every time someone transfers his or her retirement savings from one mutual fund to another one, seeking better performance, just a little bit more pressure is being applied to corporate America.
Wall Street is unrepentant, arguing that a company that does not grow more efficient by ridding itself of unneeded workers might find itself hopelessly uncompetitive, and thus unable to employ any workers. "Ignoring profitability," Mr. Wien said, "is the road to doom."
Similarly, the economy even may better off because workers who are not productive at one company are freed up to work somewhere else. That argument, of course, rings rather hollow to those affected.
Wall Street has long been known for taking a good idea and carrying it to excess, and perhaps that is happening now. Often the easiest way to get an enthusiastic reception from investors is to announce plans to cut costs.
When the United States was the dominant economy in the world, it was easier for companies to avoid these stark choices and still earn hefty profits. But the collapse of competitiveness in the 1970's changed that view. It probably won't return soon.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Jobs Report Sends the Dollar Up, Down, Then Up Yet Again

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar ended higher yesterday after a roller-coaster session, bolstered by the Government's surprisingly strong report of job growth in February.
The Labor Department's report of a larger-than-expected gain of 705,000 in nonfarm payrolls last month devastated the stock and bond markets, since it all but wiped out chances that the Federal Reserve would lower interest rates again soon to stimulate the economy. 
 Currency traders faced a quandary after the release of the employment report, which they had been awaiting all week. The strength of the report weakened the case for the Federal Reserve to lower short-term interest rates; lower rates typically hurt a currency. But the sharp selloff in the American stock and bond markets threatened to diminish demand for dollars by foreign investors.
Dennis Pettit, foreign exchange manager at Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, said: "At first the market decided a strong economy is good for the dollar. Then once the asset markets sold off, it decided that wasn't good for the dollar. Finally, we decided that higher bond yields are good."
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar rose to 105.72 yen, from 105.25 yen on Thursday. The dollar was changing hands at 1.4840 marks, up from 1.4763 marks. The pound fell to $1.5235, from $1.5295.
"Today you could almost throw everything you knew about the dollar out the window," said Jay Wertheimer, senior foreign exchange trader at Banco di Sicilia. "People decided they had to buy the dollar and they didn't care at what level."
The rise in the dollar came as the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 171.24 points, and Treasury prices plunged.
The employment data were somewhat skewed by bad weather and Federal Government shutdowns that hampered job growth in January. But few currency traders were willing to buck the trend.
European investors reportedly snapped up the dollar eagerly after the report, and the dollar may have been bolstered by rumors that central banks had gotten in contact with dealers about buying the dollar below 1.48 marks.
The widespread buying interest left the dollar in a position to test the 1.50-mark level in coming sessions, traders said.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Paying A Price For Candor

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
THE Housing Authority isn't talking about Rafael Sencion. Nor is the Mayor's office. Their silence is understandable since Mr. Sencion is suing them for reneging on a job offer, and they prefer not to comment on such matters.
Last May, the same people he's taking to court couldn't wait to court Mr. Sencion, a tenant organizer and bachelor who volunteered for a layoff to spare the job of a co-worker and family man with less seniority. No doubt moved by his selfless act, city officials offered him a similar job at the Housing Authority and whisked him through personnel. 
But there would be no press conference where all parties could trumpet a feel-good fable for tough fiscal times. Mr. Sencion, troubled by the narrow focus on his own generosity, wrote an opinion piece for New York Newsday, in which he urged Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to rethink the cuts that led to the layoffs at not-for-profit service groups like the one were he used to work.
Bad move. The day the piece appeared, Mr. Sencion said housing officials withdrew the $35,000 job offer. A later attempt to get a job at the Civilian Complaint Review Board also went nowhere. He thinks he was blackballed, which is why he sued the city this week, alleging infringement on his First Amendment rights.
SHOULD he have shown better discretion or timing? After all, the administration that cast itself as a fusion coalition is not known for tolerating dissent.
"Some people asked why didn't I wait until I had the job first and written later," Mr. Sencion said. "Very few people have dared to go beyond and challenge the status quo. In my case, I want to be able to think and do and act the way I feel independently of what the consequences might be. I guess I'll be paying the consequences for a long time to come."
The fault isn't entirely his own or perhaps even the administration's. While the news crews raced after him and dubbed him "the Saint of the City," Mr. Sencion grew frustrated over much of the glowing coverage that concentrated on one man's act.
"The economic impact that the city's budget would have on the community, nobody was interested in that," he said. "The whole thing bothered me."
So, after the Housing Authority offered him a job, he wrote a piece that addressed his concern over cuts affecting groups that worked with the poor. "The Mayor," he wrote, "definitely has his guns aimed at the wrong target."
Then the Saint landed in limbo.
Mr. Sencion said he and a reporter for El Diario tried to question the Mayor about the change of heart a few weeks later at a breakfast meeting with Hispanic journalists. Mr. Sencion said in his lawsuit that the Mayor responded by asserting his right to hire people who agreed with his policies and his political agenda.
THAT may be going too far, said Norman Siegel, the head of the New York Civil Liberties Union, which is representing Mr. Sencion. While no one disputes any Mayor's right to elect policy-making commissioners and deputies on the basis of political allegiances, Mr. Siegel cited several court decisions that said rank-and-file workers are supposed to be immune from such loyalty tests.
"Sencion's views were not compatible with the Mayor's political agenda, and that is what the First Amendment prohibits," Mr. Siegel said. "The Mayor must be neutral when it comes to hiring people in non-policymaking positions."
Mr. Sencion, who went through his savings and was scraping by on unemployment benefits until he landed a $20,000-a-year job organizing tenants for a South Bronx advocacy group last month, thinks the Mayor is too sensitive.
"He claims to be the Mayor of all New Yorkers," he said. "When he was sworn in, that was his big thing. What he's doing is basically being the Mayor of those who follow him politically."
Would another Mayor have done the same thing? For example, in 1992 when thousands of jeering police officers (and the candidate Giuliani) converged near City Hall in an unruly protest against Mayor David N. Dinkins, should they have been fired? Or were their uncivil taunts and scorn protected speech?
"I wonder if they did that to Giuliani, what would he do?," Mr. Sencion said. "Stop and think."
As for his own actions and writings, he simply says he followed his conscience. The activist in him wouldn't allow him to stay quiet. The activist friends around him would not respect him if he had.
The only ones quiet about Rafael Sencion are officials at the Housing Authority and City Hall.
Maybe it's leadership by example.

HEADLINE: Doing Major Time For a Minor Crime

BYLINE: By Randy Schain; Randy Schain heads a company that develops money-management software.

 BODY:
Every night around midnight, a dirty old van departs the Midtown South precinct and cruises lower Manhattan. This van will prowl through some of the nicest neighborhoods of the city and some of the worst. It will stay out all night, or until it is full.
The back of the van contains no seats, only a bare metal floor that smells faintly of vomit. As the evening progresses, this area will fill with members of every stratum of society, victims of a sweep by this old van and its convoy of unmarked escorts. 
 It was 1:30 A.M., on a nice block in the Flatiron district not far from my apartment. I was saying good night to a friend, watching impatiently as he finished a joint. We had seen a late show, and I was eager to get to sleep. We were both carrying plenty of identification, including New York driver's licenses and embossed photo I.D.'s from corporate employers. We were also carrying marijuana. He had a tiny bag in his pocket -- about two joints' worth -- and I had a pinch he had just given me.
The police descended on us from three directions. They were aggressive but not abusive. We were astonished, subservient and polite. The arresting officer seemed sympathetic as we were searched, handcuffed and led into the van.
The van had three other occupants: a shy white guy who worked at a tanning salon, another white guy who had just sold the first one a tiny amount of cocaine and a black guy, unemployed, who said he had been standing on a street where drugs were sold. For four hours, we sat on the floor, handcuffed from behind, as the convoy searched for more prey. (In all that time, the convoy caught one street dealer and one of his customers.) The evening finally ended when they bagged a haggard pair of white female junkies and one more guy, who said nothing the whole trip. By the end, there were 10 of us.
Although physically very uncomfortable, my friend and I were not overly worried. We joked pleasantly with our drivers, who joked pleasantly back. Neither of us had any criminal record nor any experience whatsoever with the world of cops and perps. The scene was not without its appeal. And both of us were certain that we would be issued summonses and released. A month ago, we would have been.
Not anymore. In mid-February, without any fanfare, the Giuliani administration, cracking down on so-called quality-of-life crimes, has drastically changed the punishment for using marijuana.
As part of its campaign to arrest huge numbers of misdemeanor drug offenders, the city has instructed the police to stop issuing summonses to most marijuana users. Except the lucky few who realize they should call their lawyers upon arriving at the precinct, all those arrested are sent through the central booking system. And once you are in the system, there is very little a lawyer can do until you come out the other side.
By 6 A.M., my friend's main concern was that the process was taking too long. He had a critical meeting later that morning. Then we heard the news: We were going downtown to central booking. My friend frantically called his lawyer -- who came to meet us at central booking but could not to get us out.
We spent the next 36 hours in seven different holding cells: overcrowded, filthy rooms with poor ventilation and a host of smells. For roughly half of that time, we were handcuffed, despite the bars around us. The experience was made worse by needlessly abusive guards.
My cellmates were friendly. Almost everyone was in for a drug-related charge. Crack, cocaine and heroin were the leaders, but there were several other marijuana cases, including a natty investment banker from one of the very best firms. The convoy was obviously arresting anyone, for any drug, in any neighborhood. There is a certain fairness in that.
Forty-one hours from the time of our arrest -- it can take twice that long -- we had our moment in court, and the case was essentially dismissed. The whole hearing took about 90 seconds.
By largely eliminating the routine summonses, the Giuliani administration has severely altered the de facto punishment for smoking marijuana. The pot smoker used to get a few dreadful hours in a van, followed by a summons to appear in court. This seems fair for such a low-grade misdemeanor. But now the penalty is two to four days in stifling, rancid holding cells.
The professional aftershocks of this ordeal can be far worse. My friend suffered a catastrophe. While neither of us could afford to suddenly disappear from our careers, he had especially crucial meetings those two days.He may lose his job.
Aside from an absurd legal bill, the only apparent damage I suffered was caused by a brand new puppy that had, quite reasonably after two days indoors, destroyed my apartment.
Marijuana is a double-edged pleasure that I largely avoid. One of the rare times that I choose to smoke is while listening to live music. Since one can never smoke inside a club, and I'm not wasting the best part of the high in a taxi, the Mayor has succeeded in driving all of my jazz business to a nightclub around the corner from my apartment.
Our court system is already hopelessly overburdened with petty criminals. By throwing pot into the soup, the city government is worsening a crisis, solely for the purpose of dispensing a brutal experience to a seemingly random sample of pot smokers on the street.
This is not a just punishment or a wise policy.

HEADLINE: An Illinois City, Once Down and Out, Finds Rebirth in Riverboat Gambling

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: JOLIET, Ill.

 BODY:
This once mean and wasted city is on a roll. Known just a few years ago mostly for its prison and cadavers of steel mills, Joliet is growing, building homes and adding jobs.
It has spiffed up its schools, streets and the library. Its downtown, once the nocturnal turf of gangs, has become a network of brick sidewalks and hundreds of locust trees that greet thousands of out-of-towners who pour in here day and night, every day. And even as the city has undergone this transformation, it has cut taxes. 
 "It's our time right now," said John Mezera, the City Manager and the resident most often cited for guiding Joliet's renaissance. But the good times will last only as long as the visitors, a fickle and peripatetic lot, keep coming, Mr. Mezera acknowledged.
The revitalization of this city's economy began in June 1992 with the launching of a three-story riverboat gambling casino, the Empress I, owned by the Empress Riverboat Corporation, on the Des Plaines River on outskirts of town. The Empress now has a twin, and two more riverboat casinos, the Northern Star and the Southern Star, owned by Harrah's Entertainment, are docked in a canal in the middle of downtown.
Since opening, the floating casinos, each of which can hold about 800 passengers, have showered this city with cash. An average of 17,757 people come here every day and bet a total of $1.1 million during the two-hour cruises that run 22 hours a day, according to the Illinois Gaming Board. The city collects a quarter of the 20 percent tax that the state takes from the revenues of the boats' operators, and it receives $1 for each admission, although the customers board the boats free.
 
Tax Revenues Helping City Pay Off Its Debt
Joliet's total tax revenue since the first boat opened is expected to reach $90 million by the end of this year and account for a hefty 20 percent of all its revenues over that period. Besides cutting taxes, the city has also been paying off debt, and is using about two-thirds of the revenue for capital improvements in the formerly decrepit- and abandoned-looking downtown.
The casino companies are now the biggest employers in Joliet, population 83,000, and Will County, population 375,000, paying $100million a year in wages to 4,000 workers. This sustains an economy in which the unemployment rate sometimes exceeded 20 percent in the early 1980's.
As the gambling boom has gripped America, there has been much soul-searching over whether casinos like the ones in Joliet are good or bad for cities. An industry that hardly existed outside Nevada and Atlantic City at the start of the decade, gambling has stoked miraculous recoveries of moribund riverfront communities of the Midwest and the South.
For these communities, the overnight rush that gambling can deliver is particularly seductive given the recent efforts in Congress to cut Federal spending, including aid for urban development.
But economics and experts in urban development say that although gambling is a quick way to make money, it may not lead to long-term growth because when people spend more money in casinos, they put less into savings or investments that can be loaned to growing businesses. These experts say cities tend to get carried away by the infusion of tax revenue, without considering the consequences of pinning economic development on a casino.
Meanwhile, in the cities, some residents wonder whether revenues from gambling will bring crime and addiction to gambling. And although legalizing gambling can quickly reverse a city's fortunes, the economic resurgence may prove to be short-lived as more American cities welcome casinos.
Joliet, and and eight other riverboat gambling towns in Illinois, now face competition just over the state line on the shores of Lake Michigan as the Rust Belt Indiana cities of Hammond, Gary and East Chicago are launching their riverboat casinos this year.
Midwestern casinos, unlike those in Las Vegas, draw nearly all their customers from within an hour's drive, and the 12.5 percent who come here from Indiana are likely to stay closer to home. In fact, Empress is opening a boat in Hammond that could drain business from Joliet.
Optimists say the business is so big and has been growing so fast that there is room for everyone now authorized to operate casinos. They point to statistics: attendance at casinos in Illinois doubled from 1994 to 1995, and the boats' revenues climbed two-thirds.
But one Illinois casino, near Galena, closed late last year, and another at Rock Island is ailing. Customers have been slipping across the Mississippi to casinos in Iowa. A casino in Elgin, Ill., west of Chicago, has surpassed the two Joliet operators in attendance.
To offset the loss of day-tripping customers and to keep others in town as Las Vegas does, Empress is building a 102-room hotel, the first by either operator here, across its Egyptian-style boarding pavilion. And just in case the optimists are wrong, Mr. Mezera says he has budgeted a 12.5 percent decline in his previously projected casino tax revenues, to $27.7 million, for this year, to offset the expected loss of customers from Indiana.
Even so, it is hard to find anyone here who knocks gambling as the engine of Joliet's revival. With its gambling-tax revenues, the city has spent or is in the process of spending $2.6 million for arterial streets, in part to accommodate casino traffic; $27 million for neighborhood improvements; $10 million for sewers; $4 million for schools, and $4 million to expand the police headquarters.
Joliet is also clearing $60 million in debt for city improvements, much of it accrued in the years before gambling. By the end of this year, it will have paid off $8.9 million.
"We have determined that we are going to pay off all our debt by the year 2001," Mr. Mezera said. "The important thing is that you don't create new debt, so we are now on a cash basis."
And despite of all the new spending, Joliet has also begun to cut taxes. It has eliminated a $5.50 monthly water fee for sewer improvements and a $25 annual motor vehicle tax. Property taxes are edging down, too.
 
Even a Church Leader Points to Good Results
Even among the agents of spiritual salvation, the fact that gambling underpins this economy stirs little controversy. Across the street from the pavilion where Harrah's customers eat and shop before boarding the boats is the parking lot of a church. Rather than fight gambling, the church, like the city, lines its coffers with a tax -- the $3 it charges Harrah's customers to park.
A few blocks from Harrah's, the Rev. Richard Bennett heads a Roman Catholic church in a racially mixed neighborhood. Father Bennett expressed worries about the gamblers who spend an average of $62 with each visit to the boats with nothing to show for it, and more about those who become addicted, a problem that has led to formation of a local chapter of Gamblers Anonymous.
"When the City Council was originally proposing this, five or six years ago, a church ministerial group protested about gambling and the social effects on the community," Father Bennett said. "But they just voted on what they wanted to do, and church people were ignored. Since then, no one has spoken out about it much."
Now, with that battle lost, he said, gambling has yielded important benefits. "And on the whole," he said, "it has provided jobs for people, good-paying jobs with benefits, which is important. It has provided a lot of money the city wouldn't have had."
He could use some of the money. By Feb. 11, he had exhausted the $500 he gives to the needy, and had posted a notice on his rectory door saying: "No more assistance for this month." But he blames cuts in Federal welfare for the rising demand for his aid.
For Joliet's bigger boosters, the business aboard the boats is not gambling at all, but "gaming" and "entertainment." Mr. Mezera takes umbrage at moral arguments against it. "Why is compulsive shopping O.K., where compulsive gambling is not?" he asked.
By all accounts here, the criminal side of gambling just has not shown up. Joliet has less crime than it did before the casinos opened, according to the Police Department.
Prostitution was also a fear. "Everyone said there's going to be wholesale prostitution," Mr. Mezera said. There's none."
 
But Experts Say Gambling Lacks Benefits of Factories
Economists and experts in urban development raise numerous doubts about the value of gambling as a promote to growth, saying that gambling draws money from stores, savings and investment. The experts also argue that casinos benefit a community much less than a bolted-down factory.
A factory, they say, buys more supplies and services locally than a casino does, and it sells goods far and wide, well beyond the reach of the casinos, which pulls in money only from the neighbor a couple of exits down an interstate highway. Successful factory owners also tend to invest profits locally in expansion, while most casino owners take their profits home, often far away, to invest it in other communities.
In two studies of gambling in Illinois, Earl L. Grinols, a professor of economics at the University of Illinois in Urbana-Champaign who has studied the state's gambling economy, said that in general, "the net gain is virtually zero.
"There is a job lost or a job not created for every job you see in the casinos," Professor Grinols said. "There's very little economic growth going on in riverboat areas because of the riverboats. But city councils get euphoric over the taxes they're collecting."
The economic development authorities in Joliet and Will County say they recognize the appeal of factories and other new businesses. To diversify beyond riverboats, Ruth Fitzgerald, president of the county Chamber of Commerce, has lured a number of businesses here, including a printing plant, a Toys-'R'-Us distribution center and a Japanese steel-processing plant. But none yet compare with the casinos, the area's biggest sources of jobs and revenue.
Modern factories, the officials say, would be better for the city. "But you've got to deal with reality and take what you can get," said James Heller, the city's director of community and economic development.
"There are no big manufacturing companies for communities our size. When entertainment came along, it was perfect. We were looking for something that would change the image of Joliet. And it did."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE PLATFORM;
Buchanan Courts Old Friends With a Warning

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, March 8

 BODY:
Tired of watching Senator Bob Dole raid the ranks of social and religious conservatives, Patrick J. Buchanan reversed himself today and said that, without more support, he might not be able to maintain the Republican Party's strict opposition to abortion.
"I do believe the right to life movement is at a critical turning point this year," Mr. Buchanan said at a meeting of about 125 ministers here. "The establishment of my party wants to get rid of this issue." 
 As recently as Tuesday evening, at a news conference in Buffalo, Mr. Buchanan said of keeping the Republican Party's anti-abortion plank, "I think we've won that battle."
His alarm about abortion was a telling note for Mr. Buchanan. His strategists had said only Thursday that he would try to reach beyond his traditional base while campaigning in Texas.
But today, as he campaigned here and in Louisiana, Mr. Buchanan tailored his speeches to help detain apostates rather than win converts, a strategy that might maintain his leverage within the party but seems unlikely to revive his chances for the nomination.
"If Bob Dole is able to win this, if the people around him in the establishment win it, they will sell out the right to life movement in the flicker of an eyelash," Mr. Buchanan said at a rally in an aircraft hangar in Baton Rouge, La., this morning.
Polling in primary states suggests that Mr. Dole is drawing more and more voters from Mr. Buchanan's base of support.
In the Georgia primary, 35 percent of people who said the Republican platform should include an anti-abortion plank voted for Mr. Dole. But in South Carolina and New York, about half of them did.
Mr. Buchanan said today that he believed that the Republican Party would continue to oppose abortion, if pressed. "I would urge the right to life movement right now, if you really care about this cause as I think you know I do, join and unite behind me now," Mr. Buchanan said during a new conference in Baton Rouge. "We need you now."
Here in Houston, Mr. Buchanan added a warning: "If the Republican Party ever dropped Ronald Reagan's pro-life plank, I think the pro-life movement would find a new home," he said.
The Buchanan campaign has started rejiggering its strategy almost as frequently as it leaves journalists behind at its events. On Thursday, aides to Mr. Buchanan said he would advertise on television in Texas. Today, he said he would not.
"There's no doubt we are husbanding our resources," Mr. Buchanan said in Baton Rouge. He said he would advertise on television in Michigan, where he hopes his "America first" trade message will appeal to blue-collar voters. "We're going to try to make it something of a battleground," Mr. Buchanan said.
Mr. Buchanan can still draw an ecstatic crowd, like the thousand people who turned out in Memphis on Thursday night to roar as he mocked "milque-toast Christianity" and declared himself the "bad dog" in the race.
But sometimes his support is not so vigorous, or perhaps his advance work is not so thorough. In Baton Rouge, only about 40 people showed up in the chilly, cavernous airplane hangar. Mr. Buchanan nevertheless treated them to new material, introducing his wife, Shelley, as "Hillary Rodham Buchanan."
At the end, laughing, he wondered aloud why anyone had turned up at all. "Are you unemployed, or what?" he asked.
Mike Muller and Joe Schumerth shouted back that they had taken vacation time from their jobs at an Exxon refinery to hear him. Mr. Buchanan, faced with the very loyalists he was trying to energize, instantly turned earnest.
"You're good men," he said, his grin gone.

HEADLINE: Express Track for Jobs;
Transit Tech Updates Vocational High With Courses on Modern Trains

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
John Thomas, 18 years old, wearing a blue hard hat, stood atop a ladder with a circuit tester, prodding the wiring of an old red subway car, incongruously parked in an outsize classroom at the High School of Transit Technology. The problem: a train is stalled in a crowded subway station. The assignment: find the dead circuit.
Mr. Thomas, a senior, poked at a control panel as his teen-age crew at the rear of the car shouted when corresponding circuits lighted up. 
 "All right, I think we've got it," Mr. Thomas said. "We're on our way."
In the Transit Technology course, students like Mr. Thomas are learning the rudiments of train mechanics. There's also Basic Transit Welding, Rail Car Maintenance, and Climate Control (heating and air-conditioning repair).
Transit Tech -- "the express to success," its brochures proclaim -- is a vocational school focusing on the mechanics of both the subterranean and above-ground variety of train, with 1,200 students in pursuit of jobs in transportation. Though the school, in East New York, Brooklyn, is independent of the Transit Authority, the agency's shadow looms large: the school was its idea, and it donates materials like the circa-1960 subway car, sends advisers and offers an internship program. Many students have their eyes on the New York City public transportation system as their future employer.
With the lure of good-paying jobs in a tight market, and college entrance growing more competitive, a growing number of educators and parents are encouraging students to seek hands-on training in marketable skills. When Transit Tech was established in 1986, 400 students applied. Last year, more than 5,000 competed for 400 places. At Aviation High School in Long Island City, Queens, 3,230 candidates vied for 670 slots for the current school year.
Scores of old-style trade schools, which traditionally offered teen-agers broad vocational courses heavy on woodworking, have followed suit and added courses in computers and electronics, subjects that are more relevant to today's market.
William E. Grady Vocational and Technical High School in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, which has seen a 10 percent increase in applications since 1990, now offers computer-aided design and pre-engineering courses. Virtually all public vocational schools now include an emphasis on early contact with professionals and real-life experience.
It was the Transit Authority, facing a shortage of skilled workers due to retirements, that approached the Board of Education about forming a partnership for Transit Tech. School officials immediately saw the possibilities and spent $43 million to renovate the long neglected East New York Vocational High School.
"Here we had a failed school and an agency with a shortage of technical people," said Jesse Lazarus, the principal. "It was like a marriage made in heaven."
But the school, which does not receive financial support from the transit agency, has not been the bonanza originally imagined, said John Dempsey, an assistant vice president at the Transit Authority.
Some 300 students have secured transportation jobs since the first class graduated in 1990. But the Transit Authority has no idea how many it has hired, Mr. Dempsey said, because new graduates cannot get jobs there right out of school. With Civil Service tests given only once a year and a two-year waiting list for hiring, Mr. Dempsey said many of the school's graduates instead go to private companies or other transportation systems like the Long Island Rail Road, which do not require a Civil Service test.
"I think it has been a very positive experience for the Transit Authority to know that there is a pool that can be tapped," Mr. Dempsey said. "Now what we have to do is to get them into the agency a lot quicker."
But in another departure from the old-time vocational school, some students harbor hopes for college. About 200 Transit Tech graduates have continued their education. As Mr. Thomas and his classmates worked on the subway car, they talked not only about the task at hand but also of earning degrees in electrical engineering and computer science.
"I want to go far in the transit system," said Mr. Thomas, who is awaiting word on admission to several colleges, including the University of North Carolina at Charlotte. "And college will help me."
Lawrence Edwards, assistant superintendent of the Board of Education's Division of High Schools, agreed. "The old mind-set is that if you wanted to go to college, you go to one kind of school, and if you didn't, you go to another kind of school," he said. "That is not the case anymore."
Even as the vocational schools gain popularity, some educators argue that they may limit a student's education and that some teach trades for which there is little demand, like cabinet making. They contend that the average 14-year-old is too young to decide on a career. Ideally, they say, a specialized school should combine strong academic standards with the vocation.
"They can be uni-dimensional to the degree that they deprive students of options," said Robert Berne, dean of New York University's Wagner School of Public Service. "There are a lot of students who want a marketable skill and they want that at an early age. But a lot of them change their mind four, five, six times."
Transit Tech, which offers the usual high-school curriculum, is by no means an academic powerhouse. Only 3 percent of the 250 students who graduated in 1994 received a Regents-endorsed diploma, awarded to New York State high school students who pass rigorous exams; the citywide average is 18 percent. The school's average Scholastic Assessment Test score was a combined 659 in verbal and mathematics, compared with 794 for all city high schools.
But Transit Tech students score consistently above the city's minimum requirements in reading, math and writing. A 1993-94 Board of Education report showed that the school had a graduation rate of 68 percent compared with 51 percent citywide. And its dropout rate was half the city average.
Statistics, however, tell only part of the school's story. Surrounded by decrepit rows of clapboard homes, Transit Tech, a sprawling four-story building, is like a shelter in the storm that often brews in the tough streets of East New York and its environs.
After several shootings in the school's early years, there have been few violent incidents since 1992. There are no metal detectors. The hallways are free of graffiti and litter. The walls are festooned with pictures of American heroes like George Washington and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., and a huge mural of Americana covers the wall near the principal's office, towering over a glass-covered train set.
"I wanted something different," said Roger Cousar, a senior from Crown Heights, Brooklyn. "Where I live there's nothing really to do except hang out. This school helps me get away and stay out of trouble. There were a lot of people pushing me -- teachers, security guards. They all wanted me to do well."
While the school attracts students from across the city, most come from the East New York area. Seventy-nine percent are black and 18 percent are Hispanic. And unlike the percentages at most vocational schools, often dominated by boys, 25 percent of the students at Transit Tech are girls, who also hold the top offices in the student government.
"You're not treated better or worse because you're a girl," said Shaquanna Henry, a senior from Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. "Here they motivate you to do better, and if you have a problem, they help you. It's like we're a family here."
Transit Tech administrators seek not only good students but those with a passion for the subject. Armed with brochures and fliers, school officials periodically march into junior high schools, selling children on the notion of earning up to $30,000 a year.
"We get phone calls at home from parents who want to get their children into the school," said Janice Jones, coordinator of student affairs. "This is the place to be."
Part of the reason is the demand for mechanics. After a decades-long slump in transit system rail ridership around the country, some 60 cities are looking to develop or expand rail systems, said Chip Bishop, a spokesman for the American Public Transit Association in Washington.
"There is no shortage of demands and needs out there for rail," Mr. Bishop said, "and it stands to reason we will need people to build and maintain these systems."
Allan Hoyt, a Transit Tech senior, is ready. "I like the hands-on experience," he said. "I'm not thinking about going to college. I just want a good job."

HEADLINE: Immigrants Replace New York's Natives

 BODY:
In the first half of the 1990's, new census figures show, enormous numbers of people left New York City for other parts of the United States, and were replaced mostly by people from abroad, trends that experts say continue to further vast changes in the culture and the economy of the region.

HEADLINE: House Republicans Offer an Ambitious Plan to Expand Health Care Coverage

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
House Republican leaders offered a package of health care proposals today that is significantly more ambitious than the bipartisan measure pending in the Senate, and they predicted that it would win quick passage in the House.
The Republicans said their proposals would make affordable health insurance available to half of the 40 million Americans who have no coverage. 
 Though House Republicans have not finished preparing the legislation, they said they hoped to push it through the House before lawmakers take a spring break at the end of this month.
But advocates of the Senate bipartisan measure said that by adding proposals on medical malpractice and medical savings accounts, the Republicans might jeopardize passage of any health care bill.
Representative Dennis Hastert of Illinois, chief deputy whip for the House Republicans, said their bill, like the bipartisan measure sponsored by Senators Nancy Landon Kassebaum and Edward M. Kennedy, would guarantee health insurance coverage for many people who change jobs or lose their jobs.
In addition, he said, the Republicans' bill would set limits on damages that could be recovered by victims of medical malpractice. The bill would also create tax incentives for people to establish special savings accounts to help pay medical expenses. And it would amend a 1974 law, the bedrock of the nation's private health insurance system, to make it easier for small employers to band together and buy coverage.
"While the Senate bill guarantees the right to purchase health insurance," Mr. Hastert said, "it doesn't go far enough and address the price of that policy. Common sense tells every American that the right to purchase a health insurance policy is meaningless if you cannot afford the premium."
The White House welcomed the Republicans' interest in health care, saying that "Americans are ready for Congress to pass long-overdue and meaningful health insurance reform." But Laura D'Andrea Tyson, director of President Clinton's National Economic Council, said, "We believe that the addition of controversial and experimental provisions should not be pursued if they mean that no insurance reform bill will be passed by Congress." The Kassebaum-Kennedy bill is supported by 52 senators and most House Democrats.
Some business groups have expressed similar concerns. The National Association of Manufacturers supports the Kassebaum-Kennedy bill and, in an apparent change of heart, the House Republican bill as well.
At a Congressional hearing on Thursday, Paul R. Huard, senior vice president of the association, urged House Republican leaders to "proceed with extreme caution" in pushing any legislation beyond the scope of the Kassebaum-Kennedy bill, warning that such a move could "sink the boat." But today, after learning more about the House Republican bill, Jerry Jasinowski, president of the association, wrote Mr. Hastert that the manufacturers were "pleased both to endorse and to enthusiastically support your plan."
Republicans and Democrats sometimes appear to have reversed the positions they took in the debate over Mr. Clinton's health care plan. Mr. Hastert said the same Democrats now supporting modest, incremental steps to expand health insurance coverage were insisting enactment of "a grandiose plan" in 1993 and 1994.
Now House Republicans say the Kassebaum-Kennedy is too modest. They say they want to put their own stamp on the legislation in this election year, to show that they can deliver health care improvements that eluded a Democratic Congress working with a Democratic President.
Representative Bill Thomas, a California Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, said the tax deduction and tax incentives for medical savings accounts would cost the Government $3 billion over five years. Republicans have not decided how to cover the cost, other than by cracking down on fraud and abuse in Medicare and Medicaid, he said.
The Kassebaum-Kennedy bill is tentatively scheduled for debate in the Senate on April 18 and 19. Mrs. Kassebaum, a Kansas Republican, and Mr. Kennedy, a Massachusetts Democrat, have said they will resist all amendments.
But Mr. Hastert said today: "There are going to be amendments in the Senate. The Senate is the Senate. They're going to do their thing. We don't predicate everything we do here on threats from the Senate."
Under the Senate bill, companies selling individual health insurance would have to offer such policies to people who lost group health coverage, either because they lose their jobs or switched to employers that did not offer health benefits. Mr. Hastert said House Republicans wanted to provide similar protection to workers, but were mindful of the concerns of insurance companies, which say that the premiums for individual insurance could soar as a result of such a requirement.

HEADLINE: New York's Foreign-Born Population Increases

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
In the first half of the 1990's, new census figures show, enormous numbers of people left New York City for other parts of the United States, and were replaced mostly by people from abroad, trends that experts say mean vast changes for the region's culture and economy.
Looking just at moves between the city and other parts of the United States, New York lost more than one-tenth of its population, according to Census Bureau estimates released yesterday. 
 Against that loss, foreign-born people continued to alter the city's customs and work force, contributing a net growth of 460,000 people from other countries during the same period.
Over all, the Census Bureau figures released yesterday show New York City's population down slightly, at 7,312,076 last July 1, compared with 7,322,564 on April 1, 1990, the date of the last census. While about 300,000 more people left the city than moved to it, natural increase -- the rate at which births exceed deaths -- made up nearly all the difference. The city's population has fluctuated between seven million and eight million since the 1940's.
The metropolitan region, including New Jersey and Connecticut, once again lagged behind the national growth rate, continuing a decades-old trend.
Throughout its history, New York City has been constantly remade by immigration, with native-born people leaving the city for other parts of the country, but experts say the trend appears to have accelerated in the early 90's, perhaps to the highest levels since just after World War II. "More and more, what happens to this city is hooked into the foreign-born," said Joseph J. Salvo, director of population studies at the Department of City Planning.
Andrew A. Beveridge, a professor of sociology at Queens College who studies population trends, said: "This is a very significant trend, in that it creates much more of a foreign city and a poorer city."
"What we've found is that the domestic migrants out are better-educated and higher-income than average," he said. Their departure means that "the tax base to provide social services is eroding." At the same time, he said, immigrants put an increasing burden on those services, particularly public schools and hospitals. The city's schools have averaged an influx of about 20,000 students a year, largely through immigration.
Mr. Salvo agreed that immigration was bringing broad changes and real challenges to the city, but he argued that the trends were not cause for alarm. Many immigrants are well educated, he said, and they are more likely to be part of the city's work force than their native-born counterparts.
Many people who leave the city are not from the professional ranks, he said. "A lot of poor Puerto Ricans go back to Puerto Rico, a lot of Southern-born people retire and go back to the South and a lot of the foreign-born move out of the city," he said. "Those are all part of out-migration, too."
The census figures show that both the influx and the exodus peaked in the first three years of this decade, abating somewhat in the last two years.
"This was an acceleration of the trend in the 1980's," Mr. Beveridge said, adding that the city lost about 500,000 residents to domestic migration from 1985 to 1990, or less than two-thirds of the level of the last five years. One of the most serious cultural consequences, he predicted, will be a wider-than-ever divide between an international urban core and suburbs that continue to be mostly white and native-born. He said that trend is mirrored, to one degree or another, in Los Angeles, Chicago, Miami, Houston and Dallas.
Nearly every county in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut showed a population loss to domestic migration, but in the metropolitan area, only Hudson, Essex and Passaic counties showed the kind of losses seen in New York City.
All of the new figures released by the bureau are estimates, unlike the census figures, which are based on an exhaustive attempt to count every person in the country. As a result, Mr. Salvo cautioned against drawing conclusions from small changes in the numbers, which he called "foolish precision."
Brooklyn and the Bronx are estimated to have lost residents, while Queens, Manhattan and Staten Island gained.
The Census Bureau estimates that the population of the entire country grew 5.6 percent in the five-year period, to almost 263 million; New York State's grew by almost 150,000, to just over 18.1 million; New Jersey gained more than 200,000, to more than 7.9 million, and Connecticut lost about 13,000 of its nearly 3.3 million people.
The census figures also show that the number of older people is higher and rising faster in the three-state region than in the nation as a whole. Last year, 12.8 percent of the nation's population was 65 or older, up from 12.5 percent in 1990. In New York, the percentage grew to 13.4 percent, from 13 percent; in Connecticut, to 14.3 percent, from 13.5 percent, and in New Jersey, to 13.7 percent, from 13.2 percent.
The county-by-county figures show that after a population boom in the 1980's, the New York state suburbs at the fringes of the metropolitan area saw mostly modest growth in the first half of the 90's. Rockland, Orange, Suffolk and Dutchess counties all grew more slowly in the last five years than the nation as a whole. In Connecticut, Litchfield and Fairfield Counties barely grew at all, while the population of New Haven County dropped slightly.
"This is all economically driven," Mr. Beveridge said. "In the 80's, when the economy was doing well, the city grew, those outer suburbs grew, but that came to a halt with the recession. The region has lost a lot of jobs, so it's not surprising that people leave."
But the outer ring of suburbs in central New Jersey -- Somerset, Hunterdon, Monmouth and Ocean counties -- continued to grow considerably faster than the national rate. That, too, is a reflection of the economy, Mr. Beveridge said.
"The New Jersey economy has been better than the other two states, and a lot of that has been centered on the Route 1 corridor in those counties," he said. Like New York City, the nearer suburbs -- Nassau and Westchester counties in New York, and Bergen, Passaic, Essex, Union and Hudson counties in New Jersey -- saw little change in population.

HEADLINE: Memphis Bank Buying Biggest Tennessee S.& L.

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The Union Planters Corporation agreed to acquire the Leader Financial Corporation yesterday for stock valued at $486 million, creating Tennessee's largest banking company.
The deal is the latest in a wave of consolidations in the banking industry. Tennessee in particular has been seen as a ripe area for banking acquisitions, analysts have said. 
 Benjamin W. Rawlins Jr., the chairman and chief executive of Union Planters, said in a statement that the deal was a "classic in-market merger" and that "significant economies of scale can be achieved."
Union Planters, based in Memphis, is Tennessee's second-largest banking company, and Leader, also based in Memphis, is the state's largest savings and loan association. The combined company would have nearly $15 billion in assets, surpassing the First Tennessee National Corporation of Memphis as the state's biggest financial institution.
In terms of deposit market share, however, First Tennessee would remain the largest.
The plan for the combined company would include closing about 20 branches, chiefly in Memphis. Union Planter has 405 branches, most of them in Tennessee, while Leader Financial has 21.
Under the terms of the agreement, Union Planters would exchange 1.525 shares of its own stock, which at yesterday's closing price of $29.25 would be worth $44.61, for each of Leader's 10.9 million shares. The deal is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter. If the deal is not completed, Union Planters still has an option to purchase up to 19.9 percent of Leader's common stock at $41 each.
Shares of Union Planters, amid a broad selloff in the market and banking stocks in particular, fell sharply yesterday, closing down $2.25, to $29.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Leader Financial shares, however, rose $4.25, or 11 percent, to $42.25, in Nasdaq trading.
Analysts said they thought the combination was an extremely good fit. "There are some in-market synergies to be had," said Kay C. Lister, a banking analyst at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods in New York. "These are companies that complement one another well. One's weakness is the other's strength."
For example, Leader Financial has a loan-to-deposit ratio of 125 percent, which means the company has had to borrow, sometimes from the Federal Home Loan Bank, to meet its commitments. But the combined company would be on much firmer footing, with a loan-to-deposit ratio of about 85 percent.
The deal announced yesterday will be the third significant acquisition for Union Planters in the last year. In December Union Planters completed its acquisition of the Capital Bancorporation in Cape Girardeau, Mo., for about $114 million. And more recently, it agreed to acquire the Franklin Financial Group Inc. of Morristown, Tenn., for about $150 million.
Christopher T. Kelley, an analyst at Morgan Keegan & Company, said Union Planters took advantage of a good opportunity. "They bought something very profitable, and bought it at a good price," he said. "With this acquisition, Union Planters takes out a pretty big competitor."
Leader Financial shareholders can also expect to profit. The bank first went public in 1993, with shares selling at $10. "I know one thing," Mr. Kelley said. "There are lots of happy shareholders around Memphis today."

HEADLINE: Keep College Open to the Poor

 BODY:
During the last 20 years, the incomes of college graduates have risen while workers with only high school educations have seen earnings and job opportunities evaporate. New York State, with its vast numbers of poor, cannot afford to worsen the trend. Given that imperative, one of the signal issues in Albany this spring is the dispute over funding for public colleges and universities -- the schools of choice for low-income New Yorkers seeking to better their lot.
The 21-campus City University of New York and the 64-campus State University of New York certainly need restructuring -- and perhaps even some campus closings -- to meet new fiscal realities. But cuts in student aid proposed by Gov. George Pataki have frightened even fiscal conservatives, many of whom see the cuts as too much, too fast -- and an unfair blow to the poor. 
 CUNY and SUNY have experienced a steady series of cuts in state funding -- often with dramatic consequences. The two systems were forced to impose tuition increases of $750 last year -- from $2,650 to $3,400 at SUNY and from $2,450 to $3,200 at CUNY. The higher fees drove out many struggling students, and were partly responsible for a combined enrollment drop of 16,000 in the two systems.
Now Mr. Pataki is proposing dramatic cuts and formula changes in the Tuition Assistance Program, known as TAP, that would make it even harder for low-income students to attend college. In New York City alone, TAP cuts would cause 50,000 students to lose up to $1,029 each per year -- with the heaviest hit on families earning under $16,000.
The SUNY board of trustees, now controlled by Mr. Pataki, has not protested the cuts. But an internal SUNY analysis shows justifiable worry on the front lines. At SUNY Binghamton, for example, 65 percent of the TAP recipients would lose an average of $934 each -- a ruinous sum for poor and lower-middle-class students. At some community colleges, low-income students would lose roughly 60 percent of their state aid. The administration also proposes letting aid increases lag a year behind tuition increases, further pressing poor families.
The Pataki administration says the cuts are warranted because New York is overly generous, spending three times as much on tuition assistance as Pennsylvania, Illinois or California. It estimates that, even after the cuts, nearly a third of New York's 300,000 TAP recipients will receive full-tuition scholarships. But tuition is less than half the cost of an actual SUNY or CUNY education.
State Education Commissioner Richard P. Mills was on the mark when he argued against the cuts, saying that the TAP was an investment in New York's future -- and in a more highly skilled work force. That investment is already falling short of what is needed. Despite substantial enrollment increases over the last decade, higher education aid has grown more slowly in New York than in almost any other state. Before shifting costs onto the shoulders of struggling families, Mr. Pataki needs to look hard for economies elsewhere. The Legislature needs to resolve the TAP debate quickly. Uncertainty over student aid could prompt many New Yorkers not to apply to college at all.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
