HEADLINE: Amigo Cantisano's Organic Dream

BYLINE: By Verlyn Klinkenborg; Verlyn Klinkenborg writes frequently about agriculture. His last article for the Magazine, "A Farm Farewell," appeared in June.

 BODY:
IT'S EARLY JANUARY, AND TODAY, NEAR Auburn, Calif., in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada, the sun is too warm to be seasonable, the blue sky washed by remnants of early-morning fog. Three weeks ago, after a dry autumn, a major winter storm blew across the north-central section of the state. As the storm moved eastward, its force began to wane, but not before it visited this small grove of olive trees 120 miles northeast of San Francisco, harvesting them with uncanny and unwelcome thoroughness. The ground here is purple with ripe olives unprofitably leaching their oil onto the roots of last year's olive seedlings.
"Nature bats first and last," Amigo Bob Cantisano says. He is kneeling in cool shade, his bare knees and fingers stained purple. He raises his triangle hoe, a kind of hand adz, and drives it into the earth beside a seedling with smooth opposed leaves. The soil within this canopied garden is light and friable and falls away readily as Amigo -- it seems inamicable to call him by anything but his nickname -- lifts the seedling and sets it in a small plastic pot on a flat full of pots. A few yards away, Scot Woodland, Amigo's business partner, digs at a faster pace, gathering seedlings that will be bedded for another year, then planted in other groves. Amigo is talking as well as transplanting, and when thoughts begin to crowd about him, his arms grow still. "So much work just to have it all fall on the ground," he says, dislodging another shoot. "Agriculture!" he exclaims, in mock apostrophe to that bountiful but fickle deity. 
 Amigo Cantisano is 44 and bluffly built, the result, genetics aside, of 23 years of farming. His appearance and manner are disarming only if you think you know what a farmer should look like and how he should behave. Long black hair falls down Amigo's back, and he tends to animate, in a pliant, husky voice, the stories he tells. In conversation he can be openly skeptical, but he's a pragmatically cheerful man. By almost invisible stages he has become one of the most important figures in California organic agriculture. He has had an enormous impact on wine grape growers in the Napa Valley, at wineries like Sutter Home and Frog's Leap and E. & J. Gallo, helping them adopt organic practices. It is among the farmers who seek Amigo's advice, who worry over soils and crops and marketing with him, that the future of American agriculture is being deciphered.
In 1973 Amigo became one of the founding members of California Certified Organic Farmers. He helped start the Committee for Sustainable Agriculture, which sponsors the Ecological Farming Conference held every January in Pacific Grove, Calif., one of the most important annual events in the world of organic farming. In the late 1980's he created a company called Organic Ag Advisors and began consulting with farmers, large and small, all along the West Coast and in Arizona, Central America and Hawaii, sometimes helping them convert entirely from conventional agriculture to organic farming, sometimes helping them add organic practices to otherwise conventional operations. "I get paid to get educated," Amigo says. "We set up trials, do research on farms, try out new ideas. My main job is to get my clients to rethink the problem of soil fertility. How are we going to get to fertility without buying fertilizer? How are we going to get to pest control without buying pesticides? We've forgotten that fertility is inherent and just needs managing."
There's something, too, in the shape of Amigo's career -- in his transformation from consumer to farmer to adviser -- that reflects a broader shift, still being painfully negotiated, in the consciousness of Americans, a growing awareness of the social, cultural and environmental dimensions of every item in the market basket. When I was growing up in the late 50's and early 60's, food seemed to be merely about the nutrient load it was capable of carrying. It was an atomic vision of food -- storehoused, canned, vacuum-sealed, archived for the day the bombs went off and it came in handy.
But Americans are looking for different kinds of essences these days. Although the number of certified organic growers nationwide is very small -- about 0.2 percent of farms, according to the Department of Agriculture -- the organic food market is one of the fastest-growing sectors of American agriculture. In the last eight years the number of organic growers in California has nearly doubled, while the certified organic acreage planted with field crops and fruits and nuts in California more than doubled between 1990 and 1994. According to Natural Foods Merchandiser, a trade journal for natural foods stores, the organic market has grown "well over 20 percent annually since 1989." Some of the largest increases have been in sales of produce, especially in supermarket-format stores, and in exports -- largely to Japan -- which were up some 80 percent from 1993 to 1994.
One major reason for this rapid growth is, of course, a concern for health. But the other major reason is quality. Food is no longer solely about its nutrient cargo. It is about the place food comes from, about what growing, harvesting and eating it are like, and about what else is nourished in the process. The industrial food my generation grew up eating (still available at your local supermarket!) may have been mechanically complex at every stage -- sowing, cultivating, harvesting, processing, packaging, shipping -- but it was grown in a palette of soils that are becoming, under the burden of modern farm chemicals, biologically simple, dangerously deprived. Amigo's life work has been to help recover the complexity of farming, the complexity of the earth itself.
"EVEN THOUGH THIS GROVE DOESN'T YIELD very well, and the olives fall on the ground, I love this place," Amigo says, as his hoe bites again, unearthing another seedling. "The other groves we harvest have an economic potential. This one has a passion potential. This is the romantic one." What makes it romantic is the taste of its oil -- what Amigo calls "this intense green flavor, new-mown lawn."
"There are 600 named varieties of olives around the world, but a lot of the names are synonyms," Amigo says. "It's hard to tell how many varieties there really are." He calls the type littering the ground here Saracena, though at least one of the people he has shown it to thinks it may be a Nicoise. They're small olives, scarcely bigger than the pit of a large variety like the Sevillano, and they sprout well from seed. They yield about half as much oil as other olives do, and their oil contains more wax. It clouds readily in cool temperatures, and its flavor seems especially responsive to climatic shifts.
The Gold Hill Orchard, where these olives grow, lies not far from the site of the first gold-mining settlement in Placer County, and its trees were planted sometime between 1905 and 1915. It is one of six historic olive orchards being managed by the small Aeolia Organic Olive Company, whose only full-time employee is Scot Woodland and whose spiritual and technical director is Amigo Cantisano. Like all the orchards they lease, this one was badly overgrown, just another vestige of a moribund industry in the foothills northeast of Sacramento, a region that was abandoning agriculture and rapidly subdividing.
"In Placer County in the 30's there were six operating oil mills," Amigo says. "By the 70's there was one, and it closed in 1974 or '75." Because of higher labor costs, California olive producers couldn't compete on the international bulk oil market with Italy and Spain or Turkey, Morocco and Tunisia, whose oils are often sold under Italian and Spanish trademarks. "But we saw that there was a niche coming for specialty oils," Amigo says, "and organic oil is one part of that niche." Its value has only been enhanced by recent medical reports stressing the health benefits of a Mediterranean diet, a main component of which is olive oil.
The word Amigo has used most often in my presence is "inspired," a word I'm not accustomed to hearing in farmers' mouths. And when Amigo talks about being inspired, he's likely to be talking about Felix Gillet, a Frenchman who arrived in Nevada City, Calif., 30 miles north of the Gold Hill Orchard, in 1859, when he was 24. There Gillet, who came from a family of nurserymen, opened a barbershop and began importing plants.
"One of his visions," Amigo says, "was that the foothills" -- where gold was the ruling passion -- "could become productive orchard lands. He imported the first almonds, the first walnuts, the first plums, the first chestnuts. He got the Willamette Valley in Oregon started on filberts." Gillet, who died in 1908, also helped start a silk industry in the foothills by promoting the planting of 170,000 mulberry trees, whose leaves are the sole food of silkworms, in Nevada and Placer Counties.
Amigo has continued some of Gillet's work. Ten years ago he began a census of chestnut trees in the Sierra Nevada foothills. He and his friends collected nut samples from 275 trees, most of them nearly a century old. During three successive harvests, they sampled nuts for taste, peelability and size. Then they selected the five best varieties, propagated them and gave saplings to 60 people, who altogether planted more than 4,000 trees, which at maturity will each yield 200 to 300 pounds of nuts, with virtually no care.
In this story there are two things worth noticing. One is Amigo's almost uncanny ability to find a business where no one suspected a business was hiding. The other is the cooperative, community-based nature of his work. These have been hallmarks of his career from its inception -- Earth Day 1970. "I realized we could talk a lot about the environment, but really what the environment needed was care," he says. "Agriculture seemed like a way to be involved in the environment and do positive things and also potentially make a living, raise a family." The next year Amigo walked into a health food store in Tahoe City, Calif. "I kinda went, 'You know, this isn't exactly what I would think of as the most direct way to buy food from farmers.' " So he began a food-buying club, which before long became a storefront food co-op called We the People on the north shore of Lake Tahoe. That, in turn, spawned a natural foods bakery and a wholesale distribution business.
IN 1973 AMIGO, WHO GREW UP IN SAN Francisco and had never farmed, got the chance, with his future wife, Kalita Todd, to raise organic vegetables on six acres owned by friends near Yuba City. "So we started planting," he says. "Learned how to drive a tractor. Made some horrendous mistakes. I liked the challenge. I loved getting out and growing stuff. It was like a rebirth. It was amazing to be able to grow something and get it to a finished, harvestable stage and put it into a box and put our label on it and send it to the food co-op."
It so happened that Amigo began looking for organic solutions to a pest called the walnut-husk fly at the same time that entomologists from the University of California at Davis were looking for an organic test plot, still a rarity in the mid70's. "So I became a test plot," Amigo says -- a metaphor that describes his working life almost perfectly. "At the time, most people thought of organic farming as just letting nature take its course. I learned that there were proactive things you could do that were environmentally responsible but were also successful. We tried traps using ammonium carbonate and molasses. We became one of the first test plots to use beneficial nematodes. We actually made it work. We took that orchard from 90 percent infestation to like a 10 percent infestation in one year."
Amigo began to gather the missing information base for California's organic farmers. "I became a vacuum cleaner for that kind of stuff. I walked into every office in the university's entomology department and introduced myself and asked them, 'What kind of alternative work are you doing?' " After moving up to the foothills in 1976 he opened a small organic-farm-supply business in the back of his barn. That grew into Peaceful Valley Farm Supply, which Amigo sold in 1989. Today Peaceful Valley publishes a 128-page catalogue -- still mostly written by Amigo -- full of tools, beneficial insects, natural pest-management products and, especially, natural fertilizers, many of which he first developed.
At Peaceful Valley, Amigo realized that what he enjoyed most was the time he spent visiting farms. The solution was Organic Ag Advisors.
"It's not like I went out to become a farm adviser," he says. "It's that there was virtually nobody else doing this. The reason farmers hire me is that I might cut six months or a year off the learning curve and help them save money at the same time. One of my goals is to minimize the use of off-farm inputs, organic or chemical, as much as possible. So a lot of the work I do with people is figuring out how to make composts, how to do it inexpensively so they don't have to buy as much fertility from off the farm. I'm just thrilled to hang around with the group of farmers I hang around with. These are some of the most brilliant people I know. They could be rocket scientists if they chose to be. They love the work, they love being outside, they love the plants, they love feeding people. They redefine the image of farming."
Jack Pandol Jr. is the undersecretary of the California Environmental Protection Agency, and he works with Pandol & Sons, the family farm near Delano, Calif., where Amigo has been a consultant since 1989. Pandol & Sons primarily grows table grapes, using conventional and organic practices.
"Amigo doesn't have a college degree," Pandol says. "I have a degree in viticulture from UC Davis, one of the best ag schools in the country, and I learn from him all the time. He's self-taught, and he's a tremendous observer. He's bridged over to the conventional farm community to help conventional farmers reduce the use of pesticides and fertilizer. We learned a lot from Amigo about soil nutrition, cover-cropping, composting and about the relation between the balance of minerals and nutrients in the soil and plant health, a plant's ability to resist pests and disease. From what he taught us, we found that there's an economic return. We didn't spend less on materials -- we spent more, at first -- but we improved the quality of our products."
IT'S AFTERNOON, AND WE'VE MOVED TO A GROVE of olives called the Golden Bear Orchard because it rises from the banks of the Bear River, a tributary of the Sacramento. This is rolling, dry pasture studded with olive trees, and in the distance, the high, pale ridge of the Sierra Nevada is visible. In the mid-19th century this land was part of the Johnson Rancho, one of the first places settlers chanced upon as they descended from the mountains. The olive trees in this orchard were once evenly planted, but many of them were dug up and moved to Sacramento housing developments during the 60's and 70's -- a historically null fate for these historic trees. Red-tail hawks circle above us, and bluebirds cluster on a power line over the highway. We cross a barbed-wire fence. The trees around us are dark with olives: Missions, Sevillanos, Frantoios, Nevadillos. The Nevadillos, especially, seem to have been dredged in some purple dust until they look almost like giant Concord grapes. "Hey, we got a crop here!" Amigo shouts. A small herd of cattle begins to drift away. These olives will go to the press within days.
Spending the morning amid a ruined olive harvest made me wonder why this man grows olives. "I'm really committed to having fun in life," Amigo says. "Nobody makes enough money in agriculture just to do it for that. It's too hard a work to be sour. I was just dying to get back to growing things. I like to get my fingers dirty. I still like doing farm advising, but I'd rather be a grunt any day." It's a simple answer, a joke and a truth at once. But I had also been presented with answers to that question all day long, in the taste of the oil, in the sight of Amigo and Scot Woodland performing the most basic of agricultural tasks, kneeling in an orchard, parting the earth with their hand tools.
The complexity of olive oil becomes more evident the more simply it is presented. Olive oil is like wine in that regard: you are consuming the place, the microclimate, the character of the soil and, too, the character of the human who has produced it, the care with which it has been handled and pressed. And something of the same relation prevails in farming. The simplest methods often reveal the greatest complexity. The word "organic" still seems to imply, falsely, that something has been left out of the growing process, that a farmer merely surrenders to nature in order to produce a crop whose virtue is the absence of chemical fertilizers and pesticides. "The best of organic farmers have to be highly skilled," Amigo says as we drive back across the foothills. "I mean this is not a low-tech system. You have to plan for things, you have to take actions way in advance of what the guys with the chemicals do."
While we were walking through the Gold Hill Orchard that morning, slipping on the olives underfoot, it occurred to me to ask Amigo -- who is producing, after all, an expensive specialty-food product -- how we were going to feed the world. Amigo put down his hand hoe. "We're not going to feed the rest of the world, I'll say that. I think we can only feed the group that we can feed economically. Where the rest of the world can get fed, though, is with foods that are being produced conventionally but can be farmed organically at virtually the same cost. The other place where people can keep costs down is by dealing direct -- at farmers' markets. You see a lot of lower-income people shopping at farmers' markets because that gives them an opportunity to get quality, freshness and a reasonable price."
As I listened to Amigo, I realized that my question had contained a false, half-hidden assumption -- that the world can be fed only with processed food, Government cheese -- and that it was based on the wrong syntactical model. The question isn't how do we feed the world, but how do we all feed ourselves. The vision of agriculture that will sustain a world is necessarily a complex one. It includes, as it has for millenniums, oil pressed from olives grown organically in small groves, and it includes, for the moment, tank cars filled with corn oil moving in trainloads across horizon-wide, chemically fertilized cornfields. Both crops are staples. The conflict between the way they are grown may one day turn out to be nothing more than a historic anomaly, though it often takes a person of Amigo's persistent cheerfulness to believe that agriculture is headed in the right direction.

HEADLINE: The Theory Of Supermarkets

BYLINE: By Jack Hitt; Jack Hitt is a contributing editor of Harper's Magazine. His last article for this Magazine, "How a Pilgrim Progresses," recounting a personal pilgrimage in Spain, appeared in August 1994.

 BODY:
Is it possible even to describe the otherworldly rush and animal wonder one feels on entering the modern supermarket? The journey is transforming, beginning with that blast of unnatural wind -- the chilly zephyr in summer, the dragon's breath in winter -- that conducts us through the automatic portals into this highly ordered yet voluptuous realm. It is, on some level, our greatest achievement. The painted cinder blocks of the average Food Lion are the true heirs to the walls of Jericho, built to protect the earliest stores of wheat and strike the first blow for post-nomadic culture.
At the height of his power, Charlemagne would have been hard pressed to stock even one middling Piggly Wiggly, and in just the last 10 years, the stock at the average supermarket has almost doubled to 30,000 products. To lay out a store these days that isn't baffling, graduate schools now produce a hybrid architect -- the supermarket designer -- whose sole task is to shape these items into a landscape that lures us in at the beginning, moves us about in some mysterious way and sends us back out the door. Not long ago, I spent an afternoon in the just-completed Super Stop & Shop in Hamden, Conn., struggling to discern the contours of this new narrative journey. 
 I confess to a supermarket jones. I go to them. I stand in them. I wander around in that singular alpha state triggered by those automatic doors and sustained by a hallucinogenic sea of primary colors. I like to fondle fruits and examine vegetables. I admit to a savannas-of-Africa high upon seeing slabs of meat along the length of a wall. I like to stare down dead fish nested in ice. I contemplate new offerings of foodlike substances. Frozen spicy popcorn shrimp, for example, lofted me into a state of pure Zen abstraction. But for this trip, I approached my supermarket with an open mind, note pad in hand, as clear of my culture's prejudices as an anthropologist on safari.
The doors open.
The vision at first reveals a cornucopia: tables of bright fruit and vegetables spilling out into a lascivious spread. Most supermarkets begin with produce; others open with flowers. The idea is to introduce the consumer into a realm of freshness and crispness, of color and beauty.
The array of tables and stalls leading around the perimeter means to transport the visitor to a European open market. In one counter headlined "Fresh From Around the World" there is a bewildering choice of produce: coquito, quince pear, gold tamarillo, cherimoya, carambola, horned melon, monstera and pepino melon. The mushroom bins are filled with portobello, cimini, button, oyster and shiitake. A rack of oils and vinegars features every combination of flavoring with dill or rosemary or tarragon. Cheerful clerks amble to and fro in color-coordinated aprons -- yellow for pantry, blue for seafood, classic white for meat.
But if one stands still long enough, the sensual experience begins to ebb and feel hollow. Why is it that the butchers have no blood on their white aprons? They stand behind their cases trimming tidy bits of fat from presliced meats before sealing them in plastic trays. A little rubbernecking reveals that the more rugged butchery is going on in the back, far behind this public staging area.
The same can be said for the fishmongers. There is not a single wayward scale on their sea blue aprons. And here is something especially weird: the fishmongers' stall doesn't stink. In fact, the entire store lacks an aroma. Every piece of meat and fish is hermetically sealed. The presliced pepperonis are spread on a piece of cardboard like a winning poker hand, then vacuumed in a skin of plastic. Back at produce, there is another sign, dangling between the "Fresh" and "Organic," advising that all the fruits and vegetables are dipped in a prophylactic of "Food grade vegetable-petroleum-beeswax or Lac-Resin-based Wax or Resin to maintain freshness." I plant my face in a tilted table of red apples. It smells like wood.
Only occasionally, when the pantry department opens the door to the rotating broiled chickens, is one corner of the store perfumed with anything reminiscent of food. Otherwise, the aroma is of containers. In an age of safe sex, this is safe food. Perhaps the designers suspect that a common olfactory experience would be perceived as too threatening, too ethnic, too political. Better to keep each single piece of fruit, each cut of sirloin, each fillet of mahi-mahi individually wrapped.
Another revelation becomes clear if you stand long enough. The great show of choice is mostly show. From time to time, I notice a few folks that marketers know as "innovators" -- bohemians in black, a gourmand with attitude -- considering the cherimoya or quince pear and then actually buying one. But most people passed on by and simply grabbed the five-pound bag of Florida navels or the discount sack of Macintosh apples.
Despite the colored aprons and bright awnings, the supermarket still pushes the majority toward some very familiar victuals. The folks who sailed past the charming displays of forest mushrooms, mountain coffees and foreign spices appeared happy to see them. But the luxury of feeling consumed by that blizzard of choice only gained its pleasure from the security of not having to make one. Sure, here is a cooler overflowing with cheeses from every valley. But around the corner is a monster display of the old standards -- cheddar, American, Swiss, mozzarella -- hung in handy packets. I counted about 75 hooks with different cheese options, mostly permutations in size, all pregrated and treated to maintain "freshness."
THE SUPERMARKET LAYOUT IS A CHAOTIC opera of flattery, designed to make you feel that you are a chef picking over the finest in meats, the most delicate in fresh leafy greens, the best in imported condiments. But the theorists behind this design know your heart. You are tired, or melancholy with your career, or grumpy with piles. You are dazed and confused. The displays soothe you with a wealth of options even as your cart fills with hamburger meat and iceberg lettuce, prepared cake mixes and, well, O.K., maybe that new popcorn shrimp appetizer you've heard about.
The mission of the supermarket, like everything in our culture, is supposedly dedicated to one end: choice. But it is not your choice; rather it is the retailer's. It turns out that each inch of space is scientifically calibrated to hold only what you will buy at the highest possible margin. I went back to find out what the supermarket designers know. Instead of coming upon a Frank Lloyd Wright of the A.&P. set imagining new palaces of food, I found that the supermarket has been subjected to an absurd level of scientific inquiry: complex experiments regarding display, observational studies of human movement and intricate work on the effects of lighting, color and music. The reason NASA is troubled these days may be that our Einsteins are occupied with the follow-up research to "Asymmetric Cannibalism in Retail Assortments." I read that article to prepare for this one, although it wasn't nearly as informative as "Shelf Management and Space Elasticity."
Perhaps you thought, as I did, there was only one postulate in the wide, wide world of supermarket theory: put milk at one end and bread at the other to force the shopper to trek the length of the place. Friend, that was eons ago. For you to comprehend supermarket theory, first know how well supermarket theory comprehends you.
You are probably female, although increasingly male. You shop 2.2 times per week in a supermarket (according to one of shopping's many think tanks -- the Coca-Cola Research Council). A mere 31 percent of you arrive at the supermarket with a list. But it doesn't matter: only one-third of your purchases are planned. The others, which are nearly as predictable, are sometimes called "splurchases." As such, the supermarket fills those long shelves, or "gondolas," with its 30,000 items (handsomely known in the jargon as "stock keeping units," or S.K.U.'s).
Other experiments show that if the layout encourages you to turn your cart one direction, you will look the other way, into the "strong side"of the turn. There, a cunning grocer will place what seems to be a good deal (but is not). The entire motive of the layout is to "push" you into making approaches or "shots" at a display or "facing." Other notorious locations in the supermarket landscape include the "in-aisle gondolas" (chances are you are being robbed there) or "endcaps" (same chances, because sales there are five times what they are on normal shelves).
If background music is slowed from a lively allegro of 108 beats per minute to a simple adagio of, say, 60 beats, then the speed of the average buggy slows, more shots are taken and purchases soar. Sales have been measured to increase by 38.2 percent -- a truth that, as any ambitious bag boy would know, is found in R. E. Milliman's groundbreaking study, "Using Background Music to Affect the Behavior of Supermarket Shoppers."
Typically you blink 32 times a minute. But after wafting through those automatic doors, science shows that you really do slip into a druglike narcosis, a groggy 14 blinks a minute -- fairly constant -- until you get in line at the cash register, when your mind resumes its fully conscious tempo. Blinkage may vary, however, depending on the "need state" that possesses you when you enter. According to one study, there are four of these: dieting, economizing, indulging and impressing guests.
Consumer attention is "malleable," according to the researchers who investigated "space elasticity," and whose study sought to "parameterize a model that allows us to compute an upward bound on the returns that might accrue to an 'optimal' shelf set."
What does that mean? I'm not sure. But in the course of parameterizing, the authors learned that you buy more soup if it is shelved out of alphabetical order. How much? If alphabetized, sales drop exactly 6 percent. Toothbrushes, if placed at eye level, will increase in sales by 8 percent -- no more, no less. Apparently, "shoppers process store schemas in spatial as opposed to analytical form."
According to this research, cereal arranged by type (flakes, brans) rather than brand will fall 5 percent in sales. With roughly 150 brands competing for shelf space, cereal is a rugged neighborhood. One common strategy deployed by retailers is the use of "flankers." These are simple variations of the highly profitable name brands -- either outsize box shapes or slightly altered flavors, created by preceding the named brand with words like "Apple Cinnamon" or "Honey Nut." The "new" products are dispatched to stand at the shoulders of the name brand. Their mission is to sop up precious shelf space and complicate any effort on your part to make a visible price comparison with the competing companies' flagship brands.
Other research shows that for each single minute beyond the 107.8 minutes averaged in a supermarket, you will spend an extra $1.89, not a penny more or less. As many as 95 percent of the shoppers who sample a product in the store will then buy it. The average "eye height" of a woman is 59 inches; a man's is 64 inches. And because the best viewing angle is 15 degrees below the horizontal (discovered by Eastman Kodak's think tank), the choicest elevation on any aisle has been measured at 51 to 53 inches off the floor. On average, when you examine a shelf, you like to stand four feet away.
Obviously, every wholesaler is interested in locating the best and worst position ("the maxima and minima of the polynome over-the-shelf domain"), unless you are talking about refrigerated juice counters. That's practically a separate polynome kingdom because juice is located in "a special horizontal bin at the bottom of refrigeration cases, about two feet above floor level, where consumers must lift the product up rather than pull it off the shelf."
Lift rather than pull. There's an entire shelf management Ph.D. thesis in those words.
The reason we have much of this raw data is a new technology noted by most Americans in the early 80's when it became widespread and by George Bush some five years later. "The Universal Price Code scanner put the retailer in charge," said Richard Rauch, a supermarket theorist and designer at Long Island University. "That device tells the retailer what customers are buying, when they are buying, at what price they are buying."
And, in the near future, the data collection will become even more sophisticated: not long ago, the shopping-cart company Unarco announced that some of its carts would feature "promotronics" -- a computerized screen that ostensibly will alert shoppers of nearby deals or new products. But it will also generate a map of each cart's journey, collecting data about which shot at what facing yielded which S.K.U. purchase.
BEFORE SCANNERS, THE POWER IN A STORE was held by the wholesaler, say, Campbell's Soup. Such brand-name companies were the only ones who knew what sold and moved, judging upon shifts in warehouse inventory. So Campbell's Soup could tell the retailer that Turkey With Noodle was hot this month, and relying on trust alone, the retailers responded. Now the power to know has been delivered into the hands of the grocers. An Age of Reason has overtaken the Days of Faith.
With such knowledge and given that 17,000 new products compete for space every year, retailers have found another source of profits. A typical store chain now routinely charges wholesalers "slotting allowances" -- ranging from $5,000 to $20,000 -- to locate one new product in a good facing on a popular shelf in a hip neighborhood at the right height. (The Federal Trade Commission is currently considering whether these fees constitute anti-trust violations and require formal regulation.)
Some of the more powerful wholesalers boast that they won't even consider paying slotting allowances. But almost everyone introducing a new product must do so. Some store chains have reportedly gone the way of petty tyrants, charging the old-timers "pay to stay" fees just to hang on to their positions. Otherwise, they might be exiled to floor level to be kicked around by adults and pawed by children, or dispatched to the ethereal realm of the top of the shelf where products sit like totems until dust requires their replacement. The cigarette manufacturers have surrendered completely and signed what are described as "long term 'rent' agreements" for their squalid tenement racks at the cash register.
At the end of the day, any store manager can employ software programs with names like "Spaceman" to crunch this information toward one end: to create a landscape intended to wring the most splurchases from each shopper. The plans that emerge from this warehouse of data range from inexplicable buzzwords to fully developed schemes. One peppy theory calls for reimagining the supermarket as a "servicescape." Meanwhile, the doctrine of "category management" comes with manuals, graduate schools full of tenured adherents and algorithms that will generate architectural specifics.
But not everything can be reduced to U.P.C. quantifiables. There are matters of taste involved, especially in lighting. You may have missed the 1995 Retail Store of the Year Awards presented by Chain Store Age Executive magazine, but in the competition for Best Supermarket, the winner was (cue the timpani) Kessel Premier from Flint, Mich. What really swung the judges, apparently, was the contemporary color scheme: "Teal and mauve accents against vanilla-colored walls lend an upscale touch to Kessel's traditional value price image. The subdued colors are dramatically contrasted with patterned tile floors set with bold borders. Lighted highway billboard-styled graphics complete the American ambiance."
Still, science is making discoveries even here. One esthetic theory holds that East Coast stores should dabble in "gray, turquoise and salmon" because "the sun rises over the water, giving the environmental colors a soft hue." Western stores should play with "hot pink and purple," because "the sun rises over the desert, giving the environmental colors a hot look." All of these hues are meant to transport you into a place of chromatic familiarity, a "high comfort level," for the same reason that the music is slowed down: rather than try to rouse us from our coma, the soothing pastels and assuaging complexion seek to keep us in our drowsy 14-blink, 60-beat state. Slowly. More slowly. More time. More purchases. Slowly, now. Frozen spicy popcorn shrimp. Sleepy, now. More slowly.
COMPARE SUCH CALCULATED SOMNOLENCE with the typical frenzy found in a real European market, say, La Boqueria in Barcelona. The size of several supermarkets, it is a wrought-iron structure jammed with open stalls. Everything for sale is truly fresh, doomed to spoil in a few days. Nothing is wrapped in plastic or dipped in beeswax. La Boqueria can risk it because, via the subway system, it serves almost two million customers. A good supermarket is lucky to have several thousand.
The true cause of this condition can be seen right back through those automatic doors -- the car. According to the boys in the lab, the average distance traveled to any suburban supermarket is 1.8 miles. So my Super Stop & Shop is competing with another one just down the road. Worse, there is the industry's notoriously evanescent profit margin. The longtime average of 75 cents per $100 climbed to $1.14 in 1995. The Grand Wizard of U.P.C. and all the scientific analysis that comes with it is widely credited for this meager blessing. So, what supermarket could risk selling a true variety of fresh food?
Despite these brutal constraints, the tightly packed shelf of preordained purchases can be smashed. Whatever one might think of Starbucks and the recent coffee revival, freshly ground coffee beans and a tasty cup of joe are now nearly as common here as in Europe. So it could be that we are on the verge of revolting against the supermarket, product by product, the way Starbucks crashed through a reinforced facing of freeze-dried crystals and canned grounds. But that revolution took almost a decade. By and large, the supermarket remains a fortress of plastic, vacuum seals and resin dips -- the best world in the best of all possible profit margins.
"Too often," admitted Robert Blattberg, a professor of retailing at Northwestern University, "when I am in a supermarket, my only thought is, 'Why am I in this store and how soon can I get out of it?' " Unlike many supermarket theorists, Blattberg doesn't try to muster a public-relations agent's "genuine excitement" at what he sees. If anything, he's depressed that the presentation of food -- an appetite as powerful as sex -- has employed so much science and research to create a place that is unforgivably dull.
"I think of the turn-of-the-century department stores, like Wanamaker's," he said. "They staged full-scale operas. They created incredible plate-glass windows and pioneered the notion of window shopping." But that wafer-thin profit margin continually scares off any potential Phineas T. Barnum or Walt Disney.
Our supermarkets still have the power to attract us. There will always be that first moment of walking in the door, but then how quickly our enthusiasm is tamed as we are pushed from facing to facing. The store managers claim that these new layouts are designed to improve customer convenience (even as they unalphabetize the soup cans and, to this day, locate milk and bread on diagonally opposing corners). But if convenience is the only end to food shopping, according to Blattberg, then it must end in paradox.
"If it becomes purely transactional," he said, "then someone figures out how to do it all on the Internet and deliver."
And supermarkets disappear. Which would bring grocery shopping full circle -- to a place not far from where it was before the first King Kullen opened on Long Island in 1930, before the convenience of self-service set us on the sterile path toward longer shelf life and locked-in freshness. Back to a day when most families sent a young child to the grocer with a list. Late in the afternoon, a delivery man arrived with sacks of ingredients, with the result that (instead of devoting 107.8 minutes each week groggy and alone in a supermarket) folks spent time in the kitchen, at full blinkage and with family and friends, cooking a fresh, tasty dinner.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Color! Action! Sixty percent of all supermarkets begin with produce; the others begin with flowers. The idea is to tantalize the customer, to draw you in with eye-catching displays and the promise of bounty and freshness -- as if you were entering a true open-air market. After that, the layout is designed toward one end: encouraging as many unplanned purchases -- "splurchases" -- as possible. Get the Kids Involved The premise of cereal theory, as explained by Richard Rauch, a supermarket designer, is simple: put the boxes on the lower shelves -- where kids can see them. Says Rauch, the man who discovered that ice-cream specialties sell much better if placed in front of the long checkout line: "Kids say, 'I want that,' and the mothers and fathers are happy to give it to them to keep them quiet." (pg. 57); Forget the Alphabet Turns out you will buy more soup if it's shelved out of alphabetical order. How much? When soup is alphabetized, sales drop exactly 6 percent. Another big soup issue is shelf space, always a problem because the consumer perceives soup to be a winter product. Soup companies now heavily market summer soups or push the use of various soups in summer sauces, hoping to retain precious shelf space until the leaves start to turn and they can breathe more easily. Keep It Clean The meat counter, like the bountiful produce display, aims to please the ocular senses. But real blood is anathema: the clean-aproned butchers trim tidy bits of fat from presliced meats before sealing them in plastic trays. A little rubbernecking reveals that the more rugged butchery is going on in the back, far behind this public staging area. Look Left Experts suggest locating store labels precisely to the left of the heavily advertised national product. The theory is that after seeing the name brand, the eye -- habituated by a lifetime of reading -- will automatically move left (as it would on a new page) to compare prices. There it will find the store brand, a bit cheaper but looking just as good. Thus ends the search. (pg. 58); Just Give It Away The sample table is its own sub-art in the supermarket game. No wonder: as many as 95 percent of customers who sample go on to buy. The most impressive sampling effort took place a few years ago when the folks behind Nacho Cheese-Flavored Doritos marched out six million bags in 10,000 supermarkets in a single day. Multiply the Options The supermarket is designed to make you feel omnipotent by astounding you with options. But it's mostly show. Dazzled by a plethora of international cheeses, most customers retreat to the familiar -- American, Swiss, mozzarella, hung in handy packets, treated to maintain "freshness." Eyes Front Because the best viewing angle is 15 degrees below the horizontal, the choicest elevation on any aisle has been measured at 51 to 53 inches off the floor. Studies have shown that toothbrushes, if placed at eye level, will increase in sales by 8 percent. Lift, Don't Pull Intent on locating the best and worst position for products -- "the maxima and minima of the polynome over-the-shelf domain" -- experts in shelf management have determined that juice is best located in a special horizontal bin at the bottom of refrigeration cases, about two feet above floor level, where consumers can more easily remove it. No doubt more research will be needed to refine this axiom. (pg. 59); Cover the Scent How is it that the modern supermarket -- the Western world's lascivious monument to appetite -- has no discernible aroma? Vacuum-packed meats, wax-dipped fruit: in an age of safe sex, this is safe food. (Fred R. Conrad/for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Residential Resales

 BODY:

SECTION: Section 2; Page 31; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL VIEW;
How Talented Composers Become Useless

BYLINE: By Richard Taruskin; Richard Taruskin teaches music history at the University of California, Berkeley.

 BODY:
The nice thing about anism, someone once observed, is how quickly it becomes a wasm. Some musical wasms -- academic-wasm, for example, and its dependent varieties of modern-wasm and Serial-wasm -- continue to linger on artificial life support, though, and continue to threaten the increasingly fragile classical ecosystem. A pair of new Albany CD's of music by Donald Martino, now the Walter Bigelow Rosen Professor of Music Emeritus at Harvard, have recently come my way like a gust of musty air. They prompt me to throw open a window on the miseducation of musicians in America.
One disk, consisting entirely of piano music, is especially dispiriting, precisely because the performances, by David Holtzman, are so superfluously good. The other contains two reissues of Nonesuch LP's ("Notturno," Mr. Martino's best-known piece, recorded in 1974, and Triple Concerto for three clarinets and chamber ensemble, recorded in 1978). There is also a brilliant performance by Mr. Holtzman of "Pianississimo," a virtuoso piano sonata composed in 1970 and hailed in its time by Andrew Porter as "a peak of 20th-century piano music." That such a critic could say such a thing of such a work is indeed a sign of times gone by, but there is still something that needs saying about this music. 
 Once, a long time ago, in a famous article that ever since has served as a bible of academic arrogance, Milton Babbitt tried to laugh the audience's claims on 20th-century music right out of court. "Imagine a layman chancing upon a lecture on 'Pointwise Periodic Homeomorphisms,' he wrote. "At the conclusion, he announces, 'I didn't like it.' " Leaving the snobbery to one side, the analogy did make a philosophical point worth pondering.
By comparing "serious" or "original" contemporary music to mathematics (and appropriating concepts like seriousness and originality to one kind of music was where the arrogance lay), Mr. Babbitt was saying, in effect, that such music was to be valued and judged not for the pleasure it gave but for the truth it contained. Truth, in music as in math, lay in accountability to basic principles of relatedness. In the case of math, these were axioms and theorems: basic truth assumptions and the proofs they enabled. In the case of music, truth lay in the relationship of all its details to a basic axiomatic premise called the 12-tone row.
Again, Mr. Babbitt's implied contempt and his claims of exclusivity apart, the point could be viewed as valid. Why not allow that there could be the musical equivalent of an audience of math professors? It was a harmless enough concept in itself -- although when the math professors went on to claim funds and resources that would otherwise go to the maintenance of the "lay" repertory, it was clear that the concept did not really exist "in itself"; it inescapably impinged on social and economic concerns. Yet calling his work the equivalent of a math lecture did at least make the composer's intentions and expectations clear. You could take them or leave them. Honestly asserted, they had a certain authenticity, and so did the music.
But now imagine that one engaged Claire Bloom to read "Pointwise Periodic Homeomorphisms" with all the expressive resources of voice and gesture she would bring to the role of Ophelia or Desdemona. Her performance would add nothing to the paper so far as the math professors were concerned. The "layman" would find something to admire in the beauty of her rendition (as anyone listening to Mr. Holtzman's performances of Mr. Martino's compositions on these Albany CD's will surely admire his sterling qualities of touch, timing and tone).
And yet the lack of connection between the content of the utterance and the manner of its delivery would be a constant irritant both for the professors and for the layman. Both would find the performance somehow silly and gratuitous, though their reasons would vary, and though they might both be reluctant to say so. The incongruity would be equally manifest, moreover, whether Ms. Bloom read the paper in the seminar room or on the Stratford stage.
That is the problem with Mr. Martino's piano music, which strives for conventional expressivity while trying to maintain all the privileged and prestigious truth claims of academic modernism. Because there is no structural connection between the expressive gestures and the 12-tone harmonic language, the gestures are not supported by the musical content (the way they are in Schumann, for example, music Mr. Martino professes to admire and emulate). And while the persistent academic claim is that music like Mr. Martino's is too complex and advanced for lay listeners to comprehend, in fact the expressive gestures, unsupported by the music's syntax or semantics, are primitive and simplistic in the extreme.
Insofar as he seeks to be expressive, the composer is forced to do without language altogether. Where Schumann could make his most telling expressive points by means of subtle gradations of harmony, Mr. Martino can be expressive only in essentially inarticulate ways, the way one might communicate one's grossest needs and moods through grunts and body language. Huge contrasts in loudness and register, being the only means available, are constant. The combination of gross expressive gestures for the layman and arcane pitch relationships for the math professors is a perpetual contradiction. It fatally undermines the esthetic integrity of the music.
The only harmonic support the composer can give the expressive surface is the occasional (and by now, old and tired) device of finagling some intermittent consonant harmony out of his Serial procedures. Composers who do this call it "tonal implication" or "tonal reference," but it is really nothing of the kind, because tonality is a syntax, not just a vocabulary. Invoking consonance is just another gross distinction, another primitive and largely meaningless gesture.
THESE ARE HARSH judgments but necessary ones. Academic composers still maintain a smug front. In a 60th-birthday interview Mr. Martino was still blaming everyone but himself for the lack of headway his music had made despite all his prizes and plum academic posts. He was still heaping Babbittian scorn on "laymen," lobbying, as he put it, for a "potty-trained audience" and contending that "what we need are concert hall bouncers." And, of course, he was still simultaneously bragging that audiences disliked "Notturno," his Pulitzer Prize-winning sextet, and whining that his works were not more regularly performed before such audiences.
The reason it is still necessary to expose these hypocrisies, even after the vaunted "post-modern" demise of Serialism, is that the old-fashioned modernist position still thrives in its old bastion, the academy. Composers like Mr. Martino are still miseducating their pupils just as he was miseducated himself, dooming them to uselessness. Critics and "theorists," many of them similarly miseducated, are still propagandizing for Pointwise Periodic Homeomorphisms in the concert hall, offering their blandishments as consolation for the loss of a musical language and decrying the attempts of younger composers to find a new one. Excellent performers like Mr. Holtzman, whose recordings of Stefan Wolpe show that his talents can be put to much better use, are still content to seek cozy academic approbation instead of seeking to establish a viable role for new music in the public sphere.
It is not reinforcement in their contempt of audiences, or protection from them, that young composers and performers need, but encouragement in the risky business of establishing a new symbiosis with them. Mr. Martino and his music set an entirely negative example. The only constructive purpose the circulation of these records could serve today would be a cautionary one.

HEADLINE: The Dispossessed

BYLINE: By Marvin Zonis; Marvin Zonis, who teaches international political economy in the Graduate School of Business at the University of Chicago, is the author of "Majestic Failure: The Fall of the Shah."

 BODY:

A MODERN HISTORY OF THE KURDS
By David McDowall.
472 pp. New York:
I. B. Tauris/
St. Martin's Press. $35.
 In 1976, according to David McDowall, the Select Intelligence Committe of the House of Representatives, headed by Representative Otis Pike of New York, reported to the House on the situation of the Iraqi Kurds: "Both Iran and the U.S. hope to benefit from an unresolvable situation in which Iraq is intrinsically weakened by the Kurds' refusal to give up their semiautonomy. Neither Iran nor the U.S. would like to see the situation resolved either way." Twenty years later, it would appear, the United States has replicated that same situation with the Kurds' so-called "exclusionary zone" in northern Iraq. Fearful of the consequences likely to follow the overthrow of Saddam Hussein -- the dismemberment of Iraq and wider regional instability -- Washington refuses to give the Kurds sufficient succor or aid to help them establish an independent homeland. But equally fearful of a powerful Iraq under the leadership of Mr. Hussein -- who is likely to return his country to its past policies of military and imperial aggrandizement -- the United States prefers to maintain the Kurds in the north as semi-independent of Baghdad. A weak but unified Iraq appears very much the goal of our present policy. 
 Of course, America pays only a slight price for this state of indefinite paralysis. The Kurds and the rest of the Iraqi people pay dearly. It is with the price paid by the Kurds and others in the countries where they live that "A Modern History of the Kurds," a work of impressive traditional scholarship, is concerned.
 The Kurds now number more than 25 million, inhabiting an area the size of France that stretches across the common borders of Turkey, Iraq and Iran. According to Mr. McDowall's calculations, they constitute more than 23 percent of the populations of Turkey and Iraq and some 10 percent of the population of Iran. The price they have paid at the hands of these three states has been truly staggering. Very clearly, throughout the 20th century, both Turkey and Iraq have pursued policies tantamount to genocide, seeking to destroy the Kurds as a people. Turkey has been the most resolute and vicious.
 The Ottomans used the Kurds, who were willing accomplices, to be sure, in the genocide against the Armenians. By April 1915, some one million Armenians had been killed by the Kurds in eastern Turkey. Almost immediately thereafter, the Ottomans turned their might on the Kurds themselves. By the end of 1917, forcible resettlements, famine and disease had killed off as many as half the Kurds in the east. Sulaimaniya, a major Kurdish center, for example, had a prewar population of 20,000. By 1918, it numbered 2,500.
 But the worst was yet to come. By 1923 Britain abandoned any pretense of supporting either an Armenian or a Kurdish state in eastern Turkey. (Long before, by 1919, the United States had returned to its prewar isolation.) With the withdrawal of the great powers, the Turks, according to Mr. McDowall, "sought to hammer the Kurdish people." And hammer they did. First, the Turks banned the public use of the Kurdish language. Then they turned the Turkish army on the Kurds. In 1934, the Turks adopted new legislation: Kurds were henceforth to be dispersed across the country so they never constituted more than 5 percent of the population in any place they inhabited. The military was to force the resettlements. By 1937, none of this had worked to the satisfaction of the Turkish Government, and military operations began in earnest. Aerial bombardment, poison gas and artillery shelling were systematically directed at Kurdish strongholds. In the spring of 1938, for example, at the massacre at Dersim, the Turkish military slaughtered some 40,000 Kurds.
 Similar Turkish policies continue to this day. The formation of the Kurdistan Workers' Party (P.K.K.) in 1984 brought new violence to Kurdistan as the P.K.K. targeted Kurds who were members of either the political or economic establishment and whom the P.K.K. saw as serving the Turkish state. The Government responded with characteristic heavy-handedness, culminating by 1992 in a full-scale war against its Kurdish citizens. The war continues, costing the state some $10 billion per year; it has also cost the Kurds more than 20,000 casualties and two million refugees. (The Kurds flee the southeast for the relative safety of the cities, where they then can be mobilized into a fuller expression of their Kurdish identity.)
 Iraq has pursued essentially similar policies, with even more devastating results. As early as 1932, the King of Iraq was able to call on the British air forces to bomb Kurdish villages. But the fullness of Iraqi genocide toward the Kurds awaited Saddam Hussein. Beginning in 1982, at the height of his eight-year war with Iran, Mr. Hussein began the destruction of the Kurds. In that year, his troops rounded up every male over 13 of the Barzani clan, the traditional leaders of the Kurdish struggle against the state; the Iraqis seized some 8,000 people, paraded them through the streets of Baghdad and then executed every one of them. That was only the prelude. The culmination was reached in the "Anfal" operations of 1988, when Mr. Hussein combined poison gas attacks with the roundup and execution of Kurds, "with a brutality reminiscent of Nazi death camps," according to Mr. McDowall. About 200,000 were killed in that year alone, with more violence to continue in the years up to the establishment of the exclusionary zone.
 Iran manipulated the Kurds living there, seeking to focus their efforts against Iraq instead of Teheran. The Shah, in concert with Israel and the United States, supplied the Kurds with modern weapons to use against the Iraqis in a full-scale war in the early 1970's. But when the Shah achieved his diplomatic goals, he signed an accord with Mr. Hussein in 1975 and ended all aid to the Kurds. With the border sealed, the Iraqi Army was able to devastate the Kurds, who had no access to new munitions.
 The 1979 victory of the Islamic Republic in Iran brought no respite. Military campaigns against the Kurds resulted in more than 50,000 deaths within the first years of clerical rule. Moreover, the regime mounted an assassination campaign against Kurdish leaders, just as it did against non-Kurdish opposition politicians. Abd al-Rahman Qasimlu, head of a major left-wing Kurdish party, was killed by regime-sponsored assassins in Vienna in 1989. His successor, Sadiq Sharafkindi, was murdered in a Berlin restaurant by Iranian agents in 1992. Other leaders of left-wing Kurdish groups were killed elsewhere in Europe and in Cyprus.
 The systematic destruction of the Kurds continues. Turkey -- with its recent admission to the Council of Europe, its NATO membership, its democracy and human rights -- deserves special condemnation. (The European Parliament recently awarded the Sakharov Peace Prize to Leyla Zana, one of eight Kurdish members of the Turkish Parliament who were stripped of their immunity and sentenced to lengthy jail terms in 1988 for "relations with a terrorist organization," the P.K.K.) But Iraq and Iran deserve vigorous condemnation as well.
 Condemning the perpetrators of genocide is the easy part, however. A more challenging question -- which Mr. McDowall largely answers -- is to account for the extraordinary failure of the Kurds to build a national movement that succeeded in bringing them security and the formulation and achievement of some set of coherent national aspirations. In the end, it is the Kurds who bear the most responsibility for their own horrible sufferings. The Kurdish people have been consistently ill-served by their leaders, whose barbarity, treachery, venality and stupidity have been every bit the equal of the rulers whom they confronted.
 Mr. McDowall's extraordinary account helps explain why. Although "Kurdistan" was used as a geographical term as early as the 12th century, Kurds did not begin "to think and act as an ethnic community" until after World War I. But, most significantly, the Kurds have not been able to create meaningful ethnic unity or coherent national organizations. In the 1992 Kurdish elections in their "safe haven" in northern Iraq, the Kurdish Democratic Party and the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan ended in a dead heat. By May of 1994 they had fallen into fratricidal violence. In April of 1995, Kurds established a parliament in exile in The Hague, but its operation has been no more successful, only less violent.
 The Kurds have failed to achieve unity for many reasons: They do not share common ancestry. They speak two different Kurdish languages. They are divided into numerous Muslim sects. They are spread across a number of independent countries and divided further into competing tribes and clans as well as into groups of nontribal peasants and now city dwellers.
 Other peoples have surmounted such handicaps. But not the Kurds. Until there are Kurdish intellectuals who can fashion a coherent national Kurdish identity, and political leaders who can translate that identity into achievable goals, the Kurds will remain victims of the more powerful states in which they live.
 They will never be rescued by foreign states, no matter how much they might long for intervention. Foreign states cannot build a coherent Kurdish political movement. But even more to the point is a telling comment of Mr. McDowall's about an earlier and much-romanticized Kurdish leader: "Mulla Mustafa committed the fundamental error of believing that the external players, the U.S. and Iran, would help him defeat Iraq, rather than use him for their own purposes" Until the Kurds are in a position to take their destiny into their own hands, the genocide is likely to continue.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 18; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 727 words

HEADLINE: Back to Vietnam

BYLINE: By William Prochnau; William Prochnau's most recent book, "Once Upon a Distant War," describes the early years of the American press in Vietnam.

 BODY:

DRAGON ASCENDING
Vietnam and the Vietnamese.
By Henry Kamm.
Illustrated. 304 pp. New York:
Arcade Publishing. $24.95.
 THIRTY-FIVE years ago we blustered into Vietnam full of blind certainty and can-do optimism, not only oblivious of thousands of years of history but downright uncaring about such trifles. What did all that matter? The fate of the Free World was at stake. 
 Now we are re-entering the place. This time we are going as capitalists eager for profit, and once again we are almost giddy at the prospect. But will we be any better prepared? There is an unforgettable scene in Graham Greene's wonderful novel "The Quiet American" in which the jaded British antihero tries to explain the title character to a puzzled Vietnamese: "He belongs to the American Economic Mission. You know the kind of thing -- electrical sewing machines for starving seamstresses."
 "Are there any?"
 "I don't know."
 "But they don't use sewing machines. There wouldn't be any electricity where they live."
 Near the end of "Dragon Ascending: Vietnam and the Vietnamese," Henry Kamm relates a similar cautionary tale: In 1993 the village of Xuan Dang got electricity, but few of the houses were plugged in. "Too expensive," one of Mr. Kamm's many Vietnamese friends tells him. This village is just 40 miles from Hanoi.
 "Dragon Ascending" should be kit-bag reading for the old troopers revisiting the grown-over battlegrounds of their youth and for the young troopers on their dreamy bicycle tours along Highway 1. It should especially be read by the businessmen gearing up for a new invasion of Saigon. Unfortunately, the businessmen probably won't read it, because Mr. Kamm, who was for many years a foreign correspondent for The New York Times, offers no advice for cutting through the red tape of one of the last of the old-line Communist bureaucracies.
 Instead, he fills his pages with conversations -- with farmers, poets, dissidents, disenchanted revolutionaries and revolutionaries fearful that they will become disenchanted as the free market arrives. Theirs are mostly sad stories about lives never allowed to flow, lives interrupted by the Japanese, the French, the Americans and then their own home-grown Stalins -- men and women who, after fighting so long for their country's freedom, chose as their icon a man already in the dustbin, and chose a political system headed quickly into it, too.
 As Mr. Kamm shows through his somewhat disconnected tales, there is not much joy in Vietnam today. The place is dirt poor and backward. In one of his most poignant scenes, he watches youngsters at sidewalk cafes gathering up the empties, no longer for older brothers to make into beer-can grenades but for smiths to pound into crude tools. Meanwhile, the Government employs old Iron Curtain authoritarianism while reaching out to the West to deal with its debt problems.
 Mr. Kamm has spent more than 25 years watching the Vietnamese. If his book is uneven, so is the story he wants to tell. He opens by revisiting My Lai, where in 1969 he had interviewed survivors of the village slaughter. Their numbers have been diminished by time, but Mr. Kamm's new interviews quickly reveal one of his subthemes: The Vietnamese, even those with the deepest physical and psychological scars, are better able than Americans to forgive -- or at least to let the war drift into the past. A local author notes the irony in a Vietnamese mother working for a United States search team, sifting through the earth for bone shards from a long-dead American flyer. She had lost three sons of her own, and their bodies were never found; they are statistics among the 200,000 Vietnamese M.I.A's. She needs the work.
 There is something almost neurotic about America's obsession with Vietnam. We can't shake the haunt. Mr. Kamm writes, not originally but appropriately, that to Americans this war meant "the death of an illusion . . . the self-flattering illusion that their country fought only just wars -- and won them." That is one of the reasons that books like "Dragon Ascending" still have a niche in the marketplace.
 But now, as Americans go back, there is another reason for such books. Perhaps this time we can learn from them, and take with us both less romanticism and more knowledge, not only about the Vietnamese but about ourselves as well.

HEADLINE: Living, and Buying, in the North End of Boston

BYLINE: By SUSAN DIESENHOUSE 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
THE North End is a residential and commercial waterfront neighborhood accustomed over the centuries to periodic reinvigoration by waves of immigrants. The latest wave is of domestic origin, however -- droves of Boston-area residents who find they can live in the North End while earning rental income from residential or commercial tenants that subsidize their own housing costs.
First settled by English colonists in the 1630's, the neighborhood is a place of narrow streets bordered by skinny four-story, red-brick walkups. It is one of the nation's largest Italian-American commercial districts, with roughly 125 Italian food stores, restaurants and cafes within a quarter of a square mile. 
 Tucked into the eastern corner of downtown, the North End is a short walk from the Financial District, the theater district and the Government Center. Indeed, as the site of Boston's first British settlements, the rest of the city has grown up around it, according to the Boston Redevelopment Authority.
The newcomers are providing yet another spurt of rejuvenation. The area has about 900 multifamily buildings with roughly 5,000 apartments, and recent sale prices make them more affordable than they were in the late 80's.
In 1989, for instance, the median price for a 2,500- to 3,000-square-foot building with four 600-square-foot apartments was $425,000, according to Richard H. Carlson, chief of valuations for the city assessor. But then, only 10 buildings changed hands.
By 1990, the median had dropped to $172,500. And last year, about two dozen buildings were sold or put under sales agreements at a median price in the mid-to-high $200,000 range, Mr. Carlson estimates.
Furthermore, while building prices are now more affordable, rents are rising because demand for apartments is getting stronger. Also, with only a few scattered infill sites available for new construction, there is a relatively fixed supply of these properties.
As a result, property values in this neighborhood appreciated an average of 8 percent in 1995, compared to about 4 percent for the city as a whole, Mr. Carlson said.
"Downtown is hot," he said. "These buildings are doing well because they're adjacent to downtown, where the economy is picking up, rents have increased dramatically and there is renewed demand for residential property.
"When this happens, investors become interested in the cash flow from these buildings," he said. "And owner-occupants like them because the rental income can cover their own housing costs."
Then there are the life-style and emotional factors. Many who grew up in the North End, or whose parents grew up there before moving to the suburbs, are being tugged back by what they consider a tight-knit community with immaculate streets, a virtual absence of street crime and excellent views of Boston Harbor.
Joanne Anzalone, a local realtor who sold 11 of these buildings in 1995, none in 1994 and one in 1993 said, "This is the first time in the 18 years I've been here that I've seen kids who want to stay here and older people who want to move back from the suburbs."
In some ways, Mrs. Anzalone reflects the Old World touch for which the North End is known. In addition to being a realtor, she is a justice of the peace.
"If the couple rents from me, I give them a discount on the wedding ceremony," she said matter-of-factly. "If they buy, the ceremony is free."
Last year, Mrs. Anzalone, who owns several residential properties in the North End, purchased a nine-unit building for $500,000. She will invest about $300,000 on a gut renovation and then charge $1,000 to $2,000 a month rent for one- to three-bedroom apartments, she said.
IN general, owners who renovate these small buildings can expect to increase the property's cash flow by more than 50 percent. Within 12 years, given a stable economy, they would likely see its value double, said James V. Zarella, a broker at Hunneman & Company, a large real estate firm here.
For instance, one of his clients purchased a four-unit building for $240,000 in the second quarter of last year and invested $30,000 to remodel and refurbish it. Rents then rose enough to produce a 68 percent increase in cash flow, Mr. Zarella said.
Christine M. Corey, 26, and her brother Donald, 30, are hoping for a similar performance from the four-unit building on Henchman Street that they bought for $230,000 last spring. They spent about $5,000 to renovate one apartment for Donald and a second brother, John, and to refurbish the hallway and staircase.
Ms. Corey, a saleswoman for Fidelity Investments, and her brothers occupy separate apartments. Donald and Christine Corey pay themselves rent and deposit it in their account to build up equity, and raised the rent on the other two units to $700 from $550 and to $800 from $600. As first-time buyers, they passed up the suburbs where they were raised to invest here.
Ms. Corey can walk to work, and in the evening the pair melds into the crowds of tourists and other residents who frequent the cafes. Since they are of Italian ancestry -- the family name was Corigliano -- and have several relatives living in the neighborhood, they feel at home. And they are confident that the cash flow from the building will rise steadily.
"This is our first real estate project and at some point we'll buy another place, move out and get the rent and appreciation," Ms. Corey said. "It's a fantastic investment and there's a real sense of community here. I know the grocer, the tailor, we play Keno with our neighbors. The people have been so nice."
Other recent buyers are unabashedly sentimental about the North End.
Christine M. Luongo, 41, was raised here, and most of her family still lives in the neighborhood. When she married George Hadaya, also 41, 18 years ago they rented an apartment in the nearby city of Somerville. But Ms. Luongo never cut the apron strings, spending every day in the North End and sending her two sons to a parochial school there.
"Practically everybody I meet on the street, I'm related to," she said. "We're all very close and look after each other. I like that. I moved out but I never really left."
In the 80's, the couple tried to buy in the North End but found the high prices and short supply insurmountable. Then, in 1994, they found a four-unit building on North Bennet Street with two empty apartments for $215,0000.
So far, they have spent about $70,000 on a gut renovation of the two upper floors, which they will occupy shortly. They ripped out walls to make a large kitchen and dinning area; exposed brick on remaining walls; installed a stairway to unite the two apartments; removed another stairway and installed central heat, air-conditioning and a modern master bath.
They expect to spend $70,000 more to renovate the other two units, which they intend to rent to family members.
"Eventually, we want this to be a family building," Mr. Hadaya said. "We already know the people who bought next door."
Such communal spirit in the heart of a city is a rare find. Combine it with a profitable investment and it can be irresistible. Even Ms. Corey, who already is eyeing buildings in another part of the city, concedes that her balance sheet may not be the sole factor in determining how long she lives here.
As she said, "There's a real sense of community that it would be hard to leave."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Christine M. Corey and brother Donald, left, purchased and live in North End Boston building behind them. Brother John, at left below, joins his siblings in kitchen of apartment he shares with Donald. (Photographs by Cindy Loo for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Bronx's Beth Abraham Hospital Venturing Into Westchester;
Former Warehouse to Become a Medical Facility

 BODY:
A former industrial warehouse in Greenburgh in Westchester County is being transformed into a medical facility to house two expanding medical programs offered by Beth Abraham Hospital in the Bronx.
The 15,200-square-foot facility at 335 Tarrytown Road will house an adult day health care program for disabled patients 55 years old and up and a comprehensive care-management program for chronically disabled patients age 18 and older. 
 The programs mark the 520-bed Bronx hospital's first foray into Westchester County, according to Michael Bialek, vice president for real estate development. "We found that the population for these programs was being underserved in the county," he said.
Jon Parets, a hospital spokesman, said the adult health care program was "modeled after the day care concept, but its purpose will be medical, not social." Mr. Parets said the comprehensive-care program was "designed to keep nursing-home-eligible people out of nursing homes and living independently as long as possible." The hospital is opening two additional locations for its comprehensive-care management program, one across from the hospital, which is at 612 Allerton Avenue and Bronx Park East, and another at Grand and Essex Streets in lower Manhattan.
The Greenburgh warehouse was once operated by the National Cash Register Corporation. "It was a 15,000-square-foot slab-on-concrete box," Mr. Bialek said. "There'll be a new roof, new skin, plumbing and flooring." The $4 million project is expected to be ready in mid-April, he said. It was financed in part by bonds issued through the Westchester Industrial Development Agency.
