HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
At Stratford, Yet Another Plan Takes the Stage

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: STRATFORD

 BODY:
WITH a history as tortured as Hamlet's and as long as Henry IV, Parts I and II, the former Shakespeare Theater in Stratford is up for redevelopment again. It has functioned only sporadically since it closed in 1976.
On his third try, Louis S. Burke, a theatrical producer from Johannesburg, was chosen last November as developer of the 14.5-acre site by the Connecticut's Department of Environmental Protection, which oversees the property. The state bought it in foreclosure for $1.3 million in 1983. 
 Mr. Burke has made a $1.5 million offer to buy the complex from the state, but "we asked not to pay anything for the first two years while rebuilding," he said. While negotiations continue a license was issued last month permitting a tent theater to operate on the grounds for the next two summers.
"Negotiations could take another three months," said State Senator George L. Gunther, Republican of Stratford, who is a strong supporter of Mr. Burke.
Elaborate development plans, estimated to cost $180 million over a four-year period, include renovation of the existing theater to seat 1,750 people; the addition of a 1,250-seat theater and a 350-seat experimental stage offering simultaneous productions year-round; an open-air summer theater and a children's theater.
A house on the grounds would be renovated as a graduate school of drama -- a function that the original Shakespeare Theater initiated under the stewardship of John Houseman, the late actor-director-producer, and The Theater Guild of New York.
A museum, seven restaurants, parking for more than 1,600 cars, jogging paths, tennis courts, fishing, an "Anne Hathaway's Cottage," and "Kate's Cottage" (a Katharine Hepburn Museum) are also envisioned. Ms. Hepburn, Maurice Evans and Helen Hayes were among the stars who appeared at the nonprofit theater during its heyday from 1954 to the early 70's.
An additional 25 acres of the surrounding residential neighborhood would contain an inn and a hotel accommodating more than 500 guests. To realize this, Mr. Burke says that he has options to purchase 30 houses that would be converted into shops, art galleries, restaurants and bed-and-breakfast establishments.
Mr. Burke said that Coopers & Lybrand estimates that $2 million in state income and unemployment taxes and $5 million in state sales taxes would be realized annually and that the complex would generate a $15 million annual payroll.
LAST month the Stratford Zoning Commission amended its regulations to create an entertainment district with as yet undetermined boundaries around the theater property.
"It allows uses that compliment the theater," said Susan Youngquist, commission chairman. Underlying residential, commercial, and industrial zones remain, protecting properties from becoming nonconforming.
Naming himself as president of the Stratford venture, Mr. Burke has identified John Barton, a founder of the Royal Shakespeare Company, and Michael Langham, former director of the Juilliard School's Drama School, as artistic advisers, and Brakeley, John Price Jones of Stamford as fund-raising consultants.
E & F Construction, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Morganti Group of Danbury, has provided preliminary construction figures. Joan Brickhill, Mr. Burke's wife, is co-director with her husband of Brickhill-Burke Productions, a theatrical production company and the proposed developer of the Stratford Theater. She remains in South Africa pursuing her own acting career.
As producer of lavish musical revivals in South Africa, Mr. Burke has accumulated an attache case full of testimonial letters and expressions of encouragement from numerous well-known theatrical personalities. His only American production, "Meet Me in St. Louis," got unfavorable reviews and ran for seven months on Broadway in 1989-90.
Senator Gunther said he made inquiries about Mr. Burke while on a legislative visit to South Africa.
"He was legitimate, but they don't pay big money down there," he said. "His theater was torn down for redevelopment, that's why he's trying here. I don't know who his people are since I'm not close to his operation, but I don't think there's any problem about the sale going through. He has sources for money -- not for publication."
State Representative Vincent J. Chase, a Stratford Republican, is not so certain.
"If Burke doesn't have the funding I'm prepared to go to the attorney general and ask for an investigation," he said. "Burke approached Gunther for a $15 million low interest loan for development, but I don't think it will pass in these economic times." The bill is currently before the Joint Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee.
In 1992, the proposal by Mr. Burke, in association with Robert M. DelBuono Jr., a Stratford developer, and Scott Wilson, a Boston architect, was rejected, as was a more modest proposal by David D. Reed of New Haven, a director of development at the Shakespeare Theater from 1968 to 1973.
In 1993 Mr. DelBuono and Mr. Scott broke off their relationship with Mr. Burke because of "doubts about his financial acumen," said Mr. DelBuono. He and Mr. Scott formed Stratford Upon the Housatonic (Suthi) with Steven A. Wolff, a Fairfield arts consultant, bid against Mr. Burke and Mr. Reed, and won.
Their 10-year, $95 million plan proposed a $7.5 million grant and a lease from the state. It would have included two theaters, 300 hotel rooms and limited ancillary development. Financing was to be handled by the Tishman Corporation of Manhattan, currently involved in the refurbishing of 42d Street, and the artistic director was to have been Ron Daniels, associate director of the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass.
Contending that the selection process was unfair and that Suthi had stolen his ideas, Mr. Burke filed a complaint with the state's Department of Economic Development, which then controlled the site. A seven-month investigation by state auditors and the State Attorney General's office resulted in an 80-page report in June 1994 that "was not conclusive," said Robert Jaekle, the auditor who worked on it. "We did not find unfair or dishonest procedures."
When the state administration changed hands in 1995, the property was removed from the Department of Development to the Department of Environmental Protection and the General Assembly voted to sell off the Shakespeare property rather than lease it, generating a new round of bids.
T HE same three bidders participated and Mr. Burke won when he agreed to buy the property, while Suthi stuck to its lease proposal.
"Nonprofits cannot bear the burden of capital costs," said Mr. DelBuono. "We do not think the project is viable without the state's participation."
With his partnership intact, Mr. DelBuono is waiting to see if Mr. Burke can produce, he said.
"It was clear in the Attorney General's investigation that we were chosen on merit," he said, "but we were not prepared for the political maneuvering that could derail it."
If Mr. Burke cannot raise the money, the property reverts to the Town of Stratford, to remain a park in perpetuity with or without a theater.
Some residents, including James Connolly, a lawyer, think that the town should own the property. "Twenty years is no guarantee," he said, referring to the period in which a private developer must operate a theater under the legislation.
While competition is generally welcomed by Connecticut's established theater companies, some are critical of elements in the Burke proposal. Embattled by widespread cutbacks in public funds for the arts, Edgar Rosenblum, director of the prestigious Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, said, "If Stratford gets a $15 million loan I will be on the Governor's doorstep the next morning."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Year-Old State Housing Plan Starts Up 2,600 Units

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A YEAR ago New Jersey unveiled its first comprehensive housing plan -- a broad blueprint designed to funnel $700 million by the turn of the century into the production of low- and moderate-income residences while increasing home ownership in the state's cities and rental housing in its suburbs.
So far $100 million has been pumped into the plan, known as H-EASY 2000 for Housing and Economic Assistance Strategy. It has primed the development of 2,600 units for people earning 50 to 80 percent of the median income in the area they live. 
 Below-market rate mortgages are being given to some 500 urban home buyers and 3,300 jobs have been created, data from the state's Department of Community Affairs show.
"We're on target and on schedule," said Harriet Derman, Commissioner of the department, which is charged with implementing the plan. Next month $200 million more is to be released, most for the plan's keystone program to produce mixed-income for-sale housing in cities. That would bring the plan by early 1997 half way through its implementation, she said.
The reaction from housing groups, local officials and developers to the plan's maiden year has been mixed. Some say the release of money is not fast enough in a state that needs 86,308 low- to moderate-income units by 1999. The plan is expected to meet a quarter of that need.
Others say it has not gone far enough for rentals and in the suburbs. "It is better than nothing, but it is limited in scope," said Diane Sterner, executive director of the Affordable Housing Network, of Trenton, which represents private and nonprofit builders. Her group and others continue to call for more affordable rentals and subsidies.
Ms. Sterner's organization is leading a campaign to get a $290 million bond issue on the ballot in November to fill those gaps among others. "Then," said Ms. Sterner, "a dent can be made in meeting the state's affordable housing needs."
The consensus of local officials, housing advocates and developers, however, is that so far the plan's big success has been blending the workings of the state's three housing agencies -- the semi-autonomous Council on Affordable Housing, the Division of Housing and the New Jersey Housing Mortgage Finance Agency. That has made it easier to navigate the application process and by extension to provide access to funds.
"It's a plus because the state is concentrating its funds on projects likely to be built, resulting in more housing," said Raymond Codey, director of development at New Community Corporation, a large nonprofit developer based in Newark.
The goal to streamline the regulatory process, which builders and others have long said is dysfunctional, did not move ahead, all those involved in housing say. "The plan's spending elements could of their own momentum create affordable housing, but absent permit reform the impact will be inhibited," said Patrick O'Keefe, executive vice president of the New Jersey Builders Association.
Mrs. Derman voiced optimism that a bill addressing the issue would be introduced this legislative session.
To some observers H-EASY also has not yet advanced new programs or financing pools, a contention its proponents dispute. The plan's supporters say it creates more money by expanding the bonding capacity of the finance agency and combines it with agency surpluses, private investments and funds from existing state and Federal programs. "We are putting new money on the street without adding debt to taxpayers or to the state," said Timothy J. Touhey, the agency's executive director.
By packaging the state's resources with incentives like below-market-rate construction financing, below-market-rate mortgages to buyers and subsidies to builders the plan, in theory, would help boost production levels. Estimates are that the state last year issued 7 percent fewer permits than 1994's total of 26,986.
MANY consider the 2,600 units generated by H-EASY in its first year a decent amount but say most were produced under two long-established programs.The $13 million in Federal housing tax credits allocated to the state for low-income rentals was crucial. Builders use credits to raise construction money by selling them to investors, who use the credits to reduce taxes over 10 years.
Mrs. Derman said the state last year made the selection process for credits more competitive to stress projects that, among other things, drew more private capital. The resulting 2,400 units, she said, represent a 50 percent rise over 1994's total.
Suburban projects include two in Morris County. One is a 100-unit rental for the elderly in Wharton being developed by the nonprofit Wharton Senior Citizen Housing Corporation; Affordable Housing Developers, of Livingston, is the builder. Monthly rents for the 560- to 820-square-foot units will be $400 to $600, said Leonard Solandz, a partner with Roger Gore in the company.
The other is a 122-unit, one- and two-bedroom rental in Roxbury, with 20 percent of the units for battered women, said M. Brad Ingerman, a partner in Riverpark Village Associates, the developer. He said the units would rent for $445 to $755 a month.
In response to concerns from some housing groups, Mrs. Derman said that further changes had been made in the credit-selection process, including its approach to cities. At least another 2,400 units are expected to be generated under the program this year, she said.
H-EASY also released $40 million in 30-year, zero-percent-down mortgages at 5 percent interest, the lowest ever offered. The first $15 million produced 183 loans, including one to Dennis and Cecilia Cassidy who purchased a home in Elizabeth. "It's an unbelievable deal," said Mrs. Cassidy. "There was no other way we could have bought a house."
No one disputes the mortgage program's success. But critics said it was only for buyers in Trenton, Elizabeth, Asbury Park and Camden, the focus of the administration's Urban Initiative, which emphasizes coordination of services to help cities.
An additional 300 loans should result from the $25 million more released last December, said Mr. Touhey. He said the administration would continue the program, committing $10 million more this summer and expanding it to other cities.
Mayor J. Christian Bollwage of Elizabeth said the loans get people in homes, but he wonders how they will stay in them if nothing is done to help cities reduce taxes. "New housing would help add ratables and spur economic development," he said.
To that end $1.5 million was released to rebuild rentals above downtown stores and revive commercial areas, said Robert W. Friant, spokesman for the city's Community Affairs Department. Three other programs totaling $30 million, which were delayed awaiting legislative approval, also will be in place next month. The money, he said, will go to make homes available to tenants with an option to buy, offer credits to urban home buyers who help renovate their houses and provide construction-loan guarantees for the development of rental projects of up to 25 units.
On the urban side the test is the $200 million to be released next month. Of that, $150 million will go to construction loans to builders to mix market-rate and affordable units. The homes then will serve as equity for $150 million in state-guaranteed mortgages to buyers of the homes. An additional $30 million will help subsidize low- and moderate-income units.
BUT urban housing officials felt that putting market-rate units in every city was unrealistic and pressed for flexibility in the program, which was done because "it's better to get the affordable units built than none at all," said Mr. Friant, of Elizabeth.
Annemarie C. Uebbing, director of Jersey City's Division of Affordable Housing, said flexibility was crucial to homeownership projects in parts of her city. She said she hoped that a development of 27 two-family homes -- proposed by Minority Contractors and Coalition of Trade Workers, of Jersey City -- on Wilkinson and Bayview Avenues in her city would benefit from the funds.
Trenton also hopes to tap the program for two projects. One involves 17 rowhouses on Reservoir Street, a joint venture of Eldon Affordable Housing of Cheltenham, Pa., and Roy Realty and Isles Inc., both of Trenton. The other is for 40 town houses that would be built by Affordable Housing Developers and Isles Inc. on Broad Street across from the Trenton Battle Monument, where Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced the housing plan last year.
"We want to do more homeownership projects, but we want to do more rentals, too," said Alan Mallach, Trenton's director of housing and development. "It cannot be either/or."

HEADLINE: SPEAK SOFTLY, CARRY A VEILED THREAT

 BODY:
Beijing must be delighted with Fareed Zakaria's recommendation that the United States, in its policy toward China, forget about "the problems of neglected orphans, brave dissidents and cheap labor" ("Speak Softly, Carry a Veiled Threat," Feb. 18).
Even apart from the ethical imperative not to forget these abuses, political and economic factors warrant more, not less, attention to human rights. The "cheap labor" is a potential source of major unrest. The "brave dissidents" may be a source of future leadership and are certainly a wellspring of creative thinking about China's problems. The "neglected orphans," overwhelmingly girls, raise the specter of a sexual imbalance that China ignores at its peril. 
 Moreover, if the U.S. should sit and wait for 10 years, as Zakaria suggests, while China is allowed to ignore international law in the field of human rights, how, by the time China becomes a true superpower, are we to expect that it will honor economic rules or political treaties? Assuming that Zakaria's scenario is correct and that China is on its way to becoming a superpower, the policy of indulgence could create a monster.
Demanding adherence to international human rights will set the only acceptable foundation for future relations between the world and China.
 
JOANNA WESCHLER
New York
 
United Nations Representative
Human Rights Watch

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:

TRAIL LECTURE
There are many Appalachian Trail hikes, but the ultimate is the Appalachian Trail through-hike, 2,200 miles from Georgia to Maine, completed by about 3,000 intrepid souls since the hikes began in the 1940's. 
 Larry Luxenberg, author of "Walking the Appalachian Trail," published in 1994 by Stackpole Books in Mechanicsville, Pa., will talk today at 3 P.M. at the Desmond-Fish Library in Garrison about the experiences of many trekkers described in his book. Featured with him as co- lecturer will be Mike Warren, who illustrated the book with 150 photographs.
Some people apparently take the hike after a divorce, job loss or personal tragedy, and it is usually a life-altering experience, Mr. Luxenberg said. The first through-hike was completed in 1948 by Earl Shaffer. A woman known as Grandma Gatewood began the first of her three through-hikes at 67.
Information on food, equipment and life readjustment will be discussed.
The library is at the intersection of Routes 9D and 403. Admission is free. For more information, call 424-3020.
 
CELEBRATING DIVERSITY
Akira Kurosawa's "Rhapsody in August" will be screened at the Northern Westchester Center for the Arts in Mount Kisco next Saturday at 7:30 P.M. The second film in a series titled "Celebrating Our Differences," it will be followed by a discussion led by Karen McAlister Shimode, a cross-cultural consultant.
Kurosawa, one of Japan's most celebrated directors, used Nagasaki, site of the second atom bombing in World War II, as a setting for his narrative of remembrance and healing. In the film, four teen-agers visit their grandmother who survived the blast, which took her husband's life.
The center is at 272 North Bedford Road. Admission is $5, $4 for children and people 65 and older. For more information, call 241-6922.
 
DR. SEUSS CONCERT
Rob Kapilow, a native of New Rochelle, will appear with the Bronx Arts Ensemble as the narrator of two Dr. Seuss stories, which he has set to music: "Green Eggs and Ham" and "Gertrude McFuzz." The concert will take place today at 2 P.M. at the Riverdale Y, at 5625 Arlington Avenue and West 256th Street.
Angelina Reaux, a soprano, and two young actors, Anthony Roth Costanzo and Christy Romano, are in the cast.
Besides composing, Mr. Kapilow is a conductor and public television commentator. He has appeared as guest conductor with the National Symphony in Washington, the Orchestra of St. Luke's in Manhattan and the New Jersey Chamber Music Society. He is the conductor in residence at the 92d Street Y. in Manhattan.
Tickets are $6. For more information, call (718) 601-7399.
A second concert by the Bronx Arts Ensemble, this time for adults, celebrates the 100th birthday of the Cuban composer Ernesto Lecuona. It will be performed next Saturday at 7:30 P.M. at the Hostos Center for the Arts and Culture at the City University of New York, at 450 Grand Concourse and 149th Street in the Bronx. The event marks a new collaboration between the center and the ensemble.
On the program are familiar Lecuona works, including "Malaguena," "Siboney" and "Andalucia," and the featured work is "Maria la O," a musical farce set in Havana in 1800 and presented in concert form. Felix Guerrero will conduct the Paquito d'Rivera Jazz Quartet and soloists.
Tickets are $10 to $17.50. For more information, call (718) 518-4455.
 
FOR ANTIQUES FANS
Lovers of antiques will be interested in several programs at the Boscobel Restoration in Garrison this month. They will be conducted by Charles T. Lyle, executive director of Boscobel; James Abbott, the curator of collections, and other experts, including Robert Sack of Israel Sack, an antiques concern in Manhattan.
"The Work of Early 19th-Century New York's Premier Cabinetmakers," "The Lifestyle of the Dyckmans at Boscobel" and "The Original Possessions of Boscobel" will be presented on the next three Wednesdays, with tickets at $25 each.
On March 23, the hours from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. will be filled with demonstrations of stenciling, free-hand bronzing, gold leafing and other decorative-art techniques. In addition, Shirley Berman, a trustee of the Historical Society of Early American Decorating, and several members of the society will discuss the differences between antiques and reproductions. Admission is free.
Mr. Sack's slide show and lecture on "Fakes and Forgeries in American Furniture" at 3 P.M. on March 31 will also be free, followed by refreshments.
For more information or reservations, call 265-3638.
 
GAY DIALOGUE
Dr. Amy Kohn, assistant executive director of Westchester Jewish Community Services in White Plains, and a panel of gay and lesbian youths, a parent, a rabbi and a therapist, will lead a program titled, "Putting Out the Welcome Mat for Jewish Gays and Lesbians and Their Families," on Wednesday.
It will take place from 7:30 to 9:30 P.M. at the Mid-Westchester Y, at 999 Wilmot Road in Scarsdale, and will include a dialogue with the audience. Admission is free. For more information, call 472-3300, extension 351, or 698-2060.
 
ECONOMICS REVISITED
The Joanne Woodward Chair in Public Policy at Sarah Lawrence College, where Ms. Woodward earned her bachelor's degree in 1990, will sponsor a lecture tomorrow at 8 P.M. by Laura D'Andrea Tyson, National Economic Adviser to President Clinton.
She will speak on "Building on Success: The Clinton Economic Record" at Reisinger Hall on the Yonkers campus.
Ms. Tyson is on leave from the University of California in Berkeley, where she is professor of economics and business administration. The author of a number of books and articles on competitiveness in trade, she received her bachelor's degree from Smith College and a doctorate in economics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
The Woodward Chair in Public Policy was established in 1991 to get more issues into the college's liberal arts programs.
Admission is free. For more information or directions, call 395-2411.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
A Postwar Message For the Millennium

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

DATELINE: TEANECK

 BODY:
IF economic terror and moral indifference were ever presaged by a playwright, the handwriting on the wall belonged to Arthur Miller.
No contemporary dramatist has had a deeper grasp of the corrupting power of the dollar bill. By intuiting an emotional through-line between the idolization of materialism and the toppling of the family, Mr. Miller was foreshadowing the erosion of the middle class. 
 Given the modern overtones of a country in free-floating crisis, it is sobering to come upon "All My Sons," the breakthrough play of a prophetic voice, in what is essentially a 50th-anniversary production by the American Stage Company. But there won't be trumpets to herald the occasion, for Mr. Miller, who turned 80 last year -- another milestone dutifully commemorated, if not celebrated, in this country -- is revered in London but disregarded by America's commercial theater.
One reason may be that the cosmically involved concerns of his searing early dramas gave way to the inner-directed conflicts and pretensions of his later ones. Still, "All My Sons," in revival, was a commercial failure on Broadway in 1987, as was Miller's last effort, the muddled "Broken Glass" in 1994.
Mr. Miller's importance as a playwright of conscience flowered with "All My Sons" and positively peaked with his next play, "Death of a Salesman." A 1950's retelling of Ibsen ("An Enemy Of The People") seemed inevitable. An investigation of accusatory madness ("The Crucible," now being filmed in a star-filled Hollywood version) remains his work most widely produced nationwide.
That the best of Miller still reverberates in small theaters was startlingly evident on a recent trip to California, where "All My Sons" has been selling out (and was extended) in a highly praised professional production, directed by Elina DeSantos, produced by the Odyssey Theater Ensemble in West Los Angeles.
A T American Stage, the director, Sondra Lee, once a well-known musical-comedy performer, builds a sense of the ominous from the very first lines: "There's always bad news." "What's today's calamity?" Ms. Lee shapes the elements of a tragedy as if it were a mystery. Evasions dart in and out, tantalizingly. Truths surface and withdraw, until the house of Keller caves in, inexorably. Even the play's symbolic allusions (the appearance of the light once a dead son's tree has fallen; stars going out when another son's idealism dies) are naturally fused into a transcendent overview of a play that can be narrowly perceived as a primer on ethics in the postwar marketplace.
In a fine ensemble, Don Peoples (Joe Keller) is the very model of a double-talking businessman for whom compromise is second nature but double-dealing comes first. All too convincingly, he says, "I ignore what I got to ignore," before the foulness of his misdeeds and the rationalizations of his cover-ups erupt. Having "ignored" the shipment of defective planes to the Air Force that resulted in the deaths of 21 pilots, Joe says he was building the business for his sons. "I did it for you" is his excuse.
Then there's Lee Bryant's crafty display of charm-as-camouflage in the role of Kate, delusional wife and monster mother, who knows that what keeps her family together is a necessary lie. Both Joe and his unseen partner, the fall guy, represent the other side of "the little man," Miller's oft-repeated phrase that would reach a classic consummation in Willy Loman in "Death of a Salesman."
As neighboring supporting players, Susan Aston seethes (also charmingly) with the resentment of Sue, the good doctor's acquisitive wife, and Sarah Baker gives a graceful performance that won't submit to the usually overdone giggles that overtake Lydia next door. Daniel McDonald as the Kellers' idealistic son, Holly Cate as his fiancee and Brian Dykstra as her brother are in sizzling dramatic concert.
It's as if "All My Sons" were orchestrated, all sections in tune. Ms. Lee's complete interpretation, lucid and nonjudgmental, underscores Miller's themes -- retribution, purification and responsibility to the universe -- in an engrossing and powerful staging of a heartbreaking drama. If only it could be dismissed as a period piece from which we could turn away, untouched, unbothered and removed from the inconvenience of reflection.
 
ALL MY SONS
American Stage Company
Fairleigh Dickinson University,
Teaneck
 
Through next Sunday. Performances: today and next Sunday at 2:30 P.M.; Wednesday through Saturday at 8 P.M.
(201) 692-7744

HEADLINE: Learning How to Be a Full-Time Mother

BYLINE: By DARICE BAILER 

DATELINE: PORT CHESTER

 BODY:
LIZ FOREST of New Rochelle was an economist with an economics consulting firm. She hired a nanny and continued to work after her first child, Jocelyn, was born. During her second pregnancy, Ms. Forest panicked.
There were too many evening and weekend requirements. "I didn't know how I was going to pull it off, with all the demands of home," Ms. Forest said. 
 But quit work and become a full-time mother? "I was really afraid that I couldn't do it," Ms. Forest said, "that I couldn't handle both kids and find time to still be myself."
Then Ms. Forest discovered an announcement for Female, a national support group for "formerly employed mothers at the leading edge," or women making the transition from paid employment to full-time motherhood.
"I couldn't wait to get home and call," Ms. Forest said.
Ms. Forest, 32, joined the Westchester chapter. She is a member of a support group at the cutting edge of a new kind of feminist movement that advocates government and business support for women trying to balance family and work.
Female members are well educated, bright and articulate. They are former lawyers, college professors, sales managers, controllers or research scientists. They loved their careers and felt good about their work. They brought home paychecks that were a significant part of the family income. Those paychecks contributed to their feelings of independence and self-worth.
Female meets twice a month in Westchester. On the first Tuesday, there is a guest speaker or an opportunity for discussion at United Hospital Medical Center here. On the third Tuesday, there is a mother's night out.
Speakers cover such topics as part-time work, skills of being a parent, nutrition, exercise and the best time to return to full-time employment. During open discussion nights, members share advice on issues of concern. Sandie Conner, 34, of Larchmont and Valorie Luther-Mubanda, 32, of New Rochelle are the group co-leaders.
Ms. Conner was a controller of a bank subsidiary in Boston. Bedtime fears are her latest challenge. Her son Matthew, 4, keeps waking her up at night, afraid of monsters in his bedroom. How do the other women handle that? Ms. Conner wondered at the last meeting.
The women offered advice. Suzanne Page, 34, of Hastings-on-Hudson told of giving up her career as a research scientist. "I could never have predicted how sad I would feel," Ms. Page said.
As for Ms. Forest, "No one could have told me how challenging it was going to be until I was home doing it myself, how time consuming and difficult a job it was," she said.
These days, Ms. Forest takes pride in just making a trip to the post office with her daughters, Jocelyn, 20 months, and Gabrielle, 3 months.
Twenty years ago, Ellen Fried was a typical Barnard College student, a serious overachiever -- intellectual and intent on pursuing a professional career. She said she was astounded when, a few years later, a Fordham Law School classmate told her she was taking up a man's spot in law school when she would end up being supported by her husband.
Back then, Ms. Fried would have argued that she could support herself, that she didn't go to college to stay home. But in November, Ms. Fried quit work as a litigation lawyer for the State Attorney General's office. She now stays home in New Rochelle, plugging in Barney videotapes for her son, Benjamin, 1. She watches as Benjamin runs his toy train up and over the family dog and makes play dates for herself, Benjamin and the dog.
Like the other members of Female, Ms. Fried said she missed the intellectual challenges and excitement of her former job -- and the paycheck. But work can wait, she said. "Nothing is as important as being with Benjamin right now," Ms. Fried added. "I can't go back to his being this age."
Yet Ms. Fried questions her decision to be a full-time mother, especially when bills show up or Benjamin drives her to distraction. "I question if I made the right decision every time I talk to somebody at work and they tell me about something they did that's exciting, and all I've done is watch Barney for the millionth time," she said.
Ms. Forest has her up and down days, too. "I have days when I think I cannot absolutely do this another day," she said. "And there are days when I think I cannot imagine leaving these kids at home." She is jealous of her husband. "He goes out into the adult world," Ms. Forest said. "He takes a lunch and converses with other adults. At this stage, a big day for me is going out to the mall or going to the grocery store."
Ms. Conner worked while her children -- Brian, 6, and Matthew -- were younger. It is easier for her to be home right now. "I find that the quality of our family time is clearly much better because on the weekends all we do is stuff for the four of us," Ms. Conner said -- for example, going with her husband and her boys on skating outings or to a children's play.
Childhood is fleeting, and Ms. Conner treasures her time with her boys. And yet, she loved her former job.
Ms. Luther-Mubanda did, too. She misses the excitement of sales, but she relishes her time at home with Jerelyn, 1. She puts her former career talents to work leading Female, and networks for the future with her new community of friends.
Like other members, Ms. Luther-Mubanda said she planned one day to return to work.
Whereas women once wanted to have it all, juggling motherhood and careers, Ms. Luther-Mubanda may be echoing the sentiments of a new generation. "I will have it all," Ms. Luther-Mubanda said with a smile, "just at separate times."
More information about Female may be obtained by calling Ms. Conner at 833-0943 or Ms. Luther-Mubanda at 633-1513.

LENGTH: 1355 words

HEADLINE: Anti-Smoking Code Faces Legal Hurdle

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
WESTCHESTER'S tough anti-smoking ordinance, adopted less than two weeks ago by the County Board of Health, is already facing a legal challenge from restaurateurs and tavern owners. And even if it clears that hurdle, the amendment to the Health Code -- considered one of the strictest in the state -- may be quickly superseded by a weaker bill out of Albany intended, in part, to ease the economic impact of no-smoking policies on the tourism and hospitality industries.
But those who support Westchester's stricter stance are also wasting little time. They are mounting an intense lobbying campaign in the State Legislature to quash the pending bill, which would undo the efforts of many local jurisdictions to curb smoking. 
 In particular, the anti-smoking groups have taken issue with language in the proposed state law that says "the hospitality and tourism industries are vital to New York's economy" and adds that restrictions put into effect by localities are "confusing, burdensome and costly."
"It may be a money issue for some groups, but it's a health issue for us," said Lillian R. Jones, a spokeswoman for the Westchester division of the American Cancer Society, one of the groups fighting passage of the state proposal.
She said the Federal Food and Drug Administration has labeled tobacco a Class A carcinogen, equal to asbestos and radon. And the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta has reported that tobacco kills more Americans each year than alcohol, cocaine, crack, heroin, car accidents, homicide, suicide, fires and AIDS combined.
Smarting under the suggestion that financial concerns should dictate how public health issues are addressed, Dr. Douglas G. Aspros, president of the county's Board of Health, said last week, "We're not the Board of Economics, we're the Board of Health."
Just before the Board of Health voted 9 to 1 to adopt the newest restrictions, Dr. Aspros spurned a request from County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke to wait until passage of the statewide regulation.
The state proposal, which has gained the support of the tobacco industry, is also backed by State Senator Nicholas A. Spano and State Senator Guy J. Velella, both Republicans from Yonkers.
Dr. Aspros said the increasing trend nationwide is to restrict smoking in public places and Westchester is following suit. He said that in most cases, New York's health laws set minimum standards and counties have been allowed to enact stricter codes. Among other things, the Board of Health is opposed to the pre-emptive nature of the state's anti-smoking proposal.
By contrast, many who criticize the county's tough restrictions and similar ordinances adopted in New York City and Nassau County, argue that the smoking issue extends far beyond health concerns.
"If everyone is so worried about secondhand smoke, then why not ban it in the home?" said Scott Wexler, executive director of the Empire State Restaurant and Tavern Association, which represents 5,000 eating and drinking establishments.
Restaurant owners say they will challenge the County Board of Health's new ordinance in court.
Albert J. Pirro, a White Plains lawyer hired to represent the restaurateurs and tavern owners, contended that the board had violated open-meeting laws and failed to draw up an environmental assessment of the ordinance's impact. He also said the County Board of Legislators and not the Board of Health should have voted on the new restriction.
On all three points, Dr. Aspros disagreed, saying that his board "followed the letter of the law and more."
The suit is being prepared for filing in State Supreme Court in White Plains.
Besides the arguments offered in the suit, restaurant and tavern owners say their industry should be left alone to regulate itself and respond to marketplace demands. The owners contend that they are being subjected to undue interference by government.
A placard carried by a picket outside Health Department headquarters in Hawthorne before the county's Board of Health voted on Feb. 29 read: "Mind your own business. Let us mind ours!"
The restaurateurs estimate that about 25 percent of diners want to smoke, and they say that by law most eating establishments already have separate sections to accommodate smokers and nonsmokers. New York State's Clean Indoor Air Act limits smoking in most public places, including stores, schools, taxis, work sites and most restaurants. Smoking is allowed only in private homes, bars, some hotel rooms, tobacco businesses, limousines under private hire, some box seats in indoor arenas and restaurants with 51 or fewer seats. It is also permitted at private social functions.
Those opposing the new county law also say that many owners of small restaurants are struggling to get by and that the law puts Westchester's restaurateurs at a disadvantage.
"It makes it harder for us when the smoking laws in nearby counties aren't as strict," said Brian Silverman, the owner of the Louisiana Cajun Cafe in Dobbs Ferry.
"What's next?" he said. "Are health officials here going to ban red meat too? They're making it impossible for us to compete."
The new code passed by the County Board of Health, which is to go into effect on July 1, bans smoking in all eating areas of restaurants, regardless of the size of the establishment. In that respect the law is stricter than one passed in New York City, which does not prohibit smoking in restaurants with fewer than 35 seats.
On Long Island, anti-smoking laws permit restaurants to set up smoking sections.
The Westchester code says that smoking may be allowed in a bar area so long as customers are not waiting there to be seated. Food can also be served in the bar so long as the food service constitutes less than 40 percent of the bar's gross sales.
The board is also considering an outright ban on smoking in bars and taverns.
The bill pending in committee in the State Legislature to set uniform standards for smoking in restaurants and taverns statewide says the owner of a food-service establishment must designate a contiguous nonsmoking area "sufficient to meet customer demand and may not determine that no demand exists."
It says that if 75 percent of the establishment's indoor seating is designated nonsmoking, then customer demand is considered to be met. But it also says that a designation of less than 75 percent does not "create the presumption of noncompliance."
Senator Spano said the proposal for a uniform law was "not designed to put tourism and hospitality before the health and welfare of the state" but rather to balance both sides' needs.
He predicted that the Legislature would eventually adopt a measure that was more restrictive than the current proposal. "This is just a starting point," he said. "We're willing to negotiate."
At the New York City offices of the cigarette manufacturer Philip Morris, a spokeswoman, Mary E. Coughlin, said the company was in favor of a statewide law.
"Our position is that business owners should determine their own policies, based on customer preferences," she said.
Representing the other side, a spokesman for the Coalition on Smoking or Health, which represents the American Cancer Society, the American Lung Association and the American Heart Association, said the Washington-based organization would lobby against the State Legislature's proposal.
"Given New York's prominence in taking the lead in tobacco control, we will work very hard to see that those efforts are not weakened in any way," said Peter Fisher, the spokesman.
He added that similar pre-emptive state measures have overturned local smoking ordinances in Connecticut, Delaware, Florida, Illinois, Iowa, Louisiana, Nevada, New Jersey, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania and Virginia.
But last year, pre-emptive legislation introduced in 30 state legislatures passed in only 4 states.
"We've begun to see a turnaround, some successes," Mr. Fisher said. "But the problem is that we have to spend all of our efforts in blocking preemptive bills, and that diverts our attention from developing stronger measures."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Charging Late Fees In a Co-op

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
OF all the duties that befall a co-op's board of directors -- from deciding when to redecorate the lobby to determining how to refinance the underlying mortgage -- one of the most frustrating is also the most mundane: making sure the maintenance gets collected.
Indeed, co-op lawyers and managers say they frequently get anguished calls from boards in buildings with maintenance arrears rapidly approaching critical mass. In many cases, they say, a board in such a predicament wants to adopt drastic measures -- like imposing penalties on delinquent shareholders. 
 "That just happened in one of our buildings," said Ronni Lynn Arougheti, president of Heron Ltd., a Manhattan real estate management company. "The board wanted to charge shareholders $50 a month if they were late with their maintenance payments. But when I looked at the proprietary lease, I discovered they couldn't do it."
In fact, the situation described by Mrs. Arougheti is more the exception than the rule. The exception is not with respect to the unpaid maintenance -- that is more common than many boards wish. What was unusual is that the board asked before it acted. All too often, co-op lawyers say, boards adopt resolutions imposing late fees even though the proprietary lease gives them no authority to do so.
"The issue revolves around the question of when and if the co-op board can act on its own," said Stanley E. Margolies, a Manhattan co-op lawyer.
Mr. Margolies said that most proprietary leases contain language that sets the penalty that may be imposed on shareholders who fail to pay their maintenance charges. Some establish a set interest rate on the overdue amount while others refer to the maximum interest rate allowable. That, however, raises two issues: first, with the matter having been addressed in the proprietary lease, it is doubtful that the board would have any legal authority to impose a different penalty without amending the proprietary lease itself.
And second, it seems there is significant confusion regarding just what the maximum legal rate of interest is. For example, in a case decided last November, no fewer than four different "legal interest rates" were discussed.
After a court-appointed referee imposed an annual interest rate of 19.56 percent on maintenance-charge arrearages, the lawyer for the defendant in the case insisted that the maximum rate permitted by statute was only 9 percent.
The judge hearing the case, however, after noting that the civil usury limit of 16 percent would be inapplicable because civil usury applied only to loans, ruled that the highest legal rate would be 25 percent, the limit under the criminal usury law.
The decision is being appealed.
"We advise most co-ops that what they should do is amend their proprietary lease so they can charge whatever interest rate is the highest possible rate at the time," Mr. Margolies said.
Some lawyers, however, say that imposing interest on unpaid maintenance charges is little more than a slap on the wrist. In most cases, they say, more persuasive measures are warranted.
"Even if you charge 25 percent a year, that's only about 2 percent a month," said James Samson, a Manhattan co-op lawyer. "Two percent on a $1,000-a-month maintenance charge is 20 bucks. You think 20 bucks is going to make a deadbeat shareholder pay on time?"
Mr. Samson said he advised co-op boards that want to charge late-payment penalties to do so in a way permitted by the proprietary lease -- even if that means amending the lease. Moreover, he said, the late-payment penalty should be significant enough to compel compliance while flexible enough to account for the occasional check lost in the mail.
"You've got to fit the penalty to the crime," he said. "Maybe what you do when somebody's one month in arrears is not the same as what you do when they're six months behind."
Herb Rose, a co-op consultant in Mount Vernon, N.Y., agreed.
"I've found that if the penalty is too low, shareholders have a tendency to ignore it," Mr. Rose said. "But if it's too high, they have a tendency to challenge it in court."
Mr. Rose said that a monthly late-payment penalty of $40 to $50 seems to be a good compromise for most buildings.
Arnie Zabinsky, president of Elm Management Associates Inc., said that another way to encourage shareholders to keep their maintenance payments current was to hit them where it hurts most -- not in their pockets, but in their parking spaces.
"Yank the cars," Mr. Zabinsky said. "The mere threat to terminate a parking license is one of the most effective collection strategies I've ever seen."
In many co-ops, he said, the right to a parking space is governed by a separate agreement. Often, he said, the agreement contains a clause that permits the board to revoke the shareholder's right to use the parking space if maintenance payments are not kept current.
"I've seen shareholders who would think nothing of a dispossess notice run to get their checkbook if they think they're going to lose their parking space," Mr. Zabinsky said. "It's sad but true -- an unexplained phenomenon."
At the other end, Mr. Zabinsky said, lies a more benign strategy -- reminding shareholders that they are cooperators.
"The common denominator in buildings that have no problem is a sense of community," Mr. Zabinsky said. "The board makes shareholders feel that they're part of the community and that they all have a stake in the community running efficiently."
There are times, however, when threats fail or altruism backfires. In such cases more drastic measures are in order.
"All too often co-ops allow people to go into arrears as a political favor," said Mr. Rose. "But if a board is serious about collecting maintenance, they have to be diligent, send out their notices on time, and be willing to put up with some unpleasantness and take people to eviction after a period of time."
Generally, Mr. Rose said, he advises boards to send a delinquency notice when a payment is 10 days late, then another 10-day notice when the second month's payment is late, and, after 45 days, to refer the matter to a lawyer for eviction.
"Shareholders talk to each other," Mr. Rose said. "If one person gets away without paying, you soon find you have eight or nine people who aren't paying. But if you play hardball with the first one, the others fall into line."
While such a management philosophy might sound harsh, Mr. Rose said, such is the reality of community living.
"It's like everybody is going out to dinner together," he said. "If you don't pay your part of the check, is it right that somebody else picks up the tab?"

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Eichner Begins $40 Million Conversion at Park Central;
On 7th Ave., Half Hotel, Half Time-Share Condo

 BODY:
Construction began last week on a $40 million conversion of half the 26-story Park Central Hotel into New York City's first time-share condominium. Ian Bruce Eichner, the developer, said he plans to keep the eastern half of the building as a "lower-end hotel" with its entrance on Seventh Avenue. The western half will be a 360-unit time-share operation called the Manhattan Club, with a new entrance on 56th Street.
Mr. Eichner said the initial price for seven days' use a year of a 650-square-foot one-bedroom would be $15,000; a two-bedroom will be $23,000. Annual fees would average $575, including real estate taxes. 
 Mr. Eichner, the developer of the Cityspire building on West 56th Street and what is now the Bertelsmann Building at 1540 Broadway, both taken over by other owners in the wake of the real-estate recession, is now also developing 121 apartments in a former warehouse at 80th Street and Third Avenue. A plan for a Toys 'R' Us store in the Third Avenue building has been the subject of continuing legal controversy.
The Sheraton hotel chain, which held the first mortgage for a syndicate that failed in the early 90's, agreed to hold the mortgage for the time-share project for Mr. Eichner, who agreed to pay $60 million -- $20 million more than the next highest bidder, he said. Sales are targeted to begin May 15, after a $2 million transformation of the lobby (from 1980's Egyptian to 1990's beige marble), the construction of two model apartments and a cleaning of the 1925 Tuscan Renaissance facade -- a striking melange of arches, bas relief squirrels, deer and pelicans and Corinthian half columns that, until last week, was hidden by gold-colored aluminum panels.

HEADLINE: Manhattan Sales Help Other Boroughs

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
IT is a script to delight home sellers, buyers wobbling on the fence and, of course, brokers: The residential real-estate engine that is Manhattan will churn up a wave that ripples through the other boroughs.
Right now, industry analysts say, it's just a wavelet, with sales of smaller Manhattan co-ops and condominiums creating a bit of a swell for the first time this decade. And whether and when the entire script plays out remains open to debate, subject as the real-estate scene always is to such pivotal and unpredictable performers as mortgage rates and job creation. 
 But even if the wave does rise, there are those who see worrisome counter-currents on the far horizon -- global forces like the computer-driven diffusion of office jobs from the core of central cities.
"Right now there are companies in Manhattan using data processors in the Caribbean," said Dr. George Sternlieb, the retired founder of the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University. "This is decentralization, 21st-century style, and in time it will have serious consequences for the real estate market."
For the near term, at least, there is optimism. "Everything in Manhattan is picking up," said Arthur Zabarkes, dean of the Real Estate Institute at New York University. "The big stuff, large apartments, special apartments, those were in demand even in '91, when people said the sky was falling. There were so few of them, and rich people were still rich.
"But now the rental market is as strong as ever," Dean Zabarkes said, "and there's starting to be movement in studios and one-bedrooms. In my view, it's going to be a straightforward ripple, with the major wave created in Manhattan."
Evidence of strengthening in the boroughs outside of Manhattan already exists. Prices of single-family homes, an indicator of demand, rose through most of the Bronx and Queens last year, with particularly potent performances in Riverdale and Eastchester and in southeast Queens. In Brooklyn and on Staten Island, however, prices slackened.
At the same time, condominiums -- which represent about 29 percent of the Manhattan sales market -- held their ground last year with sales increasing slightly and prices dropping a bit.
"The fact that Manhattan is coming back, we all agree to," said Jacques Gordon, an economist with LaSalle Partners, a commercial real estate investment and management firm. "The question is if and when it will trickle out to the boroughs."
The wave theory, naturally, is endorsed by other industry representatives, but also supported by data. "The market is driven from the top down, and there is still strong demand for large apartments," said Alan J. Rogers, managing director of Douglas Elliman, a brokerage company in Manhattan. "At the lower end, studios and one-bedrooms, it's essentially a buyer's market, and there are a number of factors contributing to an increase in sales." The key factor, Mr. Rogers said, is a mortgage interest rate hovering in the favorable 7 percent range.
Another potent factor, said Lawrence Sicular, director of the appraisal division at Brown, Harris, Stevens, has been the tight rental market. "The smaller one-bedroom and two-bedrooms in the $100,000 to $200,000 range were hurt badly in the early 90's," Mr. Sicular said. "But now, with rents so high, those apartments are cheaper to own -- sometimes nearly equivalent before taxes, and certainly cheaper after tax deductions. Buyers need to analyze that on an apartment-by-apartment basis."
The tightness in the high end of the co-op market can be attributed, at least in part, to a squeeze between a stock market that has climbed from below 4,000 to over 5,500 in just the last year and proposals for a drop in the capital gains tax. "With the stock market so strong," said Barbara Corcoran, chairwoman of the Corcoran Group, a brokerage firm, "we're flooded with buyers from the financial community with their fistfuls of cash, spending their bonuses on larger apartments."
Meanwhile, she said, talk in Washington of lowering the capital gains tax to 20 percent "is discouraging large-apartment owners from listing their apartments now, which makes the current shortage worse."
According to the 1995 Manhattan Cooperative Sales Report of the New York Board of Realtors, which includes data from more than 20 brokerage firms, 1,923 co-op sales were reported to the board last year, up from 1,703 in 1994. Board officials said those sales represent about a third of all transactions in Manhattan and almost two-thirds of the sales between 57th and 110th Streets, where most co-ops are located.
Most sales were in the $100,000 to $200,000 price range -- meaning smaller apartments -- which had the effect of lowering the median price for all co-ops. "It has been historically true that price per room for studios and one-bedrooms is significantly less than the price per room for three-bedroom and larger," said Deborah Beck, executive vice president of the Board of Realtors, because the rooms are often smaller and the apartments have fewer amenities. The median price per room for apartments sold in Manhattan during 1995 was $72,143, compared with $81,250 in 1994.
A T the same time, only 5 percent of the sales reported to the board in 1995 involved apartments selling for $1 million or more, while those apartments constituted 16 percent of all transactions in 1994. That reflected a buyer's market at the low end and a continuing seller's market at the top.
An advantage for sellers on the low end was a more rapid sale. "In 1993, the first year of our report," Ms. Beck said, "these smaller apartments took 9.8 months from first listing to closing. In 1995, the average was down to 6.5 months for smaller units." Average time on the market for all size units in 1995 was 6.9 months, compared to 7.8 months in 1994.
Divining real estate trends by the numbers is a murky exercise, at best. To begin with, co-op sales are not officially recorded because, technically, they are securities transactions involving the selling of shares, and not transfers of title. Condominium sales, however, are officially recorded. As a result, studies of co-op data compiled by the Real Estate Board and by appraisal concerns and brokerage houses do not claim to include all transactions in the market.
Sales of single-family homes are reported by local realty boards, based on numbers from their multiple-listing services. But not all real estate agents are members of the boards, and not all sales in a given area are recorded. And one board may use median prices -- meaning that half of the sales are above that figure and half below -- while others calculate an average. Still, the numbers, along with anecdotal impressions, provide indications of market patterns.
In its Manhattan Market Report for 1995, Douglas Elliman surveyed sales of co-ops between the Battery and 96th Street. The Douglas Elliman report, prepared by the appraisal concern Miller Samuel Inc. based on its own data and Douglas Elliman listings, surveyed sales of co-ops between the Battery and 96th Street. Purchase prices below $75,000 were not included in the sample; unlike in the other boroughs, there are few apartments available in Manhattan for less than that figure.
Like the Board of Realtors report, the Elliman survey showed an increase in sales over 1994 and a decrease in prices. There were 2,981 apartments sold in 1995, up from 2,274 the year before, the report said. The average price, however, dropped significantly, to $436,825 from $537,530 in 1994.
The Elliman report also indicated that the decrease in average prices can be attributed to increased studio and one-bedroom sales. For 1995 the Elliman report recorded 215 studio sales, compared with 115 in 1994. The report noted 961 one-bedroom apartment purchases for 1995, compared with 562 the year before. Sales of apartments with four or more bedrooms, however, dropped to 116 from 150 in 1994. The average price per room in 1995 was $80,100, down from $90,115 the year before, the survey said.
The same pattern was apparent in data contained in the Corcoran Report, a survey of sales over $75,000 below 96th Street in Manhattan, taken from deals brokered by the Corcoran Group and other concerns as well as appraisals by Mitchell, Maxwell & Jackson Inc. The report tracked 5,651 sales in 1995, up from 4,364 in 1994, and found that average prices dropped to $420,000 from $437,000 the year before.
In 1995, the Corcoran Report recorded the sales of 2,692 studio and one-bedroom apartments, a marked increase from 1,867 in 1994, while sales of apartments with four or more bedrooms rose slightly, from 133 in 1994 to 141 last year.
Condominium sales in Manhattan, according to Yale Robbins Inc., a real estate research firm, rose slightly last year, to 2,455 from 2,424 in 1994, while the average price dropped to $337,871 from $354,786. There are approximately 53,000 condominium apartments in Manhattan and about 180,000 co-ops.
Tales of two transactions paint a picture of a strengthening current market. One involves a couple who upped their bid by $125,000 without even knowing whether they needed to; the other is about a 60-cent bidding margin.
On Feb. 8, a four-bedroom townhouse on West 19th Street went on the market for $1.1 million. "A couple walked in and immediately bid the full asking price" on the day it the house was listed, a Thursday, Ms. Corcoran said. The seller accepted, issued a contract later that day and "the buyers, aware that it was a hot market, signed the contract right away," Ms. Corcoran said. "Friday, they heard nothing, despite several calls through their broker."
On Saturday, when they revisited the townhouse, they encountered another couple inspecting the place. "They panicked," Ms. Corcoran said, "didn't get any sleep Saturday and Sunday night." On Monday, they instructed their broker to raise their bid by $125,000 -- to $1.25 million -- "without even knowing whether there were any other bids." Four hours later, they found out that, in fact, their higher bid had been matched, so they raised again, to $1,250,000, "and received the signed contract that afternoon," Ms. Corcoran said.
Another transaction, Ms. Corcoran said, involved "a beautifully renovated one-bedroom on East 79th Street." To determine an asking price, the broker surveyed sales in the building during the last year, including one the previous week, "and there had not been a sale of a one-bedroom for over $200,000, ever." The broker listed the apartment at $195,000. Four offers came in the first day, all over the asking price.
"When the broker consulted with the seller on the happy dilemma, the seller instructed the broker to ask each person for a financial statement, a list of references and a written bid with a 10 percent deposit," Ms. Corcoran said. The apartment sold for $235,000.60. "The 60 cents was added on because the buyer was fearful that someone else might bid the same price.
"It points to the fact that mint-condition apartments are commanding an extreme premium," Ms. Corcoran said, "and that smaller units are catching up to the upper end. It's trickling down into the less expensive segments of the market."
WHETHER the trickle has crossed rivers is difficult to gauge.
There are hints of movement in Queens, where there were 4,280 sales of single-family homes last year, said Randy Kaplan, an official of the Long Island Board of Realtors, slightly up from 4,212 in 1994. Median prices of single-family homes remained at $165,000.
Co-op sales in Queens -- where about 120,000 units have been converted since 1982 -- also rose, while prices slipped. There were 376 co-op sales reported to the board in 1995, up from 322 in 1994, while the median price dropped to $45,000 from $50,000.
There are in Queens, in the words of Dean Zabarkes at N.Y.U., "micro-pockets that are booming, like Flushing, mostly with immigrants, renting, buying, buying commercial, bringing in very hard-working people who are succeeding." And, as Dr. Sternlieb said, "There are enclaves that are strong: Astoria, a powerhouse, and Forest Hills, somewhat."
Indeed, by an entirely different method of measuring the market, "Queens, actually, is looking pretty strong," said Robert Shiller, a professor of economics at Yale University and a founder of Case Shiller Weiss, a real estate statistics firm in Cambridge, Mass.
Case Shiller Weiss has devised a repeat-sale index to track fluctuations in prices. The survey is based on a table showing the average price of all single-family homes sold in zip code areas year by year. To determine price fluctuations in 1995, for example, the survey took the purchase price of each home sold in each zip code area during the year just ended, compared it to the price that the house brought the last time it was sold and then, using the annual index, adjusted the earlier purchase price to what it likely would have been had it sold in 1994. The survey does not cover Manhattan, where there are few single-family homes.
Of 57 zip codes in Queens, only two showed price declines of 2 percent or more, with 12 showing increases of 4 percent or more, including nine in Jamaica, the survey showed. The nine in Jamaica included several areas with large minority populations. "Price increases show no color barriers," Professor Shiller said.
"Flushing and Long Island City performed much better than in 1994," he said, "when there were a lot of declines of more than 2 percent in those areas." Last year, in Flushing, 21 zip codes demonstrated price appreciation, although only one experienced an increase of over 4 percent.
If Queens performed well, the Bronx held its own. Of the 25 zip codes in the Bronx, only one showed a decline of more than 2 percent last year; three showed increases of 4 percent or more. The Bronx Board of Realtors reported 615 single-family home sales last year, at an average of $156,660. But 1995 was the first year the Bronx board compiled data, so there were no comparison figures.
In Brooklyn, where there is no local board to compile data, the Case Shiller Weiss survey showed that 27 of 36 zip codes experienced price drops of more than 2 percent last year, and none demonstrated price increases. "The thing about Brooklyn that strikes me is that it was also relatively weak in 1994," Professor Shiller said, "so it's a consistent picture of weakness."
Statistics for Staten Island were somewhat contraditory, underscoring the lack of precision among various techniques used to calculate housing data. According to Charles Staro, executive vice president of the New York State Association of Realtors, 857 homes were sold on Staten Island in 1995, a drop from 887 in 1994, while the average sale price was $159,680, compared with $155,980 in 1994. According to the Case Shiller Weiss survey, however, Staten Island experienced what would appear to be widespread depreciation in 1995, with 11 of 12 zip code areas showing price decreases of more than 2 percent.
Professor Shiller pointed out that Staten Island "did well the year before," with seven of 12 areas showing price increases in the 2 to 4 percent range. "They had a strong year in 1994, so this looks like a market correction, and may not be of any long-run consequence."
"I wouldn't get alarmist about these numbers," Professor Shiller said. "We've seen areas where prices have gone down 10 percent a year. These are not big declines."
But why would virtually an entire borough experience price decreases? "I can only guess," the professor said. "Nobody understands these things. If you look at the boom in the Northeast in the mid-80's, there were regions where prices doubled in a few years, and really nobody knows why. I think it's mass psychology. Recessions, booms -- you'll see a million reasons."
Dean Zabarkes holds to his Manhattan-as-engine model. "You get a boom in Manhattan and it gets so hot it moves to the boroughs," he said. "But then when it declines it goes back to the real estate maxim: 'location, location, location.'
"Meaning, if I've got a converted building in Flushing and one on the East Side, I expect my East Side studio to get $200,000 and my Flushing studio to get $100,000," the dean said. "But when the market collapses, and there's a lot of stuff available, the buyer will say, 'I'd rather be in Manhattan for $90,000 than Flushing for $65,000.' And that's what happens every time there's a market collapse -- the secondary locations get destroyed."
IF the labor force in Manhattan grows slowly, "it could be another four years before you see a genuine tightness in the borough market," Dean Zabarkes said. "We're still burning up the inventory in Manhattan, but it's just a matter of speed."
Dr. Sternlieb is not so sure. Long-term factors may come into play.
Given the global computer revolution, he said, "there are questions about whether we need the scale of the paperwork factories that we call offices."
The professor is also concerned about cutbacks in the health-service industry, which became the employer of last resort for the city's lower-paid workers after the manufacturing sector withered, and about the effects of corporate downsizing. "We're still waiting for the cutbacks from the Chase-Chemical Bank merger," he said, in which approximately 12,000 jobs are to be eliminated.
So, despite the upturn in the real estate market, Dr. Sternlieb wonders whether the economy has "caught cold, or is this a wasting disease?" And he worries that city officials and planners are not taking long-term factors into account, given that "the future has no votes."
With that stew of immediate prospects and future uncertainties, Dr. Sternlieb sees "a new dynamism operating, so that the real estate market, as always, is stuck between greed and fear, and never more so than this coming year."

HEADLINE: The Thames, the Sound And Toxic Dumping

 BODY:
Arthur J. Rocque Jr. of the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection was being overly kind in his assessment that some of the opponents to the United States Navy dredging of the Thames River were "extremely economical with the truth." ("Navy Facing Criticism in Toxic Dumping," Feb. 4). Sadly, the article appears afflicted with a similar parsimony. 
Reading the article, one might think that the states of New York and Connecticut and the five Federal agencies involved in the project evaluation and authorization wanted to destroy the Eastern Long Island and Fishers Island Sound ecosystem. I assure you, that is not true.
For more than 20 years the public has been aware that if the Seawolf class of submarines was built the channel between the construction site and the submarine base would require deepening. A decade ago the channel was deepened for the Trident class of submarines. Uncertainty about the actual construction date and dimensions of the Seawolf class led the Navy to postpone full deepening and settle for what was needed at that time.
More than five years ago planning for berthing the Seawolf class began. A National Environmental Policy Act evaluation was performed. The process included public meetings, extensive impact analyses and documentation. The products of those efforts reside in the public libraries of all the involved towns.
A few of the article's inaccuracies merit comment: The project began in October, 1995, not 1994.
The Thames River Basin has never merited the description "heavily industrialized." With the exception of the submarine activities and ship building, now largely defunct, the major employers are a pharmaceutical company and gambling. However, the river supports valuable fishery resources.
The cap designed for this project is at least a half-meter thick. Monitoring of the cap placement occurs in-situ during its creation. The ratio of cap to capped material placed is about 2-to-1.
The river basin's interim sediment rating system is for dredged material disposal in Long Island Sound. Mercury testing determines the presence of virtually all mercury in a sample. Mercury is routinely found as a component of native, uncontaminated sediments in Long Island Sound. Geological mercury is not easily taken up by living things. The "moderate" level of the rating system ranges from 0.5 to 1.5 parts per million. With the geological mercury considered, the "available" level can be viewed as low. All these facts are accessible, thanks to the N.E.P.A. process, and were used in the authorization evaluations.
The Navy, in recognition of the unique biological value of the Thames estuary, imposed upon itself a construction window of Oct. 1 to Jan. 31 to perform the work. Its effort was directed at avoiding disturbance of spawning winter flounder. Bad weather and mechanical difficulties jeopardized the schedule. The Navy brought in more dredges to finish the work. That action was fully coordinated and approved.
A tugboat with a 300-foot-long barge in tow, traveling downriver past the United States Coast Guard Academy beneath the Interstate 95 and Amtrak bridges and past the New London downtown areas, even at night, when traveling with the required running lights, does not invoke thoughts of a nefarious activity. Incidentally, each barge has an independent, certified inspector on every trip to insure correct disposal.
Dioxin is a group of compounds that occur naturally as well as from human activity. A thorough analysis of the Thames River Basin was performed, seeking potential human sources. Finding none, a decision was made to forego dioxin testing. I appreciate John H. Thatcher Jr.'s verification of the appropriateness that that decision.
Perhaps Judge Thomas C. Platt "got it right." The project, as designed and implemented, will not cause "irreparable harm" to the public trust resources in the project area.
 
MICHAEL LUDWIG
 
The writer is a fishery biologist with the Habitat and Protected Resources unit of the National Marine Fisheries Service in Milford and participated in the review process for the project's permit.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SUNSET PARK;
Awaiting Hong Kong Exodus

BYLINE: By MARK FRANCIS COHEN 

 BODY:
On a recent rain-rattled afternoon, Shiu Kam Leung was walking down busy Eighth Avenue in Sunset Park, passing the prickly durians that hang in market doorways. For Mr. Leung, the bad-smelling yet sweet-tasting fruit popular in Asia is a harbinger of what he believes will be an economic boom in the neighborhood.
Mr. Leung, a business owner and president of an Eighth Avenue merchants association, left Hong Kong 15 years ago in anticipation of next year's government changeover. Today, he predicts that immigrants from Hong Kong will stream into the neighborhood in the next 500 days. 
 "Oh, 1997 is coming soon, people will see the changes," Mr. Leung said as he strolled by UEE, a video store featuring films from Hong Kong that opened on the shopping strip three months ago. "They come here and they have to pay more. And they will pay in cash."
Residents and business owners of the riot of bakeries and restaurants, markets and video stores rambling down Eighth Avenue often talk about June 1, 1997, when Britain will cede control of Hong Kong to China. Some business owners, anticipating a sudden surge in Cantonese-speaking immigrants this year, have been buying buildings and apartment houses. But many of these investments have gone unrewarded because the influx of immigrants with mounds of cash predicted in some circles has not happened. Some doubt that it ever will.
"People don't understand this community," said Paul Mak, president of the Brooklyn Chinese-American Association, from his office overlooking Eighth Avenue. "The people coming here are low income and if they're going to come from Hong Kong, they already have."
According to city Planning Department statistics, the number of immigrants from Hong Kong peaked in 1991, when 2,042 arrived in the city, and dropped to 1,140 in 1994, the most recent year for which figures are available. And according to Chinese-American community leaders, like Mr. Mak, wealthy immigrants from Hong Kong would be more likely to settle in Manhattan or upscale suburban towns rather than Sunset Park.
Still, that has not halted a rise in real estate prices here. Apartments in Sunset Park that rent for $1,200 a month were half that price five years ago, Mr. Mak said. Other community leaders said it will be years before newcomers begin to make enough money to move into these expensive apartments.
"We anticipate to see more immigrants from now until 1997," said Chang Xie, the Brooklyn branch director of the Chinese American Council. "People keep moving in. But the property value in Sunset Park is going up so fast, it is not affordable for many families."
Real estate agents said rentals are moving, but not at the frenetic pace landlords had anticipated. Many cling to the notion that Hong Kong immigrants are on their way.
"The impact has not started yet," said an agent, Paul K. Yuan, whose office window was shrouded in apartment rental signs. MARK FRANCIS COHEN
