HEADLINE: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;
A Capitalist Camp in Siberia

BYLINE: By GARY J. JAKACKY; Gary J. Jakacky now teaches economics and statistics to United States military personnel in Iwakuni, Japan, through the Asian division of the University of Maryland.

 BODY:
"Given the international diversification of this company, its enviable record of increasing earnings and the quality of its products, we feel a premium multiple to that of the market makes some sense. But at a 22 multiple of current earnings and projected E.P.S. for 1995 of $2.25 a share, the current $53 price of International Flavors and Fragrances fully reflects its growth potential for the next few years. We recommend investors defer purchase at this time."
(May 20, 1995)
 An analyst's presentation to a group of mutual fund managers? A research report culled from the pages of the Value Line Investment Survey? No, this is an evaluation by Max Bezyradin, a senior business major at Irkutsk State University in Irkutsk, Siberia, on his final examination in the finance course I taught there last spring.
Savvy investors, of course, are no strangers to the concept of international diversification and the triumph of free-market ideology that has been sweeping the globe. Still, the idea of undergraduate students in Russia issuing investment advice -- well, even I was taken aback by the sophistication they had acquired so quickly. 
 During the academic years 1993-94 and 1994-95, I was a professor of economics and statistics at Irkutsk State University, near the world's deepest freshwater lake, Lake Baikal. The trappings of financial civilization seemed worlds away; the nearest stock exchange is in Vladivostok, 2,000 miles east.
But as is the case with much of Russia these days, there is more here than meets the casual eye. In the building housing the joint Siberian-American management program, nearly 200 Russian students -- most of them conversant in English, many also knowledgeable in German or French -- study accounting, international business, finance, literature and American history. And in the computer center, they pore over Lotus spreadsheets, play computer games, send E-mail or surf the Internet -- wired to the world, even in Siberia.
The arrangement is the brainchild of Alexander Diagenov, an energetic professor of mathematics who is now dean of the program. Several years ago he struck a deal between Irkutsk State University and the University of Maryland under which students would mix study of Russian courses, English as a second language and business. They would be rewarded after five years with an undergraduate degree from both universities. Bilingual, educated and with marketable business skills, the students have bright futures in Russia's emerging economy.
"There is no program like it anywhere else in Russia," Mr. Diagenov said.
Ah, but there is the rub. Will the Russian economy emerge? While there are some substantial obstacles that must be overcome, the students express a cautious optimism and want to be ready.
"Since there will be shares in Russian companies that we might want to buy in the near future, can you show us how investment decisions are made in the West?" Larissa Motsenko, a fourth-year student, asked one day last winter.
What followed was a three-week crash course in growth-stock investing that included a real-time investment decision on International Flavors and Fragrances, the New York-based manufacturer. The students were provided with a 15-year chart of price and financial data on the company that came from the Value Line Investment Survey. I provided them with economic data upon which to frame their forecasts. Then they were given an earnings estimate for 1995 and asked to calculate a price-to-earnings ratio they saw as appropriate and to come up with a proper price for the company's shares. From this, they could determine whether it was a suitable investment.
As might be expected, the debate focused on whether the price-to-earnings ratio, then at a lofty 22, was justified in light of the company's earnings stability and product mix. Most students, like Max above, believed that it was not. Pavel Davydenko agreed: "I think the P-E ratio is too high. It's not as if this company writes software or is a computer firm," he said, showing that Russians are as enamored of technology as Americans are.
"And the P-E traditionally has been in the high teens, not the low 20's," said Zena Blinninkova, pointing to the historical data below the price chart. "I would say a P-E of 19 at most" would make it fully valued.
At that level, the price of International Flavors and Fragrances would be about $45 a share, considerably lower than its price of $53 on the day the exam was given. Not a bad call, given that the stock languished for most of last year while the rest of the market advanced more than 30 percent: the shares remain mired around $50.
Like students elsewhere, the Russians in the program worry about their futures in the job market. Most are sponsored in the program by private businesses, who chip in $5,000 a year -- not chicken feed in a country where a family's wage may be a few hundred dollars a month. In exchange, the students agree to work for their sponsor for three years upon graduation.
Perhaps the greatest enemy to Russia and these students' futures is crime. In all Russian cities, Irkutsk included, criminal gangs brazenly and openly shake down businesses and private organizations.
As an assignment, one of my faculty colleagues asked her students to submit proposals for businesses they would like to operate in the Irkutsk region. Students responded with a variety of ideas, from travel agencies to hair salons, from butcher shops to bakeries. In the business plans, though, along with the "costs of goods sold" and "labor costs" and "advertising expenses," nearly all the students had a simple line for "Russian mafia."
One hears all kinds of estimates of the burden that crime places on business, although one of my best third-year students, who carried a loaded pistol in his backpack, was quite knowledgeable and honest about the cost. "Fifty percent of all the profits below one million rubles, and 30 percent of all profits beyond that," he said, as cool and calm as an I.R.S. agent at an audit. In a country still in the throes of a cash economy (every month I received my 750,000-ruble stipend in cash, a pile that required its own drawer in my desk), such extortion is easy to hide.
For all that, most Russians are calmly optimistic that their country will plod through its current difficulties and become, in a few years, another example of a rapidly growing emerging market. It is this challenging, if dangerous, future that the students must soon face head on. Fortunately, if their investment acumen is any guide, they will be well prepared to meet it.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Factory Now a 'Jewel' in the Zone's Crown

BYLINE: By JANET ALLON 

 BODY:
The abandoned Washburn Wire factory, which sprawls for three blocks along the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in East Harlem, has become a hot property since the creation of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone.
Representative Charles B. Rangel calls it the zone's "crown jewel." It is also one of its earliest battlegrounds. 
 "You can go out on any street and bump into someone who has been promised that site," said Community Board 11's chairman, Eddie Baca.
On Friday, the Federal Government, which holds a $2.6 million judgment against the property's former owners, tried to auction it off, a move opposed by Mr. Rangel, Assemblyman Francisco Diaz Jr. and just about every East Harlem official and community leader.
After a brief bidding skirmish between a local nonprofit housing group, Hope Community, and a Long Island company, Bloomenfeld Development Group, the Government rejected the high bid, $465,000 from Bloomenfeld. The company said it would continue to pursue the property, possibly for retail development. Its president, Edward Bloomenfeld, said he has met with City University officials about sharing the site but declined to be more specific. Hope Community said it would firm up proposals to use the site for affordable housing.
The city, which holds a $2 million lien on the property, favors a sale to a private developer and opposes turning it over to the Empowerment Zone Development Corporation.
"We thought we should let the marketplace determine what happened with the site," said Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter. "I felt even more strongly about it when I heard there was serious development interest." J.A.

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Some Lessons From the 1930's

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
Investors looking for protection in today's volatile market might find refuge in the Dodge & Cox funds, says Susan Paluch, an analyst with Morningstar Inc., the fund researchers in Chicago. Dodge & Cox began managing money in the Depression, and the lessons of that era were not lost on the firm.
Its three funds -- Dodge & Cox Balanced, Income and Stock -- are bear market stalwarts, Ms. Paluch said. The stock fund gained 12 percent in 1987, when domestic diversified equity funds rose only 1 percent, on average. Similarly, the income fund lost half as much as the average bond fund in 1994. 
 That doesn't mean that Dodge & Cox investors lose when times are good. All three funds land in the top 20 percent for their objectives for the 3, 5 and 10 years ended Jan. 31.
The secret of the funds, which are team managed, is a value style of investing. The funds favor big, name-brand companies with temporarily depressed stocks. Low-priced financial and cyclical stocks are among the managers' favorites. On the bond side, they look for undervalued issues using an approach that does not involve forecasting interest rates, Ms. Paluch said.
 
New Funds
Keystone Small Company Growth II aims for long-term appreciation by investing in emerging companies with market capitalizations of less than $1 billion. The fund's sales charge is 5.75 percent.
T. Rowe Price Health Sciences invests primarily in companies involved in health care, medicine and life sciences, and it seeks to manage risk by diversifying around the world and in various sectors.
Strong Funds started five funds intended for people saving for retirement: Strong Growth and Income, Equity Income, Small Cap, High Yield Bond and Value.
First American Health Sciences aims for long-term growth by buying stocks of companies that develop, produce or distribute products or services connected with health care or medicine.
 
Getting Dizzy? How to Rebalance
Financial advisers talk about the importance of rebalancing fund portfolios, but many investors have little idea how to do it.
To get people started, Jonathan Pond, a financial planner in Watertown, Mass., has prepared a step-by-step guide and advice.
First, review your target allocation -- that's how much you want in various types of stock funds, bond funds and cash -- and make any desired changes in the percentages. Then summarize the cash value and the percentage of your holdings in each category, like small-company, growth and international funds. If you have three international stock funds, for example, be sure to add them together.
Calculate how much money would have to be added to or subtracted from each investment to bring it back to the target level.
But before making those changes, analyze the tax consequences For example, try to avoid selling securities that would generate a taxable gain, Mr. Pond advised. Look for alternatives, like selling some holdings in a retirement account, that will have few if any tax effects.
You should also consider transaction costs, which can offset any benefits of rebalancing. No-load funds are a good option, as are fund groups that allow switches within the group at no cost.
Rebalancing among several funds is often easier if done in a single fund group or in a brokerage account that combines several groups. Fidelity Investments and Charles Schwab & Company, among others, offer such brokerage services.
Most important, don't go overboard, Mr. Pond advises. Rebalancing may involve such a small amount of money that it's not worth your time and effort. If your current allocation is very close to the target, you may not want to bother, Mr. Pond says. For example, if your target for growth funds is 30 percent and your current allocation is 28 percent, you might skip rebalancing. But if your current allocation is 24 percent, you should do it, he says.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Is There a Matisse in Your Future? How to Invest in Aesthetics

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
WILLIAM M. B. BERGER -- like three generations of his family before him -- has done a lot of investing in his time. He began managing money in 1950, earned a reputation as an aggressive-growth investor, and for 20 years served as president of the $3 billion family of mutual funds that bear his name.
Now, at age 70 and still a Berger Funds director, Mr. Berger has discovered a new market: art. In the last several months, "I've bought everything from antiques to an Oriental carpet to furniture to paintings by mostly American artists," he said. 
 What led Mr. Berger to his art-buying spree was a look at the alternatives -- a stock market in the stratosphere and a real estate market likely to suffer as corporate and residential needs shrink. "There's an immense amount of money out there, and it has to go somewhere," he said. After noticing several high prices fetched at a few recent auctions, he concluded that the money was starting to feed the art market. That means there is time to buy while the market is gathering steam but before it overheats.
"I'm an outsider," Mr. Berger said, "but these are the observations of a very old market watcher. This is a very good time to buy art, pricewise."
Art rookie though he is, Mr. Berger appears to be gaining company in the art enthusiasts' camp. Dealers and auction houses that have weathered several lean years -- including a 1991 crash that sent auction sales plummeting by more than 80 percent -- are starting to see good times, if not exactly great ones.
"The market is slowly increasing," said James Goodman, a dealer in 19th- and 20th-century art and president of the Art Dealers Association of America.
Results from the association's Art Show, held this year from Feb. 23 through Feb. 26 at New York's Park Avenue Armory, bear him out. Attendance was flat, and sales of big-ticket items were slow, but dealers said they sold more pieces than they had in five years. Some were more enthusiastic. "It was phenomenal," said Richard York, an American art dealer who in those five days sold four paintings worth $1.2 million.
In their galleries, many dealers say business is up there, too. "We are as busy now as we have been since 1989," said James Berry Hill of Berry-Hill Galleries. Mr. Hill just sold at a profit a Childe Hassam flag painting, once owned by Frank Sinatra, that Berry-Hill bought at auction in 1989 for $3.3 million. Until now, the painting had fetched interest only at lower prices.
In the auction houses, the signs also bode well. Last Tuesday, Sotheby's announced that its net income climbed 61 percent in 1995, to $32.6 million, thanks largely to a 25 percent increase in auction sales, to $1.67 billion -- the best since 1990. Christie's auction sales rose 17 percent in 1995, to $1.47 billion, and its profits, due to be announced this week, are also expected to rise.
Figures for the auctioneers' bellwether semiannual sales of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art, held in New York for two weeks each May and two weeks each November, show even more impressive gains. In 1995 the total jumped to $571.8 million. That is nearly double 1994's $308.3 million, though still a far cry from the peak $1.57 billion of 1989.
Overall prices are starting to rise, too. Although prices are notoriously difficult to determine, because each work of art is unique and because so many transactions are carried out privately, the Daily Telegraph Art 100 index is one indicator. Compiled by Robin Duthy of Art Market Research in London, it tracks auction prices for 100 artists. With inflation adjustments, the index peaked in 1990 at 10,607, crashed and eventually fell to 3,864 in 1994. In January -- the most recent figure -- the index had risen to 4,178.
Investing in art is always dicey. Although several studies show that paintings, sculpture and antiques increase in value over the long term, an individual work may never show a gain. Even Mr. Berger noted, "I'm not doing it to make money, but I don't feel I'm being imprudent to be buying at this point." He believes that he will, at the least, preserve his capital as well as reap aesthetic rewards.
And art does seem to follow fairly predictable cycles, typically lasting about seven years. The rebound is taking a little longer this time, Christopher J. Burge, chairman of Christie's Inc., believes, because the 1989-90 peak was an aberration, fueled by frenetic Japanese buying that stopped completely when the Japanese economic bubble burst.
"We fell further, and it has taken us longer to right the ship," Mr. Burge said. "But we were pulling out nicely by the end of 1995." The recovery looks especially good because the buying is now diversified, coming from Europe, Latin America, the Mideast and Asia. In the down years, most buying came from the United States.
These factors add up to a market that is hearty enough to entice fresh material but is not prohibitively expensive. And that is an open invitation to would-be collectors.
No one is predicting a return to the 1980's, when buying was indiscriminate, any number of bad works fetched good prices and paintings could be bought and sold for a profit in a matter of months. "People are not just throwing tons of money at things," Mr. Burge said. "They're looking hard at quality and getting good advice. They may be paying a bit more to get what they want, but not pie-in-the sky prices."
The art market is really a collection of interrelated markets, and the categories -- Impressionist or Latin American works, for example -- tend to attract separate constituencies and move at their own pace. Right now, the most down-to-earth prices are in contemporary art.
"It's in the doldrums," said Roland Augustine, of the Luhring Augustine Gallery. He didn't sell anything at the Art Show, though he expects to seal a few deals from contacts made there. "It's a great time to buy because you can take your time and negotiate deals," Mr. Augustine said. "Prices are stable, at the same level as a year ago."
Many quality works are selling well in the category. At a recent Gerhard Richter show, Mr. Augustine said, "we had five paintings for sale, and we sold three, each for more than $500,000. That to me is very healthy." He's about to sell another, for $135,000 -- though the last, at $750,000, is still in the gallery's back room.
Many contemporary artists who made their reputations from the postwar years to the 1970's are faring better than later artists. These works by artists of the 1980's and 90's are like initial public offerings. The artists' place in history will not be known for years to come.
Art experts say that the market for Old Masters -- whose decline came later and was shallower than other categories -- is just now beginning to recover. And they forecast continued slow improvement in Latin American art.
Much stronger are the markets for 19th-century European paintings, by artists like Tissot, and for American art, by artists like Prendergast, whose "Figures on the Beach" watercolor is available at Berry-Hill for $325,000. Earlier in the 1990's, "People had the feeling they could walk in and offer a third of what you were asking for something," Mr. York said. "That's not happening anymore. We are selling at, or very close to, what we're asking for paintings."
And the market for top works by Impressionists and 20th-century artists through World War II is strong. On offer at Christie's is a Matisse still life, estimated at $1.5 million to $2.5 million. Another Christie's highlight is a Giacometti sculpture, estimated at $1.2 million to $1.6 million.
Buyers can take heart from a prediction by Mr. Burge. The market "won't go crazy this year, he said. "There'll be strength in the markets that are strong, and improvement in those that have been flat or wobbly. It's a good place for the market to be."

Interest in contemporary art is lagging behind other categories, but some artists are in demand. Gerhard Richter's 1987 painting "Feldweg" is priced at $750,000 at the Luhring Augustine Gallery. American art is doing very well. This 1896-97 watercolor by Maurice Prendergast, "Figures on Beach," carries a $325,000 price tag. Berry-Hill Galleries just sold at a profit Childe Hassam's 1916 painting "The Fourth of July," which it bought at auction in 1989 for $3.3 million. Until now, the painting, which was once owned by Frank Sinatra, had fetched interest only at lower prices.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS
JASHAH;
For Bonds, Notes From the Silver-Lining Crowd

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
BOND fund investors wondering if any air remained in the bubble from last year's rally got their answer on Friday. Prices plunged, erasing six months of gains, and long-term yields topped 6.7 percent, their highest level since August.
The needle that deflated the market was the Government's report that American businesses added twice as many jobs as expected last month. To bond traders, such signs of brisk growth fuel fears that inflation will accelerate. 
 But some bond fund managers say that, just as too many market forecasters were too optimistic at the end of 1995, investors are expressing too much gloom now. And a pair of them -- William Gross of Pacific Investment Management and Fred Quirsfeld of American Express Financial Advisors -- say they continue to find good buys, particularly among mortgage-backed securities and in selected overseas markets.
"We've hit a little bump in the road," Mr. Quirsfeld said. He predicts the current market is in a slight correction similar to that experienced last summer, when rates jumped from 6.5 percent to 7 percent. It is not, he says, the beginning of a protracted slump like that of 1994, when long-term rates rose 2 points, to more than 8 percent.
At the end of Friday's market shake-up, the yield on 30-year Treasuries stood at about 6.72 percent, up from 5.95 percent at the beginning of the year. That left general Government bond funds with an average loss so far this year of 1.93 percent, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund research firm in Chicago. Corporate bonds have recorded similar losses, with general corporate bond funds showing a median loss of 1.86 percent this year.
The returns are no doubt disappointing to investors who recall predictions from market strategists at the end of 1995 that interest rates would continue lower this year. Bond market seers, perhaps more so than their stock market compatriots, tend to use whatever has happened most recently as their guide to the future.
"You have to consider that 1995 was an exceptional year in the bond market -- when everything that could go right did," said Mr. Quirsfeld, who manages the IDS Bond fund, with $3.5 billion in assets. "That was capped by a strong rally at the end of the year, which caused a lot of people to capitulate and go long, even if they didn't feel strongly about it. That kind of set the market up for disappointment."
In the last month, the bond market frowned on several developments. First, the surprising strength of Patrick J. Buchanan, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, shifted the political debate from a balanced budget to populist topics more dear to the heart of the average American, like growth in wages. Mr. Buchanan's calls for protectionist tariffs also spooked bond investors, who saw in it the seeds of inflation. Surges in commodity prices -- particularly oil -- and signs of economic growth in Japan did not comfort bond traders either.
Even the small interest-rate increases so far have wreaked great damage on holders of the Benham Target Maturity funds, which, not coincidentally, were the biggest gainers among bond funds last year. The Target funds, which invest solely in long-term zero-coupon Treasury bonds, are the most volatile bond funds, gaining or losing value in multiple points of return for each percentage-point change in interest rates. This year's losses have wiped out about a third of last year's gains.
Less volatile funds have fared better, however, and in general, bond fund investors should not panic, the fund managers said. "A backup in yields of half a percentage point or so is a normal correction in any kind of bull market," said Mr. Gross, whose firm oversees $76 billion in bond fund assets, including the Pimco funds. "But I can say with extreme conviction that we are not going to resume or mimic the bear market of 1994. A return to 8 percent yields is not in the cards," and total returns for the full year of about 10 percent are still possible.
Both managers say they have revamped several parts of their portfolios in recent weeks, as prices have fallen. Mr. Gross says he has pared his intermediate-term Treasuries since the beginning of the year and picked up a fair amount of Ginnie Mae and Freddie Mac mortgage bonds.
"In this kind of market, where we don't expect things to change very much, the risk of prepayment diminishes," he said, dismissing the idea that home owners will refinance at lower rates in waves. "Mortgage bonds will probably continue to outperform about everything except high yields."
High-yield and convertible bonds, both of which often track the equity market more closely than the fixed-income sector, are among the few categories of bond funds to have shown much strength this year. High-yield funds, also known as junk-bond funds, have risen an average of about 3 percent.
The sector has been helped this year by continued merger-and-acquisition activity, some of which will allow highly leveraged companies to improve their balance sheets. U S West's bid last month to acquire Continental Cablevision, for example, gave a boost to the junk bonds of several other cable television companies.
And both managers see bargains overseas. "We still like Germany," Mr. Gross said. While German Government bonds fell last week as United States Treasuries declined, Mr. Gross said continued sluggish economic growth in Germany and low inflation made German bonds more attractive than their American counterparts.
Ten-year German Government bonds yielded about 6.51 percent at the end of last week, compared with 6.37 percent for the comparable United States Treasuries.
"Foreign rates are going to be coming down," Mr. Quirsfeld said. And at home, he expects rates to begin to do the same soon. "The fundamentals are positive," he said. Last week's sudden surge in rates, "will be a temporary phenomenon."

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Israeli Stocks Hang On Despite Bomb Attacks

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
BOMBS scarcely seem to scare stock markets anymore. Investors appear to calmly go about their business as long as they remain confident that a country's economy will remain strong.
That was certainly the lesson from Dublin, which shrugged off the renewed Irish Republican Army bombing in London last month. The Israeli stock market was not quite so blase about the four Hamas bombings that killed 61 people in the last two weeks, but there was no panicked sell-off as some had feared. 
 The Mishtanim index of the top 100 blue-chip stocks has fallen 1.1 percent, to 206.11, since the bombings began on Feb. 25. And part of that decline reflected not fears for the future of the Middle East peace process but disappointing results from Agan Chemicals, whose shares tumbled 7.25 percent in a day. In the United States, the American Stock Exchange/Oscar Gruss Israel Index of 11 stocks has fallen 3.7 percent, to 158.33, since Feb. 25, although the index did hit its 52-week high a few days after the first two bombings.
It is easy to see why the market took the bombing campaign mostly in its stride. Israel's economic performance remains encouraging. And its export-oriented high-technology companies are already profiting from that famous handshake on the White House lawn three years ago. The Arab boycott is crumbling, and the fast-growing markets of Asia and the Far East are opening to Israeli goods. Exports now account for 30 percent of Israeli corporate profits.
Analysts said that not only would the growing economy help push the Mishtanim index higher this year, but that stocks appeared cheap when compared with the projected earnings of Israeli companies. Some analysts even said peace was no longer an economic issue.
"Israel has already got the main economic benefits of peace" said Robert Goldman, an analyst specializing in Israeli stocks at Josephthal Lyon & Ross in Washington. He expects the Mishtanim index to rise 15 to 20 percent this year. "Peace with Syria and withdrawal from the occupied territories have negligible significance for the economy," he said.
Not everyone goes quite that far. "The peace process is not as important as it was," said Joel Bailey, managing editor of the Giza Investment Letter, a Tel Aviv-based investment guide. "But agreement with Syria and a settlement in the occupied territories would have some incremental value."
Joel Maryles of Furman Selz, a New York brokerage firm specializing in Israeli stocks, added: "The health of the economy is very strong. But there is always some benefit from peace with your neighbors."
Public outrage at the bombings may have made Prime Minister Shimon Peres regret his decision to move up the general election after the assassination of his predecessor, Yitzhak Rabin. But the outcome of that contest is unlikely to affect Israel's rosy economic prospects. The Likud, the conservative opposition party to the Labor Government, "might speed up privatization and cut some research and development grants, but that's it," Mr. Goldman said.
After growing by almost 7 percent last year, the Israeli economy is expected to expand by 6 percent in 1996, helped by a continuing influx of well-educated immigrants and growing trade overseas. Inflation is in single digits, and the Government's budget deficit is likely to be about 2.5 percent of gross domestic product this year.
Not all the news is good. Israel is running a big current account deficit, which swelled to $5.1 billion last year from $2.4 billion in 1994. "It's the main weakness of the economy," Mr Goldman said.
Israel was one of the best-performing emerging markets last year, with a 17 percent rise in dollar terms. At current levels, the Mishtanim index is still below its February 1994 peak of 257.08, though well above the trough of 145.17 it hit in March 1995. Moreover, with average earnings forecast to rise 16 percent this year, the market appears cheap, trading at just 11 times prospective earnings. The comparable figure for the European Union is 14.7.
Americans have a variety of ways to invest in Israel. The closed-end First Israel fund is quoted on the New York Stock Exchange, and 70 Israeli or United States companies that do most of their business in Israel are listed on exchanges here. Most trade as regular stocks, but some are American depository receipts.
Mr. Goldman has a list of eight buy recommendations, including Aladdin Knowledge Systems, ECI Telecom and Teva Pharmaceutical. Marcel Houtzager, an analyst with Wanger Asset Management in Chicago who specializes in smaller Israeli companies, likes PEC Israel Economic, a holding company that he said was trading at a discount of more than 30 percent to assets.
Mr Bailey recommends Opal, a semiconductor company, and Elron Electronic Industries, a holding company with investments in high-technology companies that are likely to go public this year. Mr. Maryles favors Gilat Satellite Networks, which makes satellite terminal equipment, and Mercury Interactive, a manufacturer of software testing equipment.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Anybody Want To Buy A Bond?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Sometimes, it matters who has been doing the buying.
Never has that been more important than in the Treasury bond market, circa 1996. The buyers of late have been foreign central banks and a bunch of international speculators who have been seeking a sure thing through a clever trade involving Japanese yen. (More on that later.) 
 Notably absent from the mix have been genuine investors. Mutual funds that invest primarily in Treasuries have not seen net cash inflows since late 1993, notwithstanding last year's rally in bond prices.
It was after the markets closed on Thursday that the Federal Reserve provided the evidence of just how big that swing had been. It said foreign central banks had purchased a record $17.7 billion in Treasuries in the week ended Wednesday. That brought their holdings to $547 billion, also a record.
Then on Friday came the worst day for the bond market in at least 10 years, after a report showing that more people were working than had been expected. In the upside-down world of bonds, that was bad news because it reduces the probability that the Fed will push down short-term rates. But that hardly explains the brutality of the bond plunge, which drove the yield on 30-year Treasuries up a quarter of a percentage point in a single day, to above 6.7 percent.
"This is what happens when the lenders of last resort and the speculators get long the same thing," observed Mike Rouzee, a money manager at the Friends Vilas Fischer Trust Company.
The central bank buying, says James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, has largely been a case of the Bank of Japan buying bucks to keep the yen from rising. It then invests the dollars in Treasury securities.
The Japanese central bank has been trying to keep the yen from rising to avoid injuring Japanese exporters. It has also tried to jump-start the ailing economy by keeping short-term rates very low, at about one-half of 1 percent.
That is where the speculators came in. They borrowed billions of yen, paying that low rate, and put the money into Treasuries. It was a sure thing, so long as the yen did not rise or Treasuries crash.
At the Chicago Board of Trade, where they have been trading bond futures for almost 20 years, Friday was the worst day ever. Prices fell so far that the exchange wouldn't let trading go on. It will resume tonight, and it will be interesting to see if buying materializes. Mutual fund investors have a history of buying stock funds on weakness, but of selling bond funds when they plunge. And highly leveraged speculators may have to sell Treasuries, putting more pressure on prices.
There is no good reason for the bond market's woes to have clipped 171 points off the Dow Jones industrial average. A strong economy is not bad for corporate profits, which is what stock prices are supposed to be about. But it would be easier to be confident if stock prices were not so high, and valuations so extended.
In 1987, mutual fund investors ran for the hills after the first-ever 100-point down day for the Dow, on Friday, Oct. 16. Fidelity Investments dumped American shares in London Monday morning, and the rout was on. That selling was not the only reason the Dow fell 508 points that day, but it helped.
But since 1987, mutual fund investors have regarded every 100-point down day as a buying opportunity, and the market has quickly rebounded. Tomorrow morning, a lot of traders will be watching to see what Fidelity is doing.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2439 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
The Year Is 2010. Do You Know Where Your Bull Is?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
IS the high-flying stock market, buoyed by a seemingly limitless tide of pension money, heading for a fall? No, not on the order of last Friday's 171-point drop, but something potentially far more disturbing two or three decades down the road -- when the baby boomers retire and begin to trade in their securities for Winnebagos, visits to the periodontist and trips to Disney World with the grandchildren?
"Don't bother me with this one -- too much can happen between now and then," responded Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch, reflecting the understandable impatience of Wall Streeters preoccupied with the more immediate questions of where inflation, G.D.P. and Alan Greenspan are heading. 
 But the issue, being raised quietly by the handful of specialists who study the links between demography and economics, is not the blue sky it might seem. With the population aging and Social Security drifting toward the political equivalent of Chapter 11, financial gurus are begging, pleading, cajoling Americans to save more for their own retirement. And the numbers suggest that the message has gotten through: investors have poured nearly half a trillion dollars into stock mutual funds over the last four years -- $50 billion in the first two months of this year alone.
Leaving aside Friday's 3 percent plunge, many of these new investors have known the market only to rise, and expect that to be the case right through their golden years. But economists taking the long view worry that the very process of cashing in the boomers' vast holdings of mutual funds could transform the most energetic of bulls into a sluggish beast.
"The difference between 7 percent and 3 percent real annual return is night and day," said James Poterba, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Nobody is suggesting that Rip Van Investor is going to wake up one day to discover that no one wants to buy his shares of Netscape Communications. But John Shoven, an economist at Stanford, does imagine "1970's-like stagnation in stock prices," which would extinguish many a dream of Mediterranean cruises and lazy mornings on the golf course. To protect that dream, Rip may have to save a lot more than he expected.
Start with some basics. Most personal wealth other than housing is accumulated through employer-based pensions. Mr. Shoven and Sylvester Schieber, an economist with Watson Wyatt Worldwide pension consultants, have projected future savings in both "defined benefit" pension plans, which promise a specific monthly pension, and "defined contribution" plans, which simply serve as tax-sheltered savings vehicles.
Based on plausible assumptions about the numbers of covered workers, their wages and their life expectancy as retirees, they expect real net inflows into pension plans -- contributions and investment earnings, less benefits paid -- to rise gradually from $102 billion in 1995 to $149 billion in 2010. That is the year before boomers start to turn 65.
By the second decade of the 21st century, though, increases in pension assets tail off -- and may decline even sooner if the continuing downsizing of the corporate work force pushes more Americans into premature retirement. Adjusted for inflation, the value of the national nest egg actually begins to fall in 2025.
Mr. Shoven and Mr. Schieber estimate that real pension savings will slip from about 3.6 percent of total wages today to zero in 2024 and to a negative 3.5 percent in 2040. With the flood of baby boom pensioners cashing in, total pension assets are expected to fall to $15 trillion in 2065 from $28 trillion in 2040. The total capitalization of listed domestic stocks today, by the way, is about $6 trillion.
The magnitude of this projected drop in the middle of the next century has led Mr. Schieber to refer jocularly to the research as the "market meltdown paper." This joke hits uncomfortably close to the bone.
There has long been evidence that the age profile of the population helps to determine the way people hold their savings. In a 1973 study, John Bossons of the National Bureau of Economic Research found that half the wealth owned by Americans between 25 and 44 was in housing. This percentage fell with age, reaching 36 percent for those 55 to 64 and just 31 percent for people over 65.
It should not be surprising, then, that in 1989 Greg Mankiw of Harvard and David Weil of Brown found a strong statistical relationship between housing prices and the numbers of house-needy new families over very long periods. When the adult population is growing rapidly, housing prices follow. And what worked going up in the 1970's, when the oldest boomers were hitting their mid-20's, has worked on the way down since the late 80's, when those people hit their 40's. Prices have stagnated in recent years, trailing the rise in the cost of living. And in the housing markets that were hottest in the previous decade -- Boston, Southern California, metropolitan New York -- they have actually fallen.
Gurdip Bakshi of the University of New Orleans and Zhiwu Chen at the Ohio State College of Business refined the analysis. They predicted that the baby boomers -- the roughly 80 million people born from 1946 through 1964 -- would drive the relative demand for housing and stocks as this population bulge moved through the demographic "snake."
Stocks did rise and housing prices were stable in the first two decades after World War II; the boomers' young parents, it seems, were saving for their children's education. But when those children came of age, the cost of a college education rose as demand for it rose, and priorities shifted, as a large swath of the population began favoring real estate over financial assets. By virtue of their numbers, that set off a housing boom and a stock market bust. Now, with the boomers graying, the stock market is pulling in most of their savings.
Sometime in the future, though, what goes around will presumably come around. If the boomers cash in assets when they retire, the overall decline in savings may well act as a drag on values in all financial markets. And if, as Mr. Bakshi and Mr. Chen found, investors also grow more conservative as they age, they will want to shift their portfolios from stocks to lower-risk financial assets like bank deposits and short-term bonds, even before they begin drawing down those assets.
That, however, is hardly the last word on this subject. In broad terms, opinions about the market meltdown hypothesis fit into three very different scripts:
 
Apocalypse Later
The pessimistic view, presented in full regalia, is not a pretty sight. Household savings, buoyed by the baby boomers' late rush to prepare for old age, will crest around 2010. A few years later, Washington's on-again, off-again battle to eliminate budget deficits will be lost definitively when outlays for Social Security pensions first exceed, and then rapidly outpace, revenues from the payroll tax.
With private savings declining as a percentage of national income, and with Washington slurping up much of the savings that is available by running deficits, a shortage of capital will cause real interest rates to rise. It is hard to say by how much. But research by Thomas Helbling and Robert Wescott, economists at the International Monetary Fund, provides a benchmark.
They estimate that every increase of seven percentage points in the ratio of national debt to national output increases interest rates by about one point. The run-up of public debt in the 1981-93 period thus added about 1.4 percentage points to long-term rates. The returns needed to get increasingly risk-shy 70-something investors to hold stocks would presumably have to rise by more than the change in the interest rate -- thereby reducing stock values.
Mr. Shoven of Stanford offers a back-of-the-envelope guesstimate of how much stock prices would be depressed. The boomers, he suggests, will have to induce younger Americans to buy their stock portfolios. And if this younger generation, which is about two-thirds as large, has roughly the same standard of living and the same inclination to save for retirement as its elders, it will be willing to put up only enough cash to buy the boomers' stocks for two-thirds as much as the boomers anticipated they would be worth.
Mr. Shoven notes, however, that such a decline in stock values, driven by a scarcity of new saving, is unlikely to happen overnight. The aging of the savings-prone population is a "glacially slow" and highly predictable process. Hence the securities markets would have years to understand the shift in the demand for stocks, and adjust accordingly. That, he argues, makes stagnation of equity prices far more plausible than a sudden drop.
But determined pessimists will still be able to find reasons to take the meltdown notion literally. "Naive expectations better characterize the housing market than does perfect foresight," wrote Mr. Mankiw and Mr. Weil. That translates into the language of the masses as, "Investors sometimes follow the herd, even when it is headed for a cliff."
In Southern California, housing prices continued to rise long after the demand for housing had tailed off in the 1980's. It is possible that stock prices will similarly outlast rational considerations -- and then crash.
Whether the stock market stagnates or crashes, the boomers would be in for a leaner old age than the 20th-century performance of the market would suggest.
 
China to the Rescue
Alert readers may have already noticed that the doom-and-gloom outlook echoes forecasts of a mid-1980's capital shortage in America as huge Federal deficits siphoned trillions of dollars in private savings. Interest rates did rise. But more dire predictions did not come true because foreigners -- notably Europeans, Japanese and Taiwanese -- saved much of their surging export earnings in American stocks and bonds. In effect, they replaced most of the private domestic savings that Washington was busy passing out to pensioners and military contractors.
It is not likely that these thrifty friends in need will again ride to the rescue by purchasing the stocks that the baby boomers need to sell. "They are aging more rapidly and have even lower birth rates than we do," explains David Hale, chief economist at Zurich Kemper Investments in Chicago. And while lifelong habits may brake the overall decline in their savings rates, these investors can hardly be expected to fill a new hole in American savings.
But the equally thrifty Chinese -- and perhaps citizens of the other big, high-saving emerging economies in Asia -- just might. Mr. Wescott of the International Monetary Fund calculates that rising ratios of workers to total population will increase saving rates in the third world by 3 percentage points during the next two decades. If these economies grow rapidly enough (and declines in savings rates in Europe and Japan don't offset the impact by drawing investment there), he estimates that this will be sufficient to bail out the boomers.
Living on the financial good will of Asia, however, would be a problem. For one thing, it assumes that demands for capital within the third world will not absorb the lion's share of Asian savings. Some emerging economies -- India, Brazil and Mexico -- will almost certainly need external financing if they are to grow rapidly.
Note, too, that, as in the 1980's, the flip side to importing savings is running a trade deficit. If foreigners buy the financial assets of the baby boomers, the transactions will inevitably be reflected in higher American imports. And while trade protectionism has more or less been held at bay for two decades, the surprising vigor of the Presidential candidacy of Patrick J. Buchanan suggests that it will be much more difficult to sustain wide-open markets in the future.
 
No Bang, No Whimper
The aging of America, it is agreed, will reduce household savings rates. But commensurably low birth rates, which will lead to a stable or even a shrinking work force by the second decade of the 21st century, may also reduce the demand for goods, and therefore for capital. This shift in demand could fully offset the impact of the shift in the supply of savings, and thus leave interest rates and securities prices unaffected.
Indeed, if current population projections hold, it will take no net savings to maintain a constant amount of capital per worker. Such a low-savings world would even allow for rising living standards, because continuing technological change would permit the same number of workers using the same amount of capital to produce more.
"There's light at the beginning of this tunnel," explained David M. Cutler, an economist at Harvard. "Declining fertility brings good news up front."
If there are fewer savers around, who would buy the financial assets that the retired baby boomers would need to sell? Not all capital consists of long-lived assets like buildings or power plants, Mr. Shoven said. Much of it depreciates rapidly and is normally replaced, but money designated for that kind of internal investment can be converted into cash dividends if management prefers to spend it that way. A company like General Electric, for example, currently reinvests billions of dollars for depreciation refurbishment each year. But it always has the option of shrinking by failing to replace worn-out or obsolete equipment.
This process would presumably take place automatically, driven only by the invisible hand of market incentives. With shrinking investment opportunities, more companies would simply find that the best way to sustain the value of their shares would be to buy back stock with the cash flow from the business.
How plausible is what Mr. Shoven calls the "slow growth, high consumption" outlook? Probably no more -- or less -- than the market meltdown.
Economists have never excelled at projecting long-term trends because too much depends on subtle interactions that can be safely ignored in the short run. For example, the "new growth theory," pioneered by Paul Romer of the University of California at Berkeley, suggests that the pace of technological change may depend on continuing high levels of investment. If he is right, a low-savings, low-investment world would slow technological change, retarding the growth of living standards and reducing equity values.
The life odyssey of the huge baby boom generation, most economists agree, will have enormous economic consequences. Trouble is, said Mr. Hale of Zurich Kemper, "we are only beginning to guess what they will be."

SECTION: Section 13; Page 1; Column 5; The City Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: Cocaine Daze;
Deborah Cantie Knows Guns, Drugs and Rikers Island. Now She Is Seeking Help. Can a Life Change?

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LEDUFF 

 BODY:
IT used to be that Deborah Cantie wouldn't know where she'd wake up. Life for a addict is like that, she said. Instead of a two-minute egg, she would start with a two-dollar bottle. But that was another day.
This morning, the sun cracked through the blinds of Ms. Cantie's bedroom window. The day was fresh and she had things to do. It's good to have a schedule, she said; she hasn't kept one for a very long time. After her morning toilet, Ms. Cantie emerged smelling of cocoa butter, looking composed and crisp. 
 In the kitchen, she prepared a breakfast of sweet coffee and glazed doughnuts for herself and her 78-year-old father, who sat with his hands on the radiator, smoking, looking out on the cold New York morning. They made small talk and joked about the little fat girl who lives down the block from their apartment in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn. "She's gonna be 800 pounds one day," Mr. Cantie said, laughing.
In his younger days, Alexander Cantie was a something of a hell raiser and a playboy. "I was wild when I was younger," he said, his body stooped now, his eyes full with the recollections. Mr. Cantie was a railroad worker in Oregon and an upholsterer in the Buick plant in Flint, Mich. "I just went where I had to, wherever the work was at," he said.
He was gone a lot and wasn't much of a father, he admitted, but now he and Dee have a second chance to know each other.
Ms. Cantie recently moved in after she was released from Rikers Island nearly three months ago. They like each other, he said, watching his cigarette smoke mesh with the yellow morning sunlight. He hoped there would be no more snow this season. His daughter agreed, glancing at her watch. Nine o'clock. She had to go.
When Dee Cantie used to wake up, she'd oftentimes be wearing the same stale clothes from the night before and the night before that. Battered and breathing off the lingering effects of the crack pipe, the first thing Ms. Cantie would do is put her shoes on; the second was to go down to the corner store and get a can of malt liquor. That's how the work day began. Armed with a .38-caliber revolver, Ms. Cantie would work the "spots," selling dope on the corners of Bedford-Stuyvesant. What she wasn't carrying she could get -- for a price.
"I was a con, a dope fiend and a brilliant hustler," the dark, smooth-skinned 39-year-old said, surveying her new neighborhood on the way to the A train. "I thought I was always going to get away with it."
As Ms. Cantie talked about her past, she stared blankly down a row of brownstones that line her street. A group of young men occupied the corner in front of the Wyckoff Gardens housing project, where she lives, peddling small packets to passersby.
Ms. Cantie crossed the street, diverting her eyes. She is still shaky, she has drug hallucinations; the taste is still palpable. She goes to rehabilitation. It is helping, she said. Today, she is going to visit her children.
A severe woman with arching eyebrows, a pugnacious jaw and a flat-top, she is not ashamed to discuss her history. She did what she did, and there can be no regrets. She talks because it may help someone. It may help her, she thinks.
Hers is a common story. In 1994, there were more than 4,000 arrests of women in New York City for felony narcotics possession. They sit in the Rose E. Singer Center for women on Rikers Island, awaiting trial. Ms. Cantie has been there, twice.
"I once seen these girls at Rikers, and six years later when I went back, I seen the same exact women sitting there. I said, 'What? You do this for a career?' And, yeah, that's what they do. Out in the summer and in for the winter. They like it, because they can't take care of themselves and the system does it for them."
On the subway platform, Ms. Cantie recognized a woman she knew from jail. She look malnourished, with dark rings under her eyes. They smiled at each other. The woman was missing her front teeth.
"You all right?" the woman said.
"Yeah, Stephanie, I'm all right. What you up to?"
"Me?" Stephanie winked. "I just got out, gonna go visit some people."
Ms. Cantie shook her head. "You know, it's really hard for me sometimes. But when I see something like that . . . That was me."

 
 
THE EARLY DAYS
 With her eyes closed, Ms. Cantie can recall the scent of crack as oily candles, damp, musty basements and sour garbage. There were many dark nights spent on soiled couches with other wild-eyed addicts waiting for their blow, for that exalted state of numbness, for the inevitable crash. She hears the snapping of lighters, the greedy sucking sounds, the occasional argument about someone holding back on someone else. She feels the tingle of paranoia: the police were always on the other side of the door. She sees the embers of cigarettes and the glowing stems of crack pipes. Deborah Cantie can taste it like it was yesterday. Getting high was her life. It's been that way since she was a girl.
Growing up, the 10 children in Ms. Cantie's family were like chickens scratching for crumbs of attention. Mom was a party girl, holding all-night poker games, staying out for days at a time.
Ms. Cantie's grandmother, Millie Plummer, took her daughter's first three babies, and soon she would have Dee and two more. As Mrs. Plummer explained it: "My daughter was young and wild. She was out living a hard life." Mrs. Plummer is a religious woman, with beginnings in South Carolina. There was no way she would allow her blood to be warehoused in foster care, she said; the good Lord and her principles wouldn't allow it. So when a social worker walked up her steps with three more infants, Dee among them, she was glad to take them. It would be the most normal home they would know. They lived in a well-kept home in west Bedford-Stuyvesant. Mrs. Plummer ran a beauty parlor out of her house. Her husband worked. "We wasn't about to take welfare," Mrs. Plummer said.
It was in her household that the children learned all they need to know: restaurant manners, how to tie their shoes, their phone number and how to pray to God. They called their grandmother Mama. They still do.
Six years after arriving, the children returned to their mother. "I felt it was time for them to know her, and for her to take responsibility for her kids," she said. Mrs. Plummer bought the family a two-story house on Cooper Street in Bushwick. "I felt like I was giving myself away when I brought them back." She held her tears that day until she was far away.
Things hadn't changed much with the children's mother. She stayed out; the kids raised each other. Their fathers were long gone. The youngsters ran wild. The house became unstitched. The floorboards came up; the doors fell off their mountings. Dee became unhinged and unmanageable.
As her older sisters moved on, Dee, not even a teen-ager, had to care for her three younger siblings. The anxiety made her angry. She needed attention herself. "I was always defending someone, but nobody defended me," she said. Once in an argument over the size of her forehead, she tried to staple her brother's eye closed.
Mrs. Plummer did what she could. She spied on the children, pretending to be in the neighborhood window shopping. In the mornings, she would park down the block, peeping out her car window, making sure the children went to school. She came over on Saturdays and fried fish. She did the children's hair. It wasn't enough.
The family moved around, eventually ending up on the corner of Madison Street and Throop Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant. The apartment was borderline squalid: no heat, rats and missing steps. The children shared beds and cooked what they could buy from the corner store. Unsupervised, Dee began to drink. She had her first swallow at 12 and by 14 she was sneaking into night clubs. She ran away for hundred-day stretches and dropped out of school.
As she grew older, Dee was drawn to the glow of drugs. Regularly, she and her mother drank wine and smoked marijuana together. She found that they were a way of self-medicating ingrown sores, a quick slice of joy. Then cocaine hit hard on the scene. Ms. Cantie, then 18, snorted; it was a favorite candy of hers and she liked to have it. By 21, she was free-basing. She started tagging along with an older crowd. She needed people, and the people she found got high.
"I was a groupie, a follower," she said. "They used me, and I let myself be used. It's a problem of mine, being people's furniture."
The older crowd did teach her how to get legitimate jobs while turning on. She lied about having a high school diploma and found work in a pharmaceutical factory in New Jersey. She stole diet pills and sold them to drug dealers who used them to dilute their cocaine. She made money. By 31, she owned two cars and a house in New Brunswick. Everything was sweet.
Then the sugar pot cracked. She was hit by a motorcyclist who was high on PCP. Her leg shattered and she could not work. She moved back with relatives in the old neighborhood in Brooklyn. But the Demerol she was taking for pain and the $25,000 insurance settlement got the party train rolling.
"Everybody was my friend -- you should have seen it," she said, wringing her hands with the memories. "But everything I had, the money, the cars, the house -- all of it was gone in less than a year."

 
 
BAD MEMORIES
 Stepping off the A train at the Kingston-Throop station, Ms. Cantie emerged from the subway with a show of uncertainty, like an unsure child at the edge of the ocean. The midday streets were bustling, and the voice of Minister Farrakhan blasted from a loudspeaker somewhere. The father of Ms. Cantie's first child drove by in a black car. He ignored her. Ms. Cantie lit a cigarette, appearing a little shaken.
These streets are stained with memories; they were her wrecking yard.
She pointed out corners she would work, places she would get high, stopping at a sagging, boarded-up hotel. She recognized the man across the street. He didn't recognize her.
"You don't remember me?" she laughed.
"Dee?" The man smiled.
"Yeah, you old fool, Dee." She became animated now, her confidence back. Dee was happy to see Mitch. He's an old friend. A straight friend.
"Girl, I didn't hardly recognize you," he said. "Last time I saw you was across the street in that hotel there getting high. You was nothing but a raisin with legs."
"It's been a while, boy." She hugged the older man.
"You look good, girl. Just don't forget where you come from," he said.
Gilbert Mitchell is a recovering alcoholic . He used to stay at the hotel, having more than once stepped over her, incoherent and splayed across the stoop.
"I'm done with that," she told him.
"No baby. One day at a time. You never know what's going to happen tomorrow."
The sun shone bright, and the day was brittle cold. Walking down Tompkins Avenue, Ms. Cantie waved to a score of people. She was clean and she carried herself erect.
"That was me," she said, pointing to an underdressed woman with tattered shoes rummaging through a garbage can. The woman waved.
"Dee, I miss you, baby."
"Keep on missing me then," she bellowed.
Deborah Cantie shook her head. "Man, I did whatever it took. I was always looking to get over. Not much of a career."

 
 
'IT WAS SLAVERY'
 Dee Cantie, 31, broke and unemployed, found odd jobs in the old neighborhood, none of them good, she said. Among other things she was a dealer in stolen merchandise, a burglar and a con artist. She worked as a counter girl in a bodega.
But things had changed in the neighborhood. This storefront dealt in illicit brands of confections and powders. A cartel of crack dealers took over the property, welded an iron gate across the entrance and padlocked Ms. Cantie inside with three grand in crack rock. She would be imprisoned for days on end, selling nickel and dime pieces of crack through a sliding window. The boss brought her warm buckets of water to bathe, candles to count by and junk food to wash down the alcohol. She slept on the countertop.
"It was slavery, but I didn't care," she said in a husky voice. "I was addicted to the hustle, I would get a rush off it."
She used the gun once. A man tried to steal. She blew his kneecap off on the fly. She shot him from the basement window of the bodega. He crawled away.
As she told that story, she laughed, "You don't have to shoot to kill." Deborah Cantie is tough, and she's got a mean streak.
She made $25 for every $100 she sold while working at the bodega and had to pay for her own crack. Once she smoked too much, and when the boss came back, she was $30 short. Dee Cantie took a good beating, and when it was done, she was chained in, forced to work for a straight week.
Like most pushers who dip into their product, she got sloppy. Sallow and sunken eyed, she didn't see it coming. The cops broke the door down and found her hiding in the basement with $3,000 worth of crack, a handgun and $1,200 in cash. She got six months in Rikers and five years on probation. Her bosses got away. She went through a drug treatment program. The rehab didn't stick, and she stopped visiting her probation officer. A warrant was issued in 1990.
She ran for nearly six years. Dee Cantie spun out of control, living on welfare and sugar cookies, bouncing from one couch to the next. She sold dope to get dope. Her clothes stank, her hair was matted, her skin was blotchy. Her feet hurt when she wore shoes because she never bothered to trim her toenails. "I remember kids would see me in the hallways and say 'Yo, nasty butt, go head somewhere.' I felt ashamed about it, but I didn't care as long as I could cop the stuff." She had no one to talk to, "so I'd talk to the bottle about it," she said.
She never realized how down she was, until she tried to help an old lady with her groceries.
The old woman looked like her grandmother, Ms. Cantie recalled. What the old woman saw was a dried-up crack hag, a mugger, and she backed away, pleading not to be hurt.
"I just wanted to help," Ms. Cantie said.
She skulked off in a stupor of self-pity, crying. She went and got high.
Deborah Cantie couldn't see things clearly, she was sick. One day, on the way to the bootlegger's to buy a bottle of bathtub booze,
she collapsed in a diabetic episode. "I just thought I needed a drink to take the edge off," she said. "When I woke up in Kings County the next day, I checked myself out and got that drink."
She bought it with the subway tokens the hospital gave her to get home.
Deborah Cantie gave birth to a baby boy in 1994 with cocaine in his blood. It didn't stop her. Four months later, she was pregnant again.
She dismissed the fathers as flings; she was married to the pipe. Her second boy was born premature, he, too, with narcotics in his blood. She cried in the delivery room, realizing the addiction was no longer just her problem. The devil was on her back.
"It was like a snowball," she said. "I had guilt, and I would use more. The more I used, the more I had to have." Officials threatened to take her children, so she checked herself into detox.
Her new family meant everything to her. It was all she had. "It's about the kids, man," she said as she walked through the streets of her childhood. "Without their mother, what are they going to do? Die?" Her new family is important to her. Her other family was so messed up.
The rehabilitation was good for Ms. Cantie. She stayed clean and sober for seven months, her longest stretch ever. She wanted to go right, she said, for her children. But with just three months left to complete the program, the warrant from six years ago caught up to her. The police showed up last December after she pummeled her girlfriend in a domestic dispute. Dee Cantie was sent back to Rikers, her children wentto her grandmother. She had the drugs under control; her anger was the problem now.
Dee Cantie sat in jail wondering if she could ever get it together. But then she got a break. She was released from jail after 15 days because she had demonstrated improvement with her drug problems. She was remanded to Crossroads, a day treatment program designed to help women with felony narcotics arrests get clean and put their lives in order.
It seems to be working for Ms. Cantie, said Bryn King, her case manager at Crossroads. "Most of Dee's legal history has been with drugs and assault," she said. "But now, instead of acting out in really destructive ways, she shows up every day and deals with her anger." Ms. Cantie is a leader, her counselor said. The other women voted her community president.
But the sober life, a "normal" life, is a strange existence for Deborah Cantie. She's never known it. She goes to "clean" parties and sometimes doesn't know what to do with her hands. "It's boring sometimes," she said, "but I can live with it. It's better than dying."
It can be scary to turn your life around, she said. A family and a home and a job, they are good goals, but how to reach them? Who wants a recovering addict with a prison record? She fell silent. Sometimes the big questions are overwhelming. But you can't look at life that way. Start with the little things.
It was near dusk, and Ms. Cantie returned home after spending the day with her children. She was angry and she slammed the door. As it happens, she said, the children may be taken away from her grandmother over a technicality. It seems to Ms. Cantie that no matter how hard she tries or how fair she plays, an obstacle always stands in her way.
Her father was in the kitchen making curried chicken for dinner. She steered her anger toward him and they quarreled over peas. Who was going to get them? She stopped herself, choking down the anger that's got her into so much trouble before and gathered up her coat.
"I'm going to get some peas, Daddy," she said on her way out.
"Black-eyed peas," he called.
The old man stood over the stove, whistling. "It's nice to have her back," he said.
 
Rehabilitation at Rikers: The Promise, the Limits
DEE CANTIE saw a flier while sitting in a holding cell at the Rose M. Singer Center at Rikers Island awaiting trial. "We got out of jail and into treatment where we belong," the flier said. Ms. Cantie called collect.
Case workers from the Crossroads program reviewed her record: drug abuse and felony arrests for narcotics possession, no prior record of robbery and a strong desire to turn her life around. They said they could help. After Ms. Cantie served 15 days, a judge placed her in their care.
Established in 1993, Crossroads, a nonprofit organization, serves as an alternative to jail for women who have a history of drug use. The program was created by the New York City Office of the Criminal Justice Coordinator to relieve the overcrowding in the prison system.
Ken Bloomfield, the program's director, said it was the only out-patient drug treatment program for incarcerated women in the city. "Women with drug and alcohol problems have different issues that the male-based treatment model doesn't address," he said. Most of the women in the program have children, most have been sexually abused, and their medical concerns are different.
The first phase in the year of treatment is getting clean; the second is setting goals. Finally the women start to visualize life on their own. There are Narcotics Anonymous meetings, survivors of rape and incest groups and acupuncture. The women are tested daily for drugs. After nearly three months in the program, Ms. Cantie is clean and hopeful. "I'm getting my vision together here," she said. "You need to see the goal before you step to it. I see that now."
The National Development and Research Institutes is doing a five-year follow-up study on the women of Crossroads, but until it is completed, the center relies on word-of-mouth accounts. Of the 41 graduates, perhaps 20 percent have jobs, Mr. Bloomfield said.
There are pitfalls. The women live at home, often in the neighborhoods where they had sold drugs, and many can't afford to move. They are not allowed to work until the final stage of the program.
Crossroads offers no job training because of budget constraints, Mr. Bloomfield said, but the program does help them navigate the social-service bureaucracy.
It doesn't work for everybody. Eight of the 107 women who have come through Crossroads have walked off. Warrants have been issued for their arrests.
"I was selling drugs because I needed a way to live," said Karen Wright, a 22-year-old single mother who was placed in a convent in Queens. "I had rent; I have a baby. Don't get me wrong, it's good to be clean, but what am I going to do when I get out of here? My circumstances are still the same." CHARLIE LEDUFF

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS 

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
More Good News About Growth. Uh-Oh.
A stronger-than-expected employment report showing that 705,000 jobs had been created in February dashed hopes that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates any time soon. And that sent the bond market into a remarkable nose dive, as the 30-year Treasury fell 3 points on the news and ended there, its worst day in more than five years. And with it went the stock market: the Dow Jones industrial average fell more than 3 percent, or 171.24 points.
 
MERGERS
 
A Swiss Surprise
In one of the largest corporate mergers ever, the Swiss pharmaceutical giants Sandoz and Ciba-Geigy announced they would merge, hoping that joint research, a much larger pocketbook and cost-cutting would revive their lackluster product lines. The resulting company, to be known as Novartis, will be the second largest in its field after Glaxo Wellcome. Part of the strategy is to eliminate 13,500 jobs, 10 percent of the companies' combined work force.
 
COST-CUTTING
 
Getting Little Things Right
The Ford Motor Company began an aggressive campaign to lower its costs, planning to reduce its product engineering and product development staffs by a total of 12,000. Among the product changes: one cigarette lighter will have to make do where Ford now uses 14 different models; the insides of ashtrays will no longer be painted on the Explorer; one carpet fabric will be used in trunks instead of seven.
 
ADVERTISING
 
Pulling the Plug
Tired of analgesics makers raising questions about the safety of each other's products, the TV networks ordered a time-out. ABC, NBC and CNN said they would no longer run commercials for pain relievers that make comparative safety claims about rival products. CBS said it would no longer run the ad that started the fuss: an Advil ad that called attention to a warning on Tylenol that advises people consuming more than three alcoholic drinks a day to ask a doctor about the potential for liver damage from combining acetaminophen and alcohol.
 
ON LINE
 
Apple Tries a New Tack
After shutting its own on-line service, eWorld, Apple Computer announced that its computers would provide access to America Online and that it would publish on the service. In other attempts to regain traction, Apple named a turnaround specialist, Fred Anderson, as its chief financial officer and announced an Internet technology alliance with Netscape Communications and Silicon Graphics.
 
TRADE
 
Bridge Across the Americas
Secretary of State Warren Christopher called on Brazil to help the United States forge a free-trade zone spanning the Americas by 2005. Mr. Christopher's proposal came as Brazil moved to strengthen its patent law, which has been a major obstacle to trade relations with Washington. But how Brazil will react is uncertain. It helped organize the Mercosur trade pact with Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay, and Mercosur has now opened talks with the European Union about establishing a free-trade zone. President Fernando Henrique Cardoso of Brazil was cool to a recent Mexican proposal to discuss a trade alliance.
 
MORTGAGES
 
A 'Unique Housing Market'
Fannie Mae, the nation's largest provider of residential mortgages, is making $8 billion available for New York City residents -- and changing its rules so that middle-income and even wealthy families can apply. The goal: to raise the historically low level of home ownership in New York. Some parts of the program will also be extended to the close-in suburbs.
 
COUNTERPUNCHING
 
RJR Nabisco Raises Dividend
Continuing its proxy battle with Bennett S. LeBow and Carl C. Icahn, RJR Nabisco raised its dividend 23 percent, to 46.25 cents a quarter. The company also said it would buy back 10 million shares. The plans were announced the day after Mr. LeBow's Brooke Group mailed shareholders its proposal for higher dividends and other changes.
 
REJECTIONS
 
A 'No Thanks' From Grace
W. R. Grace, the troubled chemicals and health care conglomerate, rejected a merger offer from Hercules Inc., another chemical manufacturer. Grace also said Thomas L. Gossage, chairman of Hercules, had resigned from Grace's board, which led to speculation that Hercules might be planning a hostile offer. Then Peter Lynch, vice chairman of Fidelity Investments and former manager of its Magellan Fund, said he would resign as a Grace director. A Grace spokeswoman said the two departures were unrelated.
 
LABOR
 
Strike Hampers G.M.
Strikes at two brake-parts factories in Dayton, Ohio, disrupted General Motors' production of Chevrolet, Buick, Oldsmobile and Pontiac cars. While only 3,000 of G.M.'s hundreds of thousands of workers were on strike, nearly all the brakes used at 29 assembly plants in North America are made in Dayton. The dispute involves safety and job-security issues.
