HEADLINE: Returned Refugees Say Cuba, Defying Pact, Retaliates

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: CAMAGUEY, Cuba, March 4

 BODY:
One day after Washington and Havana agreed last May that "boat people" fleeing Cuba would no longer be guaranteed political asylum in the United States, 13 men were picked up aboard two rafts adrift in the Caribbean. Assured by the American and Cuban Governments that there would be no retribution against them, they were forcibly returned to their homes here.
Ten months later, however, members of the group, the first to be handed over to the Cuban authorities under the agreement, contend that neither Government has lived up to its obligations. The Cuban Government, they complain, has from the day of their return carried out a campaign of reprisals, intimidation and harassment against them, while the United States has failed to prevent continued violations of the immigration accord the two nations had signed. 
 In six hours of interviews in this industrial city 350 miles southeast of Havana, the returnees said they and several of their relatives had been systematically threatened by State Security agents, arrested on trumped-up charges or accused of working for the C.I.A. All but two are now without jobs because of their political status, they said, and the pair still employed are regularly harassed by co-workers, bosses or State Security officials.
"For the two Governments, this agreement has been marvelous," said Ulises Cabale, 29, an electrician who has been assigned to a temporary work-training program to repair electrical meters. "But for us, it has been a disaster that leaves us in a worse position than ever."
It was not possible to corroborate independently all the accusations the returnees made. But they offered specific details about actions taken against them, including dates and the names and ranks of the security officials said to be involved.
All those interviewed said they were interested in making their situation known because they still wished to leave Cuba and hope eventually to be admitted to the United States.
Under the May agreement, the Cuban Government promised to "insure that no action is taken against those migrants returned to Cuba as a consequence of their attempt to emigrate illegally." In return, the United States ended its 30-year policy of treating virtually all Cubans who reached American shores as political refugees, and was authorized to send diplomats from the American Interests Section, its quasi-embassy in Havana, to interview returning raft refugees to insure that the accord was being properly carried out.
 
'Illegal Departure' Is Still a Crime
But the agreement does not "preclude the obligation of the Cuban authorities or society to act against such a person for other reasons or crimes committed before or after the attempt" to leave Cuba, Ricardo Alarcon, the Cuban official who negotiated the accord, noted a week after it was announced. Nor did Cuba revoke an "illegal departure" statute on its books, which the rafters here said has recently been used to detain and question several of them.
The returnees said they had repeatedly told the American diplomats who are monitoring the accord of those and other reprisals being taken against them. But American officials have simply brushed aside their complaints, they said, and urged them to apply to a program that selects 20,000 Cubans each year for entry to the United States.
"Every time the people from the American Interests Section come, they tell us we do not meet the requirements to be political refugees," said Felix Ivan Rodriguez, a 29-year-old cook. "They tell us we have no priority, that our best chance is to try our luck in the lottery, like everyone else."
Human rights groups suggest that it is no accident that American officials are reluctant to pursue claims that the accord is being violated. Despite a recent heightening of tensions between Washington and Havana, they say, the Clinton Administration has a vested interest in preventing another flood of Cuban refugees toward Florida.
"There is a conspiracy of self-interest and silence going on between two contending parties, the United States and Cuba, that victimizes these innocent asylum seekers," said Arthur Helton, director of the Forced Migration Projects of the Open Society Institute, a New York-based human rights group. "The last thing either Government wants to do is raise the question of the viability of the migration accords."
Officials at the American Interests Section in Havana declined to discuss how the immigration accord is carried out, referring all questions to the State Department in Washington. [A spokesman there said on Friday that the returnees appeared to be subject to the same type of surveillance and ostracism as any other disaffected Cuban, but that there was "no proof they are being persecuted" as a direct result of their effort to leave Cuba.]
In a letter to the Open Society Institute last month, Peter Tarnoff, the State Department official who negotiated the agreement, said the United States was "generally satisfied that the Cuban Government has fulfilled its commitment." While there have been "individual instances of concern," he added, "we have engaged the Cuban Government vigorously on each of these."
For its part, the Cuban Government has consistently rejected any suggestion that it has taken reprisals against returnees.
"In all cases, Cuba has received them in accordance with the agreement," Carlos Fernandez de Cossio, a Foreign Ministry official who specializes in relations with the United States, said at a news conference in Havana on Feb. 29.
Since the agreement was signed in May, just over 300 Cuban asylum-seekers have been forcibly returned to their homeland by the United States. Though it is not clear how the experience of later groups compares with that of the first 13 returnees, human rights observers say it is likely that they have also been subjected to acts of official reprisals, harassment and intimidation.
Indeed, the Open Society Institute has documented several instances in which returnees from other groups have apparently been victims of official reprisals. In one case, a university professor lost his job because he was considered a "dangerous example" to his students, and in another a returnee was beaten by the police shortly after his return and the doctor who treated him was dismissed.
In testimony to Congress last year, Mr. Tarnoff said the United States would regard the inability of returnees to get a job as a reprisal "if it results from an attempt to leave Cuba without authorization." He also said any threat against relatives of repatriated refugees would be considered a reprisal "if it is officially sanctioned and is in response to the attempt to leave Cuba without authorization."
Interviewed at the small house he shares with his brother and fellow returnee Cesar and their mother and wives, Ulises Cabale said that only he and one other member of the first group that returned under the agreement were still employed. All of the others, he said, have been dismissed or are unable to get jobs because their files identify them as politically "unreliable."
 
One Is Accused Of Being a Spy
One of these others, Julian Avalo, 32, an automobile mechanic, said: "The only kind of work I've been offered is forced labor, harvesting sugar cane in a work brigade. Everyone knows that we were deported, so do you think they are going to give me a job over a party member, especially when unemployment is so high here? No way."
Denied employment as a Government cook, Mr. Rodriguez found a job at one of the new private restaurants the Government has allowed to open. But after he was visited by American diplomats late last year, he said, State Security agents turned up at the restaurant and accused him of being an American spy.
"They told the owner that I am cooperating with the C.I.A. and need to be put under constant vigilance," Mr. Rodriguez said. "Now I am worried I am going to lose this job because my boss doesn't like the idea of having to report on my activities all the time."
Both Mr. Avalo and the Cabale brothers said they too had been warned that they might be arrested for spying for the United States as a result of their contacts with the American Interests Section. Because they are returned refugees, they said, their telephone is tapped, and they are under increased surveillance by State Security, the police and the neighborhood watchdog group known as the Committee to Defend the Revolution.
"I've been thinking lately that it might be better to tell the American diplomats not to come anymore," Mr. Avalo said.
 
A Wife, Too, Finds She Is Unemployable
Mr. Rodriguez's wife, Giselda, who lost her job at the telephone company shortly before her husband set off from Cuba, has also discovered that she is unemployable. "Everywhere I go, they tell me I can't work for any state enterprise because my husband tried to leave the country, and that makes me an unreliable person," she said.
On the other hand, another returnee, Victor Aballe, 43, spent six months in jail on what he says was a fabricated charge that he had embezzled money at his former job. While imprisoned, he said, State Security "insinuated that I was in this fix for having left the country, and that they were using this other case to cover that up."
Mr. Aballe, a lawyer, said that since his release last month, he and another returnee, Augusto Trinidad Ochoa, a 41-year-old electronic technician, had been formally accused of espionage. The charges have for the moment been dropped, he said, but "the way things work here, you can never tell what will come up."
Ulises Cabale said that as a result of the reprisals the returnees "feel like there is a hand on our necks, squeezing, and that we can't continue to live under this yoke." In the face of American indifference, he said, he fears that the Cuban Government will be emboldened to take even harsher reprisals.
"It seems like the migration agreement was signed between the authorities in Washington and Havana," he said. "But we live in Camaguey, not Havana, and we have no one here to protect us."

HEADLINE: The Geograpy of Taste

BYLINE: By Florence Fabricant

 BODY:
IT USED TO BE THTA THE FOOD YOU chose to put in your mouth revealed your roots as readily as the accent that came out of it. Now food preferences linked to region alone are beginning to fade. People move around. Food companies market nationally. Nonetheless, the quirks and wrinkles of particular tastes continue to faintly mark the culinary landscape. High sales of Nilla Wafers in the South, for example, or of chunky peanut butter in the West reflect endemic, though frequently inexplicable, affinities that have existed for generations. here are some of the things we like to eat, and where we like to eat them.

Babecue The number of barbecue restaurants in the country jumped from 5,947 in 1985 to 6,670 in 1992, the last time they were counted. What was originally a regional food is becoming national as the country's palate heats up - spice consumption, espeically of the hot peppers that go into barbecue sauce, has skyrocketed. Preferences remain regional, however, when it comes to the meat. Port is prefered east of the Mississippi, with vinegar in the sauce; beef in cattle country and in the West, where the sauce is tricked up with tomato paste.
 
Beef Consumptionw was up to 67.1 pounds per person last year, compared with 65.1 pounds in 1993, reversing an 18-year decline, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture. More people are ordering beef in restaurants (up 3.2 percent), especially in steakhouses, where business is up 24.5 percent. According to Morton's of Chicago, a chain of 31 restuarants, a 24-ounce porterhouse sells well in New York. The biggest seller in Palm Beach is the New York strip sirloin. Dallas likes its filet mignon rare; in Atlanta the preference is for medium and in the Deep South, well done. In 1994 there was an incrase of 11 percent in the servings of large hamburgers, 6 percent for large cheeseburgers and 18 percent for bacon cheeseburgers. Three-quarters of all beef eaten in the U.S. is in the form of hamburger, and burger consumption was up 2.7 percent in 1994. Eighty-seven percent of Americans ordered a hamburger or a cheeseburger in the past year, which translates to five billion hamburgers a year, 14 million a day.
 
Butter In the Northeast 72 percent of families use butter, compared with 39 percent in the South, where they use margarine. Economics drove that choice, from the time when margarine was a cheaper substitute, and habit has taken over. Salted is preferred to sweet all over the country.
 
Cheese White cheddar is preferred in New York and New England, yellow in the rest of the country. The color-coding started more than 100 years ago, when Wisconsin began mass-marketing cheese and wanted to differentiate theirs from everyone else's. In 1970 the per capita consumption of mozzarella was 1.19 pounds. IN 1995 it was 8.27 pounds, virtually all of it consumed on pizza.
 
Chicken Forty-six percent of folks in the South eat fried chicken, compared with about one-third of the residents in other regions. Seventy-three percent of those in the Northeast eat chicken baked or roasted. Americans spent $25 billion on chicken last year and at 70.5 pounds per person. Consumption is expected to increase to 74 pounds per person this year. In the past, when chicken-eating went up, beef-eating went down, but now both are gaining.
 
Chocolate Seventy-one percent of Americans prefer milk over dark chocolate. More milk chocolate lovers than dark chocolate lovers did not graduate from high school. People who prefer dark devoted chocoholics. The tend to buy it 30 percent more of it. Candy bars with peanuts are the nationwide favorites and most popular in the South. Goo Goo Clusters, a favorite in Tennessee, are not sold anywhere else. Snickers is the No.1 - selling candy bar.
 
Cookies In general, people who live in the mountain states eat 30 percent more cookies than those in other parts of the country. Mallamars are sold in the Northeast in fall and winter. (The dark chocolate can't be sold in war weather - it melts too quickly - and anyway it doesn't tempt the rest of the country.) Sixty percent of all Nilla Wafers sold end up in the South and the Southwest, often make the banana pudding pie recipe on the box. More people (35 percent) eat Oreos by twisting them open than by any other method, especially in Topeka, Kan.; Waco, Tex., and Birmingham, Ala. In New York, 39 percent twist, 29 percent dunk, 156 percent nibble and 16 percent freestyle. The top dunking city is Hagerstown, Md.
 
Hot Dogs Nobody seems to know for sure why they eat them the way they do in different parts of the country. But during the Depression, the Vienna Beef company of Chicago, the major purveyor in that city, collaborated with vendors on the Chicago dog: yellow mustard, chopped raw onion, sweet relish, dill pickles, tomato and celery salt on a poppy-seed bun. In New York hot dogs are topped with steamed onions and yellow mustard. In Kansas City sauerkraut and melted Swiss go on top, and coleslaw is popular in the South. People in the East and Middle West are more partial to hot dogs than residents of other regions because, according to the National Park Producers Council, more of them are descendants of Germans and Eastern Europeans.
 
Ice Cream Americans east an average of 13 quarts of ice cream a year and spend $3 billion on it. More ice cream is consumed in the South than in any other part of the country. But people spend more money on ice cream on the coasts, where the superpremium brands like Haagen-Dazs and Ben & Jerry's originated. Frozen yogurt is more popular in the East than in any other part of the country, perhaps because more yogurt is eaten there than anywhere else. Frozen yogurt sales have never encroached on ice-cream sales, which in any case are on the increase, resulting from an influx of low-fat and no-fat products in many ice-cream brands. Haagen-Dazs says vanilla is the top flavor nationwide. Chocolate is second. In the West, espeically Los Angeles, they prefer their chocolate with stuff in it, like chocolate chocolate chip. In the East, they like butter pecan, in New York, coffee.
 
Mayonnaise On the West Coast they treasure Best Foods mayonnaise. Always have. On the East Coast, Hellmann's. The Middle West clings to Miracle Whip, that Depression-era invention bulked up with starchy extenders to replace some of the fat. Mayo is king in New Orleans, where they eat 2.4 times as much as anywhere else. For the past 10 years, America's most popular sandwich has been ham with mayonnaise. The least amount of mayonnaise is consumed in Omaha.
 
Orange Juice Over the las tyear Americans drank 743 million gallons of orange juice, according to Florida Department of Citrus. New York is the city with the highest consumption, at more than 64 million gallons; in Los Angeles, consumption was 34 million gallons. Fewer people in the South use frozen O.J., which is used the most in the West.
 
Peanut Butter Average per capita consumption is 3 pounds a year, 9,120 calories. By brand, Skippy is the choice in the East and the West, Jif in the Middle West and Peter Pan in the South, the regions where these brands were originally produced. Red Wing is a cult favorite in New York. Creamy tops chunky by almost two to one, except in the West, where chunky gains. The manufacturers of Skippy speculate this is because chunky is perceived to be more "natural," and "natural" products play well in that part of the country. Thirty-three percent of all the peanut butter consumed on the West Coast is Skippy Super Chunk.
 
Pizza There are approximately 60,580 pizzerias in the United States, as of Jan. 31, 1996, up from 39,937 10 years ago. In New York State there is one pizzeria for every 3,525 people. Mississippi has only one per 9,777. Twice as many pies and slices are ordered with cheese no meat, in the Northeast, where restaurant pizza is also most popular. Frozen pizza, especially with meat (sausage, etc.), has the biggest following in the North Central region, where total consumption is highest. On the West Coast they like pizza with vegetables.
 
Potatoes French fries are the most popular form, and the Middle West eats the most of them. Fries are eaten mainly in restaurants, especially fast-food restaurants, and especially to go.
 
Salad Dressing Tastes run to Russian and Thousand Island in the South, French (the orange-colored kind) in the Middle West, Italian - especially Wish-Bone - in the East and ranch in West. Newman's Own Caesar dressing sells best in the West, where the Caesar was invented.
 
Salsa With salsa sales at $734.5 million, up 6.4 percent, and unit sales at $366.8 million, up 1.7 percent, as of Dec. 3, 1995, salsa is playing catch-up with ketchup. During the same period, ketchup sales reach $420.7 million, up 1.7 percent, with unit sales at $293.2 million, down 1.7 percent. Salsa is preferred hot, and often green, in the West and mild in the East. But Vermont is the exception, a salsa-loving corner where no fewer than a dozen brands - mild and hot, green and red - are produced.
 
Soup Some soup flavor preferences are easier to understand. Philadelphia is partial to pepper pot, which is said to have been created for Washington's cold, hungry troops at nearby Valley Forge in 1777-78. And Philadephia is the only city where the soup is now sold. And if they like French onion soup better in New Orleans than elsewhere, the demographics, with so many residents with French roots, are the reason. Campbell's chicken noodle? Cincinnati. But in Miami, chicken broth. Albany prefers Manhattan clam chowder; New York likes green pea. Indianapolis, chili beef; El Paso, chicken with rice; St. Louis, New England clam chowder and cheddar cheese in Memphis. A third of a billion cans of Campbell's cream of mushroom soup are consumed annually; Grand Rapids, Mich., is the city that likes it the most.
 
Tea The South is the iced tea capital, where it is made with tea bags, the cheapest way. That's how they can afford to give it away, as they do in most restaurants. Herbal tea is most popular in the West, where Celestial Seasonings is based. Instant hot tea is particular to the Central States; the East is where the most hot tea is drunk.
 
Tuna More than 90 percent of all the tuna consumed in America is canned, with highest consumption in the East, especially in Harfrod and New York. New York is No. 1 when it comes to white albacore tuna, with 25 percent of the total national consumption. Annual consumption of canned tuna (3 1/2 pounds per person) is higher than it is for peanut butter.

HEADLINE: Did Yeltsin Get a Sweetheart Deal on I.M.F. Loans?

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
Poor countries usually do a bit of groveling and a lot of kicking and screaming when they negotiate with the International Monetary Fund, needing the loans the organization provides but resenting the demands for austerity that accompany its help.
The pattern seemed different, though, as the fund negotiated and then reached agreement on a three-year, $10.2 billion loan package with Russia last month, raising questions about whether Moscow was getting special treatment. 
 President Boris N. Yeltsin bragged to Russian voters that he had used his influence with Western leaders to make sure that the I.M.F. treated his country right.
Far from steeling the country for further budget cuts, Mr. Yeltsin announced that some of the cash would be used to help with huge unpaid wage bills the Government owed workers, one of the Russian leader's most sensitive political problems.
Then, last week and the week before, in moves that were hard not to interpret as Russia thumbing its nose at the monetary fund, Mr. Yeltsin's Government proposed raising tariffs on many imports, a step that would run counter to the spirit if not the letter of the loan agreement.
With Mr. Yeltsin trailing in his bid for re-election in June, his bluster toward the fund was no doubt shaped in part by a desire to be seen at home as the man who can wring aid and concessions from the West.
But the loan deal, and Moscow's reaction to it, have left some analysts wondering whether the I.M.F. tacitly put aside its avowedly apolitical approach to economic development by giving Mr. Yeltsin a sweetheart deal -- or at least a good deal at a very propitious time.
Officials at the fund's headquarters here strongly denied any political favoritism, saying that if anything the terms, which include detailed monthly assessments of Russia's economic policy and peformance, were especially tough.
And while they said it would be naive to suggest that their programs did not have political consequences, they said their lending decisions in Russia, as elsewhere, continued to be based only on economic factors.
"Our treament of Russia on this occasion is the same as our treatment of other member countries," said John Odling-Smee, the director who oversees the fund's dealings with Russia. "We're not supporting Yeltsin or his Government. We're supporting the economic program which they are pursuing."
In the United States and in Europe, though, some foreign policy analysts saw the loan agreement as motivated in part by a desire to support Mr. Yeltsin against Communist and nationalist rivals who are hostile to market-oriented economic reform.
Some even suggested that the fund was effectively helping to finance the war in Chechnya by giving economic succor to Mr. Yeltsin at a time when the military bill was biting deeply into the budget.
Saying the loan was "an implicit vote in favor of candidate Yeltsin," the French newspaper Le Monde editorialized that "the West is playing a dangerous game" and that there was "neither the urgency nor the necessity for a gesture so spectacular."
Officials outside the monetary fund who deal with international economic assistance programs said any deal with Russia would necessarily be a special case, especially given the country's strategic importance to the United States and the other big industrialized democracies that provide most of the fund's money.
American officials said they did not seek to use the fund to conduct foreign policy. Yet while officials of the fund were still negotiating with Moscow early this year, President Clinton stated publicly that the United States, the fund's biggest contributor, wanted the deal to happen -- undermining the I.M.F.'s bargaining power with Russia in the process, officials outside the fund said.
"I believe the loan will go through, and I believe that it should," Mr. Clinton said during a visit by the Russian Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, to Washington in January.
During the negotiations, Russia said at different times that it wanted as little as $9 billion and as much as $12 billion. At $10.2 billion, the three-year credit finally agreed on was large by monetary fund standards, but not unprecedented.
The general guideline is that countries can borrow annually up to 100 percent of the amount they have contributed to the fund over the years -- in Russia's case, about $6 billion a year.
The guideline is occasionally put aside, as it was for Mexico in late 1994 when an economic crisis there led officials to agree to a $7.8 billion loan that was nearly 700 percent of Mexico's quota, or theoretical credit limit, under the fund's guidelines.
Among all countries with three-year agreements similar to Russia's, the average loan amount is 42 percent of the national quota per year, according to figures provided by the I.M.F. Russia's loan averages 53 percent of its quota a year over the three years.
Russia's first big loan from the fund, a one-year agreement reached last March, was 100 percent of its quota.
The fund's decision to grant the new loan, officials said, reflected Russia's success in meeting all of the targets for economic performance set out in last year's loan agreement. In particular, Russia succeeded in bringing down its inflation rate and budget deficits, and it began the process of establishing workable tax and financial systems.
"Last year's program was viewed by most observers as quite successful, perhaps surprisingly successful," said Jack T. Boorman, the director of policy development and review at the fund and the official in charge of insuring that all countries are treated equally.
"The institutions and the political policy makers had proven themselves capable of instituting this and holding themselves together," Mr. Boorman said, "Now it's time to get on with a three-year arrangement with a more aggressive transformation program."
The timing of the loan, Mr. Boorman said, was dictated largely by Russia's budgetary cycle, and not by the schedule for the presidential election.
Recognizing that there could be a change in government after the election, the fund's managing director, Michel Camdessus, met in Moscow last month with some members of opposition parties in Parliament, although he did not make a concerted effort to see all the opposition party leaders, Mr. Boorman said.
Russia, fund officials said, is just one example of how the fund, without wading directly into domestic politics, increasingly gives explicit recognition to the interplay between purely economic issues and social welfare issues that have great political sensitivity.
It would be bad policy, they said, to pretend that fiscal belt-tightening and conservative economic management of the kind the fund insists on can succeed if they do not provide for social welfare and stability.
In that sense, they said, Mr. Yeltsin's use of money from the fund to pay workers what they are owed, or to increase pension payments or finance social welfare improvements generally, are not just acceptable, but desirable.
In recent years, the fund has helped introduce an unemployment insurance program in Albania, urban job creation programs in Senegal, financing schemes for young entrepreneurs in the Ivory Coast and better pension plans in Kazakhstan and Moldova.
"There are mechanisms -- not paying civil servants, for example -- that give reform programs a bad name," Mr. Boorman said. "We don't want to be associated with that kind of program. We want to encourage countries to be more forthcoming on safety net issues."

HEADLINE: Sudan Holding Election That Some Call a Charade

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, March 10

 BODY:
The Islamic military Government in the Sudan is pressing ahead with an election this week, asserting that the polling will transform this country into a modern democracy.
But the leaders of opposition parties have dismissed the election as an elaborate and meaningless show intended to legitimize an unpopular Government. 
 Several candidates with ties to banned opposition groups have tried without success to withdraw their names from the contest, complaining that voter registration lists are incomplete and that a ban on political parties has crippled their chances.
The elections, as Khartoum faces crises at home and abroad, mark the first balloting of any kind in this desperately poor country since 1986. It is the first time the Sudanese have voted directly for president.
The vote comes at a critical time. The economy here is in tatters, the 30-year-old rebellion in the south continues unabated, and relations with the country's nine nearest neighbors range from tense to bellicose.
At the same time, the United States has cut off aid and last month pulled out its diplomats from Khartoum, citing security worries and saying the Sudan supports Islamic terrorists. Moreover, the United Nations threatened last month to impose sanctions unless the Sudan turns over three men wanted in the assassination attempt on President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt in Ethiopia.
Since a coup in 1989, the country has been ruled by a military Government under Lieut. Gen. Omar Ahmed al-Bashir. The Government is controlled by the National Islamic Front, a fundamentalist party led by Dr. Hassan al-Turabi, which was a minority party before the military takeover.
General Bashir badly needs the election to succeed to gain respectability for his increasingly isolated Government. The two largest parties in the previous Government, the Umma Party and the Democratic Unionist, have called on him to resign and to form a national unity government, which would organize new elections under a multi-party system. Most of their supporters are boycotting the election.
As the voting entered a fifth day today, turnout at polling places in the dusty, furnace-hot capital continued to be low. Many people said they were boycotting the balloting because they believe General Bashir's victory was a foregone conclusion.
"Each new government is just as bad as the last one," said a 28-year-old lawyer, speaking on condition of anonymity. "People know the game, you know.'
Government officials brushed aside opposition complaints about campaigning restrictions and continued to predict that a majority of registered voters would cast ballots before the polls close on March 18.
In an interview, Dr. Turabi, who is a candidate for Parliament, said the restrictions on campaigning were intended to rid the elections of the influences of money. He defended the ban on political party activity, saying it was intended to divorce the Sudan from its history of sectarian and tribal politics.
"The idea here is to teach the Europeans another lesson," he said. "Elections there are distorted completely by financial power. If you are rich, you can beat the poor. Our moral life, ultimately, is against parties."
But some candidates said the measures the Government described as intended to level the playing field were in reality tailored to favor General Bashir and the governing party.
The dizzying number of candidates and the short campaign make it almost impossible for the candidates to educate 1.3 million registered voters about their positions. About 900 people are running for 275 seats in Parliament.
There are 42 candidates for president, most of whom were relative unknowns before this contest. They were given only 12 days to campaign in the country a quarter of the size of the United States. The Government paid for and printed one piece of campaign literature for each candidate. Each also received one 15-minute spot on the state-owned television and radio station to explain his platforms.
Arguing that the country has too many illiterate people to allow words on the ballots, the Government printed ballots sporting a list of symbols rather than names. Officials in polling places are allowed to "help" voters tick off the right symbol if they are confused, election officials said.
In a raffle last week, General Bashir picked a symbol of a fan, while Abdel Rahman Farah, a former member of the Umma Party who is seen as the only realistic challenger for the presidency, picked a table. Other candidates are represented by signs including an elephant, a rifle and a razor blade.
Dr. Turabi, who is seen by most diplomats as the de facto leader of the Government, tried to put the best face on the isolation the Sudan is suffering. He said, "Every new rise in civilization is encircled."
Dr. Turabi has argued that being cut off from United States aid and other foreign assistance will force the Sudanese to become self-reliant and develop industries like oil refining.
"I don't think the Sudan is close to collapse, though other people may like that," he said. "This country is self-sufficient in oil, arms, culture, food, everything you like."
"I don't care about the world," he added. "For me this is an act of religion."

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Great Disconnect

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A company announces layoffs that will make its products cost less and its profits rise. This is greeted as good news by investors, and the stock goes up.
But the Reich-Buchanan popu-libs -- their philosophy deeply mired in the 1930's -- treat "downsizing" as a sign of rampant greed by plutocrats at the expense of exploited workers. 
 The nation announces the good news that our rate of unemployment is making new lows, that job-creation is booming. Because this is treated as bad news by investors fixated on interest rates, the stock market falls out of bed.
Ah-hah! cry the popu-libs -- this logical disconnect goes to show that what's good for Main Street lumpen-proletariat is bad for Wall Street stuffed shirts.
On the campaign trail, Bob Dole cannot decide whether to identify with the resentment crowd or to admit that under Clinton, business is good. In the White House, Bill Clinton is equally torn, not knowing whether to share our joy or feel our pain.
Time for a half-dozen home truths.
1. You can't make a prosperity omelet without breaking eggs. Downsizing -- making a bloated, high-cost enterprise lean and green by laying off layers of supervisors -- provides the greatest good for the greatest number.
Overstaffed companies in Germany and Japan are playing catch-up because the U.S. has shown how slimmed-down producers deliver more value for consumers, more profits for investors and -- because only the fittest companies survive -- more security for workers.
2. Low unemployment is good for the economy. High employment's upward pressure on wages, which might reduce profits, is more than offset by increased aggregate demand for products, which adds to profits.
When the rate of unemployment was 8 percent, blue-collar workers bore the brunt of joblessness; today Joe and Josie Sixpack are back at work by the millions, but with middle managers getting the squeeze, you never heard such popu-lib anguish.
3. What is good for the economy is good for the stock market. Contrary to the current market mantra, good news is not bad news. Away with the notion that sweet are the uses of inversity. Try this for long-term insight: Only good news is good news.
Only bad news -- unemployment, recession, red ink, bankruptcies, plunging earnings multiples -- is bad news. If the day ever comes that Alan Greenspan's Fed gives away toasters to get us to borrow at no percent, that easy money would not disguise hard times.
4. Main Street is Wall Street. Who do you suppose profits most when stocks go up? Pension funds, which are the employees' assets, and mutual funds, which are owned by marvelous hordes of workers and consumers. Many union funds are putting heat on companies whose stock they own to maximize profits and increase the value of workers' investments.
Soon our Social Security Fund will invest in broad indexes of companies, seeking far higher historic returns than available from government bonds, thereby reducing the tax take from workers. The owners of America are the American people.
5. The devil should not take the hindmost, but the tail should not wag the dog. Sure it's humiliating to be laid off before retirement age. The human impact of staying competitive is undeniable, though smart managements seeking the value of loyalty ameliorate it. And new law to make health insurance portable will help.
But the sacrifice of the relative few in these prosperous times benefits the many. The alternative -- government meddling -- would interfere with job creation. Rather than join the popu-libs in whipping up the fear of getting fired and urging government-backed vengeance for the supposedly victimized, free-enterprisers should exhort each other to act as individual survivalists -- improving our performance, finding security in making our services more valuable as we get older.
6. Success is to be emulated, not envied. Professional resenters on the right and left are demonizing good executives and making achievement a dirty word. Owners, employees and consumers should want their companies to attract the best managers, the better to compete with other enterprises here and abroad, and competitive compensation tied to performance is often a wise investment. No salary is "obscene" that turns around a failing enterprise.
(Boy, will I get mail on this one.)

HEADLINE: U.S. to Fight Magazine Ad Tax by Ottawa

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is about to put its trade weaponry to work against Canada on behalf of American magazine publishers, and in particular, Sports Illustrated.
Administration officials said today that they planned to take formal action on Monday that could lead to the United States' imposing trade sanctions against Canada over tax policies that, they argue, form a barrier against the American magazine industry. 
 Fighting for the right to bring sports news and swimsuit-clad supermodels to Canadian readers may not rival prying open the Japanese auto-parts market in economic or political significance, but the action would be the latest in a particularly sensitive area of trade disputes -- those involving national culture.
It comes as the Clinton Administration is under criticism from Republicans, including Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the likely Presidential nominee of his party, for not acting tougher toward the nation's trading partners.
Canada has had laws since 1965 to protect its publishers. But this dispute concerns an 80 percent excise tax imposed in December on revenue from Canadian advertisers taken in by foreign companies publishing magazines in Canada.
The officials said the United States would act through the World Trade Organization, charging that Canada was unfairly keeping American magazines -- at this point mostly Sports Illustrated, a Time Warner publication, and a Canadian edition of Sports Illustrated it started two years ago -- out of its market.
To the American Government, it is a clear case of protectionism in entertainment and information, areas in which the United States is the world leader and that have drawn increased attention from Administration officials. The recent world trade pact, for instance, was held up for a time in 1994 over France's demand for protection against imported American movies.
To Canada, it is a matter of trying to safeguard its culture in the face of an onslaught of movies, television shows, books and magazines from the behemoth to the south.
The process would start with formal consultations between the two nations and then proceed to an international dispute panel. If no compromise was reached and the American position was upheld, the process could end with the United States' imposing unspecified retaliatory sanctions in about 18 months.
The Americans said they would act under rules of the World Trade Organization rather than provisions of the North American Free Trade Agreement among the United States, Canada and Mexico. That agreement exempts some cultural categories.
Many American magazines are sold in Canada, but only a few publish Canadian editions that compete for advertising from Canadian companies, in part because of other longstanding restrictions on foreign publications.
In this case, the obvious target of the new tax was Sports Illustrated, which for the previous two years had been publishing a Canadian edition seven times a year and was considering making it a weekly. The Canadian edition, which was printed outside Toronto, had some articles just for the Canadian market, but was otherwise largely the same as the American edition.
Although Sports Illustrated's Canadian circulation of 125,000 was considered modest and had no direct competitor in Canada, the Government in Ottawa acted under pressure from the Canadian Magazine Publishers Association. The association feared that if Sports Illustrated was successful, it would lead more American publications to enter the market and compete for advertising.
Sports Illustrated subsequently halted publication in Canada. Although the magazine remains available by mail and on newsstands, and has maintained its circulation, it is the American edition, and it no longer contains stories specifically for Canadian readers. Sports Illustrated no longer solicits advertising from Canadian companies.
"We felt the Canadian position on this should be challenged," said Peter Costiglio, a spokesman for Sports Illustrated. "We commend what the U.S. trade representative and the U.S. Government are doing."
Mickey Kantor, the trade representative, said that Canada knows it is violating trade agreements but is acting "on commitments to protect its domestic industry."
"This is part of a broader and more disturbing picture regarding so-called cultural issues," Mr. Kantor said, adding that Canada had been acting to block free access to its market in the distribution of movies by direct satellite broadcasting and access to cable systems for the American-owned Country Music Television.
"Other countries will be watching the situation with Canada to see how we react," Mr. Kantor said.
Canadian officials said they had not yet been informed of the American decision to act on the dispute, but would defend their position before the World Trade Organization.
"We are of the view that we have a right to insure than Canadian culture is protected, certainly when dealing with a trading partner 10 times its size," said Ariel Delouya, a Government spokesman on trade issues in Ottawa.
The economic justification behind Canada's policy has always been that American publishers cover all or most of the cost of their editorial product by selling ads in the American market, and that they therefore can undercut Canadian publishers by offering more attractive advertising rates -- in effect, dumping their products on the Canadian market.
Alvaro Saralegui, Sports Illustrated's general manager, said that argument did not hold up with his publication because its advertising rates were about 8 percent higher than Canada's biggest general-interest magazine, Maclean's, on the basis of advertising cost for each 1,000 readers.
A handful of American magazines, like Time, have been exempt from the longstanding publishing laws of Canada on the basis they were competing there before the laws took effect. But they, too, have complained of unfair treatment.
For Sports Illustrated, which does not sell any other international editions, Canada seemed a natural opportunity, Mr. Saralegui said. Not only was there no national sports magazine, but the sports overlap between the United States and Canada was considerable and growing; indeed, the Toronto Blue Jays' winning the 1992 World Series was one reason the publication decided the time was right to begin a Canadian edition.

HEADLINE: Memorial to Black Soldiers Faces Deadline

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
Sponsors of a project to build the first monument on the Mall here dedicated to the achievements of African-Americans are running out of time to raise the $5 million they need to save the project.
For 10 years, the Black Patriots Foundation has tried to raise $6.5 million to build a memorial honoring the 5,000 black soldiers who fought in the American Revolution. Now the group is racing to beat an October deadline. That is when legislation approving the location for the monument will expire. 
 New life was breathed into the project last month when the General Motors Corporation pledged $1.1 million, generating some fund-raising momentum. All the contributions must be private, since no Federal money is being used in construction of the memorial.
"The pledge from General Motors was critical," said Wayne F. Smith, the executive director of the Patriots Foundation. "Like many other memorials before us, we have struggled. Although many people think this is a great idea, donations have not been particularly strong. Over the years, we have written everybody to join our cause."
Also last month, the foundation asked Congress to approve the sale of a commemorative coin for the monument. A portion of the proceeds would be given to the fund.
The foundation has created a task force to broaden its grass-roots campaign and hopes to use the General Motors contribution to attract more corporate support. Early in the campaign the Coca-Cola Company and the Du Pont Company made small contributions. Last month the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People joined the campaign for the first time and stood alongside supporters from the Congressional Black Caucus at a Washington news conference.
The foundation is still $5 million short of its goal. Foundation officials said potential contributors could call (202) 452-1776.
Like organizations responsible for raising the money for the Vietnam and Korean War memorials, the foundation has traveled a long and often difficult road during its 10-year history. The project's co-founder, Maurice Barboza, a Virginia lawyer, was abruptly removed in 1992 by the foundation's board.
During Mr. Barboza's tenure, the group managed to raise only $1 million, and much of that has now been used up just keeping the group going.
Foundation members blame a sluggish economy and the emergence of competing projects, principally the monument to women who served in Vietnam.
When asked what might happen to the project if the fund raising falls short, Mr. Smith said, "We don't think America will fail us."
The monument would be built between the Washington Monument and the Lincoln Memorial. The design features two curved walls and a 90-foot bronze sculpture. One wall is devoted to a narrative describing the contributions of the many slaves and freed African-American men who elected to fight against the British for the independence of the Colonies.
Mr. Smith hopes the project will do more than memorialize patriotic African-Americans.
"It is important young people see a reminder that both black and white people helped found this nation," he said. "It is also important that blacks see that their ancestors have made an investment in this country."

HEADLINE: The Jobs Immigrants Take

BYLINE: By Roger Waldinger; Roger Waldinger, professor of sociology at U.C.L.A., is the author of the forthcoming "Still the Promised City? New Immigrants and African-Americans in Post-Industrial New York."

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
America is in the throes of another debate over legal immigration, and this time those that would close the country's doors seem to have the upper hand. While an unhealthy nativism lies behind today's backlash, there are real reasons to worry about immigration. The most important: its negative effects on low-skilled African-Americans.
Until recently, the argument that legal immigration hurts blacks has found little scholarly support. 
 For one thing, immigrants often have a hard time winning the jobs filled by African-Americans. In New York City, for instance, more than one-third of African-Americans in 1990 worked in government. These jobs are among the most difficult for immigrants to get. Paradoxically, immigration spurs black employment in government, because immigrants need public services like street cleaning and public education.
But for low-skilled blacks, immigration is a different story. Stuck in the inner city at a time when immigration has significantly expanded, they are finding increased competition for jobs.
From World War II until 1965, the number of low-skilled people in New York City dwindled even faster than the supply of low-skilled jobs. But the 1965 immigration bill changed that. Since then, the number of people chasing low-skilled jobs has been increasing.
And in cities with large numbers of immigrants, these jobs increasingly belong to the foreign-born. In 1990, immigrants made up two-thirds of employed Los Angelenos with less than a high school education, and 90 percent of the employed with only an elementary school education.
Why do immigrants win these jobs? First, immigrant groups are very good at creating their own job niches and networking. And economists and sociologists have repeatedly demonstrated that personal contacts are important, especially among blue-collar workers.
Everyone knows about Korean-owned groceries and Indian-owned newsstands. But large industries also hire through the immigrant network. In 1990, Mexican immigrants were heavily overrepresented in 53 of Los Angeles's 82 largest manufacturing industries. A supervisor in a printing plant told me: "The referrals occur before the vacancy appears. Everybody out there knows about it before we do."
Secondly, employers play a role in immigrant hiring. Many, if not most, believe, however falsely, that immigrants will be more productive than blacks.
Recruiting through the immigrant network cuts off the workplace from the open job market. The result: African-Americans are often a very small minority in manufacturing industries. In New York's garment industry, for instance, only 3 percent of workers are black.
This disadvantage is likely to become worse in the future. Blacks have had the best of economic times when a vigorous economy has encouraged employers to pull in workers whom they previously had excluded. In 1970, for example, 81 percent of African-American men were employed. But the immigrant influx makes it unlikely that African-Americans would reap dividends even in a period of full employment.
That said, closing the immigration door even partly may not help. Legislation in Congress would cut the flow to 500,000 to 600,000 immigrants a year. At that level, New York, Los Angeles and other cities with huge immigration populations can still expect to receive a large and disproportionate share of newcomers, who tend to settle where their contacts are.
Alleviating the economic distress of low-skilled blacks requires attacking two problems: the unwillingness of employers to hire them and the lack of meaningful training. Putting roadblocks in the paths of immigrants simply won't do the trick.

HEADLINE: U.N. Agencies Feeling the Pain as the U.S. Lags on Payments

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 8

 BODY:
Congressional reluctance to provide money for international organizations combined with Clinton Administration delays in allocating the scarce funds that are available have begun to cut into a wide range of United Nations programs, many of which serve the world's poorest countries.
At the World Health Organization, the failure of the United States to pay any of its 1995 assessment has forced reductions in global surveillance systems tracking epidemic diseases and in programs to provide expert assistance to vulnerable countries. 
 The United States owes the W.H.O. $104 million for 1995, a quarter of the organization's budget, and another $107 million for 1996.
The United States pays the United Nations in two ways. Certain payments are assessed by international agreement -- for the organization's regular operating budget, peacekeeping missions and autonomous bodies like the World Health Organization, World Bank or International Civil Aviation Organization. The United States is now more than $1.5 billion dollars behind in those.
Other payments are "voluntary," in that the United States decides how much to contribute. For this year, the Clinton Administration had asked for $425 million for contributions to such agencies as the United Nations Children's Fund, the United Nations Development Program, the Environment Program, the Population Fund and the International Atomic Energy Agency. Congress appropriated $285 million, down from $374 million in 1995.
The smaller amount of money available this year has already led to competition among United Nations programs and to lobbying at the White House and State Department by American officials assigned to the United Nations, who are fearful of losing both projects and influence.
"This is only the beginning of what could become an increasingly bitter struggle over a shrinking pie," an American official said. "The unwillingness of Congress to provide minimum levels of funds for our efforts to support development around the world makes it harder and harder to argue for a leadership role in the organizations that carry out these tasks."
Although final figures on allocation of voluntary contributions have not been made public, the agency likely to be hit hardest will be the United Nations Development Program. Its allocation may be more than halved, to about $52 million from $113 million in 1995.
The Development Program's administrator is James Gustave Speth, who, with the rank of Under Secretary General, is the highest-ranking American in the United Nations and the overall coordinator of development projects. With the reduced allocation, the United States will drop from the program's top donor to sixth place or lower, opening the way for a European bid for the top job when Mr. Speth's contract comes up for renewal in July 1997.
Last year, European nations lobbied hard for the directorship of Unicef, saying that the European Union donated more to the organization for children than the United States did. Only intense pressure from the Clinton Administration saved the job for an American. Carol Bellamy, the former Peace Corps director and once a New York City Council president, was appointed executive director.
Unicef, which enjoys popular support in the United States, will probably do better than other voluntary organizations, receiving about $100 million, the same as last year.
Administration officials say delays in making the allocations are caused by the difficulty of making fair decisions with diminished resources.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Another Frill: Giving the Poor Good Lawyers

BYLINE: By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
ONE day last winter, Mitchell D. was accused of robbing a midtown deli. He said he didn't do it, but his court-appointed lawyer said he had a bad case and advised him to plead guilty. He refused.
A relative got him another lawyer, who learned that Mitchell D.'s fingerprints did not match the prints found in the deli and noted that while the police report said the eyewitness described the robber as dark-skinned, the defendant was light-skinned. That case went to trial, and the 29-year-old unemployed street cleaner was acquitted. 
 He credits his lawyer, who was provided at public cost. The lawyer works for Neighborhood Defenders Service of Harlem, a pilot project created as an alternative to conventional Legal Aid. The concept was to give some indigent defendants the kind of legal help that the more affluent can buy.
The program, which began almost six years ago, is scheduled to end this spring. The city will allow it to expire because it is considered a luxury. Beneficence to the poor is not a popular concept these days.
"Who likes lawyers, poor people, or people who are lawyers for poor people?" asked Daniel L. Greenberg, executive director of the Legal Aid Society. "It's part of the general climate that we live in -- anti-defendant and even anti-judge, and that's a shame. It's so shortsighted."
THE idea behind the service was to provide indigent defendants with comprehensive legal help, more than most get now from Legal Aid or lawyers in private practice who are assigned by the courts to poor defendants.
Poor defendants, by law, have a right to a lawyer, but the courts are swamped. Legal Aid lawyers usually meet their clients for the first time in court and can rarely do what the Defenders Service did in the deli case: investigate and look for inconsistencies.
Had he pleaded guilty, Mitchell D., whose lawyer insisted that his last name not be used, would most likely have served six years in prison. That would probably have been all right with the eyewitness, who still thinks he is guilty, Mr. D. said. It probably would have been fine with most Americans, who have little patience with defendants' getting off because they have good lawyers. But the law still considers people innocent until proven guilty.
"N.D.S. is a way of taking the integrity of the criminal justice system seriously for a community that we all know, after the O. J. mess, is incredibly alienated from the system," said Christopher E. Stone, president of the Vera Institute of Justice, which devised the program. The service's record shows that clients get more time, attention and service from Neighborhood Defenders, based on 125th Street, than from Legal Aid, whose office is near the courts downtown.
Its lawyers have a reputation for being well prepared, which reduces court delays. But the program is expensive.
"WE weren't saving anything in terms of municipal dollars," explained Paul A. Crotty, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Corporation Counsel. "We wouldn't mind paying more if more people got out on bail or got through the system faster. But we didn't find that."
The Harlem program, which is financed by the city, serves 2,500 clients on $3.8 million a year, while Legal Aid has 250,000 clients and a budget of $79 million. So, the service's per-client cost is about five times Legal Aid's. But the Harlem program's supporters say the comparison is misleading, because it provides more than just lawyers.
"The traditional formula used -- the cost-per-case analysis -- is an inappropriate measure here," said Robin Steinberg, the Neighborhood Defenders' deputy director. "We provide pre-arrest work, after-care services, and those fall outside those traditional measures. You can't cost it out."
What, for instance, is the cost of keeping someone out of the court system? Geraldine Scott, an unemployed railroad clerk, said she was about to be arrested for writing bad checks when she turned to the Defenders Service. A lawyer worked out a repayment schedule for her, and Ms. Scott, 51, has paid back all but the last few dollars. "I would have been arrested and taken through the system, would have had a record," she said.
In one way, the program does save money -- but it's state money. One study by Vera shows that Defenders Service clients serve 100 fewer days in prison, on average, at an estimated saving of $24 million a year in prison costs. "Crotty may say most of that is state savings, but most people are the same people -- taxpayers," Ms. Steinberg said.
The program might have grown instead of facing extinction. When the Mayor sought competition to Legal Aid, the Defenders submitted a bid to cover all Manhattan. Because it was too expensive, it lost to Legal Aid. "We never wanted to grow that much," said Leonard Noisette, the director. "But it doesn't seem to make a lot of sense to completely eliminate us."
The program is scheduled to close its doors on June 30. It was always just a pilot project, Mr. Crotty points out.

HEADLINE: Students Looking to Unions for Careers in Social Change

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: MIDDLETOWN, Conn.

 BODY:
With large-scale layoffs and falling wages creating many of the same anxieties felt in the 1930's, Lazar Treschan, like hundreds of other idealistic college students, is planning to do what many of the best and the brightest did after college in the Depression: become union organizers.
Disillusioned by an economy in which corporate profits are soaring while millions of workers are being squeezed or discarded, Mr. Treschan, a history major at Wesleyan University here whose parents belong to a teachers' union, says the labor movement is the place to be for young people who want to set things right. 
 "I want to use some of what I learned to work for social justice," said Mr. Treschan, who is from Washington Heights in Manhattan. "I want a job where I can make a difference."
Since October, 400 students have applied to the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to be organizers, and federation officials predict that the number will reach 1,000 by graduation time -- more than twice last year's total of 450. Of that number, about two-thirds will be selected for an intensive three-day training program that is the first step toward a career as an organizer. The influx of graduates, union officials say, will be the largest since the heyday of Cesar Chavez and the United Farm Workers in the 1970's, and perhaps the largest since the Depression.
While some of the heightened interest could stem from the lackluster job market, it also results in part from a stepped-up recruitment drive by the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which has sent 22 recruiters to more than 100 campuses. The aim is to fulfill two goals of the federation's new president, John J. Sweeney: to train 1,000 new organizers and to reverse the decline in union membership.
Explaining why they want to become organizers, many students say the labor movement conjures up not the disquieting images of Jimmy Hoffa and corrupt, beer-bellied bureaucrats, but inspiring visions of aggressive, defy-the-odds organizers seeking to unionize $4.25-an-hour hospital aides or conducting sit-ins to raise janitors' wages.
"This is the best opportunity that I've seen for a college student to have a real job while working for change," said Celia Mosca, a government major at Cornell University who has applied to be an organizer. "Obviously a lot of companies are into downsizing, into getting people to work at the lowest possible price. The union movement is trying to create a better balance of power between companies and workers."
Chris Woods, who runs the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s efforts to recruit organizers, said she had been surprised by the upswing in applications from campuses. When recruiters visited Swarthmore last week, 30 students applied to be full-time organizers after graduation or to work as interns this summer. At Wesleyan, a dozen seniors have applied to be full-time organizers, while there were 13 at Rutgers, 6 at Cornell, 15 at Oberlin, 23 at the University of Wisconsin and 24 at the University of Oregon.
"It's phenomenal," Ms. Woods said. "We've never seen numbers like this. These students realize they're the first generation that will have a lower standard of living than their parents. These things are causing them to think what they should do in terms of trying to create some change."
To strengthen ties to campuses, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is also setting up "Union Summer," a new program in which about 1,000 young people will spend three weeks as interns doing organizing or political work.
Richard Bensinger, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s organizing director, said the spread of corporate layoffs was spurring student interest. "There's a tremendous concentration of economic power in the hands of corporate America," he said, "and on the other hand, there are very vulnerable, insecure employees, many of whom are the parents of these students and are having problems paying tuition. There's a sense of hopelessness permeating society, and college campuses. These are the sons and daughters of people being downsized, and they want to do something about it."
Union leaders and many professors, many of them veterans of the civil rights and antiwar movements, are delighted to see these students sign on with labor. But business executives are unhappy to see the students dedicating themselves to battling management.
Bruce Josten, the American Chamber of Commerce official in charge of countering the labor movement's lobbying and organizing efforts, said the A.F.L.-C.I.O. was using fear and falsehoods to lure the impressionable.
"Sweeney is trying to sell them fear to sell his cause," Mr. Josten said. "Fear is a powerful motivator. I'm not sure how much it helps. His people talk a lot about downsizing and corporate layoffs, which have been and will be a fact of life in an economy that's dynamic. But do they tell these young people about the 70 million jobs that have been created since 1979?"
Some union leaders are also less than enthusiastic, questioning whether students can move smoothly from their ivied halls, their squash courts and wine-and-cheese parties to organizing poultry workers in Mississippi or sweatshop seamstresses in New York's Chinatown.
"I think basically it's a good idea," said Stefan Orza, president of the Central Labor Council in Middletown. "But these young adults will have a lot of obstacles to overcome. These jobs aren't going to provide them with six-figure incomes. They'll go into situations that are uncomfortable. I don't know whether they possess that kind of intestinal fortitude."
While many of their classmates are taking jobs at banks or consulting companies for salaries of $35,000 to $50,000 a year, these would-be organizers insist that they do not mind starting at $20,000.
Many students say they are eager for the commitment, confrontation and hardship that are an organizer's life. Some say they look forward to spending a month of 16-hour days organizing textile workers in North Carolina, or hopping to Los Angeles for a month of organizing janitors.
"Some of my friends say, 'Oh, my gosh, why does she want to take a job for $20,000?' " said Anna Davidson, a University of Colorado senior from Manhattan. "I think they've grown to respect what I'm doing. I tell them that people's voices in this country are going unheard, and that means we have to do grass-roots organizing."
Cedric de Leon, a Yale senior from Toronto, said his father, a cook, and his mother, a clerical worker, sent him to Yale with the hope that it would be a springboard to corporate success.
"There was a cultural and financial expectation for me to do well, and sending me to Yale was part of the plan," said Mr. de Leon, a sociology major. "But I couldn't reconcile my ambition to be a corporate executive with what I see has to be done in the world."
Having helped organize a United Farm Workers support group at Yale, he says he is willing to forgo a large salary because he wants to fight corporate flight and improve the lot of workers.
A.F.L.-C.I.O. officials say an important criterion when they select applicants is how well they can communicate with workers. Those who spout polysyllables and quote Hegel are less likely to be accepted than students who have done community organizing or set up workshops on the problems of Hispanic, Asian and black women.
Last week at Sarah Lawrence, two recruiters, Maria Wickstrom and Kate Shaughnessy, interviewed Ciara Wilson, a senior with the type of resume the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is hungry for. Ms. Wilson has counseled poor New Yorkers about government benefits and has worked in Brazil counseling low-income families on AIDS prevention.
Ms. Wilson, a tall, assertive woman from Los Angeles, said she was not deterred by some people's perception of the labor movement as lethargic and hostile to minorities.
"In order for it to turn around," she said, "I want to be involved -- as a black woman and as a vigorous woman who is not lethargic."
After students have been accepted into the three-day training program run by the federation's Organizing Institute, 60 percent are chosen for the next step: a three-week internship in an organizing drive. The next step is to spend three months apprenticed to an organizer. After that, these fledgling Joe Hills are usually hired by one of the federation's 79 affiliate unions as full-time organizers.
Federation officials say they have spots for about 300 young people to complete the organizers' training program this year, double last year's number, with the number rising to 400 to 500 next year. About half the trainees come directly from colleges, while half are union staff members sent by their unions.
"We're looking for people who have a passion for change, a commitment to social justice," said Ms. Shaughnessy, one of the recruiters at Sarah "We're looking for people with a spark in their eye, people who not only can listen and understand working people, but can also inspire them."

HEADLINE: POLITICAL POWER LIKELY TO SHIELD SHIPS' SUBSIDIES

SERIES: SPECIAL PLEADERS -- A periodic look at lobbying.

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER DREW 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
In 1993, a task force advising Vice President Al Gore on "reinventing government" recommended the elimination of subsidies for the fading maritime industry, which it described as "a cancer eating away" at the Federal Treasury.
Soon after the Republicans took over Congress last year, the House Budget Committee put the maritime payments high on its hit list of dubious "corporate welfare" programs. 
 But now, the White House and Republican leaders are pushing a new plan for $1 billion in subsidies over 10 years for the country's private merchant-marine fleet, which has been dwindling for decades despite large amounts of Federal support.
After intense lobbying by maritime unions, shipping lines and powerful politicians from coastal states, the House passed the new program in December. And the Senate Republican whip -- Trent Lott of Mississippi, the son of a shipyard pipefitter -- is pressing the Senate to approve the bill this month, even though critics complain that there has been practically no debate on the issue.
Indeed, at a time when a vast array of corporate subsidies is under scrutiny, maritime programs are sitting snugly in an unusual political haven, backed as forcefully by labor unions as by industry.
The unions have shrewdly curried favor with influential Republicans as well as Democrats, dispensing more than $14 million in campaign contributions in the last decade.
The result is that while workers in other troubled businesses fear that they have nowhere to turn, the Federal Government seems on the verge of tossing the maritime industry another lifeline.
The industry's backers say, however, that one person's pork is another's salvation. The American maritime fleet has been badly hurt by subsidized foreign competition, and its backers say it deserves help because it could be needed in a war. The Secretary of Transportation, Federico F. Pena, has warned that without the new program, "in all likelihood our U.S.-flag presence in international trade will vanish."
To be sure, the aid would be much smaller than under the Depression-era program set to expire next year. The new bill would cut direct subsidies to ocean-shipping lines to $100 million a year from $200 million. It would also prod them to compete more with cheaper foreign shippers, and it would give the military more flexibility in calling on the civilian ships and terminals in wartime.
But even some shipping companies complain that other types of Federal aid, including a loan guarantee program for building ships, are flowing too freely into the industry.
A Houston shipping company recently filed a lawsuit that accuses Transportation's Maritime Administration of bending over backward to approve a shipbuilding deal involving Tenneco that hinged on $215 million in Federal loan guarantees. The suit says such cheap credit could encourage too much shipbuilding in the fragile United States coastal shipping trade and destroy some of the shipping companies.
A bigger version of the program did just that in the 1980's, costing the Government $2 billion in defaults. But the Clinton Administration, backed by Republican leaders, revived the program in 1993, saying the guarantees were vital to save America's shipyards.
Senator Charles E. Grassley, a Republican from Iowa, said the maritime programs, which have cost taxpayers $10 billion in direct subsidies since 1936, "are not really making any sense." He said he might try to block Senator Lott's effort to bring the subsidy bill to a vote unless substantial debate was allowed.
Thomas A. Schatz, president of Citizens Against Government Waste, a nonprofit group, wrote last week to Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, denouncing the bill as "entrenched corporate political pork."
But Mr. Grassley said the maritime unions had "tremendous clout." He said he was trying to convince fellow Republicans that a "good chunk" of the subsidies helped pay union workers who contributed to efforts to unseat some Republicans.
As foreign ships with lower operating costs have siphoned off cargoes, and as more goods are moved on fewer ships, thanks to improved technology, America's oceangoing merchant fleet has shrunk. It went from more than 2,000 ships in the late 1940's to about 850 in 1970 and is approximately 320 today. The number of seafaring jobs has dropped to 8,500 today from 100,000 in 1960. Tens of thousands of others work on ships that stay in domestic waters or at docks and shipping terminals.
To hold on to the Government aid, maritime political action committees, supported by both labor and corporations, have donated $17 million to Federal candidates in the last decade. The unions, ranging from the Seafarers International Union of North America to the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, have given the bulk of it, $14.2 million, according to Common Cause, the government watchdog group.
On average, union members earn more than $60,000 a year, and they fear that their jobs are at stake. The two largest shipping lines, Sea-Land Services and American President Lines, have registered some of their vessels under foreign flags and have threatened to make more use of cheaper foreign crews if the legislation is not passed.
Political action committees at American President and at Sea-Land's parent, the CSX Corporation, have accounted for $700,000 of the $2.8 million donated by industry in the last decade, Common Cause said.
The unions are also credited with persuading the Clinton Administration to drop the Gore task force's criticism of the subsidies. But while they backed Bill Clinton in 1992, "we're not like other unions that have kept an eye out for one party," said Daniel Duncan, the communications director of the Seafarers International, who keeps an old bumper sticker that says "Maritime for Nixon" in his office.
Albert J. Herberger, the Maritime Administrator, said the new bill aimed to offset some of the cost advantages of foreign shipping lines. But he said it would also revamp the subsidy system, cutting the number of subsidized ships to 47 from 75 and pressuring American lines to modernize and cut costs.
Currently, the Government calculates the annual subsidy for each ship, which averages about $3 million, an estimate of how much more it costs to operate the ship under American labor and safety regulations instead of under foreign rules. The new bill would limit the subsidy to a little more than $2 million a year. The bill would also define it as compensation for ship owners who agree to turn over their vessels and terminals at fair market rates to the Pentagon in a national emergency. Congress would have to appropriate the $100 million for subsidies each year.
Senator Grassley said, however, that the bill would not limit an even bigger boon for the industry: a requirement that the Government use American vessels to ship much of its goods, like peacetime military supplies and donations of surplus farm commodities. Congressional auditors say these laws cost taxpayers an extra $500 million a year and reduce the amount of food aid.
Critics also contend that the ability to commandeer merchant ships is not so crucial as it was in the cold war. The Pentagon has built its own $6 billion cargo fleet. In the Persian Gulf war, it easily hired both foreign and domestic liners to help out, and it did not have to requisition any of the subsidized ships.
While the new bill would aid the ocean-shipping lines, the loan-guarantee program is designed to help shipyards, like Tenneco's big facility in Newport News, Va., make up for reductions in Navy work.
Having a Federal guarantee against default enables shipping companies to finance new vessels on better terms from private lenders. In the last three years, the program has helped finance more than $1 billion worth of construction of Americanbarges and ships, including the first foreign orders in 30 years.
But a furor erupted last month when the Maritime Administration agreed to guarantee a $215 million loan for building five tankers to carry refined-oil products on domestic coastal routes. Tenneco, based in Houston, and its partners, including a Dutch-owned company and a union life insurance company, plan to build the ships at the Tenneco yard in Newport News, where employment has dropped to 18,000 from 30,000.
Other ship owners and consultants say that rates for chartering coastal vessels have been so low that no one would build the ships now without the Government's help, and they doubt that rates will rise much for years.
The lawsuit, filed by the Kirby Corporation in Houston, accuses the Maritime Administration of violating economic guidelines by approving the project for "a laudatory, but improper, political goal of short-term job creation."
Documents show that the agency agreed to let Tenneco and its partners repay the loan principal at a slow enough rate to avoid projecting losses for the first several years.
But John E. Graykowski, a Deputy Maritime Administrator, defended the deal, saying the agency was "absolutely confident" that the venture would be profitable. He said another advantage was that the ships would have double hulls and would therefore be less prone to spills.
"We protected the Government against the risks," he said. "We are not Pollyannas here."
