HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook: Stalin's Shadow;
The Pain and Pride Of Russian History

BYLINE: By PHILIP TAUBMAN 

 BODY:
Though Josef Stalin died 43 years ago, he torments Russia to this day. As Russians prepare for a presidential election this June, a revived Communist Party is struggling with the still volatile issue of Stalin and his legacy. Gennadi Zyuganov, the party's presidential candidate, seems wary of condemning one of the founding architects of the Soviet state yet fearful of embracing him. Other Communists openly defend Stalin as a great leader.
Americans find it hard to understand how Russians could regard Stalin with respect, even admiration. He was among the most brutal dictators in history, a leader who spilled the blood of millions of his countrymen in a drive to modernize Russia and enforce ideological conformity and personal loyalty in the Communist Party. 
 But the continuing debate over Stalin, recently described by Michael Specter of The Times, reveals some important, disquieting truths about Russia that America and the world should bear in mind as Russians choose a president this spring.
One is the power of wounded pride. The disintegration of the Soviet Union has brought democracy and the makings of a market economy to Russia, but it has also left Russia a second-class power. Its empire is gone, its once-powerful military is shattered and its place in the world is no longer clear.
Stalin gave Russia power and pride. The human cost was unimaginable. As many as 20 million people died during the forced collectivization of agriculture and the party purges, but many Russians see those losses as the price of industrialization and the emergence of the Soviet Union as one of the world's two great powers. Russians also credit Stalin with the Soviet Union's survival and eventual victory in World War II.
On the surface, the Communist Party today is far removed from the party of Stalin. Mr. Zyuganov and his colleagues offer Russians a retreat from the political upheaval and economic dislocation of reform, couched in the rhetoric of moderate social democratic policy. But smoldering just below the surface is a more visceral promise to restore Russia's power and pride. The refusal to denounce Stalin underscores that intention.
The debate over Stalin also reveals resentments that linger from a long-running struggle to shape the record of Russian history. Four decades after Nikita Khrushchev attacked Stalin in a secret speech to the Communist Party leadership, and nearly a decade after Mikhail Gorbachev reopened public discussion about Stalin's crimes, Russians are still divided over whether they have a 20th-century history worth honoring, beyond their role in the defeat of Hitler.
To disown Stalin is to dismiss much of Soviet history. As terrible as Stalin was, and as much as Russians suffered under his rule -- it is hard to find a family not wounded by the terror he sanctioned -- a people cannot easily repudiate its past. If the Stalin era is written off as deformed, then little is left to justify the sacrifices that were made and the lives that were lost. Younger Russians may not care much about this issue, but for older generations, where support for Mr. Zyuganov is strongest, it matters a great deal.
A Russian I knew well in Moscow once said that despite all the revelations about Stalin's brutality, the dictator was still her hero. He had transformed Russia, she said, from a backward land into a great nation. It was her way of saying that her life, for all its misery, had been part of a greater enterprise.
Stalin's place in Russian history may not be an overt issue in the presidential campaign, but it will be an undercurrent. Boris Yeltsin is already telling voters that his re-election is the only way to prevent a return to the abuses of Communism. Mr. Zyuganov in oblique ways is is trying to exploit the hunger among many Russians for a restoration of pride and power. It will be many more years until Russia finally escapes Stalin's shadow. PHILIP TAUBMAN

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS' STUMBLE: THE WAIT;
Fund Investors Hold Key To Health of Stock Market

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Each time Wall Street has panicked in the last few years, investors on Main Street have stepped in and stemmed the tide of selling. Whether that continues today will depend on the hundreds of thousands of people who have invested in mutual funds in recent years.
At mutual fund and brokerage firms around the country yesterday, the volume of calls from customers rose, but there was no sign of panic selling in the wake of Friday's nosedive in the stock and bond markets. So if recent history is a guide, the stock market should stabilize. 
 But at least two large questions are unanswered. One is whether investors can tolerate the stock and bond markets' recent volatility, with record highs for the Dow Jones industrial average and sharp plunges following on each other's heels. The other is whether the stock market will continue to be driven by interest-rate changes and the pressures of the bond market, which pulled it down on Friday, or will respond positively to corporate profits and economic growth.
Fidelity Investments, the country's largest mutual fund company and one of the biggest discount brokerage firms, said phone calls were running about 10 percent ahead of a normal weekend pace. But in contrast to Friday, when sales of mutual fund holdings increased late in the day as word spread of the plunging markets, there was no strong selloff of investments over the weekend, said Teri Kilduff, a spokeswoman.
At Charles Schwab & Company, the nation's largest discount brokerage firm, telephone traffic was a third more than normal levels. Among the firm's mutual fund investors, "we expect to see a net redemption" today, Hugo W. Quackenbush, a senior vice president at Schwab, said. Telephone volume was up even more at Twentieth Century Mutual Funds in Kansas City, Mo., rising 50 percent above normal levels on Friday afternoon, a spokeswoman said.
On Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 171.24 points, or 3.04 percent. Perhaps more startling was the drop in Treasury bonds: the price of the benchmark 30-year bond fell more than three points, pushing its interest rate -- which moves in the opposite direction of price -- to 6.72 percent, its highest level in six months, from 6.46.
What started the rout was the Labor Department's report that 705,000 jobs were created in February, greatly exceeding expectations. That dashed hopes that the Federal Reserve would further cut interest rates, an expectation that had for weeks been pushing both stock and bond prices higher.
If individual investors appeared calm for the most part, professionals spent the weekend wondering if stock prices would continue to take their cues from the bond market.
"Signs that the economy might be getting a little stronger are infinitely better for stocks than for bonds," said Abby Cohen, co-chairman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company. A stronger economy means continued growth in corporate profits this year and next, which, she said, indicates that "at these levels the stock market has some value in it."
The bond market, where individual investors are a much less significant factor, might be in for a rougher time, some analysts said.
"Too much damage has been done to too many people too fast to have it settle out anytime soon," said John Liscio, editor of The Liscio Report, a financial newsletter in Upper Montclair, N.J. "This kind of volatile market could go on several weeks, if not longer."
For much of the weekend professional investors warily awaited last night's opening of bond futures trading at the Chicago Board of Trade. Bond futures contracts give the holder the right to buy or sell bonds at a given price at some point in the future, and prices fell slightly at the opening, and fell a bit more during the session.
Most Pacific stock and bond markets also declined in trading today, in what traders described as follow-up selling to Friday's activity in the United States. In Tokyo, stocks were lower; the Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 359.58 points or 1.78 percent, at 19,796.29. In Hong Kong, where trading has been more volatile in recent days because of Chinese pressure on Taiwan, the market closed down more than 8 percent.
That is likely to put initial pressure on the American markets this morning.
"I would expect some follow-through selling on Monday, but the stock market should then stabilize," said Byron Wien, chief domestic strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company. The greater-than-expected job growth in February "is, in fact, good news for the economy," he said, adding, "I think a lot of people were expecting earnings to be disappointing this year."
The Dow's 171-point drop on Friday was the third-worst ever in points, though in percentage terms it was not among the 100 worst trading sessions.
On five previous occasions since January 1988, the Dow has fallen more than 100 points in a single day. Each time, stock prices rebounded on the next trading day, in large part because individuals did not place large orders to sell their mutual fund shares that invested in stocks and put the money in cash accounts.
But when the Dow last fell 100 points, on Dec. 18, it closed at 5,075. Before Friday's drop, the Dow had risen 11 percent from that level in less than three months.
For much of that time, bond prices had been heading lower. The yield on 30-year Treasuries had increased more than half a percentage point in that time.
That disconnection between stock and bond prices has left some analysts thinking that while bond prices face continued declines, stocks will be helped by the growing economy. Others, though, anticipate further retreats in stocks, while bond prices hold steady or rebound.
"The feeling that interest rates would go continually lower has been one of the pillars of the bull market in stocks," said Leo Melamed, chairman of Sakura Dellsher Inc., a futures trading firm. And while a strengthening economy does bode well for corporate profits, he said, "I'm afraid that good earnings have already been factored in considerably" to current stock market valuations.
By contrast, Mr. Melamed said, "I fully expect the bond market to rally after a weakening opening" today. With long-term interest rates at 6.7 percent, "that's no small number for the stock market to compete with."
Increasing the volatility of both the stock and bond markets lately has been a greater-than-usual amount of speculative activity.
Extremely low interest rates in Japan encouraged professional traders and some large institutional investors to make a complicated multimarket bet known as a carry trade, analysts said. By borrowing at rates as low as one-half of 1 percent in Japan, converting the yen into dollars and buying United States Treasuries that paid 5 percent or more, a trader could lock in easy profits. The trade worked as long as the dollar-yen relationship remained steady.
But in recent weeks, as American bond prices fell, the dollar weakened and Japanese interest rates rose, the traders all got caught racing for the door at the same time. Some of those bets remain outstanding, analysts said, and they could contribute to further sharp moves in bond prices.
In addition, investors in stock mutual funds adopted a more conservative posture in late 1995, increasing their purchases of less volatile growth-and-income funds while scaling back their interest in aggressive funds. But as stock prices accelerated upward in the new year, money again began flowing to the higher-risk funds.
Bob Adler, president of AMG Data Services, which tracks mutual fund flows, said that in the last four weeks, $2 of every $10 invested in equity funds went to the category of funds known as aggressive growth -- twice the rate of the first four weeks of the year.
By contrast, investors picked up their rate of withdrawal from bond funds in the last half of last week, as bond prices plunged, according to Charles Biderman, editor of Mutual Fund Trim Tabs, a newsletter based in Santa Rosa, Calif.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Indicting China's Terrorism

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
By firing missiles into the waters off Taiwan, Communist China is committing open, deliberate international terrorism of enormous danger.
Americans count on Beijing's survival instincts to stop the terrorism short of the disaster of war with the U.S. That may happen -- this time. 
 But every day that Washington fails to bring the missile blackmail and blockade of Taiwan before the U.N. increases the chances it will happen again, or something worse, until the disaster does take place.
The Communists' rage and fear at the example of Taiwan's democracy off their shores will not let them rest unless the Taiwanese give it up.
That is not likely. If any pro-democracy majority is elected in the March 20 voting, before long there will be another round of terrorism.
That may include some Chinese military landings on Taiwan. U.S. vessels will have to move in to live up to American word and legislation that the Taiwan-China relationship will not be changed by force.
So far, the U.S. has had to act alone. The Japanese do not have the political courage to make any strong public protest against the terrorism. I have not heard our European allies warn the Chinese that if it comes to it, they will immediately line up with the U.S.
U.S. failure to bring the Chinese before the U.N. will destroy a basic purpose of the U.N. The U.N. was not created simply to end wars but to stop them before they begin. Article 34 of its charter authorizes the Security Council to take up any matter that might lead to "international friction or dispute."
Any member of the U.N. -- or the Secretary General -- can bring a threat to the peace before the Council. China's veto power cannot be used to prevent putting a threat to peace on the Council agenda.
Separately, the U.S. and any country that considers itself a friend both of peace and America can condemn Chinese terrorism. Together they can present a resolution speaking for the U.N.
China will veto that. But if Beijing is so out of control as to threaten more terrorism in the face of a U.N. condemnation prevented only by a veto, we should know it as soon as possible.
Meantime, President Clinton should consider one sentence that tells how his Administration got to this point.
"The experience of China in the past few years demonstrates that while economic growth, trade and social mobility create an improved standard of living they cannot by themselves bring about greater respect for human rights in the absence of a willingness by political authorities to abide by the fundamental international norms."
The sentence in itself is not remarkable. It sums up the message of human rights victims around the world: strengthening our oppressors empowers them to torture us further. But it comes from the latest report on human rights of the State Department. It took courage by those officials who wrote or agreed to it.
Since 1993, the Administration has based its China policy on a contrary vision of morality and history. It insisted that economic growth in China would create a willingness by the dictatorship to live up to those "fundamental international norms." Beijing would give Chinese more human rights. It would stick to agreements against selling nuclear weapon technology. It would allow the people of territories it claims as its own, such as Tibet and Taiwan, to live in peace and dignity.
China's economy certainly has grown, stimulated nicely by $40 billion more that it sells to America than it buys from America.
So: Torture and political repression have increased. And so have oppression of religion, and forced abortion. The choke-leash around Tibet tightens. The chief economic beneficiary of the trade that led to economic growth has been the Communist army, which owns vast parts of the economy, including the forced-labor camps.
The new, richer China has sold nuclear technology to Pakistan and has become the missile salesman to the world's dictatorships.
President Clinton promised to struggle for human rights in China. He did not.
Now his China policy lies adrift in the Strait of Taiwan. He owes us a new one. Its moral principle and historic reality were written for him by the meaning of that sentence in the State Department report: enrichment of dictators enchains their victims.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Audrey Cohen, 64, Innovative Educator, Dies

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Audrey Cohen, an innovative educator for more than 30 years and president and founder of Audrey Cohen College, died on Sunday morning at her home in Manhattan. She was 64.
The cause was cancer, said Alida Mesrop, acting president of Audrey Cohen College. 
 Despite her diminutive and seemingly frail stature, Ms. Cohen was a powerhouse of energy when scorning the rigidity and failures of the contemporary educational system and proposing how to reform it.
Her central idea -- that education must never be abstract but must be closely linked with clearly understood purposes -- attracted wide interest, especially among individuals and institutions serving members of minority groups, immigrants and the disadvantaged seeking access to the mainstream of American society.
At present, Audrey Cohen schools enroll about 20,000 elementary and secondary school students at locations in five states (Arizona, California, Florida, Mississippi and Tennessee), and some 1,500 undergraduate and graduate students in Manhattan at 75 Varick Street.
All of these institutions practice what Ms. Cohen described in a recent interview as "purpose centered" instruction. Her theory, she explained, is that students learn best when they use their knowledge and skills to achieve a stated purpose.
In the early grades, she said, an entire class guided by a teacher may focus on a single purpose, like finding ways to work together. Older students plan and carry out individual programs aimed at purposes like "We work for safety" or "We help people through the arts."
College-level students devote each semester to a more complex purpose in classes like "Values and Ethics," in which they study history, literature and government to extract ethical ideas, and "Self and Others," for the study of arts and writing, to develop productive relationships with people of all ages and cultures.
"Instead of teaching, let's say, the works of Schopenhauer or Rousseau," she said, "our college students concentrate on a purpose such as 'Values and Ethics' in which they may read passages from the writings of Schopenhauer, Rousseau and others which are relevant to the study of values and ethics. That way, it has a deeper meaning to the students."
Asked if approaching the classics with relatively narrow and invariably positive preconceptions might distort their meaning, Ms. Cohen insisted that students at her institutions are encouraged to read more than just assigned passages. "Our approach helps students to fit things together," she said.
Her methods have attracted considerable interest and support among educators throughout the country. Since 1992, Audrey Cohen College has received substantial grants from the New American Schools Development Corporation, a private, nonprofit organization based in Arlington, Va., that supports research to find ways to revitalize teaching.
This year the college has been selected for support by the Education Commission of the States, a nonprofit organization that advises the states on education policy.
Born and raised in Pittsburgh, Ms. Cohen graduated magna cum laude from the University of Pittsburgh, and later did postgraduate work at George Washington University.
In 1958, recognizing that college-educated women restricted by child rearing needed jobs with flexible work schedules, she founded Part Time Research Associates, a social science research corporation.
In the 1960's, Ms. Cohen became aware of the nation's shift from a manufacturing to a service economy, and the lack of training to meet the new requirements. This awareness led to her founding the Women's Talent Corps, which prepared numerous women for careers in such fields as social work, mental health services, occupational therapy and paralegal work.
Soon the Talent Corps became the College for Human Services, and there Ms. Cohen developed the ideas that led in 1964 to the founding of Audrey Cohen College, with its emphasis on practicality and purpose.
Ms. Cohen is survived by her husband, Dr. Ralph Wharton of Manhattan; two daughters, Winifred Alisa Cohen-Smith of Manhattan and Dawn Jennifer Cohen Margolin of Piedmont, Calif., and a brother, Carl Cohen of North Haven, Conn.

HEADLINE: Sales of New Homes Jumped in January

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
Despite some havoc from the blizzard, new-home sales shot up 4.2 percent in January. It was the second straight gain as mortgage rates dipped to a two-year low.
"I think that a lot of people in January decided to take advantage of mortgage rates that in many parts of country were below 7 percent," said David Berson, an economist at the Federal National Mortgage Association. 
 But sales plunged 40 percent in the Northeast, which bore the brunt of the snowstorms. It was the steepest decline there in nine years. In the South, West and Middle West, sales rose.
Over all, sales of single-family homes totaled 693,000 at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, up from 665,000 in December, when they rose five-tenths of a percent, the Commerce Department reported today.
The report included data for both December and January, which had been delayed by the blizzard and partial Government shutdown earlier in the year.
For all of 1995, sales slipped nine-tenths of a percent, to 664,000 from 670,000 in 1994. It was the lowest level since 610,00 new homes were sold in 1992, soon after the economy emerged from recession.
The year's decline reflected four months of declining sales from August through November. Many analysts said that the drops reflected worries over job and income growth and high levels of consumer debt, and that these concerns offset falling mortgage rates.
But in January, 30-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.03 percent, down from more than 9 percent a year earlier and the lowest since February 1994. That meant a saving of $140 a month for home buyers as the monthly payment on a $100,000 mortgage fell from $805 to $665.
Still, rates have been edging up since then and averaged 7.38 percent last Thursday -- before the Government reported a big increase in the number of new jobs that sent long-term rates higher.
"The housing sector is extremely sensitive to upticks in mortgage rates and this can certainly inhibit activity going forward," said David Lereah an economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association.
But Mr. Lereah was skeptical about the size of the January sales increase, noting that existing-home sales -- more than 80 percent of the total -- fell for the fourth straight month.
And David F. Seiders, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders, was troubled by the number of unsold new homes, which he said could cause builders to cut back or lower profit margins in an attempt to sell off the large inventories.
The seasonally adjusted estimate of new houses for sale at the end of January was 381,000, representing a supply of 6.7 months at the current sales rate. It was the largest since a 390,000 backlog in January 1980.
The median price of a new home was $128,900, down from $136,000 in December but above the $127,900 price a year earlier. The median is the midpoint, meaning half of the homes cost more and half cost less.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drifts Lower as Possibility Of Rate Cut in Germany Fades

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar failed to take advantage of recoveries in American stock and bond markets yesterday, drifting lower as a strengthening German economy changed the possibility of an interest rate cut there.
The dollar fell in light trading against the German mark and the Japanese yen as investors questioned their assumptions about the dollar's prospects following the plunges in stocks and bonds on Friday. 
 A German report issued yesterday showed industrial production rising there, and that helped dispel thoughts of any imminent reduction in German rates.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar slipped to 105.41 yen from 105.72 yen on Friday. The dollar was changing hands at 1.4807 marks, down from 1.4840 marks. The British pound rose to $1.5241 from $1.5235.
Friday's selloffs in stocks and bonds came after the Labor Department reported more than 700,000 jobs were created in February. The surprisingly strong number undermined the markets' expectations that the Federal Reserve would need to cut short-term interest rates to stimulate the economy. But the assumption that the Fed would hold rates steady bolstered the dollar on Friday.
"A lot of people wondered why on Friday, when we had the kind of fireworks we had in the bond market, why the currency didn't do more," said Lisa Finstrom, senior currency analyst at Smith Barney.
A similar shift in expectations about German interest rates occurred yesterday, after a report showed that industrial production in Germany rose 1.6 percent in January from December, and was up 2.2 percent from a year earlier.
This was accompanied by comments by a German central banker who said that given the rise in German bond yields it would be hard for the Bundesbank to lower interest rates further.
In Japan, where the central bank has been supporting a stronger dollar and trying to end its four-year recession, a report showed that country had its first current account deficit in five years -- after expecting a surplus.
That kind of weakness might make Japanese companies -- in an effort to improve their results -- sell more American bonds than usual at the end of Japan's fiscal year on March 31, Ms. Finstrom of Smith Barney said.

HEADLINE: Gaming on Wall Street

BYLINE: By Martin Mayer; Martin Mayer is a guest scholar at the Brookings Institution.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Today, the one sure tip in the stock market is to buy any company that is about to be added to the Standard & Poor's 500. The market is full of mutual and pension funds and bank trust departments that must buy stock in every company on that 500. Each time a company is chosen to replace one that has merged or gone bust, there is a sizeable demand for its stock, even if it has just published a lousy earnings report.
Increasingly, the stock market itself has become just another commodity -- as its recent volatility has shown. Instead of buying the stocks of individual companies, based on earnings and performance, increasing numbers of investors buy or sell "the market." Yesterday's rise on Wall Street, like Friday's fall, shows how much the market moves on bits and pieces of information far removed from the realities of business. 
 In the old days, the Wall Street credo was to buy on the rumor and sell on the news. The winner was the guy who bucked the tide. But in commodities markets the message was the opposite: The trend is your friend. Now that the stock market has become a commodity, speculators pile on whenever some report creates excitement.
The larger players use mathematical models that mix purchases and sales of stocks, index futures contracts and options in patterns that guarantee a return as safe as the interest on Treasury bills and somewhat -- maybe considerably -- higher. One strategy involves "dynamic hedging" -- selling in the futures or options markets when prices are falling and buying when prices are rising, which exaggerates all price movements.
The commoditization of the market has also undone the traditional reverse symmetry between stock and bond prices. Historically, when economic activity was expected to increase, stocks rose in anticipation of better profits, and bonds fell in anticipation of higher interest rates. When economic activity was expected to decline, stocks fell and bonds rose.
Thus in early 1987 the optimism that propelled the stock market depressed the bond market. When that optimism vanished in October, stocks plummeted but bonds jumped. The pension funds and balanced mutual funds that held both stocks and bonds lost very little in the market crash.
But the mathematics used in trading today's index funds emphasizes interest rate changes. Thus the stock and bond markets now tend to move together. On Friday, bonds suffered even more than the stocks. Only after the bond futures market closed for the day did stocks recover some part of their losses.
John Maynard Keynes once observed that businessmen who consider themselves paragons of common sense are usually slaves to the ideas of some dead economist. Today the economist is more likely to be alive, but the dangers remain. The big players in the markets are disciples of finance economists -- and finance economics is about making money, not about producing anything.
Because stock prices and production now have so little to do with one another, the 1987 crash did not slow the growth of the real economy. The slowdown in 1995, when downsizing actually reduced productivity, spawned a bull market.
It is not clear how much harm has been done by the hypertrophy of the markets. But the fact that a rising market no longer causes Americans to think the economy is improving is a clear indication that the markets have become less effective as a stimulus to real capital creation.
An even greater problem is that we have sold more than half a trillion dollars of our national debt to foreign banks to keep the dollar strong when interest rates are low. Foreign borrowing will eventually influence all securities prices, but the computers are programmed to ignore it. Too many our most able and perceptive young analysts have moved from problem solving in the real world to gaming in the financial world.
Our markets and our political discourse focus increasingly on the immediate, reducing our ability to understand the larger forces that act on the economy. And people who don't understand what they're doing are always susceptible to panic.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: As West Booms, Suburbanites Ask If Wild Horses Make Good Neighbors

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: RENO

 BODY:
For longer than anyone can remember, wild horses have come down from the hills here every fall, grazing amid the sagebrush just outside this high desert city until they return to their summer range in the mountains.
The horses' winter home, Hidden Valley, has in recent years turned into a residential enclave southeast of town, by the dry Virginia Range and far from downtown Reno. Here, residents have long enjoyed the seasonal migration, some feeding carrots and apples to the animals, others counting and naming members of the herds, watching them grow, play and start their own families. 
 "They're beautiful creatures, just beautiful," said Jean Carr, as several of the dark mustangs frolicked around her in the street the other day.
But the valley is no longer so hidden. As fast as sagebrush can be bulldozed, thickets of houses are rising up and suburban instincts colliding with feral ones. Those not so enamored of the horses, which nibble at lawns and stomp on sprinklers, have chased them off the country club in golf carts, thrown rocks at them and even fired guns into the air to frighten them away. Last year, a motorist accidentally struck a stallion that had been gamboling in the street, and veterinarians had to kill it.
Tom Clark, a real estate broker who has lived in the area for 22 years, said that each year there seemed to be more horses staying longer. He worries that the dark-colored animals are a safety hazard in a neighborhood with no street lights. And he blames people who feed and pet the horses for making them too comfortable around homes and then becoming angry when other residents try to drive the mustangs off their lawns.
"I'm not saying, 'Send them to the slaughterhouse,' " he said. "But if they eventually wind up in a horse burger factory, so be it. Is it better for them to hang around a residential area and get spooked every couple of hours?"
There appears to be a concensus that the horses, which run in three bands and total about two dozen, pose a problem, but there is little agreement on a solution. No government agency claims direct responsibility for them. One group of residents wants to build a fence to keep the horses in the hills; another wants to round them up and sell them to the highest bidder.
"They're not really anyone's responsibility, and that's a problem," said Maxine Shane, a spokeswoman for the Federal Bureau of Land Management, which protects wild horses on public ranges but not on private property.
With about 35,600 wild steeds roaming the fast-growing mountain states, the problem of the Hidden Valley horses is snapshot of the changing West: a clash between the region's cowboy heritage and a booming regional economy.
No state has more wild horses than Nevada, where about 22,200 wander the hills that break up the vast desert plains here. So well have the mustangs, descendants of the beasts brought by Spanish several centuries ago, taken to the terrain that the Federal land bureau regularly thins out the population. Last year, the bureau captured 5,600 horses in Nevada and sold them people around the country at $125 a head.
But when wild horses wander onto private property, they become the problem of the the State Division of Agriculture, which takes custody of horses captured by people on their property. The state authorities hold those horses for 10 days. Unclaimed horses are sold at auction. Last year 25 such animals were sold at auction in Nevada.
"These horses generally fall through the cracks," said Steve Mahoney, the chief of the state livestock identification bureau. "Nobody wants them. More often than not they go to a commercial buyer, and they probably end up going to slaughter."
During their summer romp in the mountains, the horses are watched by the Virginia Range Wildlife Protection Association, a nonprofit group that manages the horse population on over 37,000 acres of private land within the range but has no control over the animals when they descend into lower areas like Hidden Valley.
In 1990 mustang lovers formed the Hidden Valley Wild Horse Task Force and the next year raised $16,000 to help pay for the removal and adoption of 50 horses. But more horses soon replaced them, and the community cannot agree on how to handle the animals.
Ms. Carr, a member of the task force, has suggested building a fence, which her group estimates would cost about $35,000, to keep the horses from coming into the neighborhood. The plan would also require that food and water be lugged into the hills, which task force members have done during the recent drought anyway.
"We'd lose the beauty of our horses, but at least they'd be safe, and that's what we're after," Ms. Carr said.
But Mr. Clark, the real estate broker, does not want the fence, which he said would be too expensive, take too long to build and be too hard to maintain. He said it would also keep residents from biking or hiking as easily as they do now in the hills.
"It's a residential area," Mr. Clark said. "It shouldn't have horses wandering around."
This time of year many of the ranch-style homes, each of which sits on at least a third of an acre, are tied up with ropes and makeshift fences to keep the horses away. One fence is even topped with barbed wire.
None of this seemed to bother a nine-horse band chewing on grass at the edge of the neighborhood on a bitter cold morning recently. When Bobbi Royle, who runs Wild Horse Spirit, a nonprofit organization outside Reno that tries to protect mustangs, drove up in her pick-up, she was engulfed by the horses, which quickly began munching on bales of alfalfa in the back of the truck.
A hazel foal, a month old and friendly as a puppy, gnawed on Betty Kelly's coat sleeve. "You're so beautiful," cooed Ms. Kelly, who lives in the neighborhood.
But the dulcet tones gave way to growls when the future of the horses came up.
"I'd rather get rid of the people that don't like them," Ms. Kelly said. "It would be a beautiful neighborhood then."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Regain About a Third From Selloff

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved sharply higher yesterday and recouped about a third of the selloff on Friday, as buyers, sensing an oversold condition, moved back into the market looking for value.
Traders said hedge funds were buying two- and five-year notes, which had a positive effect on the long end of the market. The price of a 30-year bond rebounded almost two full points in early trading, signaling strongly that Friday's close was at least temporarily the market's price bottom. 
 The bellwether 30-year Treasury bond rose 11/32, to a price of 91 27/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, fell to 6.63 percent, down nine basis points from 6.72 percent on Friday. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Earlier, the bond market largely overlooked a strong housing report in the morning, which caused only a minor price dip. Some analysts regarded the market's resiliency as a return to a degree of rationality that was not displayed last week.
As early momentum for the market, Anthony Dwyer, chief market strategist for Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, cited near-term short-covering by speculators who had bet that prices would continue to drop yesterday. They were forced instead to cover those bets, buying securities to repay the borrowed ones they had sold.
Mr. Dwyer said he interpreted the market's performance yesterday as indicating that investors believe "there will be a rebound in the economy, but with no clue as to how strong will that rebound be."
"And at this point," Mr. Dwyer said, "despite the large employment number, my opinion is it will be a moderate one.
"While we anticipate bond trading to remain volatile over the near term," he continued, "it will take a couple more months of data to determine a major move in either direction." Among the data to be reported are producer prices on Thursday and consumer prices and industrial production on Friday. Next week the market will also get a look at February retail sales.
Contemplating the strong market reaction Friday to an employment report that seemed to dash hopes of an interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve, James Hale, fixed-income analyst at MMS International in San Francisco, said that "Friday's slaughter leaves many in the market wondering if any one government report is worth 25 to 40 basis points of yield in Treasury securities since Bureau of Labor statistics are often more an art form than a science."
While the employment number was strong, Mr. Hale noted, it would be wise to be cautious. A policy forecast is probably not warranted on this single report. "The selloff was so overdone on Friday that investors can probably find solid value," he said, "particularly in the short-dated notes."
Mr. Hale said that yesterday's report on single-family home sales for January, which showed a rise of 4.2 percent, was strong, but not strong enough to confirm the belief that the economy is so robust that the Fed will not be cutting rates any time soon.
"The report was received with relief since it didn't show the extraordinary deviance that Friday's employment report did," he said.
Yesterday's auction of three- and six-month Treasury bills drew only lukewarm demand at an average rate of 4.95 percent for the three-month, up six basis points, from last week and 5 percent for the six-month maturity, up 20 basis points.
Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, noted that investors had the weekend to think over Friday's jobs number and the market's reaction. Emotional market downdrafts like the one last week are opportunities, he added.
"Bonds will have a tough time rallying back to 6 percent, but 6.70 percent bonds and 2.75 percent inflation don't go together," he said. "We would still be bond buyers." He predicts any easing by the Fed will be delayed, but not canceled.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Transit Authority Is Planning To Cut 800 More Token Clerks

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
The Transit Authority plans to cut 800 more token booth clerks from New York City subway stations, slashing their ranks by a third, over the next two years as it goes ahead with its electronic fare collection program, officials said yesterday.
The cuts are part of a five-year plan to cut $2.4 billion from the Transit Authority's budget. Yesterday, commuters began feeling the impact of the loss of 125 token booth clerks as part of a previously planned reduction, which left some of the city's busiest stations with only one clerk at rush hour. 
 Officials said they hoped that they could carry out the future cuts painlessly with expansion of the Metrocard program, which would reduce the need for token clerks. While the Metrocard program has encountered many obstacles, transit officials say they hope to outfit all 463 subway stations with the turnstiles that accept the cards by 1997. The Metrocard is already accepted for the Transit Authority's 3,600 buses.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Transit Authority's parent agency, wants to broaden the Metrocard program beyond the subway and buses. Officials have been touting it as an all-purpose card that can be used to buy everything from groceries to newspapers. They hope to generate millions of dollars from those alternate uses.
Yesterday, at some of the city's busier stations, commuters were already chafing at the loss of clerks under the smaller, previously announced reductions.
"This is ridiculous," said James Thompson, 37, standing in line at the Eighth Avenue subway station at 34th Street. "Service is getting worse while we keep paying more. It simply does not make any sense."
Charles Seaton, a Transit Authority spokesman, said the reductions were part of an effort to make the transit system more efficient in the face of deep cuts in state and Federal aid. "What we're trying to do is use our resources more intelligently and we're also trying to use them more economically," Mr. Seaton said. "It's necessary that we do make cuts to meet our budget, and this is one area that we have chosen."
The reductions come in the wake of a 25-cent fare increase -- from $1.25, to $1.50 -- that was imposed last November. That increase preceded a reduction in the number of trains for 11 lines, which has meant longer waits and more crowded trains for some commuters. In addition, train maintenance and cleaning have been cut back.
Gene Russianoff, a lawyer with the Straphangers Campaign, a transit advocacy group, questioned whether the Transit Authority was being realistic in trying to cut the number of token booth clerks so deeply. He said that the Metrocard was available at only 164 of 468 subway stations and that some riders could not afford to buy tokens in large quantities, as the Transit Authority has suggested.
"It's like a let-them-eat-token attitude," Mr. Russianoff said. "We're cutting service and the solution is for you to buy more tokens, and that's not possible for a lot of people."
While transit officials are encouraging people to buy tokens in bulk to deal with the current cuts, they are also considering phasing out the 10-pack tokens next month, a move transit officials said would save $1 million. The 125 token booth clerks whose jobs were phased out yesterday are expected to save the Transit Authority $5 million a year.
Yesterday, long lines kept commuters waiting at several stations affected by the cuts. Many booths previously staffed by two clerks had one person handling several tasks, including selling tokens, giving directions and buzzing through people with special passes.
At the narrow South Ferry station, passengers were surprised to find only one clerk at the booth. "It does not make any sense to have one token booth clerk in such a heavily used area," said Aaron Bryant, who lives on Governors Island. "First a fare increase, and now this."
"It's almost impossible to get on line," said Barbara Kent, who had just come off the Staten Island ferry and was on her way to work.
Yesterday, a transit worker stood by the service gate of the South Ferry station, opening and closing the door for passengers with baby carriages and others who cannot go through the turnstiles.
But Audrey Mosley-Marcus, the station manager, said the worker was there simply to try to make sure things went smoothly on this first day without the extra clerk.
She said that yesterday she received at least 20 complaints from passengers about delays. All of last year, said Ms. Mosley-Marcus, who is also the station manager for three other stations in the area, only two people complained.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Token buyers lined up yesterday at the South Ferry subway station, where only one clerk was working. The Transit Authority is reducing the number of subway token clerks as part of its budget-cutting efforts. (Philip Greenberg for The New York Times) (pg. B3)

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeking Tougher Sanctions To Press Nigeria for Democracy

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has circulated a proposal for strong new economic sanctions intended to force the Nigerian military Government to move toward democracy. But the proposal has received a cool reception from several European countries, according to diplomats, officials and American business representatives watching the negotiations.
The United States has asked industrial countries to join it in banning all new foreign investment in Nigeria and in freezing financial assets that the country's leaders may have in their banks. It also wants them to halt joint sporting events once this summer's Olympic Games are over and to ban Government-sponsored cultural contacts. 
 The Administration has ruled out for the time being any embargo against Nigeria's oil exports, currently running at about 1.8 million barrels a day, which provide the Government with 90 percent of its foreign exchange earnings. About 40 percent of Nigeria's prized low-sulphur crude is bought by American companies. Just yesterday, Royal Dutch/Shell confirmed it had made a potentially significant oil discovery off the Nigerian coast. [Page A8.]
The proposals have not been announced by the Administration, as it gauges the willingness of its allies to cooperate. It is not clear whether the United States will carry out some of the penalties on its own if that support does not appear.
"We believe in multilateral action, but we haven't ruled anything out," one Administration official said today when asked about the possibility that the United States would proceed alone.
Administration officials say the proposed new sanctions are intended to show Nigeria's rulers that the West is serious about pressing for a rapid return to democracy. They would follow a number of measures taken against Nigeria by the United States, Europe and the Commonwealth countries last year after the execution of Ken Saro-Wiwa, the Ogoni writer and human rights activist.
"The package is supposed to establish our seriousness prior to re-engaging the military regime in order to secure a speedy passage to democracy," an Administration official said. Gen. Sani Abacha, the military leader, has promised to hand over power to civilians in 1998. But the military annulled Nigeria's last elections in 1993.
Last week the State Department listed Nigeria as a major human rights abuser in its annual human rights report.
Imposing new sanctions against Nigeria would win President Clinton praise from human rights groups and liberal black organizations that have been critical of the Nigerian Government. But it would be fiercely opposed by big business, and many companies that operate in Africa have already spoken out against the idea.
European governments, which were presented with the plan about 10 days ago, are not expected to deliver their formal replies for a week or so. But diplomats say several of them -- including Britain, France and the Netherlands, all of which have substantial business interests in Nigeria -- are not enthusiastic.
These countries contend that blocking new foreign investment, which totaled $1.95 billion in 1994, according to the World Bank, would merely deliver another blow to the crumbling economy of a deeply impoverished country where the annual average income is a mere $280.
It would not, they say, affect its notoriously corrupt military rulers, who would still have more than $10 billion a year in oil revenues.
While it is unclear how new investment would be defined under the American plan, several foreign oil and gas companies are currently engaged in major new Nigerian projects, which they declined to cancel or postpone after Mr. Saro-Wiwa's execution.
A consortium of British, Dutch, French and Italian oil companies led by the Royal Dutch/Shell Group has just signed a contract to build a $3.8 billion natural gas liquefication plant at Bonny, in eastern Nigeria. The Mobil Corporation is also engaged in a new $800 million offshore natural gas project due to start production in 1997.
And Shell confirmed yesterday that it had made a potentially significant oil discovery in deep water off the Niger Delta.
American corporations with interests in Nigeria are also campaigning hard against the Administration's sanctions plan. Last year the Corporate Council on Africa, which represents 80 firms doing business there, said "economic growth provides the best foundation for any successful transition to democratic government" and warned that "a collapsing Nigerian economy serves no one's interests, especially not the 100 million Nigerians."
The National Foreign Trade Council, which represents 500 American multinational corporations, has also come out publicly against economic sanctions on Nigeria.
And about 100 American business representatives made their views known personally to the Under Secretary of State for Economic, Business and Agricultural Affairs, Joan Spiro, at a special State Department meeting called on March 6 to discuss the Administration's use of economic sanctions, participants said.
Many European countries are also not enthusiastic about freezing Nigerian bank accounts and other financial assets. Britain, France and Germany are traditionally reluctant to take any action that might damage their position as international financial centers.
With China unlikely to allow the United Nations Security Council to impose an immediate asset freeze, blocking Nigerian funds in British banks would require a special act of Parliament. While Parliament prepared and voted on such a new law, Nigeria's leaders would have ample time to move their funds to safer havens
European diplomats contend that the American move also risks splitting the unified stand that the United States and the 15 European Union members have taken toward Nigeria recently. After Mr. Saro-Wiwa's execution, the European Union joined the United States in denying visas to prominent Nigerians, banning sales of arms and withdrawing their ambassadors from Nigeria, though these have now returned.
At the same time the Commonwealth suspended Nigeria's membership for two years and asked a multiracial group of foreign ministers to seek a firm commitment to democracy from its leaders and report back this spring.
So far, however, Nigeria's leaders have refused to receive the Commonwealth team. "If we fire all our ammunition now we won't have anything left when the Commonwealth mission reports," one diplomat said.

HEADLINE: DOW LEAPS 110.55 AS STOCKS RECOUP MUCH OF SELLOFF

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
After taking a weekend to reflect on the worst percentage decline in the Dow Jones industrial average in four years, the stock market yesterday rode a wave of buying from mutual funds and other managers of large pools of investments to its strongest gain in almost two years, retracing nearly two-thirds of the ground it lost on Friday.
Enamored of the opportunity to pick up many of their favorite stocks at deep discounts from the levels of only a week ago, investors bought stocks across the board, pushing the Dow industrials up 110.55 points, or 2 percent, to 5,581.00. Bond prices, the catalyst for Friday's sharp market declines, also rose. 
 "Friday was the day the traders acted," said Alfred Kugel, senior investment strategist at Stein Roe & Farnham, a Chicago mutual fund company, referring to Wall Street professionals who try to capitalize on minute-by-minute movements in the prices of stocks and bonds. But after Friday's decline, he said, "we had a lot of money come into our mutual funds, and we made a decision to put a significant amount of it to work today."
Indeed, individual investors appeared to cling to the notion that every sharp dip in stock prices is merely another buying opportunity. Mutual fund companies across the country reported a surge in inquiries from customers over the weekend and through yesterday's trading session, and several said that buyers outweighed sellers.
But while average Americans seemed not to believe that Friday's selloff signaled the start of a bear market in stocks, a large number of them are likely to pay more attention to one factor that has not been as present in other recent sharp stock market declines -- a jump in interest rates.
Yet another sign of a strengthening economy, which caused the markets to shudder so badly on Friday, appeared yesterday when the Commerce Department reported that nationwide sales of new homes were stronger than expected in January, despite a sharp blizzard-related decrease in the Northeast.
While the financial markets shrugged off the news, consumers did not. At the midtown Manhattan office of the discount stockbroker Charles Schwab & Company, Jesse Maiurano had a single purpose in setting up a new brokerage account: selling stocks to raise money for the down payment on a new house.
"I'm trying to buy it before interest rates go up too far," said Mr. Maiurano, a 50-year-old staff director in the real estate planning department of Nynex. "I still have some money invested in stocks for the long term, but I want to hurry to make a decision before rates get out of hand."
Interest rates fell yesterday as the bond market rebounded from Friday's drubbing. Bond prices and yields move in opposite directions, and the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond, a closely watched harbinger of consumer rates, declined to 6.63 percent from 6.72 percent on Friday.
But that did not keep home mortgage rates from jumping sharply. At the Emigrant Savings Bank on East 42d Street in Manhattan, where the rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage is posted each day at noon, the rate jumped to 7.625 percent yesterday from 7.5 percent on Friday.
That continues a general trend of rising consumer interest rates that has lasted for close to a month. Those interest rates have climbed because many bond market investors fear that the Federal Reserve will not lower short-term interest rates amid signs of growth in the economy.
Until Friday, there remained enough investors who thought the opposite -- that is, that a recession loomed and that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates to keep the economy moving.
Now, some economists say they expect a general pickup in economic activity to continue, at least for several months, which at the least will stretch out the current period of uncertainty. Kenneth Safian of Safian Investment Research in White Plains said he did not expect interest rates to decline much, if at all, "until we see signs that this rebound is slowing up."
While Mr. Safian said he did expect such a slowing toward midyear, he added that the financial markets were churning much more violently than the underlying economy. That uncertainty is itself bad news. "I've never seen such a trading orientation on the part of institutional investors," Mr. Safian said. "I don't view that as a favorable development."
More volatility might lie ahead, as well, as additional economic data are released later in the week. On Thursday, the February Producer Price Index, a measure of the prices that manufacturers and farmers charge for the products they sell to retailers, distributors or other buyers, will be released, followed on Friday by the Consumer Price Index, a similar measure of costs of goods and services for individuals and households.
Befitting an environment of economic growth, investors yesterday were particularly eager to buy cyclical stocks, or stocks that tend to mirror the fortunes of the economy. Automobile, airline and other transportation-related stocks in particular gained favor, and the Dow Jones transportation index rose 2.8 percent.
Yesterday's percentage gain in the Dow Jones industrial average was the best since April 5, 1994, and followed the average's worst percentage decline since Nov. 15, 1991. Yesterday's 2 percent rise in the Dow industrials, however, overstates the strength of the overall market. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 6.52 points, or 1.03 percent, to 640.02, while the Nasdaq composite index jumped 16.77 points, or 1.58 percent, to 1,080.50.
Some institutional investors continue to believe that yesterday's activity is a sign that what lies ahead for investors is more of what they saw before Friday's rout -- a continuing period of low interest rates and slow economic growth.
"We've seen the amount of a correction that we're going to see," said Richard Froehlich, chief investment strategist at Van Kampen/American Capital, a mutual fund and investment company. "I think the market will continue to be strong for the rest of the year."
If the economic numbers later this week give further indications of economic strength, "we might step back and take a closer look," Mr. Froehlich said. "But you don't throw out six months of analysis and economic trends showing sluggishness because of two days of data."
In that respect, institutional investors might take a lesson from smaller investors, who over the weekend gave no indication of wanting to bail out of the stock market.
"For a long-term investor, last Friday was not a big deal," said Glenn Dames, who visited the Fidelity Investments brokerage office in Rockefeller Center on his lunch hour yesterday. Mr. Dames said he was about to make his final payment on his home mortgage, and with the additional discretionary income that would provide, "I think the stock market is the best place to put my money."
Indeed, enough investors thought so yesterday to send nearly twice as many stocks to gains as declined. Among the best performers in the Dow industrials were two cyclical stocks, Alcoa and Union Carbide, whose fortunes usually track trends in the general economy and each of which rose 4.7 percent over the last two trading sessions. Yesterday, Alcoa rose 3 3/8, to 61 1/2, and Union Carbide rose 2 3/8, to 47 5/8.
Shares of automobile makers, which depend on economic growth and consumer confidence for rising sales, also climbed sharply yesterday. General Motors added 1 3/4, to 52 5/8; Ford Motor rose 1 1/8, to 32 3/8, and Chrysler gained 2 3/8, to 60 1/4.
Technology stocks were among the strongest industry groups, with shares of companies that manufacture semiconductors inching up before the release this afternoon of the industry's book-to-bill ratio, a key indicator of demand for computer chips. The statistic had been scheduled for release yesterday. Intel, the largest semiconductor maker and the most active stock in American markets yesterday, trading 9.4 million shares, rose 1 3/4, to 55 1/4, while Texas Instruments added 3/4, to 50, and Motorola moved up 3/8, to 53 3/8.

HEADLINE: Fidelity Shifts Management At 26 of Its Mutual Funds

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
In one of the largest management shifts in its history, Fidelity Investments, the country's largest mutual fund company, is reassigning 26 of its equity-portfolio managers in an effort to improve the performance of the funds.
The Boston-based company, which manages some $560 billion in assets and is a unit of the FMR Corporation, announced the changes yesterday as part of a major overhaul of how it handles investment responsibility for its domestic and international stock funds. In addition to shuffling managers at almost a third of its stock funds on April 1, Fidelity is dividing its funds into smaller groups and assigning each one a group leader. 
 "It really is a natural evolution," said William J. Hayes, Fidelity's director of equity investments. As Fidelity attracted more assets and developed new funds, he said, it found it needed to reorganize its 87 stock funds into more workable groups linked to specific investment objectives.
While Mr. Hayes played down the notion that the changes were a response to disappointing performance among any of the company's 87 stock funds, analysts think the move reflects the insistence of Fidelity on delivering superior returns and the need to have more controls over its funds.
"Last year, it was the bond funds; this year, it is the stock funds," said Eric Kobren, the editor of Fidelity Insight, an independent newsletter in Wellesley Hills, Mass., that tracks the company's funds. "Ned Johnson is famous for stirring up the pot," he said, referring to Fidelity's chairman and chief executive, Edward C. Johnson 3d.
Fidelity is leaving Jeffrey Vinik as the portfolio manager of its $56 billion Magellan Fund. Magellan, the company's biggest fund, gained 36.8 percent last year, handily beating most of its competitors in the growth-fund sector.
Still, the managerial changes include several important shifts. Among the most significant is the removal of Robert A. Beckwitt as manager of the Fidelity Asset Manager Fund, an $11 billion fund that divides its assets among different types of stocks and bonds.
Despite Mr. Beckwitt's spectacular performance in the early 1990's, the fund stumbled badly in 1994, losing 7 percent, when Mr. Beckwitt made wrong bets on emerging markets. The fund was only an average performer in 1995, gaining 18 percent.
Under the reorganization, the responsibility for Asset Manager and two smaller asset-allocation funds that were managed by Mr. Beckwitt will now be divided among four different managers, including George Vanderheiden, the successful manager of the Destiny funds. Mr. Vanderheiden will oversee the stock portion of the funds, in addition to continuing to run his previous funds.
Mr. Beckwitt has been reassigned to Fidelity's Portfolio Advisory Services, which is geared to providing investment services to high-net-worth individuals.
Asset Manager "has not been a disaster by any stretch," Mr. Kobren said. He said that investors had a hard time understanding Mr. Beckwitt's investment strategy, which involved sometimes buying exotic securities and making bets on broad economic trends rather than simply investing in a more usual mix of stocks and bonds.
Other significant manager changes include the removal of Robert Haber as head of the Fidelity Balanced Fund, a $5 billion fund that has also had disappointing performance in the last few years. Stephen R. Petersen, the manager of the Fidelity Equity-Income Fund, will also assume management of the Balanced Fund.
Mr. Haber has been named the new head of Fidelity's equity-research department. "He's been a mentor to many, many fund managers over the years," Mr. Kobren said.
In another change, Daniel R. Frank, the manager of Fidelity Advisor Strategic Opportunities, was replaced as of yesterday. Mr. Frank, who became the subject of controversy recently when he lobbied several hospitals to use a product marketed by a company in which he had invested, is the only manager who has been replaced but not reassigned to a new position yet, Mr. Hayes said. Mr. Frank remains an employee of the firm, but has been replaced by Harris Leviton, the former manager of Retirement Growth.
"There's not a lot of tolerance for mistakes," said John Rekenthaler, the publisher of Morningstar Mutual Funds, the Chicago research firm, said of Fidelity. "They seem to be even less tolerant than they were a decade ago."
The firm's stock funds will be divided into eight groups, depending on their specific investment objective. While Mr. Hayes emphasized that portfolio managers would have no less responsibility in making investment decisions than before, the groups will let managers share ideas with one another more easily.
"With so many funds out there, they had to rethink the structure of the investment groups," Mr. Kobren said. "This type of slicing and dicing will offer these fund managers a more efficient use of their time."
"They're trying to define their funds more precisely," Mr. Reken thaler said. "It will force a little more discipline on some of those funds."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Hong Kong Stocks Plunge 7.3%, Rattled by U.S. Bond Prices and China

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, March 11

 BODY:
As Hong Kong's stock market spiraled precipitously lower amid worries of war over Taiwan and over American interest rates, a mood of anxiety settled over this territory today.
In the four days since China fired three ballistic missiles into waters off Taiwan's two major ports, the volume of oratory and the pace of armed buildup have rapidly mounted. On Saturday, China announced that it would begin a week of live-fire military exercises over 6,000 square miles of the South China Sea off the coastline of Taiwan. This was followed today by news that the United States was sending two aircraft-carrier battle groups to the region. 
 And Hong Kong, a spit of land and islands clinging to the massive Chinese mainland, is spooked.
"I think it would be naive to be too complacent about the situation," said John M. Mulcahy, managing director at UBS Securities here. "The reality is that military situations that escalate in this way can all too easily tip over the edge."
"Over the last few days, I've noticed a sharper edge in the contretemps between China and Taiwan, and in the views of Hong Kong," he said. "People are worried that the fallout for Hong Kong, if there is a regional conflict, would be devastating. Hong Kong will be one of the immediate victims of that."
China maintains that Taiwan is a rebellious province and has pledged that it would take military action to prevent any move toward independence. President Lee Teng-hui -- who is seeking another term on March 23 in the island's first direct, popular vote for president, and is expected to win in a landslide -- has built his campaign and career on promises to expand Taiwan's international presence. He has succeeded in this while always stopping short of suggesting that he would push for a formal declaration of independence.
The rising military tension in the South China Sea late last week made Hong Kong's stock market, a skittish animal in the best of times, ripe for panic. And Wall Street's tumble Friday provided the catalyst.
In a knee-jerk reaction to the 3.04 percent slide in the Dow Jones industrial average and similar drops in other American stock indexes, the Hong Kong market went into free fall. By the end of the day, the benchmark Hang Seng index sank 820.34 points to close at 10,397.45, or 7.31 percent, its second-worst drop ever and more than double that on Wall Street. At the day's low, the index was down more than 8 percent.
[Hong Kong stocks bounced back somewhat by Tuesday afternoon, recouping 259.85 points, or 2.5 percent, to stand at 10,657.30.]
Last Friday's bloodletting in New York spilled over into financial markets almost everywhere, but the carnage was much worse in Hong Kong -- both because of the military posturing and because the Hong Kong dollar's exchange value is linked to the American dollar. American interest rates play a big part in the financial markets here, too.
In the absence of such factors in Tokyo, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues fell, but more modestly, losing 359.58 points, or 1.78 percent, to close today at 19,796.29. [Japanese stocks also erased some losses on Tuesday, with the Nikkei rising 153.98 points, or almost eight-tenths of 1 percent, to close at 19,950.27.]
Major European stock indexes declined somewhat today, too: 0.96 percent in London, 1.19 percent in Frankfurt and 1.35 percent in Paris.
Even on Taiwan, the target of Chinese anger, the market's losses were restrained in comparison with those in Hong Kong, with the Taipei index off 2 percent.
Here, the mood was anything but upbeat.
"We are worrying about this getting hotter," said Ting-ko Chen, a senior executive vice president of the Charoen Pokphand group, a Thai conglomerate that is one of the heaviest foreign investors in China. "We're hoping for no military conflict. But certainly, this is having an effect on people's minds."
Mr. Chen said that investment in "the 1,2,3 area" -- China, Taiwan and Hong Kong -- had been down in the last year, anyway. But now, he said, the escalation of military tension in the region would dampen the enthusiasm of investors even further, at least until the political-military situation stabilized.
While that remains unpredictable, some regional analysts think the chances of conflict are small. Robert Broadfoot, managing director of Political and Economic Risk Consultancy Ltd., offered odds of 80-20 on a positive outcome of the current standoff. While he could envision a worst case, in which the United States thwarted a Chinese blockade of Taiwan, touching off a flight of people and capital from the island, he said he believed that a happier outcome was more likely.
"After the presidential election, the Taiwanese will try very hard to reopen negotiations with China," said Mr. Broadfoot, who advises major companies that want to invest in Asian facilities and services. "If things go favorably, you're going to see joint ventures between Chinese state companies and Taiwan companies -- what you don't see now."
At Lehman Brothers, Miron Mushkat, chief economist for Asia, said it remained difficult to disentangle the factors behind the plunge in Hong Kong's stock market. Concern over American interest rates and worries about China and Taiwan "seem to be reinforcing one another," he said, moments before the market gasped to a close. "I think the impression here locally is that because of the Chinese saber-rattling and arm-twisting, the crisis has escalated to a level above expectations."
"And what complicates things is the fact that all this Chinese pressure is in vain," he said, referring to the surge in the polls for Mr. Lee's candidacy in Taiwan -- the opposite effect China has sought. "No one would like it to get out of hand. It will only take a junior field commander issuing wrong instructions for things to get out of hand. It's a factor in market behavior."
Even so, many economists here say that a certain measure of common sense may prevail in Beijing. "China recognizes that its most important asset is the risk of conflict, rather than the conflict itself," Mr. Mulcahy of UBS said. "It has achieved a lot of objectives by forcing the independence movement to back away."
And, he added, it is not in China's interest to alienate the United States, one of its biggest trading partners. "At the end of the day," he said, "China still needs the U.S. from an economic standpoint."
