HEADLINE: Burbank: A Cinderella City Where Fantasy Pays the Bills

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: BURBANK, Calif.

 BODY:
Drive just outside the airport here on Thornton Street and look at an unmarked gray building where workers are busily tearing off the windowless walls, and one is face to face with how the economic pain brought by the end of the cold war is being transformed into Burbank's new promise.
Until six years ago, when the region was hit with tens of thousands of layoffs in the aerospace industry, and a punishing recession, the Lockheed Corporation was the biggest employer in this working-class city, and it designed its top-secret Stealth jet in the ominous gray box. 
 Lockheed is now all but gone, along with most of its jobs, but a $45 million renovation is turning the former design center into the harbinger of a new economic wave: the sunny home of a Walt Disney Company animation studio. It is, in fact, just one of dozens of such conversions here.
Long the butt of jokes by Johnny Carson, "beautiful downtown Burbank" was for years a metaphor for suburban dreariness. Even in the aerospace industry's heyday, the city, in the San Fernando Valley about 12 miles north of central Los Angeles, had a lifeless downtown, with no movie theaters and few restaurants. Burbank was regarded as a backwater, a follower of Los Angeles's glimmering lead.
No longer. Burbank, which has been associated with the movie industry for decades, is at the forefront of an economic transformation that is affecting Southern California and, in some regards, the country. The changes are based on the growth of new forms of entertainment, like computer games and CD-ROMs, the expansion of cable and satellite television, the international demand for American films, and the huge increase in the number of companies in the business.
The Burbank City Council is even debating an issue that would have seemed an impossible luxury just three or four years ago: Should it slow an expansion that has filled downtown with shoppers and prompted a construction boom?
Near the Burbank airport, for example, a former factory that made landing gears has been reborn as the Western Studio Service Company, a warehouse for sets and movie props. Warner Brothers is building an office in an old Dassault aerospace plant. MTV recently shot a special at a new studio next to another Lockheed property that developers might turn into a large shopping center.
Construction on more than one million square feet of office space is to begin this year, and nearly all of it is expected to be snapped up by film production and media companies at some of the highest rents in Los Angeles County, close to $30 a square foot.
"This is all being driven by the entertainment industry, and thank God for it," said Gregory K. Barsamian, an industrial real estate broker who recently pointed out the changes to a visitor, along with the hangar where he got his first job after college -- as a Lockheed engineer.
Burbank still lacks the cachet of nearby Glendale or Pasadena; its residential districts are more working class, even now. But the city is proud of its small-town feeling. Its streets are relatively safe, there is little graffiti, and the local newspaper, The Burbank Leader, is filled with articles about the fierce rivalry between high school football teams.
But its powerful commercial rebound is making the city the envy of Los Angeles County. Downtown is now bustling with a new Media City Center mall, a theater with more than a dozen screens, a huge Ikea store and a Virgin Megastore.
Ian Fagan, the owner of Byrne Home Furnishings on Magnolia Street, said that streets once nearly devoid of pedestrians were now thriving and that his business had grown sharply, in part because he is now renting furniture for movies.
"Ten years ago, you couldn't find a place to get a sandwich," Mr. Fagan said. "You could not watch a movie here. If you saw two people, it was a crowd. That has changed entirely."
The end of the cold war was devastating for Burbank and all of Los Angeles County. Since 1989, the county has lost more than 150,000 aerospace and other military-related jobs because of cuts in Pentagon spending, and no one expects them to return. Burbank, with a population of 94,000, lost nearly 14,000 jobs, many terminated when Lockheed, now Lockheed Martin, shut most of its operations and moved others.
But as of last year, Los Angeles County was finally growing again; Jack Kyser, the economist at the Los Angeles Economic Development Corporation, said that by the end of 1996, the county would have regained about 150,000 of the 510,000 jobs lost since 1990. The migration from Southern California, which had deepened the recession here and raised worries about a permanent decline, is expected to reverse this year.
Those trends have been led by Burbank, whose unemployment rate has now dropped to 5.3 percent, compared with 8.6 percent in Los Angeles and 5.6 percent nationally. This suburb has capitalized on the fact that it has been the home for a number of studios since the 1920's. It long ago surpassed Hollywood as a center for the industry, but employment growth had earlier been modest. Walt Disney, Warner Brothers and NBC, where Mr. Carson once held court, have studios here, in what is known as the Media District, while Universal Pictures is adjacent to Burbank's northern border.
The big studios have been forced to fight for the little available space in the Burbank market, and they are constructing more. Warner Brothers has a master plan that envisions the construction of 3.3 million square feet of studios and offices, while Disney's master plan would put the same combination on 1.8 million square feet. In the next 25 years, Universal Pictures plans to build a theme park, hotels, offices and studios covering 6 million square feet.
Commercial vacancy rates have dropped to about 4 percent in Burbank from 17 percent in 1989, said William Boyd of the CB Commercial Real Estate Group. That compares with a vacancy rate of nearly 20 percent in downtown Los Angeles, where rents cost about half as much.
The changes have gathered momentum quickly. M. David Paul, the developer who is renovating the old Lockheed design center for Disney's animators, was asked if he would have predicted such investments even three years ago. "Not a chance," Mr. Paul said.
The aerospace industry, which once employed nearly 300,000 workers in the county, now has about 133,000. Officially, the motion picture industry employs 129,300. But Mr. Kyser said that figure was about half of the actual number because the industry included thousands of small companies whose employees have not been counted.
"This industry seems to be growing like a house on fire," Mr. Kyser said.
Burbank's recovery from the painful loss of its military industries makes it, in certain important respects, a microcosm of trends that are affecting the entire country. Small businesses are replacing big corporations. Knowledge-intensive companies serving the new digital world are replacing manufacturers. The biggest employment gains are taking place in the suburbs rather than in the old city cores.
But there are still reminders of Burbank's cold-war legacy. Industrial solvents used by Lockheed and other companies have left the ground water badly polluted. The companies and the city have been forced to initiate a costly cleanup.
And some officials question the pace of growth now, concerned that it will alter the quality of life. The current focus of the debate is the airport, which is a great convenience for the movie industry. Planners have proposed a new terminal that would be twice as big as the current one. But several City Council members have said the expansion and added traffic would cause too much noise and disruption.
"The outlook is rosy for the city whether the airport is expanded or not," Councilman Bob Kramer said. "We have to protect our citizens first."
The good news, of course, is not being spread evenly in Los Angeles County. Long Beach, a port city at the opposite end of the county, has lost thousands of jobs from a McDonnell Douglas plant, and two Navy installations have been shut down. A plan for a big marine park planned by Disney, which the city had counted on, has been dropped.
Nevertheless, Long Beach has been helped by the rapid growth in another sector of the economy, foreign trade. Long Beach has become the nation's busiest container port.
It is clear, though, that Long Beach will lag behind Burbank for some time because of the flow of jobs the studios are attracting. For instance, the union local representing grips, or movie crew members, recently ended 50 years in Hollywood and moved to Burbank.
"It puts us right smack in the middle of the business," said Patrick Hoff, the local's chief financial officer. "We're just following the money."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Warner Brothers is one of the movie studios that has revitalized the economy of Burbank, replacing the aerospace jobs that once sustained the area. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Strike's Effect Widely Felt In Auto Plants

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 11

 BODY:
The effects of a week-old brake-factory strike rippled across North America today, with the General Motors Corporation's closing of 14 assembly plants and 16 parts plants from Chihuahua, Mexico, to Oshawa, Canada.
Today's layoffs turned the strike into the largest auto industry work stoppage in recent years, surpassing a 1992 strike at a G.M. parts factory in Lordstown, Ohio, that idled 43,000 workers at nine assembly plants. 
 The walkout by 3,200 members of the United Automobile Workers at two G.M. brake factories in Dayton, Ohio, idled 58,000 G.M. workers elsewhere today, as assembly plants ran out of brakes to install and stopped building cars and trucks. Companies across the continent that supply G.M. with parts also began reviewing today whether to shut down their operations.
The strike has halted production at nearly half of G.M.'s 29 assembly plants in North America and forced the furlough of a sixth of its North American work force. It is probably costing G.M. $30 million to $40 million a day, said Scott F. Merlis, an independent automobile-industry analyst in Westport, Conn.
G.M. began the strike with a very large inventory of cars and fairly large supplies of popular pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles. Spot shortages of some popular vehicles could develop if the strike continues. The strike has also delayed cars that customers order from factories.
Because G.M.'s operations are so vast and affect so many other industries, the strike already appears to have lasted long enough to have a small but measurable effect on the United States' overall economic output in the first quarter, said Paul D. Ballew, a longtime Federal Reserve economist who recently joined J. D. Power and Associates, an auto industry consulting firm.
Even if the strike ends quickly, G.M. may not be able to resume full production quickly. "It could take them a good week," Mr. Ballew said. "They've got to get Dayton back up and running, you've got to get parts back in the pipeline."
Despite the damage from the strike, union and company negotiators in Dayton have gone three days without even trying to hold talks. "There are none and there are none scheduled because we seem to be very far apart," said James M. Hagedon Jr., a G.M. spokesman. There were some informal contacts in Detroit between union and company officials over the weekend.
About 300 of the 3,200 striking workers in Dayton continue to enter the factories each day with the U.A.W.'s approval to produce brakes for the Chrysler Corporation and American Isuzu Motors Inc. Some U.A.W. hard-liners have criticized the unusual arrangement. Tom Lewis, the union's strike chairman, said today that these workers remained on strike against G.M. itself and carried picket signs when they were not inside the factories.
The strike is ostensibly about whether General Motors has kept a 1994 pledge to continue buying almost all of its brakes and brake parts from the Dayton factories. G.M. says that while it now buys some brake parts elsewhere, overall employment at the factory has edged up because other parts are now being made there. The union says the company should build many more parts there and hire more workers.
But, more broadly, the U.A.W. is fighting to keep its control over the production of auto parts as well as the final assembly of cars and trucks. G.M., the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation are all trying to buy more parts from outside companies that have lower costs and typically have lower wages. The extent of these purchases will be a central issue when the union's national contract expires on Sept. 14, auto executives and union leaders say.
Strikes at parts factories are also cost-effective for the U.A.W., because it only needs to pay $150 a week in strike benefits to several thousand workers at one or two factories. When big auto companies then lay off tens of thousands of workers at assembly plants and other parts factories, the laid-off workers quickly qualify for state unemployment compensation, possibly driving up G.M.'s unemployment insurance costs for years to come.
About 7,300 workers at G.M.'s Saturn division were idled this afternoon when the company shut down its operations in Spring Hill, Tenn. But those workers went into training sessions and maintenance work instead of being laid off, because they had a separate contract.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stock Market Recovers Two-Thirds of Its Loss
The stock market regained nearly two-thirds of the ground it lost on Friday in its worst drubbing in four years. Riding a wave of buying from mutual funds and other investment managers, who saw an opportunity to scoop up bargains, the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 110.55 points, or 2 percent, to 5,581.00, its strongest gain in five years. [Page A1.]
 
Utility stocks did not bounce back. Rather, the Dow Jones utility average fell 0.56 of a point to 215.69. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D10.]
 
In Hong Kong stocks tumbled because of concerns about American interest rates and worries of war over Taiwan. The benchmark Hang Seng index sank 820.34 points, or 7.31 percent, to close at 10,397.45. [D8.]
 
Treasury Securities Prices Rise
Prices of Treasury securities moved sharply higher, recouping about a third of Friday's panic selloff, as buyers sensed an oversold condition. The 30-year bond rose 11/32 to a price of 9127/32 , yielding 6.63 percent, down from 6.72 percent on Friday. [D20.]
 
Arms Makers in $1 Trillion Contest
The $1 trillion competition to design and build a midpriced jet fighter for the Air Force, Navy and Marines begins in earnest this week, and executives from Lockheed, Boeing and a team linking McDonnell Douglas and Northrop Grumman cannot find enough superlatives to inspire their troops. Each seeks guaranteed prosperity in an otherwise bleak period. [A1.]
 
Rolls-Royce and General Electric said they would jointly develop an engine to compete for contracts worth $90 billion. The engine would power a new military strike aircraft for both the United States and Britain. [D4.]
 
W. R. Grace to Sell Unit to Betz
W. R. Grace agreed to sell its Dearborn water treatment and process chemicals business to Betz Laboratories for $632 million in cash. The sale is part of a continuing drive at Grace to enhance shareholder value. [D7.]
 
Battle Mountain Gold in Merger
Battle Mountain Gold, based in Houston, said that it had agreed to merge with Hemlo Gold Mines of Toronto, exchanging stock worth $1.5 for Hemlo's stock and creating one of North America's largest gold producers. [D2.]
 
New-Home Sales Rose in January
New-home sales shot up 4.2 percent in January, even though sales plunged 40 percent in the Northeast, which bore the brunt of the season's snowstorms. It was the second straight gain as mortgage rates dipped to a two-year low, 7.03 percent on average for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage. [D4.]
 
Plan for Nigerian Sanctions
Washington is circulating a plan for tough sanctions against the military Government of Nigeria. It would ban all new foreign investment there and try to freeze the financial assets of the country's leaders, but it does not call for an embargo against Nigerian oil. Europeans are cool to the proposal. [A1.]
 
Royal Dutch/Shell made a potentially important oil find off the Nigerian coast. Human rights groups have criticized the company for its operations in Nigeria. [A8.]
 
Effects of G.M. Strike Felt Across Continent
The effects of a week-old strike at two General Motors brake factories in Dayton, Ohio, rippled across North America; G.M. closed 14 assembly plants and 16 parts factories from Chihuahua, Mexico, to Oshawa, Canada. Responding to shortages caused by the walkout by 3,200 brake workers, the company laid off an additional 58,000 G.M. workers, making the strike the auto industry's largest work stoppage in recent years. [A10.]
 
Microsoft and DirecTV in Deal
Microsoft and the satellite broadcast system DirecTV said they would collaborate to deliver digital entertainment and information services to personal computers within the year. They plan to develop new forms of interactive, digital services. [D2.]
 
Cuervo Gold's Island in the Sun
Heublein, which imports and sells the Jose Cuervo brand of tequila, is designating a tiny Caribbean resort island -- eight acres at low tide -- as the Republic of Cuervo Gold. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D9.]

HEADLINE: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;
St. John's Forces Mahoney To Leave

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN 

 BODY:
Brian Mahoney reluctantly walked away from St. John's University yesterday. He was asked to leave the job he once coveted for years, the one for which he waited patiently if anxiously in the spring of 1992 while a slow-moving search process eliminated more-established candidates.
Less than one year later, Mahoney was the Big East coach of the year. Today he is unemployed. 
 Five days before, at the somber conclusion of a third consecutive nonwinning season, Mahoney had stood in an emptying dressing room in Madison Square Garden and repeated that he had no intention of resigning as head basketball coach.
"He was asked to step down," said Ed Manetta, the St. John's athletic director, who delivered his decision to Mahoney during a meeting yesterday. The resignation, after an 11-16 season completed Mahoney's four-year record of 56-58, including 31-47 in Big East play, leads St. John's to a situation the university has not faced for decades, if ever.
St. John's must now respond to the forced departure of a coach without anything close to an obvious replacement, as pressure builds to produce a high-powered successor. When Frank Mulzoff left in 1973 after three post-season appearances in three years, Lou Carnesecca was ready to return from the New York Nets of the defunct American Basketball Association. When Dusty DeStefano, an assistant under Frank McGuire, was removed as head coach in 1956 after an experience similar to that of Mahoney, Joe Lapchick was eager to return from the Knicks.
Now, as other metropolitan area teams work to raise their profiles, St. John's must start over.
"There will be no search committee," Manetta said. "I will interview the candidates. I will select the finalists."
At that point, Manetta said, he will make his recommendation to the Rev. Donald J. Harrington, the school president, who declined to discuss the decision yesterday. The president's office released a two-paragraph statement that said in part: "At St. John's, our priority has always been the total development of our student athletes -- both as competitors and as people. That is our commitment to them. Ed's decision has been made in keeping with that commitment, and he has my support."
Manetta said he did not have a timetable in mind. Although the process may be more direct than it was in 1992, the marketplace has grown four years more complex and costly. The search will soon establish whether St. John's can break from the pattern established by past Big East hires by meeting the demands of high-profile candidates seeking minimum packages of $500,000 a year.
The second- and third-generation coaches hired by Big East schools, like Jim Calhoun of Connecticut and Steve Lappas of Villanova, established their coaching credentials at a level beneath the elite leagues. A move within that economic framework could lead Manetta to conversations with Fran Fraschilla of Manhattan, Mike Jarvis of George Washington, Herb Sendek of Miami of Ohio and Bob McKillop of Davidson.
Fraschilla, when reached at his office yesterday afternoon, said his only concern was preparing the Jaspers for their National Invitation Tournament game against Wisconsin. "That is really all I am going to allow myself to think about," he said. "I owe it to them."
The choice of a coach with a higher profile, such as P. J. Carlesimo of the Portland Trail Blazers or Tom Penders of Texas, would require an unprecedented economic commitment, enough to possibly require the school to establish an endowed position. Penders has seven years remaining on his contract.
"I'm not expecting anyone to call me," Penders said last night. "I'm not looking for a job. I don't need an offer to improve my situation. I don't think it would be fair to Texas or the kids I have in my program."
Attempts to reach Mahoney were unsuccessful. A 16-year assistant under Carnesecca, he was rewarded with a seven-year extension after his first season ended with a second-round National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament appearance in 1993. Manetta did not discuss details, except to say: "We have an existing contract with Brian. We'll fulfill what needs to be done."
Mahoney had insisted in recent weeks that his contract was guaranteed to the year 2000. A person familiar with the contract, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said that a provision calls for the university to cover the difference if Mahoney's future salary should be less than than his base pay at St. John's.
Felipe Lopez, whose decision to enroll at St. John's as the national high school player of the year intensified the program's expectations two years ago, said the players had been told they would meet with administrators today to have the decision explained to them.
"It was a struggle all year for the coaches and the players," Lopez said. "It's kind of surprising because coming in, we had a great recruiting class. We never knew that it would come to this."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Brian Mahoney compiled a 56-58 coaching record in four seasons at St. John's. The Red Storm finished this season at 11-16. (Barton Silverman/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Board Members, Too, Are Getting Investor Scrutiny

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
In a move that could mark the beginning of a new phase in the shareholder-rights movement, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters' pension fund is expected to release today a list of what it calls the 23 "least valuable directors" in corporate America.
Among those named are Frank C. Carlucci, the former United States Secretary of Defense, and Vernon E. Jordan, the politically active lawyer and former head of the Urban League. 
 The list is "an attempt to put a face on inefficient board oversight," said Bill Patterson, the teamsters' director of corporate affairs. "A bad board is a breakdown of individual shareholder's rights, but you can't just look at a board as a monolith," he added. "Oversight will improve when shareholders focus on the individuals.
"We are trying to stimulate a discussion and to challenge shareholders to think about who's on boards."
The teamsters' pension fund, which has $46 billion in assets, will vote against the re-election of directors on the list, Mr. Patterson said.
The teamsters said the rankings were based largely on a list of poorly performing companies with highly paid chief executives that was compiled by Graef Crystal, the consultant on executive pay, who said he had not been contacted for the study. The rankings presumed that directors serving on the boards of several of these companies were tolerant of poor performance.
"There seems to be a mutual support network of people who say, 'You be a director on my board and overpay me and I'll serve on your board and overpay you,' " said Bart Naylor, the teamsters' national coordinator of corporate affairs.
The rankings also looked at the directors' attendance at board meetings and at whether they had conflicts of interest.
The teamsters called Mr. Carlucci "one of the most overcommitted corporate directors in the United States" because he attended 150 board meetings in 1994. Mr. Carlucci serves on the boards of Ashland Inc., the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and others.
Mr. Jordan was cited for serving on the boards of 11 companies, 7 of which use the services of his law firm, Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld. The teamsters also said Mr. Jordan had one of the worst attendance records of American directors. Mr. Jordan is a director of the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, the American Express Company and the Union Carbide Corporation, among others.
Mr. Jordan and Mr. Carlucci could not be reached for comment. The teamsters released the list yesterday after business hours.
The other directors on the teamsters' list are Drew L. Lewis, the chairman of the Union Pacific Corporation; Marshall M. Criser, the former president of the University of Florida; Richard M. Morrow, the retired chairman of the Amoco Corporation; Richard D. Simmons, the publication director of The International Herald Tribune; Paul R. Tregurtha, the chairman of Mormac Marine Group; H. Jesse Arnelle, a corporate lawyer; Jack S. Blanton, the president of the Eddy Refining Company; Douglas C. Yearley, the chairman of the Phelps Dodge Corporation; Lois Rice, a guest scholar at the Brookings Institution; John T. Hartley, the former chairman of the Harris Corporation; John M. Kucharski, the chairman of EG& G Inc.; Kathryn Eickhoff, an economist; Richard M. Rosenberg, the chairman of the BankAmerica Corporation; Richard H. Jenrette, the chairman of the Equitable Companies; Howard H. Baker Jr., the former Republican Senator from Tennessee and the White House chief of staff for a time during the 1980's; James L. Broadhead, the chairman of FPL Group Inc.; Joseph L. Dionne, the chairman of the McGraw-Hill Companies; William LaMothe, the former chairman the Kellogg Company; Victor G. Beghini, the vice chairman of the USX Marathon Group; Michael H. Jordan, the chairman of Westinghouse; and William May, the former chairman of the American Can Company.
For more than a decade, a number of large investors have been pressing companies to improve their financial results and pushing directors to be more independent and to take a more active role in the board room.
But in the past, shareholder-rights advocates generally focused individual attention on chief executives. When it came to the board room, these shareholders generally concentrated on governance practices, not on the individuals. They pushed for the selection of directors with no connections to chief executives, for the payment of directors' fees in stock rather than cash and for the appointment of a lead director to act as a counterweight to a powerful chairman and chief executive.
By highlighting individuals, the teamsters have gone a step further.
"It's not enough to say, 'We want independent directors,' " said James E. Heard, president of Institutional Shareholder Services, an advisory firm in Washington. "You have to know who they are."
Most large companies have a majority of independent directors now, said Patrick McGurn, director of corporate governance at the Investor Responsibility Research Center in Washington.
"So now the institutions want to look at stock ownership of a director, potential conflicts of interest with the company, service on too many boards and attendance at meetings," he said.
As proxy statements are filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission this year, the center is beginning to keep track of those things in its data base.
Such moves serve notice on directors that their individual performance, not just their collective record, is under scrutiny. The California Public Employees' Retirement System, which is known as Calpers, is using profiles of directors as the basis for some complaints in its current discussions about performance and governance at 10 companies it says are underperforming.
As these large investors gain more information on directors, they are expected to try to vote some of them out of office at annual meetings.
"You'll see board exits by directors the same way we've seen exits by C.E.O.'s," Mr. McGurn said. "Underperforming directors will be eased off boards."
Some will go voluntarily, simply not standing for re-election, Mr. McGurn predicted. "There'll be a thousand other reasons given for these exits, and not the real reason. You'll never know for sure unless you get in the board room."

HEADLINE: Don't Let Immigrants Take Jobs From the Poor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was puzzled by the March 11 Op-Ed article on immigrant competition with black Americans, "The Jobs Immigrants Take." Roger Waldinger spent almost the entire piece outlining how immigrant numbers and networking freeze low-skilled blacks out of jobs -- then concludes that reducing immigration won't help! 
 He may be right that the modest cuts proposed in legislation before Congress would still result in large numbers of immigrants moving to our big cities. It would seem, however, that the corollary should be that deeper cuts are needed, and that a larger proportion of those who are allowed in should be skilled, so as not to compete with the United States' own working poor.
Reducing the flow of unskilled immigrants is not a panacea for our inner cities; Professor Waldinger's prescription for providing job training and attacking pro-immigrant discrimination is right. But no effort to help this nation's poor, black or otherwise, can succeed without changes in our pernicious immigration policies.
 
MARK KRIKORIAN
Executive Director
Center for Immigration Studies
Washington, March 11, 1996

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES;
12,927 Aid Neediest Cases, As $4.8 Million Is Raised

BYLINE: By SARAH JAY 

 BODY:
Bernadine T., a single mother of four children in Brooklyn, budgets her monthly $1,426 paycheck meticulously. Even so, there were days last year when she came up short. No money for diapers, or food, or both.
In those moments of crisis, Ms. T., who in the last few years has rallied back from a rape, homelessness and unemployment, relied on the Catholic Charities of Brooklyn and Queens, one of seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, whose 84th annual campaign ended earlier this month. 
 A total of 12,927 donors to the 1995-96 appeal gave $4,815,609.76, the second highest tally since the fund began in 1912. Although the drive ended on March 1, the final tally was completed yesterday. The highest total was $5,083,550 in 1991-92, and the next highest was $4,590,568 in 1993-94.
Last year, thousands of people besides Ms. T. turned to the charities as a last resort for food, clothing, medicine or perhaps just a word of advice. They included people like Yorna Mera, who received rent assistance from the UJA-Federation of New York when illness and injury prevented her from working, and Rodney Palacios, a single working father unable to provide medication for his 9-year-old son without the help of the Children's Aid Society, also supported by the Neediest Cases Fund.
This year, as changes in the welfare system take effect, the heads of the charities say they expect to see even more people like Ms. Mera and Mr. Palacios even as budget cuts force the charities to reduce their services. In that light, money they receive from the fund can have an even more critical role.
The drive, which began on Nov. 26, kept pace with last year's until the final week, when several large gifts arrived from Wall Street firms, which made record contributions this year. There were also a number of smaller last-minute gifts from individuals moved by George C. Ginsberg, a 96-year-old New Jersey man also known as the Penny Philanthropist, and there were first-time givers like Daniela Varon, who sent $18 in late February.
"As a new New Yorker, I am thrilled to live in this city," Ms. Varon wrote, "not least because it is really so many cities, each neighborhood having such different characteristics and energies -- and I am grateful for all you do to make this city a better place for people to live in."
As in the past, a significant portion of the fund total came from interest and distribution of trusts and estates. Among those contributing to trusts and estates, which totaled $1,137,889 this year, were the estate of Elizabeth H. Bryant, which gave $250,000, and Evelyn Y. Davis of Washington, who gave $51,000.
The idea for the fund dates back to 1911, when Adolph S. Ochs, the publisher of The Times, came upon a beggar in the street. Mr. Ochs gave the man some money but continued to think about the plight of the city's most destitute citizens and ways that he could help them. The next year, The Times published summaries of the 100 neediest cases, and 117 readers responded by sending in a total of $3,630.
As the city's population increased, so too did the number of people living in poverty, and the fund responded by accepting donations beyond the 100 neediest cases. The money is divided among the seven charities, which provide direct aid and services. Although this year's campaign has ended, the fund accepts contributions throughout the year and will credit them toward next year's drive.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 14, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund misstated the source of one recent donation. The $51,000 contribution came from Evelyn Y. Davis and the Evelyn Y. Davis Foundation, not the estate of Evelyn Y. Davis.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (92%); 

CITY: NEW YORK, NY, USA (91%); 

COMPANY: THE TIMES (65%); 

GEOGRAPHIC: UNITED STATES (92%); NEW YORK, USA (92%); NEW YORK, NY, USA (91%);

HEADLINE: 'Ambiguity' On Taiwan

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
With China test-firing missiles into the seas around Taiwan's main ports and American warships patrolling the Taiwan Straits in response, the United States remains deliberately vague about the depth of its commitment to defend Taiwan from attack.
That ambiguous approach has long been viewed by Republicans and Democrats alike as a prudent one. But now, as some Congressional Republicans call for more pointed guarantees by Washington to defend Taiwan, the traditional consensus is under threat. 
 While some Republicans still favor what the policy makers call "strategic ambiguity," a swelling chorus of China critics are pushing for a more explicit commitment. Even Senator Bob Dole, the Majority Leader and front-runner for the Republican presidential nomination, has edged from his usual bipartisan caution on foreign policy toward a more explicit embrace of Taiwan.
The United States' defense treaty with Taiwan was abrogated in the years after President Nixon's visit to Communist China in 1972. The visit led to recognition of Beijing, accepting its argument that it, not Taiwan, was the Government of a single China.
But in return, the United States received promises that reunification with Taiwan would happen peacefully and at some vague time in the future. And in the Taiwan Relations Act of 1979, the United States set forth the intentionally vague commitment that now applies.
The law asserted Washington's right to help Taiwan defend itself and declared Taiwan to be within the American sphere of interests. And it said the United States would consider "any effort to determine the future of Taiwan by other than peaceful means, including by boycotts or embargoes, a threat to the peace and security of the Western Pacific area and of grave concern to the United States." It said the United States would "maintain its capacity to resist" any act that jeopardized the security or the social and economic system of Taiwan.
But the act does not require any particular response.
"The act is an important framework whereby China knows that the use of force will have consequences," a senior Administration official said. "Without pre-committing or allowing Taiwan to dictate our China policy, it's very important that China knows it cannot act with impunity, and that we have options and can use them."
[Speaking to reporters in Chile, Defense Secretary William J. Perry declined to say if Washington was planning for any eventual Chinese attack on Taiwan, Reuters reported. But Assistant Secretary of State Winston Lord said tonight on "The News Hour with Jim Lehrer" that the naval build-up was meant to "reassure our friends in the area that we have a big stake in the stability and peace of that region."
["At the same time," he added, "we are not on the brink of war."]
By sending more American ships to patrol near Taiwan, officials say, the United States is insuring that China does not underestimate American resolve, while stopping short of an explicit challenge that could lead to a confrontation.
"We want to make clear, against indications of some in Beijing who are thinking of using force, that we are committed to a one-China policy, but in the context of peaceful unification," one official said.
But the Administration is also trying, by this ambiguous show of force, to head off more drastic measures in an election-minded Congress. Some proposals now alive in Congress could infuriate China: providing more advanced arms to Taiwan, supporting United Nations membership for Taiwan or issuing invitations to high-ranking Taiwan officials to visit the United States after Taiwan's presidential elections March 23.
"What the Administration has done in the last two or three days has been a measured, prudent but necessary step," Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, said in an interview. "But by emphasizing only one side and emphasizing military force, China is making it harder for the United States to maintain bipartisan support for the policy," Mr. Nunn said.
Senator Dole has been circumspect on China, criticizing the Administration for being weak on Chinese violations of human rights and arms accords and calling for more American forces to be sent to back up Taiwan, but stopping short of a promise to go to war over the island.
The United States should make it clear to China that Washington has strong ties to Taiwan and "if necessary, we would protect them" from any Chinese military action, Mr. Dole said over the weekend, without saying how. He suggested China was testing Mr. Clinton because of a wavering foreign policy.
Senior Administration officials accuse Mr. Dole of playing politics and say a Dole Administration policy would be no different.
"It's a campaign year, and they will very likely play for any advantage they can get," one official said -- including using Mr. Clinton's 1992 campaign promises to get tough on China against him.
Mr. Nunn said: "The unfortunate thing about presidential candidates in both parties is that they focus so much on getting elected they don't focus on what foreign policy commitments they've made. Dole will have a lot of pressure on him not to be responsible about China."
Stanley O. Roth, of the United States Institute of Peace, says that while it is vital that China understand that Washington would react, "if it becomes a formal defense commitment, we may rue the day it is made."
To defend Taiwan against unprovoked aggression is one thing, he says, but if Taiwan should declare independence, "it's quite another thing if you're really intervening in a 50-year-old Chinese civil war."
"That's why the ambiguity makes sense," Mr. Roth added.
Too strong a confrontational policy, he said, frightens American allies in Asia, while too soft a reaction undermines American credibility as Asia's "great balancer."
A senior Asian diplomat applauds Washington's show of force but says: "If you get into a direct confrontation with China, you'll probably be alone," given China's importance to the region. "No one expects a war, but everyone is worried that given the political, domestic dynamic in America, Taiwan and China, it could somehow get out of hand."
But there is pressure in Congress to alter the terms of the Taiwan Relations Act to recognize that while Taiwan has moved toward democracy since 1979, China remains Communist and is not respecting its commitments, says Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California.
"It was one thing to normalize with China when both Beijing and Taiwan had authoritarian regimes," Ms. Pelosi said. "The fact is, Taiwan is now a democracy, and that makes all the difference in the world."
Many in Congress "want to see Taiwan's rights respected," she added, including free elections.
"It could mean peaceful reunification or self-determination," she said. "Fundamentally, there's a commitment to one China, but now there are two economic and political systems, and it increases the challenge."
 
 The article also misstated the change that took place when President Nixon visited China in 1972. He did not recognize Beijing as the government of a single China; rather he began the process of establishing diplomatic relations with the mainland and left open the question of which government was the rightful ruler of a single China.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 20, 1996, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A news analysis article last Wednesday about American policy toward Taiwan referred imprecisely to the timing of the United States' cancellation of its mutual defense treaty with Taiwan. It occurred in 1979.

HEADLINE: Film Price Hits $8.50, But There Are Ways To Save

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
The price goes up. The price goes down. Sony Theaters, the city's second-largest chain, has quietly raised the price of a ticket at its Manhattan theaters to $8.50 from $8, keeping New York securely in first place as the nation's most expensive city in which to see a movie.
But in an experiment that has attracted moviegoers in droves, Cineplex Odeon has been showing older first-run films for $2 at its Worldwide Cinemas, a six-screen complex in Worldwide Plaza on West 50th Street near Ninth Avenue. The policy, introduced two years ago, draws near-capacity crowds even on weeknights to theaters that had previously been deserted. On weekends, the Worldwide is a mob scene, with films often selling out early. 
 Sony, which has 10 locations and 46 screens in Manhattan, said that its latest price increase was a cost-of-living adjustment. "This is only the second time since May 1990 that we've raised prices," said Marc Pascucci, Sony's vice president for advertising and publicity. "If we kept at the rate of inflation for the New York area, we'd be at $9."
The new price puts New York a dollar above the top price in Los Angeles, Boston and Chicago. Nationwide, the average price for a movie ticket was $4.35 last year, according to the National Association of Theater Owners.
Many New Yorkers have already reached the $9 barrier, since they order tickets through a telephone service operated by Moviefone that charges users $1.25. For some users, the service is a convenience. For others it is a necessity, since popular first-run films often sell out well in advance of showtime at the city's busiest theaters. The 45 Manhattan theaters that use Moviefone sell up to 50,000 tickets weekly through the service.
Cineplex Odeon, which operates 21 theaters and 51 screens in Manhattan, has not raised prices. Howard Lichtman, the executive vice president for marketing and communications, would not say whether the company planned to follow Sony's lead. "Pricing is something that we review at least twice a year on a very specific market-by-market basis," he said. "We look at a host of factors, and one factor is the pricing of our competitors. We haven't matched Sony's yet, but we understand why they raised their prices."
Mr. Lichtman cited the rising cost of presenting films, and an increasing investment by theater companies in better sound systems, screens and even cup holders. "Why wouldn't the cost of movies go up on an annual basis?" he said.
The $8 ticket is the standard for first-run Hollywood films in Manhattan, with a few exceptions, like the Quad Cinemas in Greenwich Village, which charge $7.50, and the Cineplex Metro Twin and the Cineplex Olympia, on the Upper West Side, which charge $6.50.
Otherwise, the $8 ticket prevails even at most repertory and art houses. Film Forum recently raised its prices to $8 from $7.50, and the Museum of Modern Art and the Whitney Museum both have an $8 museum admission fee to see films. An exception is the Walter Reade theater at Lincoln Center, which charges $7.50 for the general public and $5 for members of the Film Society of Lincoln Center.
Most first-run theaters offer price breaks to the elderly and children, and some nonprofit theaters, like the French Institute and Anthology Film Archives, also offer discounts to students. A few theaters offer matinee discounts as well.
Cineplex Odeon, United Artists and Sony also sell blocks of discounted tickets to corporations and to membership organizations like the Automobile Association of America. Members of the automobile association, for example, can order booklets of tickets at about $4.50 a ticket. The Sony tickets are good only after a new film has been out for 10 days.
And some films are actually free. At the Museum of Modern Art, children under 16 can see films free, and no one has to pay to see old films at the Donnell Media Center at the Donnell Public Library.
The Cineplex Worldwide may not be free, but it comes as close as New York is likely to see. Since early last March, the theaters have booked first-run films, like "Seven," "Goldeneye" and "Get Shorty," that have already played for several weeks elsewhere. The $2 ticket price applies to all films at all times.
Cineplex has tried the cheap-seats policy in a few other cities, but none have drawn the crowds Worldwide has. Mr. Lichtman said that the company expected about 1.5 million customers to pass through the theater's doors this year, making it one of the most heavily attended theaters in the country, although it operates at a loss. There are no plans by Cineplex to extend the policy to other Manhattan theaters, he said.
The pricing policy was a defensive measure by Cineplex, which had opened the Worldwide in 1989 with the expectation that the neighborhood was on the way up. The optimism proved to be unfounded. "The area did not become as attractive as we hoped," Mr. Lichtman said.
The Worldwide has attracted three kinds of customers: bargain seekers, procrastinators and fence-sitters, who are willing to take a chance at $2 on a film they are not sure they will like.
"It's just so much cheaper, and you get to see all the movies you missed the first time around," said Jessica Liberman, who is 24 and works for a public-opinion research company. "You can see all the movies you could see on video, but for less money and on the big screen."
Ms. Liberman said she lives on the Upper West Side and walks to the Worldwide. "I really want to make sure it's a $2 experience," she said. "Otherwise, the subway would be more than the movie, and that would ruin it."
Cineplex, of course, is the company that administered a dose of shock therapy to New York moviegoers when it raised ticket prices to $7 from $6 in 1987, a move that was quickly followed by Loews, the city's second-largest chain, which has since been bought by Sony. The increase caused howls of outrage not only from ordinary citizens but also from the Mayor, Edward I. Koch, who called for a consumer boycott to force a price rollback.
The movement went nowhere. In June 1989, Cineplex raised prices 50 cents more, and in May 1994, Cineplex and Sony both raised ticket prices to $8.

HEADLINE: A Korean Family's Dream, A Community's Struggle

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE 

 BODY:
WHILE their high school friends spent most Saturdays and summer vacations lolling in bed, playing basketball or going to movies, Veronica Jung, now 21, and her sister Rose, 19, worked.
At their family's two grocery stores -- one was in Floral Park, L.I., the other is in Fresh Meadows, Queens -- they stacked tins of tuna, made pyramids of gleaming red peppers and arranged persimmons, pointed ends up. They sprinkled water on cilantro and watercress, swept floors, bagged groceries and made change. If there was a free moment from 7:30 A.M. to 7:30 P.M. on Saturdays, and if it was the school year, they did homework. 
 Their mother, Agnes Soo Jung, 45, and father, Young Hun Jung, 51, simply worked -- 10 to 12 hours a day. The Jungs, South Korean immigrants, have worked to send their daughters to good schools and, they hope, better lives.
The plan has so far paid off. Veronica, a junior at Harvard University, and Rose, a sophomore at Bryn Mawr College, are moving away from the back-breaking work of their parents. "Even now when I see them work, I see that I would personally hate to do this, day in and day out," Veronica said.
Their parents' lives are not so certain. Their first store, Green Village, opened in 1986, but after about three years, the Jungs left it and, exhausted, took a year off. In December 1990, they opened Royal Fruits, at 187-08 Union Turnpike in Fresh Meadows. But business is down, eroded by competition from too many stores. Flowers, for example, once 50 percent of sales, have dropped to 20 percent.
Business is so bad, in fact, that on March 29, the Jungs have to vacate the store. Their landlord wants a more profitable tenant, Veronica said.
The Jungs are not alone. After some 20 years, groceries like theirs -- owned and operated by Korean immigrants -- are either on the wane throughout the city or are reinventing themselves.
The city's first Korean groceries were established in the late 1960's, in Manhattan's garment district, in the West 30's, said B. J. Sa, the executive director of the Korean Produce Association, a trade group founded in 1970 and based at the Hunts Point produce terminal market in the Bronx. In the early 1970's, it had 35 members; in the late 80's, 3,000, but as of January, membership was down to 2,500. Some grocers, "maybe a hundred," have returned home, Mr. Sa continued, adding that his figures were conservative.
At first, New Yorkers embraced the little stores, which stayed open 24 hours a day, selling fresh food, convenience and pleasant ambiance. But the customer and the market have changed.
"We worked 24 hours for the convenience of the customers," Mr. Sa said. "But the decline is due to competition by the same Korean-American groceries, too many on the same block or in the same territory." He also attributed the downward spiral to the influx of small markets being opened by Vietnamese, Turkish, Indian and other immigrants -- and to the opening of giant supermarkets. "Customers want one-stop shopping," he said, "and supermarkets have all the fruit and vegetables."
The average Korean grocer, working 80 hours a week, makes around $50,000 a year, said Andrew Ku, the president of another trade group, the Korean-American Grocers Association of New York, which is based in Long Island City, Queens, and was founded in 1986. "You don't need any special skills," Mr. Ku added. "It depends on ability and luck." (Ability is a synonym for hard work.)
Most Korean grocers spend three to five years working 72-hour weeks for someone else, save $10,000 to $50,000, then open their own stores. When times were best, through about 1993, the number of Korean-owned groceries had reached about 5,000, Mr. Ku said. Today, he continued, there are 3,500 to 4,000.
To survive, some store owners are striving to be wholesalers. Mr. Sa's group, which sometimes buys food and beverages in volume, recently bought 2,000 cases of a soda, with 10 cans to a case, a move that saves each retailer $1 to $2 a case. "But with 2,500 members, it's difficult to park and to distribute," Mr. Sa said. "We need some kind of facility." Eventually, he said, grocers may go directly to the farmers to buy.
Many of the grocers also haunt fancy-food shows, tasting salsas of red, yellow and green peppers; popcorn, and strawberries dipped in chocolate. They sip drinks of papaya, kiwi and ginseng. And they crunch on potato chips flavored with sour cream, mesquite and vinegar. They are searching for the next profitable step in selling food.
They want to be manufacturers, wholesalers, importers and exporters. "We want to have our own food service, own our own bakery line," Mr. Ku said. Although many Korean grocers sell similar foods -- the ubiquitous fried chicken, potato salad and green salads -- the food does not come from a central commissary. A few owners have upgraded their delicatessens to restaurants, making corned beef and roast turkey in their own kitchens, selling them along with cappuccino. Mr. Ku's group is considering importing coffees, iced teas and waters and exporting to South Korea anything American, like dried groceries and pots and pans.
For the Jungs, business has been failing for the last year. On a recent day, for example, they had only six customers in two hours, and the purchases were tiny -- a pack of cigarettes here, a cup of coffee there.
Times weren't always so tough. "There was one year when they were unemployed," Veronica said over the telephone from her dormitory in Cambridge, Mass. The year was 1989. "They thought the world was too exhausting for them, physically, and they wanted another occupation. We lived on savings -- and we ate up all the savings." In December 1990, they opened their second store. Asked what he would like to do now, Mr. Jung said through an interpreter, "At the moment, I have no idea."
Mr. Jung sighed and added softly, "Ideally, we would like to move away from New York and move to Memphis, where my eldest brother is." In Memphis, where Samuel Jung owns three dry cleaners, the weather would be warm, and a job with him would be guaranteed. But that dream, too, is being deferred. "Our daughters don't want us to move," Mr. Jung said. "They think that New York is the center of their lives, and they would miss their parents."
His wife added, also through the interpreter, "All our lives we've lived together, and we feel it's not right to live far apart."
The Jungs have nurtured their dream for more than 20 years. In the 1970's, Samuel Jung moved to Memphis and sent back word to Seoul that the Jungs should move to New York, where there were more Koreans. "Ever since we were married in 1975, he wanted to emigrate," Mrs. Jung said. "But I didn't."
In Seoul, Mr. Jung worked for an offset printer, binding books. He often took home discarded books without covers. The girls remember biographies of Abraham Lincoln and Marie Curie and Mark Twain's "Adventures of Tom Sawyer," all in Korean. "My daughters begged me to read to them," Mr. Jung said.
Veronica was in a private school in Seoul, where tuition cost the equivalent of $400 every three months and escalated yearly. Rose was in a public school, because the family could not afford tuition for both girls. The Jungs also thought the Korean education system was rigid. "In Korea, you have to immediately declare what you want to study, what career you want, and that's what the college prepares you for," Veronica said. "In American colleges, you explore what you want to do."
In 1983, when Veronica was 8 and Rose 7, Mrs. Jung gave in, and the family moved to New York. When they arrived, Samuel Jung, who had flown from Memphis, met them at Kennedy International Airport, Veronica recalled. He helped them settle in Astoria, Queens, where they had a distant relative.
Within a week, the family had joined a Korean-American Catholic parish. A priest found Mr. Jung a job at Kim's Fruit Store, at Second Avenue and 21st Street in Manhattan, where he worked from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M. Three nights a week, he would go home and eat dinner, and at 11 P.M., he would go with his employer to the Hunts Point market in the Bronx, where he learned to select the perfect, freshest specimens of cantaloupes, strawberries and bananas.
Mrs. Jung, who had been a homemaker in Seoul, suddenly found herself working odd jobs 12 hours a day. "I knew I had to work," she said. "But I didn't realize how hard. It's different hearing the warning and actually facing it."
For the first year, the daughters clutched English-Korean dictionaries, struggling to learn the language. After school, they went home, took their snack money from the table and went a few doors down to a local pizza parlor. "For dinner, we'd wait for our parents to come home, late at night," Rose said. When they watched television, they were told to watch only Channel 13.
They obeyed.
In 1984, Mrs. Jung's mother, Deborah Kim, arrived from Korea, and life became more gracious. She would be home for the girls when they finished school, making Korean food, like beef soup and grilled fish, and keeping the house clean.
In 1986, the Jungs had saved enough to open their own grocery. By the time the girls were in high school, they were working with their parents at the store, on weekends and during part of their summer vacations. "Every Saturday -- no matter what," Mrs. Jung said.
Three nights a week, Mr. Jung would go home at 8, eat dinner, and sleep from 9 P.M. until 2 A.M. Then, like other grocers throughout the city, he would go to Hunts Point to buy much of the food for that day. Since last month, however, he no longer goes there. Instead, he has hired a delivery service. It is no longer worth the trip.
The Jungs fret about themselves, but not about Veronica and Rose. Most of their daughters' education is paid for by scholarships and financial-aid and work packages, with books and clothing paid for by the Jungs. While some parents brag about their children, Mr. Jung is shy. "The girls don't want us to talk about them in a proud kind of way, because their academic career has just begun," he said.
But the daughters worry about their parents. "I am concerned about their future not being secure, because they don't have retirement funds and they lack fluent language skills," Veronica said. "Their options are going to be very limited. I see them starting something new, but it would be some kind of manual labor. As they get older, I'd like to see them do something less strenuous, physically and emotionally."
Whatever the daughters do in the future, Veronica said, they know that part of the money they earn will go toward helping their parents.
Veronica is an advocate. At Harvard, she is trying to push the school into adopting an Asian-American studies program; at home, she is registering Korean-American voters. She hopes to go to law school. Rose is more the humanitarian than the advocate. She has tutored children, volunteers at hospitals and wants to be a physical therapist.
One thing the daughters share is the knowledge that they do not want to sell oranges. "If Rose and I never know relentless manual labor as daily reality," Veronica said, "it will be precisely because my parents knew it so well."

HEADLINE: Journal;
Beyond the Birdcage

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
Who would have guessed that we live in a country where Robin Williams and Nathan Lane are a sexier box-office pair than Robert Redford and Michelle Pfeiffer? Not me or anyone in Hollywood. But that's a fact: "The Birdcage," a comedy celebrating a gay couple's 20-year bond, sold $18 million worth of tickets last weekend while "Up Close & Personal," which it knocked out of the No. 1 slot, had opened to a mere $11 million.
A fluke? Perhaps. Many gay and straight critics have viewed "The Birdcage" as a safe retread of "La Cage aux Folles" with "tried and true gay stock characters" -- in the words of Jeffrey Friedman, the co-director of "The Celluloid Closet," the documentary charting Hollywood's often shabby treatment of homosexuals. Yet the popularity of "The Birdcage" comes only months after two of TV's most popular sitcoms -- "Friends" and "Roseanne" -- staged sincere, even sentimental gay weddings, to sky-high ratings and mere ripples of protest. Could the public be ahead of politicians in its live-and-let-live attitude toward same-sex marriage? 
The question is important because same-sex marriage could be the next bloody battleground of the culture wars. In August, on the eve of both political conventions, a Hawaii court will hear a case that experts on both sides believe will lead to that state's legal recognition of marriages between homosexuals. Since the "full faith and credit" clause of the Constitution might require other states to recognize Hawaiian same-sex marriages, the legislatures of 20 states are now rushing to pass laws that will try to void those marriages once the couples cross state lines.
Why would gay people want a government-sanctioned civil wedding as opposed to the religious or spiritual ceremonies already being performed on both TV and in real life? The most practical explanations come from those who are already booking their tickets to Hawaii. Fran De Benedictis and Emma Llaurado, New York City police officers who've been together for 12 years, talk of how much costlier and more cumbersome it is to jointly adopt their child without legal benefit of marriage. Nor could either collect the other's considerable "line-of-duty" death benefits under their pension plans.
Russell Reish and his partner of 25 years, Albert Masse, who could have stepped right out of "The Birdcage," are proud of having raised two of Mr. Reish's nieces who were abandoned by their own parents. (The girls are now married with children of their own.) Speaking by phone from Los Angeles, Mr. Reish expressed concern that when he dies, other, hostile members of his family will try to wrest his estate from Mr. Masse -- because even an ironclad will and his hiring of "a very nasty attorney" do not guarantee his wishes being carried out.
Couldn't the equal benefits denied same-sex couples, from tax, Social Security and health-plan advantages to the right to make medical decisions for an infirm loved one, be achieved through strong "domestic partnership" laws? Some pragmatic gay activists argue for such an incremental strategy, even though domestic partnership could not equalize all marital benefits, since it avoids raising the red flag of "marriage." No major national politician in either party, after all, has come anywhere near endorsing same-sex marriage.
But that's why the popularity of "The Birdcage" and TV's gay marriages may be more telling than what politicians do or don't do. From the start, the most eloquent proponents of same-sex marriage have not been gay people on the left, some of whom oppose marriage in any event, but gay conservatives who argue that marriage promotes mainstream ideals -- "social cohesion, emotional security and economic prudence," in the words of Andrew Sullivan, editor of The New Republic. Or as Rich Tafel, head of the Log Cabin Republicans, argues in debates with religious-right opponents of his party: "You can't have it both ways -- accusing gays of being promiscuous and then denying us the right to incorporate into monogamous, legally recognized relationships."
In "The Birdcage" and its TV cousins, same-sex marriage is presented in exactly that conservative fashion -- as an enclave of familial stability in a country full of broken homes. If Nielsen and box-office numbers tell us anything, it's that this message has a huge constituency. Politicians who plan to run this year on a platform of exclusionary family values had better stop by the mall to check out what their voters are applauding in the multiplex.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
China's Nationalist Tide

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
We met in a restaurant on the edge of Beijing, a seedy place with warm Tsingtao beer and a fish tank full of giant frogs. My dinner companion was a thirtysomething veteran leader of the 1989 democracy uprising in Tiananmen Square, who'd done his jail time. He came to talk about changes in the human rights struggle in China, and I think his words are worth listening to at this key juncture in U.S.-China relations.
I began by asking how the U.S. should deal with China on the human rights front and he answered swiftly: "I believe in secret diplomacy," adding that all his dissident friends now held this view. "You have to preserve the face of Chinese leaders in public and then pressure them very, very hard in private. If five U.S. Congressmen write a letter to [President] Jiang Zemin in public, it will have no effect, but if George Bush writes one letter in private it can have an effect." But, I said, many U.S. human rights activists say China's leaders will only respond if they are publicly embarrassed. No, no, he shook his head: "They don't understand -- we are swimming in a different sea today." 
 Communist ideology, he explained, has increasingly been replaced by a rising nationalism that resonates widely among China's people. China's aggressive stance against Taiwan today may be misguided, but it is very popular here. If the U.S., on human rights, tries to confront China's leaders publicly, Washington will crash straight into this nationalist wave and most Chinese -- even liberals -- will rally behind their leaders, he said. This is especially true after years of the Chinese media telling the people that it is the U.S. that is keeping China from assuming its rightful place in the world: the U.S. barred China from getting the Olympics, the U.S. bars China from the World Trade Organization, the U.S. encourages Taiwan's independence.
"When Tiananmen happened there was a lot of emotion -- it was the culmination of a decade of democracy debates, and people here knew who was the enemy," he said. "But seven years later, it is not so clear to everyone that the Government is the enemy. People are more nationalistic, and because of economic growth they have more personal space and freedom and money, so it makes it easier to accept the Government's line." Moreover, with about half of China's companies now privately owned, people don't blame the Government for everything anymore, because it doesn't run their lives as much, he said. And with more Chinese working in private factories in the cities, more of them have an economic stake in stability. They don't want confrontation.
Not only should America rely more on private pressure, he argued, but it should put its human rights arguments more into a U.N. framework, and less of a purely U.S. one. "If America wants to improve human rights in China," he explained, "it has to establish a legal framework for criticism of China that the leadership here can't ignore. You should be pressing China to accept the U.N. Declaration on Human Rights. Get away from the purely U.S. arguments." And the top priority should not be elections, but getting China to establish the rule of law. "I can wait 10 or 20 years for an election in China," he said, "but we need the rule of law right now."
He was encouraged, he said, by the legal reform bill that could be passed on Sunday by the National People's Congress. It would for the first time give Chinese some protection from arbitrary arrest and detention, protection from presumption of guilt, the right to a lawyer before a trial starts, and the first tentative protections from corrupt and abusive court officials. This was precisely the reform Chinese dissidents were demanding during last year's congress. If it now passes it would suggest that China may be slowly following the model of Korea, Singapore and Taiwan -- where one-party governments eventually discovered that they could not operate a modern economy, or control a rising middle class, without providing their people with the rule of law.
Before disappearing into the night, my dinner guest left me with this thought: Tiananmen was seven years ago, and "China has changed in a lot of ways since then" -- some for the better, some for the worse. It's time for U.S. officials to review their China human rights strategy to see whether it really fits today's China.
I know just the person and just the restaurant where they can start.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
Of Nixon and Kissinger: What Might Have Been

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY 

 BODY:
There's a briefly introspective moment in Russell Lees's entertaining "Nixon's Nixon," when Richard M. Nixon (Gerry Bammon) and Henry A. Kissinger (Steve Mellor) consider how far they've come from their humble origins. It's late on the night of Aug. 7, 1974. The place is the Lincoln Sitting Room in the White House and both men have had a lot to drink. Facing impeachment, the President of the United States is being urged by his Secretary of State to bite the bullet and resign. Nixon refuses to make a decision. Kissinger is worried about his own future.
"Sometimes I stare in the mirror," Kissinger muses. "What's happening behind those eyes? I'm astonished. Mystified." There's a pause. He adds, "I like it." Nixon admits that although he doesn't often stare in the mirror now, he did on the way up. He not only stared, but also talked to himself: " 'You sly dog,' I'd say. And we'd share a secret smile. But then I fell. I fell like Satan tossed from heaven." 
 "It's the great American story," Kissinger says benignly, as if to soothe. "Requited ambition." Which prompts Nixon to suggest that maybe one should commit suicide when one's at the top, before triumph turns to tragedy. "There's the catch," the President points out with brow furrowed. "You don't know when to kill yourself until it's too late."
This is the stuff of Mr. Lees's blissfully funny and sometimes cruel fiction, which opened last night at the Westside Theater, after its limited engagement at the MCC Theater Off Off Broadway.
"Nixon's Nixon" deserves all of the good things you have heard about it and more. It's both a serious work of the imagination and a fully realized political satire of the sort that the American theater seldom sees. It may also be the perfect antidote to Oliver Stone's fancy and flatulent three-hour-plus movie, "Nixon," an upscale docudrama that pretends to deal in facts, a number of which may not be true.
"Nixon's Nixon" makes no such mistake. It's like a jazz riff on contemporary history. It's one playwright's speculation about what went on at a meeting that was closed to all except the two parties involved. There were no flies on the wall of the White House that night. Mr. Lees uses this occasion to create a small, vivid drama that confirms and even humanizes the participants as they are known through their public personalities. The revelations here are not of facts but of fiction that informs.
Jim Simpson has staged the intermissionless 80-minute piece with admirable simplicity and with two splendidly effective actors. As you may have read, Mr. Bamman and Mr. Mellor eschew all padding and putty that might make them look like their real-life counterparts.
At times Mr. Mellor seems to resemble Mr. Kissinger at the age of 30, long before his Washington days, but that seems accidental. The distinctive accent and voice are suggested, not imitated. Mr. Bamman doesn't resemble Mr. Nixon at all, though he has the hand gestures, the facial expressions and the walk. Best of all, both actors have the characters as written by Mr. Lees.
This Nixon is desperate, shrewd, paranoid, utterly baffled by the situation in which he finds himself. As the night of drink and talk, of accusations and reconciliationscontinues, he seems increasingly unable to finish a sentence. His mind is going too fast. No sooner does one thought come into his head than another arrives before he has fully articulated the first. His language is obscene. He also has a gift for the matchlessly inept simile. "Rugs as thick as thieves," he says of the carpeting in Mao Zedong's Imperial City.
Kissinger also disintegrates in his own fashion. He's alternately unctuous and aggressive until Nixon lets on that there are tapes that could bring the Secretary of State down, too. At which point Kissinger begins to see the value of whomping up a small international crisis to keep Nixon in office. The colleagues who initiated the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty, opened China and negotiated the end of the Vietnam War are suddenly back in business.
They discuss various "Dr. Strangelove"-like possibilities until they seize on the idea of an incident along the Russian-Chinese border. Says Kissinger: "A provincial mayor gets assassinated sort of thing." They foresee how the crisis will escalate. Kissinger: "We tell both sides what's going to happen." Nixon: "We play 'em like banjos." Kissinger: "It gets tense. Who can prevent world war? Who has the power and prestige and trust of the Soviet Union and China? Who?" Nixon: "Me!"
"Nixon's Nixon" has the brio of a revue sketch constructed with a playwright's appreciation for character. The play doesn't cut deep but it cuts true. Within its short running time, it also manages to touch lightly on most of the major events so laboriously recapitulated in Mr. Stone's fractured film. In its wit and economy, "Nixon's Nixon" recalls Robert Altman's 1985 film, "Secret Honor," adapted from the one-character play about Mr. Nixon by Donald Freed and Arnold M. Stone. That work, too, was pure speculation.
At the time Mr. Nixon left office, who could have foreseen that he would become a figure of such fascination in fiction? Who would have thought the old man to have had so much blood in him? Maybe Mr. Lees is right when he has his protagonist announce, "I appeal to the Richard Nixon in everybody."
 
NIXON'S NIXON
 
By Russell Lees; directed by Jim Simpson; set and lighting by Kyle Chepulis; costumes by Daniele Hollywood; sound by Mike Nolan; production stage manager, Erica Blum. The MCC Theater production, presented by the Shubert Organization, Capital Cities/ABC, Jujamcyn Theaters, Robert LuPone and Bernard Telsey. At the Westside Theater, Downstairs, 407 West 43d Street, Clinton.

WITH: Gerry Bamman (Richard M. Nixon) and Steve Mellor (Henry A. Kissinger).
