HEADLINE: Japan Votes for Clinton

BYLINE: By R. Taggart Murphy; R. Taggart Murphy, a former investment banker who has lived in Japan for 15 years, is the author of "The Weight of the Yen."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
When forecasting the Presidential election, the punditocracy endlessly debates Bob Dole's electability, the Buchanan insurrection and Bill Clinton's resurrection from political death. But the commentators have ignored an enormously important factor: Japan.
The last three Presidential races were greatly influenced by events there, and this year will be no different. Washington and Tokyo have agreed on steps that could help protect President Clinton from the greatest threats to his re-election: soaring interest rates and market instability. 
 Government leaders on both sides may win, but American workers are likely to continue to get the short end of the stick.
Of course, Japan has no votes in the Electoral College. But in the early 1980's, its willingness to buy tens of billions of dollars of Treasury securities let Ronald Reagan cut taxes and run up the largest-ever peacetime deficit. Deficits stimulate the economy -- at least until the bills start coming due -- and Mr. Reagan's 1984 re-election campaign labeled the resultant economic euphoria "Morning in America."
Likewise, in 1988 Japan's Ministry of Finance so zealously browbeat the country's financial institutions to support the dollar and the American bond market that some financial analysts jokingly suggested that it should register as a Republican political action committee.
To be sure, the ministry had motives beyond influencing the American election -- Japan's economy would be crippled if a dollar crisis upsets the world financial system. But the Japanese felt that Michael Dukakis was more inclined toward protectionism than George Bush, which no doubt gave the Ministry of Finance powerful additional reasons to act.
On the surface, Japanese support for President Clinton may seem improbable. Mr. Clinton is more widely disliked in Japan than any President since Harry Truman. Although his trade initiatives have accomplished little and he long ago abandoned his campaign pledge to halve the trade deficit, his speak-loudly-and-carry-a-small-stick approach has led the Japanese public to consider him a Japan-basher.
Privately, high-ranking Japanese officials say they would love nothing more than to see the White House back in the hands of a predictable, George Bush-type Republican. But it is the Ministry of Finance, not popular views, that has the greatest control over Japan's markets. Indeed, the ministry's temporary loss of this control helped defeat George Bush in 1992.
In 1990, officials at the ministry and the Bank of Japan punctured Japan's overheated "bubble economy" -- which had made Tokyo's stock market the world's biggest and raised the market value of Japanese land -- by raising interest rates and putting controls on lending.
But these officials got more than they had bargained for. Japan's stock market fell to less than half its late 1989 peak, and banks discovered that the development projects they were financing were worth only a fraction of the tens of billions of dollars in loans taken out to finance them.
Needing cash at home, Japanese investors cut their buying of long-term United States securities, which helped send long-term American interest rates soaring. These stubbornly high rates helped keep the American recession of the early 1990's going much longer than expected, giving Bill Clinton his "It's the economy, stupid!" campaign platform.
This year, of course, Mr. Clinton needs low interest rates for the economy to work in his favor. Conventional wisdom says the Japanese can have little effect, because they have not returned to the market for long-term dollar securities and the Federal Reserve sets short-term rates.
But such reasoning ignores the one thing that could force the Fed to raise rates sharply and thus possibly doom Bill Clinton: a dollar free fall. And the Japanese help keep the dollar stable.
Japan has been running trade surpluses of more than a hundred billion dollars for each of the last four years. Its Government and private banks hold at least $350 billion -- a good half of America's external debt.
Fortunately for Bill Clinton, the Japanese authorities have almost as much to lose from a dollar crisis as he does. Japan needs a stable dollar to work out the festering bad debts of its financial system, officially estimated at some $400 billion (but possibly two or three times that large).
These bad loans have hung like a storm cloud over the Japanese economy for four years, dampening new investment and sabotaging growth. For the last few weeks, Japan has been embroiled in a political crisis over the Government's decision to liquidate seven bankrupt housing-loan companies that together managed to run up some $7 billion in uncollectable debt.
The widespread bashing of the Ministry of Finance by the Japanese media has helped the opponents of Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and increased the pressure on the ministry's bureaucrats to get the bad debt problems behind them.
For that, a stable yen-dollar rate is absolutely essential, one in which the dollar is high enough to allow Japanese corporations to earn at least moderate profits on their exports so that they can service their debt.
Last April, the value of the dollar fell in a few frightening weeks from 100 yen to less than 80. No Japanese exporter could make money at that rate; it threatened to unravel the Ministry of Finance's entire strategy for dealing with the bad debt problem. It also threatened Bill Clinton's re-election, because it signaled the possible end of the dollar's role as a global currency and with it our ability to finance the national debt without economy-crushing interest-rate hikes.
Thanks in part to an arrangement reached quietly last June between the Clinton White House and the Ministry of Finance, the dollar rebounded against the yen and has been stable. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and his deputy, Lawrence H. Summers, agreed with Japanese officials to help prop up the dollar while the Japanese supported the United States bond market.
Since then, the ministry has taken several steps to boost Japanese investment in dollar securities, including allowing insurance companies and pension funds to hold more of their assets in foreign currencies. For its part, the White House has called off the tough talk on trade and taken bold steps to shore up the dollar.
Not only is the pressure off Japan to open its economy further to American goods, but letting the dollar rise against the yen makes American goods less competitive against Japanese products. Once again, American jobs are sacrificed on the altar of a stable dollar.
Republicans can console themselves with the thought that Mr. Clinton's new allies are forcing him to govern like a Republican. Thanks to the debt run up by Presidents Reagan and Bush, Mr. Clinton has no alternative to putting the priorities of the debt holders in Japan ahead of those of working Americans.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices In Retreat Once Again

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended lower yesterday as expectations that the Federal Reserve would not soon lower short-term interest rates continued to dog the market.
A bearish mood returned to the market a day after Treasury prices recouped about a third of what they lost in the selloff on Friday. Still, a late wave of buying helped bonds erase much of the day's declines. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond settled down 1 3/32, to 91 14/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.66 percent, from 6.63 percent on Monday. Shorter-maturity bills, however, did fare better, supported by investors fleeing the volatility of the stock market. The rate for a three-month bill was unchanged at 4.95 percent.
Bond prices were under pressure at the opening because of selling in overseas markets overnight. Prices fell further after the Mitsubishi Bank/Schroder Wertheim weekly survey of chain-store sales showed more strength than expected. The survey's index rose 1 percent for the week that ended Saturday.
"With enough people in the market harboring bearish sentiment it didn't take much to get the selling started," said Theodore Ake, government trading manager at Everen Securities Inc. in Chicago.
But another weekly retail report, from Johnson Redbook, seemed to counter the Mitsubishi data. The Johnson Redbook report, released in the afternoon, showed a drop of 1.5 percent in the first week of March. The report helped bond prices turn around by the end of the day.
Bonds also got some support from a weak manufacturing report from the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta and from a Commerce Department report showing a rise of seven-tenths of 1 percent in wholesale inventories, an increase that was greater than had been expected. The reports pointed to continued weakness in the economy, reviving hopes among some in the market that the Federal Reserve could still cut rates.
As a result, the data prompted some short-cover buying by speculators who had bet against a rise in bond prices, Mr. Ake of Everen Securities said. "Besides that, there are a number of large accounts sitting on the sidelines with cash on hand who continue to come in and take advantage of the stable moments in the market to buy," he said.
Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, agreed that the Atlanta Fed survey indicated a significant deterioration in activity during February. "These data are in sharp contrast to the recently reported employment data, at minimum raising the red flag to the reliability of that data," she said.
More clues to the state of the economy will be available tomorrow when the Government reports on producer prices. Reports on consumer prices and industrial production will be released on Friday.
In other action in the Treasury market yesterday, the Government announced that it would sell $9 billion of 42-day cash-management bills today to raise cash to pay a cash- management bill maturing tomorrow.
In the municipal bond market, Merrill Lynch & Company made the wining bid on $430 million of general obligation bonds from the State of Georgia, priced to yield from 4.15 percent for maturities in 1999 to 5.55 percent in 2015. The debt is rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service and AA+ by Standard & Poor's.
Rising rates prompted the Puerto Rico Highway and Transportation Authority to postpone its sale of $834 million in revenue bonds. That sale, which was to have been negotiated through Merrill Lynch, would have been the largest bond pricing of the week.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Lower, Tracking A Hard Day's Trading Gyrations

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar followed American bond and most stock prices lower yesterday.
The dollar was also under pressure as expectations for steady interest rates in Germany and Switzerland bolstered the Swiss franc and the German mark. 
 Tensions between China and Taiwan weakened the Japanese yen and were viewed as potentially negative for the dollar because of the possibility of United States involvement in the conflict, market analysts said.
"We were seeing a good bit of buying of marks," said Kevin Harris, international economist at MCM Currency Watch. "The funds were coming out of the dollar in frustration with the U.S. markets."
In trading in New York, the dollar largely mirrored the ups and downs of the volatile investment markets. It fell to its lows of the day as stocks bottomed out, with the Dow Jones industrial average down 95 points. The dollar then trimmed losses ahead of the close in tandem with other markets.
Falling markets often hurt the dollar's value because demand from foreign investors wanting to buy American assets diminishes. But yesterday's response differed sharply from that on Friday, when the dollar largely shrugged off stock and bond plunges. Currency traders then focused instead on the prospects for American interest rates' remaining steady or rising -- which tends to help a nation's currency.
Yesterday, the stock market erased most losses by the close and ended mixed while bonds were weaker but off their lows, as well.
In late trading in New York, the dollar slipped to 1.4745 marks from 1.4807 marks on Monday. It was quoted at 105.25 yen, down from 105.41 yen. The British pound fell to $1.5235 from $1.5241.
The mark and Swiss franc gained broadly after the president of the Swiss central bank, Markus Lusser, said he saw no need at the moment to cut interest rates further, while a Bundesbank official, Franz-Christoph Zeitler, said the German bank might have room for further rate cuts if factors like money supply and market rates allowed.
His comments followed those by another member of the bank's rate-setting council, Ernst Welteke, who said on Monday that lowering the discount rate would be hard, given the rise in long-term bond yields.
The yen came under pressure as China began war games in the Taiwan Strait. Investors moved money out of yen into Singapore, Australian and New Zealand dollars and possibly the mark and Swiss franc as safe-haven currencies.

HEADLINE: Sovietologists, Years After the Collapse, Cope With a New Reality

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
With breathtaking suddenness in 1991, the cadre of academicians popularly known as Kremlinologists -- pampered and privileged by years of Federal, foundation and academic patronage -- found themselves outmoded.
The Soviet Union had collapsed, the cold war was over and, despite their vaunted scholarship, linguistic proficiency and esoteric reporting skills, they had utterly failed to foresee one of the turning points of the 20th century. 
 Hand-wringing and mea culpas echoed from the pages of the liberal Nation to the neo-conservative National Interest, with the latter asking, "Why did it take virtually everyone -- and especially most of the supposed experts -- by surprise?"
There has been no shortage of answers. One of the more ingenious came from Vladimir Kontorovich, a Haverford College Sovietologist, who argued that had it not been for Yuri V. Andropov's weak kidneys the Soviet Union would still be in business today. Mr. Andropov's death in 1984 made possible the ascension of Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
Now, five years after the Soviet collapse, the effect on the profession has been profound. Subsidies from both the Government and the private sector are rapidly drying up. Students look elsewhere for more promising careers. Academic departments shrivel by attrition and sometimes by more drastic means.
"It's a classic case of restructuring taken from the corporate world," said L. Jay Oliva, president of New York University and a professor of Russian history. "You have people who are experts on a vanished age, and so the question is, How do they retool?"
Many have given up and retired. Some are turning their attention to Eastern Europe and Latin America or issues with international scope like protection of the environment. And there are indications that post-Soviet regional studies are proving attractive to a new generation of scholars excited by the fact that the field is now liberated from the static ideological clashes of the cold war.
"Three of my students are organizing a conference on private life in Russia," said Jane Burbank, who is on sabbatical as director of the Center for Russian and East European Studies at the University of Michigan. "That's something we could never have done in the past when we were preoccupied with the cold war."
On the other hand, not a few ex-Kremlinologists are fighting the trend with warnings that Russia, even shorn of the newly independent states, is still the world's largest nation and one with plenty of nuclear power. Further, they say, the rise of the ultranationalist Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, who has evoked comparisons with Stalin, suggests the possibility of a rising tyranny that could threaten world peace.
But the general public has lost interest in the field. Mark Von Hagen, director of the Harriman Institute at Columbia University, called the public's new attitude "triumphalism -- the arrogant belief that we won the cold war because we were right and nothing more needs to be said about it." The Harriman Institute was one of the chief centers of Kremlinology, but now concerns itself broadly with the study of Russia, the Soviet Union and the successor states.
Congress has sharply reduced Federal grants for post-doctoral research, area studies and training in the languages of former Soviet bloc countries. Even more striking is the fact that most private foundations have virtually abandoned the field.
"The ostensible object of our study no longer existed," said Hillel Frandkin, vice president of cultural and international programs at the Bradley Foundation, a Milwaukee institution that until recently supported Soviet studies at Harvard University and the University of California at Los Angeles.
Shepard Forman, director of international affairs programs at the Ford Foundation, said that since Russia seemed to be on the way to becoming an open society it was time to support Russian studies by Russian scholars working inside Russia. In order to explore such prospects, Mr. Forman said, Ford opened an office in Moscow earlier this year.
The Russian Research Center at Harvard announced last month that it had received a $10 million pledge from a longtime supporter, and in gratitude would change its name in April to the Kathryn W. and Shelby Cullom Davis Center for Russian Studies.
"It couldn't have come at a better time," Marshall I. Goldman, associate director of the center, said of the pledge. "After the end of the cold war, we lost the support of Mellon, Ford, MacArthur and Bradley."
Post-Soviet scholarship also suffers from a lack of interest among university presses. "It used to be that they would take just about anything we had to offer, but now they shy away from us," said Alvin Z. Rubinstein, a specialist on Soviet foreign policy at the University of Pennsylvania.
Given the situation, it is not surprising that college students are seeking other career paths. David Maxwell, director of the National Foreign Language Center in Washington, said a recent survey showed that college and university-level study of Russian in the United States declined 30 percent to 50 percent from 1989 to 1994.
"Today, more students want to study Japanese and Swahili than Russian," said Kermit Hall, the dean of humanities at Ohio State University. Mr. Hall said he anticipated sharp cuts in the department of Slavic and East European languages and literature, which has already lost about one-third of its faculty.
Across the nation, Soviet-studies professors who retire are not being replaced. At the University of Pennsylvania a few years ago, three members of the history department devoted themselves to Soviet studies. Now, two have retired, one is on long-term leave and almost no one expects any of the three to be replaced by Soviet or Russian specialists.
Unlike universities, independently endowed centers like the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace at Stanford University and the Harriman Institute are much less vulnerable to intellectual trends and fashions. Yet Hoover, which is cushioned by its $165 million endowment, still has to raise about $5 million a year and nowadays finds it much easier to come by that sum for domestic rather than international studies.
Despite their ideological divisions, post-Soviet Russian scholars are united today in their belief that they -- and the problems of that part of the world about which they have special knowledge -- have been written off prematurely.
Richard F. Staar, a former United States arms negotiator and now a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution, is one of a minority in the field who argue that Russia remains a potential military threat.
"It may take a generation," Mr. Staar said, "but they'll solve their problems and emerge in the big league of world politics.
"We like to say their fleet is rusting at Vladivostok. Well, their new submarine, the Akula-II, is quieter than ours, and fires a nuclear-tipped missile. They're developing a new ICBM, the Topol-M, which had two successful tests over the last several months. They have five new types of military aircraft under development."
James H. Billington, the Librarian of Congress and an authority on Russian history, also recognizes many risks, but he is generally optimistic. "Rational self-interest should dictate our continued study of Russia," Mr. Billington said. "There's a chance it could become another United States with huge national resources and a highly educated work force."
William C. Potter, a defense expert and director of the Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies at the Monterey Institute of International Studies, dismisses as "paranoid" the notion of Russia as a military threat, but agrees that the region bears close watching because of frighteningly lax safety standards at more than 50 nuclear power plants throughout the former Soviet Union.
Many of these scholars comment on the paradox that at a time when Soviet archives are open as never before there are fewer American students and scholars able to study them. The Hoover Institution is busily engaged in microfilming records of the Soviet Communist Party in an arrangement with the State Archival Service of Russia. Nearly eight million documents have been copied.
Another striking feature of post-Soviet Russian studies is that the old ideological rift is gradually giving way to a generational one.
Senior members of the profession who maintain their deep suspicion of Russia are typified by Myron Rush, an emeritus professor of Soviet affairs at Cornell University whose tour de force of Kremlinology in 1955 revealed to the world that Nikita S. Khrushchev had become Stalin's successor.
Professor Rush had noticed that the official Soviet press sometimes capitalized the words "First Secretary" of the Communist Party in rendering Mr. Khrushchev's title. But sometimes the title was not capitalized. Being a microscopic reader of the Soviet press, he recognized that the variation was not a matter of typographical carelessness but reflected Mr. Khrushchev's fortunes in the Kremlin power struggle.
Within a few days, Professor Rush saw that the word "First" in Mr. Khrushchev's title began to be consistently capitalized, and then -- like an astronomer discovering a new planet -- he was able to announce Mr. Khrushchev's ascendance.
Younger scholars express admiration for the feats of scholars like Professor Rush, but say that such work has little in common with their own.
"Back when you didn't have any information, you had to impute a lot," said Professor Von Hagen, who at 41 is a member of the rising generation of historians of the Soviet Union. "Today we adhere more to professional scholarly standards. Let's just say there's less room for creative speculation."
Michael McFaul, a young politicial scientist at Stanford, said: "The isolation of the older generation of Sovietologists sitting here in California was probably not a good thing. They looked at Russia as totalitarian, but it isn't that any more. It may be more like what you have in Latin America. We need to have more people go there and see what's happening."
Still, the old guard and the new have at least one thing in common. "Today we are afflicted with a great humility," said Arnold Beichman, a research fellow at Hoover. "We were all wrong. And we know it."
 
An Array of Grants Dips For Post-Soviet Studies
 
 Support for post-Soviet studies has markedly declined in recent years. Following are some examples of the loss of support.
Last year, grants for postdoctoral research, area studies and training in the languages of former Soviet bloc countries under Title 8 of the National Higher Education Act were reduced to $7.5 million from $10 million.
Federal grants under Title 6 for fellowships for foreign-language study -- a large share of which has helped to keep alive the study of such languages as Ukrainian, Uzbek and Kazakh -- have aroused opposition in Congress and their future is uncertain.
The Andrew Mellon Foundation, which in the 1980's gave grants of $1 million and $500,000 to Soviet studies programs at Columbia, Harvard, the University of California at Berkeley and the University of Michigan, has discontinued almost all of those programs. Much of the money has been redirected to East European research.
The Bradley Foundation, which poured $250,000 a year from 1988 to 1990 into the Russian Research Center at Harvard and a little less to a similar program at the University of California at Los Angeles, has discontinued both grants.
The Ford Foundation markedly decreased its support for Russian studies in the United States but recently gave about $1 million to the Russian Science Foundation in Moscow to set up a competition for research fellowships for Russian scholars in the social sciences and economics.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Mark Von Hagen, top, of the Harriman Institute, said the public believes the cold war is won and "nothing more needs to be said." But Richard F. Staar, of the Hoover Institution, says Russia remains a threat. (Darcy Padilla for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 536 words

HEADLINE: Governor Rowland's First Year

 BODY:
Gov. John Rowland has rightly focused attention on the problems of Connecticut's troubled cities. But he also promised to reduce spending that is vital to urban areas and to deliver a $200 million tax cut that will make it even harder in future years to assist the cities. The Connecticut Conference of Municipalities, which represents the state's cities and towns, has estimated that the Governor's proposed cuts in aid to municipalities add up to $65.4 million for 1996-97. The group has begged him to put off the tax cut. He should forget about it altogether.
The nonpartisan Office of Fiscal Analysis estimates that the state faces a shortfall of $2 billion over the next four years -- a deficit that will become even worse if Mr. Rowland carries through on an election promise to abolish the state's income tax over that same period. True, the Governor wants to pay for most of the first year's tax cut by selling off a small part of the state-owned lottery to private investors. But that is an ill-conceived solution that provides relief for only one year. 
 Although it has the highest per capita income of any state, Connecticut contains three of the country's poorest cities, and four that are losing population the fastest. Badly hit by the decline of the insurance, defense and banking industries, it lost about 162,000 jobs in the recent recession and its personal income growth rate has been the slowest in the nation in recent years. The State Comptroller estimates that only 14 percent of the job losses had been recovered by the second quarter of last year. The middle class has fled the cities, decimating their tax base.
The state's last Governor, Lowell Weicker, pushed through the state's first income tax in 1991, then did not seek a second term. Governor Rowland campaigned on a pledge to abolish the income tax within five years. But once in office he realized that he could not immediately repeal the tax, which provides some $2.6 billion a year, more than a quarter of the state's revenues, so he has proposed a $200 million cut for the next fiscal year instead.
Mr. Rowland plans to partly replace the lost income tax revenues by selling 6 percent of the state lottery to private shareholders. But the lottery sale would not make up for the continuing lost revenue. Comptroller Nancy Wyman notes that Mr. Rowland's plans also do not include an inevitable cutback in Federal assistance and are overly optimistic about revenue growth.
Mr. Rowland is relatively young, 38, and energetic. His concern for the cities -- he hails from Waterbury -- seems genuine, but his promised tax cut makes it virtually impossible for him to give them any substantial relief. He has little support for the lottery sale in the financial community and faces skepticism in the Legislature, which will have to approve any plan.
Mr. Rowland is also trying to balance his budget by cutting general assistance recipients off after two months, reducing rental assistance and cutting money for school transportation and property tax relief for the elderly. If he insists on an ill-advised tax cut, and on temporizing with a partial sale of the lottery, Connecticut's cities will continue to bleed.

HEADLINE: Rich Are Getting Richer, but Not the Very Rich

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
The rich appear to have gotten richer in the early years of this decade, according to Federal statistics issued today, but this time they did it at the expense of the super-rich.
The portion of the nation's wealth in the hands of the richest 1 percent of Americans declined to 30.4 percent from 37.1 percent from 1989 to 1992, a survey for the Federal Reserve and the Internal Revenue Service showed. The next richest 9 percent saw their share of the wealth grow to 36.8 percent from 31.2 percent. 
 The results of the 1992 Survey of Consumer Finances, however, showed little or no improvement in the relative position of the vast majority of the population. The bottom 90 percent of Americans saw their share of the wealth rise to 32.8 percent in 1992 from 31.8 percent in 1989, a statistically insignificant increase.
Much has changed in the economy since 1992, including the biggest bull stock market in history. Further, economists said they were concerned that the survey, which is conducted every three years and is the most comprehensive of its kind, might have been plagued by problems that yielded unreliable findings this time around. Moreover, the survey results appear to contradict other findings that indicate a continuing growth in economic inequality.
But assuming the results are valid, they said, the figures indicated a sharp reversal in the trend of the 1980's, when wealth became increasingly concentrated among the very richest households.
"If it's true, it would certainly be good news," said Edward Wolff, an economics professor at New York University who studies wealth and income distribution. "It would show that the tremendous increase in inequality that occurred during the 1980's has not only stopped, but actually reversed."
The survey showed that the aggregate wealth of the bottom 90 percent of Americans grew by 20 percent from 1989 to 1992. The total net household worth of the richest 1 percent declined by 4.6 percent during that period, while the biggest winners, the next 9 percent, saw their total wealth increase 37 percent.
Long the subject of ideological debate, studies showing increasing income and wealth inequalities were an issue in the 1992 Presidential campaign, with Democrats charging that 12 years of Republicans in the White House had led to policies favoring a wealthy elite at the expense of the middle class.
Today's figures, if valid, suggest that concentration of wealth at the very top of the scale was moderating even before Bill Clinton regained the Presidency for the Democrats in 1992.
But because they show little change in the relative position of the vast majority of people -- a transfer of wealth from, say, Donald Trump to a Greenwich stockbroker is unlikely to resonate with the middle class -- today's numbers will probably only underscore the themes of economic insecurity that have played a large role in this year's Presidential race.
"Even if you take the numbers at face value, if you look at the bottom 90 percent of the population, it's still lost in this story," said Dean Baker, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute, a research group in Washington. "The gainers are still disproportionately those at the top."
"If you could really show big changes across the board, or down to the 50th or 60th percentile, it might make a difference," Mr. Baker added. "But someone concerned about holding onto a job is not going to stop being concerned because somebody at the 90th percentile is gaining from someone at the 99th percentile."
The figures suggested that the distribution of wealth had reverted approximately to where it was in 1983. At that time, 31.5 percent of wealth was held by 1 percent of the population, with 35.1 percent in the next 9 percent of the population and 33.4 percent held by the bottom 90 percent of Americans.
The sharpest fall was in the top half of 1 percent of households. That group saw its share of wealth fall to 22.8 percent in 1992 from 28.8 percent in 1989.
The survey defines wealth as household net worth -- or the total of a household's assets, including real estate, stocks, bonds, insurance policies, self-owned businesses and savings accounts, minus its liabilities, meaning all debts including mortgages and credit cards.
The results of the survey were released by the Federal Reserve in the form of a working paper on the methodology of the project. In its only general analysis of the results, the paper, by Arthur B. Kennickell of the Federal Reserve, Douglas A. McManus of Freddie Mac and R. Louise Woodburn of the Internal Revenue Service, said that the aggregate net worth of the top half of 1 percent of households fell 8 percent from 1989 to 1992, while the total for all households rose 17 percent.
"There were also sizable declines in the top group's holdings of bonds, trusts and other assets," the paper said. "This drop in the wealth of this group may reflect directly or indirectly the lingering effects of the 1991-92 recession, falling prices for real estate, the rise in business failures, or a cooling in the markets for some financial assets and for art."
Economists outside the Government said that surveys of this sort were plagued by the problem of getting people to fill out lengthy questionnaires fully and accurately. In addition, the Government agencies hired a different outside group to do the survey work than they had in 1989, and used different techniques to account for the difficulty of adequately representing the wealthiest households in the sample.
Economists also said the survey's results were hard to reconcile with research that showed that other measures of inequality, particularly in income, had continued to increase during the period.
"The income numbers show widening inequality in a host of different ways," said Claudia Goldin, an economic historian at Harvard University.
Among the most striking findings of the survey was a shift in holdings of stocks. In 1989, the top 1 percent of households held 49.4 percent of the value of equities, with the next 9 percent holding 35.9 percent and the bottom 90 percent holding 14.6 percent.
In the 1992 results, the top 1 percent held 38.8 percent, with the next 9 percent holding 42.3 percent and the bottom 90 percent holding 18.9 percent.

HEADLINE: C.I.A. Confirms Blunders During Economic Spying on France

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
Blunders by Central Intelligence Agency operatives trying to gather secret information on French trade negotiations and economic espionage led to an international embarrassment, a report by the agency's inspector general concluded today.
The career of one legendary spy is over, the agency's role in gathering economic intelligence may be damaged, and its reputation may suffer another self-inflicted wound as a result of the internal investigation into the C.I.A.'s Paris station, officials familiar with the report said. 
 The report, which is classified, is likely to intensify the debate over the risks and rewards of spying on allies for economic intelligence.
It found that the C.I.A. station chief in Paris, Dick Holm, kept the United States Ambassador to France, Pamela Harriman, in the dark about important aspects of his work, the officials said. They said Mr. Holm allowed an operative to carry on a love affair with the French official she was targeting, a decision that may have doomed the operation. And his underlings, including the lovestruck spy, made serious blunders that led to an international embarrassment, they said.
Mr. Holm retired last year while waiting for the inspector general to compete his report. He is a famous figure to his fellow cold warriors. He was flying into Zaire -- then the Belgian Congo -- during a counterinsurgency operation in 1962 when his light plane disappeared from the radar. He was presumed lost. But he lived, though horribly burned and permanently scarred, and was nursed by villagers who pulled him from the wreckage.
The wreckage of the Paris operation goes beyond Mr. Holm's career. Joseph DeTrani, chief of the Europe division of the C.I.A.'s clandestine service, has been placed in administrative limbo and at least four covert operators have been recalled from Paris. The inspector general's report will be shared with the congressional intelligence committees, some of whose members are likely to use it as a club with which to bash the C.I.A. for its work in the field of economic intelligence.
Officials familiar with the report said the basic facts of the case were accurately disclosed by France's Interior Minister, Charles Pasqua, in February 1995. In interviews, intelligence officials added details to the story, which was a major embarrassment for the C.I.A. when the French revealed it.
In 1993, R. James Woolsey, then a new Director of Central Intelligence, publicly announced that economic intelligence was a major new priority for the C.I.A. This naturally entailed spying on allies like Japan, Germany and France. The French had been particularly aggressive in spying on American executives -- bugging and stealing from hotel rooms, for example. "No more Mr. Nice Guy," Mr. Woolsey warned in a speech.
Soon the C.I.A.'s Paris station had at least five operatives -- four officers posing as diplomats and a woman posing as the Paris representative of a private American foundation -- working on a two-pronged project. They were assigned to uncover French positions on world trade talks and to counter French economic espionage against American companies.
The undercover operative posing as a foundation representative made fundamental mistakes: communicating too openly with the C.I.A. station and communing too secretly with her target, a French official. Mr. Holm, the station chief, found out about the love affair she was conducting with the official. It was clear that the romance could compromise the operation. He and Mr. DeTrani, his boss as chief of the Europe division, agonized over whether to abort it. Mr. Holm wanted to carry on, and he convinced his boss.
Neither man told Ambassador Harriman that their operation existed, was imperiled and could be exposed. But French counterintelligence officials soon knew that a network of C.I.A. officers was operating against them. Either through sloppy work or through pillow talk, the undercover operative had revealed her secret status as a spy. The operation quickly unraveled.
The French, breaching the traditional protocol in such cases, raised an uproar over the spying rather than letting the four accused spies working under diplomatic cover slip out of the country for activities, as the phrase goes, "incompatible with their diplomatic status." The ensuing publicity raised questions about whether spying on allies for economic data is a worthy pursuit for the C.I.A., or whether its operatives would do better to concentrate on the activities of terrorists and other deep political secrets abroad.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Protesters Fight a Plan For Washington's Home

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: FALMOUTH, Va., March 11

 BODY:
If George Washington really cut down that cherry tree, this is where it happened, on the back edge of Ferry Farm, his boyhood home. It is also where he tossed a dollar across the Rappahannock River, or maybe it was a stone or maybe that never really happened, either.
Anyway, this much is certain: The future first president lived here in Stafford County with his family on nearly 600 acres along the river from the time he was 6 years old to age 20. And now Wal-Mart wants to build a store on a piece of the 70 acres of the farm that remain, plans that have touched off the latest in a series of emotional fights in Virginia, pitting historians against the forces of economic development eager to create jobs and tax revenues. 
 So far, historians have held their own. In recent years, they have defeated attempts to put a Formula One race track on the Brandy Station Civil War battlefield in Culpeper County, a shopping mall on Civil War battlefields near Manassas and a Walt Disney theme park near Civil War battlefields in Haymarket.
But this latest clash could deal them a mighty blow.
Six years ago, the county agreed to rezone about 25 acres at the southern end of the farm from agricultural to commercial; in exchange, the current owners, the Samuel Warren family of Arlington, Va., would donate the remaining tract to the county. County supervisors who negotiated the deal hailed it as a major coup, preserving acreage that included the Washington family residence for a much-needed tourist attraction to compete with nearby historical sites in Fredericksburg and elsewhere.
The Warrens then negotiated a deal with developers in Richmond.
But when the developers found a willing tenant in Wal-Mart, and the retailer last month announced plans to build a 93,000-square-foot store, leaving space for an adjacent small shopping center, the mood among historians and many local residents turned downright revolutionary.
Even promises by Wal-Mart to plant a 50-foot buffer of trees to hide all commercial development from the farm and to offer $100,000 in matching funds to build the tourist attraction has failed to blunt their attempts to drive Wal-Mart away.
"A store of that size and all the additional facilities will simply overwhelm the farm," said Richard Moe, president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, which had also worked to oppose the Disney project.
While much of the original Ferry Farm has long since been developed with houses, stores and fast-food restaurants -- a McDonald's and 7-11 are plainly visible across a highway from the presumed cherry tree incident -- historians contend that the remaining acres are probably filled with artifacts of the era.
Earlier studies of the property, which Washington's father, Augustine, bought in 1738, produced evidence that at least seven slaves also lived on the farm and that one of Augustine's daughters, Mildred, who died at the age of 1, is buried near the residence, only a foundation of which remains after a fire in the late 1700's.
Augustine Washington died in April 1743, leaving the farm to George, and he spent much of the next nine years there with his mother, Mary Ball Washington, and her four other children until he moved north to Mount Vernon in the French and Indian War. His mother continued living in the farm house until she moved across the river to Fredericksburg in 1772, at the age of 64.
Washington sold the farm in 1774, 15 years before he became president.
Groups opposed to the Wal-Mart store have tried a variety of tactics to thwart the development. They have argued before county supervisors and the five members of the county Architectural Review Board, which is scheduled to vote April 1 on the Wal-Mart plans. They have staged rallies, written letters and pleaded with Wal-Mart executives to choose another site in the area.
"This is the most important historic site in Stafford County," Bill Beck, president of the Historic Fredericksburg Foundation, told the review board during a hearing today that was attended by 200 people, most of them opponents of the Wal-Mart store. "If you allow this, you cannot deny anything in any other site."
Charles L. Cabell, a lawyer representing the Richmond developers, told the board that Wal-Mart would do whatever was necessary to comply with regulations, even use colonial-style light poles in the parking lot and colonial-style bricks in construction. He assured them that Wal-Mart executives were sensitive to the concerns of historians and did not want to spoil a national treasure.
Some opponents expressed the fear that if the Wal-Mart is built, Ferry Farm's application to become a National Historical Landmark, like Mount Vernon and Washington's birthplace 30 miles east of here, would be denied. But all vowed to fight on and some seemed hopeful that they would prevail. In her closing remarks to the board today, Rae Ely, a lawyer from Gordonsville, Va., suggested the April 1 vote might become the board's "finest hour."
"One of the wealthiest corporations is in front of you," she said, "and all of the people of the United States are behind you. This is a sacred trust."
When she finished, scores of opponents in the audience leaped to their feet and led by a woman dressed like George Washington's mother, began singing "America."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
N.F.L. Won't Use Replay in 1996

BYLINE: By THOMAS GEORGE 

DATELINE: PALM BEACH, Fla., March 12

 BODY:
Instant re play used from the 1986 through the 1991 seasons and creating as many problems as it did solutions -- is not likely to return for the 1996 National Football League season, but may be used on an experimental basis this fall, Paul Tagliabue, the league's commissioner, said at the league owners meeting here today.
Partly because 21 of the N.F.L.'s 30 current head coaches were not in that position when instant replay was last used in 1991, there has been new support from coaches for the return of instant replay. Despite the many headaches instant replay caused, including long game delays and controversy even after reviews, these coaches say that replay still has merits. They want it back in a new form. 
 The owners, who will make the final decision, appear unconvinced that instant replay is needed. A vote on whether to experiment with it further during the coming season will most likely be held here Wednesday.
"My sense is that everybody feels that if we're going to have replay, we should look for a concept that works, maybe with experimentation in '96 and implementation in '97," Tagliabue said. "There is feeling that replay can be used as an officiating supplement. But we want to do it right."
The questions the owners ask about replay include:
*Who triggers review of a play or call?
*Who makes the call?
*What are the plays that are covered?
Answers to those questions remain elusive. In the old system, officials made the decision on which play to review. The new system could involve challenges, where coaches could ask for review. In the old system, replay officials in a booth made the call. In the new one, a sideline monitor and official would help the referee.
The old system mainly covered plays that involved change of possession. The new one could involve scoring plays, out-of-bound plays and possession calls.
"Even there, in the scoring plays, you have questions," Tagliabue said. "What is a scoring play? Is it one where the guy stepped out of the end zone? Or is it a fumble at the 5-yard line that would have been a scoring play? There are plenty of things still to be evaluated on this concept."
In other news, the owners heard from Phil Bredesen, the Mayor of Nashville, which has lured the Oilers from Houston. On Monday, the Houston Mayor, Bob Lanier, made a folksy presentation on why Houston deserved another N.F.L. franchise if the Oilers did leave; at the very least, Lanier said, the Oilers should fulfill the final two years on their contract at the Astrodome.
Bredesen said today that his city had proposed building a $290 million stadium in downtown Nashville and that the mid-South region of America "is an enormous business and economic opportunity with Nashville serving as the center because of its music industry."
He said that more than 46,000 private-seat licenses to help build the stadium had already been sold, accounting for $71.5 million. "We asked for our day in court, and we had that today," he said.
The Seattle Seahawks' planned move to Los Angeles appears to be more of a problem. Both sides will very likely wind up in court, Tagliabue said, and he added that the concerns over the Seahawks' current playing site, the Kingdome, residing on a seismic fault is a concern "that should not be taken lightly."

HEADLINE: Mount Sinai Rejects Plan To Run Public Hospitals

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
In a surprising setback to the city's efforts to dismantle its public hospital system, Mount Sinai Medical Center has withdrawn from the bidding to take over Elmhurst Hospital Center and Queens Hospital Center, two of the three hospitals that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had offered for long-term lease.
Mount Sinai, which has long been affiliated with the two hospitals and which has provided the medical staff for Elmhurst for almost 25 years, had been considered the obvious candidate to take over the Queens hospitals. And its decision to pull out of the bidding leaves the future of the two institutions -- as well as the Mayor's plan to dismantle the Health and Hospitals Corporation -- very much up in the air. 
 "From the beginning Mount Sinai had been viewed as the pre-emptive favorite for the Queens sites," said James R. Tallon, the president of the United Hospital Fund, a research and philanthropic group. "It doesn't suggest that this is impossible, but it does suggest that putting these marriages together is going to be a pretty complicated thing."
Mount Sinai officials refused to comment on the decision or even to confirm it. "We entered into a confidentiality agreement with the city at the start of the bidding process," said Mel Granick, the hospital's director of public affairs.
But in a letter to Mount Sinai employees who work at the two hospitals, Dr. John W. Rowe, the president of Mount Sinai, said that the terms of the leases laid out by the city were unacceptable.
Mount Sinai "reluctantly concluded that we could not submit a formal binding proposal consistent with the terms and conditions required by the city at this time," he wrote.
City officials also confirmed the withdrawal. "We regret that Mount Sinai has elected not to submit a bid for Elmhurst," said Coleen A. Roche, the Mayor's spokeswoman. "The city will, however, go forward with those who have expressed interest." But she would not disclose how many bids had been submitted.
One known bidder is New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. Myrna Manners, a spokeswoman for the hospital, said it had recently bid for the two Queens hospitals as well as for Coney Island Hospital in Brooklyn. Catholic Medical Center has also expressed interest in the Queens hospitals.
But until today, both were considered dark-horse candidates that would -- if their bids succeeded -- be taking over struggling hospitals that were unfamiliar to them.
The proposal to find new operators for Elmhurst, Queens and Coney Island hospitals was intended as the first step in the Mayor's ambitious plan to privatize a significant part of the public hospital system. Elmhurst and Queens, which are close to each other, were offered as a package deal, with the stipulation that the buyer would be required to rebuild Queens, a tired, aging complex.
Many health analysts said that the Mayor had chosen the two hospitals as guinea pigs in the privatization experiment, in part because it was considered a sure bet that Mount Sinai would buy them.
Since the plan to sell the hospitals was put forth last year, it has been hit by lawsuits from the City Council and community groups seeking to bar the hospital leases, and by a scarcity of interested bidders. The Council contends that the Mayor does not have the authority to sell or lease the hospitals.
Opponents of the sale expressed relief at Mount Sinai's decision. "This throws a monkey wrench into the privatization train," said Rory Lancman, chairman of the community advisory board for Queens Hospital Center, which opposes the Mayor's plan. "It confirms what we've been saying all along: that selling a public hospital is a lot more complicated than the Mayor thinks."
Health care experts said the withdrawal underscored the difficulty of finding private operators for public hospitals, particularly while the financing of health care for the poor was so uncertain. Mr. Tallon said that recent Medicaid cuts from Albany and the specter of further cuts in the next year may have made private hospitals warier about taking over a public hospital, so that deals that seemed sweet in 1995 may have soured by now.
It is unclear exactly what turned Mount Sinai, which previously expressed interest, away from the plan, although many health experts have said that it would make more economic sense to shrink Queens Hospital Center than to rebuild it.
Also, the Health and Hospitals Corporation currently pays Mount Sinai well over $50 million annually to provide doctors for the two Queens Hospitals. Some health care experts speculated that the issue of how to compensate Mount Sinai for this loss of income if it became the owner of the hospitals was a sticking point in the negotiation.
Although Dr. Rowe's letter to employees dangled the possibility that Mount Sinai might negotiate an "alternative approach" with the city to the current bidding process, it is unclear what that approach might be, and the Mayor's office said it was pressing on with its bidding plan.

HEADLINE: Ex-Soviet A-Bomb Fuel an Easy Target for Terrorists, U.S. Says

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
The republics of the former Soviet Union cannot account for a large share of the hundreds of tons of bomb-grade uranium and plutonium once listed in their stockpiles, creating a "primary national security concern for the United States," Government investigators are warning in a new report.
The investigators say that the nuclear material is an easy target for smugglers and terrorists, given the lax security procedures at scores of civilian and military nuclear sites throughout the former Soviet Union, and that the United States has little ability to track the material if it is stolen. 
 In the report, to be released on Wednesday, the investigators for the General Accounting Office said, for example, that they had been able to wander into one prominent nuclear storage site in Moscow, the Kurchatov Institute, without showing identification, and that it had been guarded by a single unarmed policeman.
While the investigators said they had no direct evidence of the existence of a nuclear black market linking sellers in the former Soviet Union to buyers elsewhere, the recent seizure of nuclear material in Russia, Germany and the Czech Republic suggests that a black market could be forming.
The report was prepared for the Senate Government Affairs permanent subcommittee on investigations, a panel whose leaders have joined in a bipartisan call for the Clinton Administration to step up programs aimed at controlling the international spread of materials used to make nuclear, chemical and biological weapons.
While there has long been concern over the smuggling of uranium and plutonium from the former Soviet Union, the report provided several new, disturbing details on the lax security systems protecting nuclear stockpiles, and on the ease with which thieves could steal and sell nuclear components.
The report suggested that social and economic tensions in former Soviet republics had created new opportunities for nuclear thieves and terrorists, with employees in nuclear plants so poorly paid and demoralized that many might be tempted to steal.
"The challenge is to insure that the former Soviet Union does not become a vast supermarket for the most deadly instruments known to man," said Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, the senior Democrat on the investigations subcommittee. "Unfortunately, there already appear to be many prospective customers."
The General Accounting Office report said that when the Soviet Union fragmented in 1991, it had stocks of 1,200 tons of highly enriched uranium and 200 tons of plutonium, some built into warheads but much held in civilian and military storage sites in containers small enough to be carried by one or two people.
Now, the report found, the nuclear material is scattered across Russia and several other republics, and many of the newly independent governments are clearly unable to provide adequate security. The report said the material would be highly attractive to terrorist groups because it was easy to transport and could be easily converted to weapons use.
The investigators from the General Accounting Office said they had traveled to nuclear sites throughout the former Soviet Union and found that several had no "comprehensive" records on the size of their stockpiles of uranium and plutonium.
At one site in the Russian city of Obninsk, the Institute of Physics and Power Engineering, Russian officials said that there were 70,000 to 80,000 small disks of uranium and plutonium, but that they had no exact count.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Cone Says His Fastball Is Popping and Hopping

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY 

DATELINE: DUNEDIN, Fla., March 12

 BODY:
David Cone has never been concerned about regaining his precise touch on pitches and getting his splendid right arm to perform productively. He chuckles at speculation that he has thrown too many pitches to be effective anymore and he reminds doubters that the Mets whispered about his supposedly overworked arm after trading him four years ago.
Guess what? Cone is still ticking. 
 Except now Cone is with the Yankees, and every pitch he throws is scrutinized because he is the unchallenged leader of the still-evolving staff and perhaps the new leader of the team. So even when he stumbles slightly in spring training, Cone hears questions about his arm. Then he pitches and silences the critics again. "It was never to a point," said Cone, "where I doubted whether I could do it again."
Cone set the tone for the Yankees again today by breathing life into his fastball and sharpening his breaking pitches to plow through five innings and help the Yankees defeat the Toronto Blue Jays, 8-7. Forget that he allowed three runs, three hits and walked three, Cone said, because he had crisp stuff. In 78 pitches, he displayed better arm strength as he struck out three batters and retired the side in order three times.
Should anyone worry now?
"When you have a David Cone on your team, you can't worry much about spring training," said Manager Joe Torre, who stressed that he did not worry after Cone's first two sluggish outings. "You've made your bed with him and he's it."
Because Cone logged 147 pitches in the decisive game of the American League division series against Seattle last October and because he has averaged 225 innings over the last eight years, the doubt about his arm strength becomes a topic whenever he does not come close to reaching 90 miles an hour on the radar gun. But Cone said his fastball today had "pop" and "hop" against the team that traded him to the Yankees last July.
"I heard the same talk when the Mets traded me," said Cone, who has permitted 8 earned runs and 12 hits in 11 innings this spring. " 'He's got too many miles. He's not worth it. Time to dump him now.' I do have some hard miles on me. I'd also like to think I pitch with a style that allows me to pitch longer and throw more. There's nothing wrong. I pitched the first game of spring and I'm pitching opening day."
After the Yankees burst to a 5-0 lead behind Tino Martinez's two-run double and Paul O'Neill's two-run homer, Cone encountered his only troubling inning in the bottom of the third. With two out and none on, Cone loaded the bases on two walks on 3-2 pitches and a bloop single by Joe Carter.
Cone fed Ed Sprague sliders until the count reached 3-2 and he opted to fire a fastball that Sprague bounced off the fence in center for a three-run double. After the hit, Cone retired his last seven batters on an economical 27 pitches.
After signing Cone to a three-year, $19.5 million contract, the Yankees are expecting major dividends from the 33-year-old right-hander and he knows it. He could have been much more anonymous with the Orioles in Baltimore, but he is attracted to the attention in New York. He expects it.
"It's starting to come together now," Cone said. "I'm aware that the team is watching me. I know it's time to start picking it up a notch. Today was a nice step. Today is something good to build on."
 
INSIDE PITCH
RUBEN SIERRA's experiment as an outfielder went awry as JOHN OLERUD's looping liner to left field in the sixth inning hit off his glove and was generously scored a double. Sierra was slow reacting to the ball and then failed to block it as it rolled past him. "If he can't catch it, he's got to keep it in front of him," said Manager JOE TORRE. . . . After General Manager BOB WATSON said DWIGHT GOODEN's start versus Cleveland Wednesday would not be particularly critical, he added, "If MELIDO PEREZ continues pitching well and Dwight Gooden continues to scuffle, I'm quite sure MEL STOTTLEMYRE and Joe will tell me they want to make a change." . . . MATT LUKE hit a mammoth two-run homer and JIM LEYRITZ knocked in two runs with three hits to power the Yankees to a 4-3 victory over the Reds in Plant City, Fla., on Tuesday night. ANDY PETTITTE gave up two runs and five hits in four innings for the victory.

HEADLINE: Backpack: An Inalienable Right?;
Student and Her School Tangle Over Civil Liberties

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: HAMILTON TOWNSHIP, N.J., March 12

 BODY:
On one side of the courtroom was a willfully defiant 14-year-old honor student, well versed in the civil disobedience of Thoreau and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and eager to start carrying her maroon backpack to classes again.
On the other was the principal and some teachers from William Annin Middle School in Bernards Township, N.J., and the district superintendent, all eager to persuade Judge Solomon A. Metzger of the Office of Administrative Law that bulging backpacks were threats to the health and safety of students and teachers and deserved to be outlawed from classrooms, halls and the cafeteria. 
 So began a civil-liberties-versus-school-authority clash today between the eighth grader, Elyse Meredith, and the educational hierarchy of a well-heeled suburb hoping for Judge Metzger's blessing that its ban on backpacks is reasonable and its enforcement powers have not been exceeded.
During their testimony today, Annin's staff members depicted a backpack craze turned dangerous in a school of 500 students. Teachers talked of monster and mega backpacks overflowing with cans of hair spray and stuffed animals in the halls of Annin; of tripping over straps poking into aisles from beneath desks; of getting whacked in the face by careless students turning abruptly, and of the backpack machismo of eighth-grade boys intimidating sixth graders.
"You have three or four boys coming down a hallway," said a guidance counselor, James Buist. "It creates a bit of a flow problem,"
Sandra Hyde, a math teacher, testified about being struck twice in the face by the backpacks of students who turned unwittingly into her path. No permanent injuries, she told Judge Metzger, just "startling blows."
"I need to now be defensive as I walk through the hallways," Ms. Hyde said, "because I never know."
Miss Meredith said she did not consider backpacks as safety threats, and rejected the argument about the unwary tripping over straps protruding into aisles. "I feel they're almost like an extension cord on the floor," she said during a court recess.
When the school imposed the ban on Jan. 2, Miss Meredith ostensibly began her disobedient behavior by refusing to stash her backpack in her locker, as the school rule required. She has complained that the three-minute break between classes is not enough time to go back and forth from her locker, and each class requires a separate three-ring binder. The books are heavy.
But she also views her struggle more philosophically. She has read Thoreau's essay "Civil Disobedience."
"I admire him and Martin Luther King, too," she said outside court. "I feel this is all a question of liberties. I feel it's important to stand up for liberties you have, to keep them. I feel it's taking away students' rights to property."
Her defiance of Annin School's backpack ban has cost her 10 days in suspensions from classes. She served that time in a room in the school, doing homework under the watch of a teacher. A ruling last month forced her to abandon her maroon backpack, a moderate-sized one like those lugged around by millions of college and high school students. She now carries her books and other belongings to class in a black attache case that her father, Charles Meredith, gave her.
Mr. Meredith seems to delight in his daughter's fight, although he regrets that she has received her first B-plus at Annin after a string of A's. He is a burly former football coach and history teacher at Rutherford High School in Bergen County who now works as a salesman. For now, he is serving as his daughter's lawyer, albeit one a bit unpolished procedurally. Several times today, Judge Metzger admonished him gently to ask direct questions and refrain from offering opinions.
"We've always taught her that the first element of intelligence is questioning," Mr. Meredith said of his daughter outside of court. "The purpose of this country is to think critically. That's the purpose of education, theoretically."
Miss Meredith's challenge might extend beyond Annin School. If the backpack ban is upheld, other school districts in New Jersey might be encouraged to enact similar prohibitions. Only a few have them now in middle schools, including Bridgewater, Raritan, and Flemington. Bernards Township's school board has already spent $10,000 fighting this battle, and the Superintendent, Dalen Showalter, said the district would appeal if it loses this round of the fight.
This is the second time that Judge Metzger, an administrative law judge, has heard the case this year. Initially, the board came before him on an emergency basis and asked him to order Miss Meredith to obey. He refused, calling the ban a "minor school rule," and said he was not convinced that Miss Meredith had to submit to authority.
"If other parents and children do not understand, then it is the kind of learning opportunity that civics teachers pray for," Judge Metzger wrote in early February. The school board appealed to the State Education Commissioner, Leo F. Klagholz, and he overruled Judge Metzger, deciding that Miss Meredith's disobedience was akin to anarchy.
But her classmates today seemed unwilling to join Miss Meredith in a mass protest. Some seemed already weary of the two-month-old dispute. "She's never going to win," said John Cooney, a fellow eighth grader. "The backpacks are a fire hazard. The judge should decide that if the principal makes a decision, the kids should follow it."
To a few parents, the issue is also economic. Mary Besbris, whose son Jeremy is an eighth grader there, suggested that the district has its priorities confused. "We can't even get the supplies we need, and now we're paying lawyers' fees," Mrs. Besbris said. "Let the kid go."
To the school board, however, the broader issue is whether the rule is reasonable and within the board's rule-making authority, an important point for school boards statewide.
The school board's lawyer, Les Aron, sought to justify the rule today on grounds that the backpacks pose a safety risk. A substitute teacher at Annin, Dorthy Norris, told of tripping over a backpack and falling. Her ankle hurt for six or seven weeks, she said. Elaine Lent, who teaches fine arts and industrial technology, said she tripped twice over backpacks, hurting a thigh the first time and an arm the second.
Of her second fall, she said: "It just knocked the wind out of me, it really did. I would not consider it a major injury, but it was nasty."
The hearing will continue on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: California To Get More In Quake Aid

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 12

 BODY:
More than two years after the Northridge earthquake jolted Southern California, the Clinton Administration announced today that it would pay $932 million to Los Angeles County to help rebuild or replace four local hospitals.
The announcement ends a lengthy and, at times, contentious dispute between the Administration and county officials over the scope of the earthquake damage and the amount of money the Federal Government would ultimately funnel into the region. During the negotiations, critical parts of the hospitals have been closed or barely operational. 
 The relief package was announced today by officials of the Federal Emergency Management Agency. It includes $394 million for the Medical Center of the University of California at Los Angeles, $373.7 million for the Los Angeles County-University of Southern California Medical Center, $133.5 million for St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica and $30.8 million for Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles.
The sudden willingness to resolve the dispute offers fresh evidence of the White House's determination to be seen as sensitive to California's economic concerns, which even before the earthquake had made California, a politically crucial state, the focus of special Administration attention.
Today's announcement raises the estimate of the Federal contribution in the wake of the 1994 earthquake to more than $13 billion, more money than had been expected.
In Washington, James Lee Witt, the FEMA director, said in a statement, "In the event of a future tremor the magnitude of the Northridge earthquake or larger, it is absolutely imperative that critical care facilities such as hospitals are effectively operating."
He added that residents in the area could now "rest assured that these four hospitals will continue to serve their needs when disaster strikes."
Zev Yaroslavsky, a county Supervisor, said: "It's not as much money as we asked for, but it's more than the Government initially offered. We have something to work with."
Last October, the Federal emergency agency offered to provide $300 million to help the county repair the four hospitals, including the 2,000-bed County-U.S.C. center, one of the nation's largest medical complexes. The relatively small relief package was reported to be the result of official skepticism in Washington about local estimates of earthquake damage in the Northridge section of Los Angeles, northwest of downtown.
But state and local officials balked at the suggestion that they were exaggerating the damage from the earthquake to get a Federal windfall.
The Northridge quake, measuring 6.7 on the Richter scale, left 61 people dead, 9,000 injured and 25,000 homeless. It seriously damaged more than 30,000 houses, apartments and businesses, many beyond repair, and left perhaps 250,000 others with minor damage.
The dispute over the amount of relief threatened to become a political issue when Gov. Pete Wilson, then a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, publicly chastised the Clinton Administration for its handling of the matter.
Today's announcement, political strategists said, could help Mr. Clinton's standing in the state, especially in the Los Angeles area, the biggest population center. In 1992, the Los Angeles area gave Mr. Clinton the edge he needed to carry California and win the Presidency.
Although the Federal aid was prompted by the earthquake, local officials said it would also help the county cope with major budget cuts and revitalize its troubled medical care system.
Last year, county officials discovered a $1.6 billion deficit, with about a third of it caused by rising health care costs. They decided that one way to help balance the books would be to close most of the county's public hospitals and clinics, which provide free health care to the 2.5 million Los Angeles residents -- out of a total population of 9 million -- who are too poor to afford medical insurance. The sprawling County-U.S.C. medical center was among those that was to be closed.
But in a surprise move, the Clinton Administration announced a $363 million Federal bailout of the county's public health system, which local political experts hailed as a savvy tactic, especially because of Governor Wilson's much-publicized reluctance to aid the county. The state is strapped for money because of various strict limits on tax rates and because it is still recovering from the recent national recession.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
Blocking School Board Winners
 
Legislative leaders reached agreement on a bill that would strengthen the hand of the New York City Schools Chancellor at the expense of the community school boards as he investigates corruption. The bill would allow the Chancellor to block winners of school board elections in some districts from taking their seats for up to a year. The bill falls far short of what the Chancellor, Rudy Crew, the Board of Education and Mayor Giuliani had requested: the outright postponement of elections, for at least year, in all 32 community school districts. [Page B1.]
 
Rough-and-Tumble Politics
 
Politics is never gentle, not even in the seemingly tranquil, ever-so-polite suburbs. In Harrison, N.Y., a fight over a Town Councilman's seat could lead to court. Our Towns by Evelyn Nieves. [B1.]
 
A Blow to Hospitals Plan
 
Mount Sinai Medical Center has withdrawn from the bidding to take over Elmhurst Hospital Center and Queens Hospital Center, two of the three hospitals the city had offered for long-term leases. The decision is a blow to efforts to break up the city hospital system. [B3.]
 
Charge Links Drugs and Aliens
 
Six Chinese immigrants were indicted on charges of selling heroin, and offering discounts in return for forged passports to help them smuggle illegal immigrants into the United States. Law enforcement officers said the indictments illustrate the link between Asian heroin trafficking and alien smuggling. [B3.]
 
A Warning on Teacher Layoffs
 
Dr. Crew warned a City Council committee that the school system may have to resort to laying off teachers if it were forced to reduce its spending by $1 billion. [B4.]
 
Students Crowded Out of Class
 
Because of overcrowding, nearly one in every eight public high school students in Queens attends class for fewer hours daily than the minimum required by law, according to a Board of Education report. [B4.]
 
The End of an Incinerator
 
The $40 million incinerator built in Glen Cove, L.I., in 1983 is to be torn down and abandoned, a victim of determined opponents, tougher pollution laws and the changing economics of the trash industry. [B6.]
 
After a Tree Falls in a Forest . . .
 
Governor Pataki said that millions of trees damaged when a potent windstorm pummeled 430,000 acres of Adirondack forest would remain where they lie, allowing the forest to heal naturally. [B6.]
 
Death-Case Fees Assailed
 
The Pataki administration denounced as exorbitant a proposed set of fees for court-appointed lawyers who represent defendants in death penalty cases, provoking a debate over how much the state should pay to insure the defense of poor people facing capital punishment. [B5.]
 
A traffic dispute ended violently when one driver shot the other to death in Greenwich Village, the police said. [B2.]
 
REGION
 
For Irish, Pride and Concern
 
Many of the 2.6 million Irish-Americans in the New York metropolitan region find themselves making distinctions about how they commemorate their Irish heritage. They are careful to explain that their intense animosity for the British Government should not be interpreted as applause for violence. [B1.]
 
Gerry Adams, leader of the I.R.A.'s political wing, Sinn Fein, arrived in New York for a six-day visit. [B2.]
 
Ice Ties Up Traffic on Bridge
 
Ice broke off the towers and cables of the George Washington Bridge in chunks that smashed onto the roadway, forcing the closure of the upper level and starting traffic jams on both sides of the Hudson. [B6.]
 
NEW JERSEY
 
Backpacks Hauled Into Court
 
A New Jersey court began hearing a "civil liberties versus school authority" clash between an eighth grader who wants to keep carrying her backpack to school and a school that has banned the packs as threats to the health and safety of students and teachers. [B1.]
 
Advertising a Tax Amnesty
 
For the first time since 1987, New Jersey is offering tax amnesty. The state has planned a $4 million advertising campaign urging anyone who owes the state back taxes to pay now without any penalty during a tax amnesty program that starts Friday and runs through June 1. [B6.]
 
CONNECTICUT
 
Judicial Layoffs Threatened
 
Gov. John G. Rowland said that 178 judicial employees would be laid off by the end of the month and that more layoffs would follow, eliminating about 6 percent of the Judicial Department's employees. [B6.]
