HEADLINE: Key Semiconductor Index Falls for 2d Month

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 12

 BODY:
The semiconductor industry's leading indicator fell for a second month in February, a trade organization reported late today.
Although the decline was within industry analysts' expectations, the report showed that orders for chips continued to slow. 
 The report was issued after the stock market closed, and it set the stage for continued volatility in at least some technology stocks.
The Semiconductor Industry Association, which is based in San Jose, Calif., reported a book-to-bill ratio for the three months ending in February of 0.90, down from a revised figure of 0.92 for the period ending in January. But the trade group said that the chip market appeared to be stabilizing after a steep drop in January, which was the first time the indicator fell below the break-even point -- or 1.00 -- in five years.
"The new numbers suggest that the dramatic drop in January was a one-month aberration," said Doug Andrey, the association's director of information systems and finance. "Over all, we continue to expect solid growth for the semiconductor industry throughout 1996 because the global consumer demand for chip-related products, such as personal computers, is going to increase for the foreseeable future."
But analysts said that while the ratio was within the range of expectations, which ran from 0.88 to 0.93, the underlying figures still showed a significant decline in orders, and an end to the industry's ability to defy normal cyclical demand.
The book-to-bill ratio compares the rate of orders to that of shipments. Thus, a ratio of 0.90 indicates that for every $100 worth of computer chips shipped, only $90 worth were ordered for future use, an indicator of declining sales.
One factor driving the book-to-bill ratio down is the steep drop in memory prices. Andy Neff, an analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company, wrote in a recent report that 4-megabit dynamic random access memory chips have dropped to a wholesale price of $7 apiece from $14 in the last four months, primarily because of excess inventory.
"Mathematically, the book-to-bill ratio can drop during a period of sharp price declines, even in the face of higher unit demand, because the unit prices for products ordered this month are lower than the revenue from products shipping this month that were ordered a few months ago," Mr. Neff wrote.
Analysts attribute the price drop to an inventory correction as personal computer manufacturers must use up stocks accumulated in anticipation of a too-optimistic forecast for Windows 95, the new operating system Microsoft released in August. The Intel Corporation's overestimate of demand for printed circuit boards called motherboards and Apple Computer Inc.'s unexpectedly weak sales also contributed to an oversupply of memory, Mr. Neff said.
Semiconductor orders for February reached $3.9 billion, a 4.5 percent decline from the $4.08 billion in new orders recorded in January, but a 5.7 percent increase over bookings in February 1995. In comparison, orders in January 1996 declined 16.8 percent from the December 1995 numbers.
Shipments in North and South America totaled $4.34 billion in February, down 1.8 percent from $4.42 billion in January 1996, but a 31.6 percent increase over the $3.3 billion mark recorded in February 1995.
"Relative to the doomsday scenario some people were predicting, the overall ratio is not that bad," said Dan Niles, an analyst with Robertson, Stephens & Company.
But the 5.7 percent year-over-year increase in orders is down from 14 percent in January and 45 percent in December, he noted. "The trend is definitely not working in the direction you would like," he said. "This is not going to help semiconductor stocks tomorrow."
The book-to-bill ratio is computed using a three-month moving average and is seasonally adjusted. The Semiconductor Industry Association began adjusting the number last year. Using unadjusted numbers, February's number is the lowest since November 1985, when the ratio was 0.89.

HEADLINE: Stigma Curtails Single Motherhood in Japan

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 12

 BODY:
This was a grandchild that Mika's parents did not want.
Mika, then 19, was secretly living with her boyfriend, so her parents were startled when she told them she was eight months pregnant. Her parents met her at the train station, whisked her inside and kept her hidden from the neighbors until they drove her to the hospital for the delivery. 
 "I made a mistake," said Mika, now 21, who spoke on condition that her last name not be used. "At the time I was ferocious about raising a child. I didn't think it would be so bad for my kid. But now I've cooled down and, as I look back, I think my parents were right."
Mika gave up her baby, and she is not the only one in Japan who thinks that having a baby outside of marriage is a terrible idea. Although the numbers of single young women giving birth is soaring in countries all over the world, Japan is a striking exception.
Only 1.1 percent of births in Japan were to unwed mothers in 1994, the most recent year for which figures are available, compared with 30.1 percent in the United States. In America the proportion has soared in recent years, fueling a debate over family values. But in Japan it has tumbled -- Japanese women are much less likely to become single mothers in the 1990's than in the unsettling years after the war, in the late 1940's and 1950's.
In 1994, 14,700 babies were born to unmarried mothers in Japan. (The United States, which has twice Japan's population, recorded 1,240,172 births to unwed mothers in 1993, the latest year for which official figures are available.) The Japanese figure was a slight increase over the previous years, but it was only about one-tenth the number of births to singlemothers in 1947, the first year for which figures were made available.
Why has Japan not had a surge in single mothers? For a start, it may be that Japanese teen-agers are less active sexually than young people abroad. Moreover, abortions are easily available -- and common -- for those who become pregnant.
But the most important factor is social pressure. Single mothers face economic and social discrimination. In Japan, having a baby without being married is still a humiliation.
In the United States there is a great debate about whether welfare programs encourage births to unmarried women by creating financial incentives for them to have babies. Such an incentive also exists in Japan, where a single woman who would not get benefits might receive them under certain circumstances if she has a baby.
But even unwed mothers prefer to find work and day care rather than go on welfare, and the result is that less than 7 percent of single-parent households receive benefits.
 
Less Teen-Age Sex Than in the U.S.
It is tough to gauge how sexually active Japanese teen-agers are. Certainly many Japanese say that by their standards the young people are very promiscuous.
"I get the impression they have sex very frequently," Kunio Kitamura, who runs a family planning clinic, said of teen-age girls. "Even a 13-year-old once came to me."
But surveys suggest that Japanese teen-agers are much less active sexually than young people in America or Europe.
"I don't want to have sex until I go to college because I'd feel sorry for my parents," said Ayako Kitagawa, a 16-year-old student at an all-girl high school. "I'd feel bad because I'd be lying to them.
"Having sex is just an outrageous thought for us -- we don't even have boyfriends. Those girls who supposedly have had sex are flashy bad girls, so I wouldn't pity them if they become pregnant."
When they do get pregnant, Japanese girls often get an abortion. While doctors prefer parental consent from teen-agers for abortions, many perform them without it.
Even if they insist on having the baby, the mothers often end up buckling to family pressure by marrying the fathers or by giving up the baby, as Mika did.
Social pressures are also intense. Marriage prospects for the children are slimmer, and sometimes even funeral services are affected: in one case relatives refused to enshrine the ashes of a man in the family tomb because he had been born out of wedlock.
 
Unwed Are Shunned In a Family Culture
There is ubiquitous name-calling and bullying, high schools sometimes turn down the children, and companies often will not hire the parents.
Some older children of single mothers have reported being told by teachers that even if they excel in national examinations they will not get into prominent schools.
And if all these pressures were not enough, official discrimination against single mothers and their children is still overwhelming. Children of single parents, for instance, have weaker inheritance rights and their unusual status is recorded on their family registration, a document the Government requires every family to file.
Moreover, tax policies discriminate against women who choose single motherhood. Mothers who were divorced or widowed after having children can take a few thousand dollars in tax deductions against their income.
In contrast, mothers single by choice get none. Not only do they pay more national and local income taxes, but by reporting higher income because they do not get the deductions, single mothers also pay higher public day care fees and, in some areas, health premiums.
"It seems the national Government thinks that if you allow single motherhood to proliferate, it would damage Japan," said Shuhei Ninomiya, a law professor at Ritsumeikan University in Kyoto, who has researched children's rights.
"Japan accomplished high economic growth through this very established system of families, in which people took care of their parents.
"The national Government feels that if single motherhood proliferates, Japan's family system would break down and family morals would collapse."
Keiko Nakada, a 40-year-old woman who is raising her 1-year-old boy, Tsukasa, on her own, worries that he may be mistreated.
 
 'I Will Fight for Him,' An Infant's Mother Says
"If it happens, I will fight for him," she said, as she cuddled him in her studio apartment. But she feels bad that even her older two children, who are in the custody of her first husband and his wife, are being warned by their relatives: "Kids grow up fine when both parents are around, but when one is missing, there are doubts about how they will be raised."
After her first marriage failed, Ms. Nakada remarried, got pregnant again and then, even when her second husband divorced her, she continued with the pregnancy.
She thought she could count on her experience as a mother, but she was unprepared for everything else.
Now her parents have refused to visit, her sister does not help out, even welfare officials are rude, and she was turned down by five real estate agents because she was a single mother.
After she found a place to live and was late a few times in paying rent, her landlady complained to Ms. Nakada about her unstable social and economic status. Ms. Nakada has company, at least, for she helped find an apartment downstairs for her friend, a single mother with two toddlers. Her 23-year-old friend finally decided to take a night job and leaves her children, 1 and 3, at home while she goes out to work. So Ms. Nakada goes downstairs two or three times during the night to check on the toddlers.
Most high schools expel pregnant students, so teen-agers sometimes go to great lengths to disguise their sexual activities.
Kazuko Yokota, who runs Motherly Network, a small adoption foundation, described the case of a 16-year-old high school student who was impregnated in a rape that she never revealed to her parents.
She always wore loose outfits and, as she grew larger, her parents thought she was sick so they took her to the hospital, only to find out that she was due to give birth in a few weeks. She wanted to continue school, so she stayed home, got a doctor to make up a medical excuse and then returned to class several weeks after the birth.
"Single mothers are not permitted in Japanese society," Miss Yokota said.
 
Many Try to Deny Anything Is Amiss
But in most cases, the teen-agers have a sense of what they are doing, though they may deny to themselves that anything is amiss. A year before she gave birth, Mika had an abortion. Her boyfriend, Naoki, paid for it with $1,000 from his mother's bank account.
When she became pregnant again, after she graduated from an all-girl high school, her boyfriend began using tranquilizers and she spent her days in his bedroom, keeping him company. Naoki's mother, who works long hours and did not see Mika much at all, finally noticed Mika's expanding belly, when the girl was eight months pregnant, and ordered Mika to go to the hospital.
For a month after the birth of her daughter, Natsuki, both families argued over whether Mika and Naoki should get married, but in the end, they did not. Instead they put the baby up for adoption at Miss Yokota's Motherly Network.
Even among teen-agers who get pregnant, many do not talk about it, have never heard of other similar situations and do not think twice about getting an abortion. When Yuka Sugimoto, a 19-year-old student, got pregnant more than a year ago, she was shocked.
She held a conference with her boyfriend, her sister and her best friend, whose father is a gynecologist, and they mapped out a plan. She found a doctor, but when he asked for a letter from her parents, she nearly fainted.
Miss Sugimoto ultimately persuaded the doctor to keep her parents out of it. She explained, "If my parents even knew that I have a boyfriend, they wouldn't let me go out of the house."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Keiko Nakada is bringing up her year-old son from a failed second marriage on her own, which makes her an exception among the relatively small number of single mothers in Japan. Ms. Nakada, seen here playing with her son, Tsukasa, is worried he may be mistreated or bullied. (Noboru Hashimoto for The New York Times)(pg. A11)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Most G.M. Factories Close After Strike at Parts Plants
A week-old strike at two G.M. parts-making plants has caused the closing of nearly three-quarters of the company's North American assembly plants, idling 83,000 workers. By now, 21 of G.M.'s 29 car and truck assembly plants have run out of brakes and sent their workers home. With those plants closed, 30 other G.M. parts factories have shut down.
The strike previews an issue that will come up in this year's union bargaining with the Big Three: the extent to which G.M. will buy parts from nonunion suppliers. [Page A1.]
 
After Skidding 95 Points, Dow Rebounds for a Small Gain
Blue-chip stocks ended their third tumultuous session in a row with a slight advance. The Dow Jones average plunged 95 points before recovering, to end up 2.89 points, at 5,583.89. The wide swings followed a plunge of 171 points Friday and a rebound of 110 points on Monday. Outside the Dow, stocks generally fell. [D8.]
 
Treasury prices ended lower as a bearish mood returned, and the yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.66 percent. [D18.]
 
Chip Index Drops for 2d Month
The computer chip industry's leading indicator ebbed in February to its lowest point in five years, after plunging in January. [D4.]
 
Rest of Gucci Is Up for Sale
Investcorp plans to sell its 51 percent stake in the Gucci Group to the public. The sale, which would be valued at $1.14 billion at current stock prices, would complete the Italian company's move from a troubled company to one of Wall Street's hot stocks. [D5.]
 
Investment in 3d World Rises
Foreign businesses invested $90 billion building factories and equipment in developing countries last year, up 13 percent over 1994, the World Bank said. [D5.]
 
Cloud Over Denver Bonds
Rising interest rates have clouded two bond deals aimed at reducing the borrowing costs of the new Denver airport. [D2.]
 
Quaker Oats to Sell 2 Lines
Quaker Oats put up for sale its Aunt Jemima frozen breakfast line and the Celeste frozen pizza line, which together generate about $175 million in annual sales. Campbell Soup and Unilever are expected to look them over. [D6.]
 
Microsoft Discusses Internet Role
Microsoft disclosed new details about how the company intends to attain a dominant role in the Internet market. [D4.]
 
A group of on-line services and a consumers' league is planning a campaign to educate the public about privacy, property rights and consumer protection on the Internet. [D4.]
 
Apple Hires a P.R. Firm
Apple Computer, having endured a public relations debacle during recent merger talks and the ouster of its chief executive, retained Burson-Marsteller to handle its image. [D18.]
 
Debate Over Value Of Coke Shares
Coca-Cola told analysts that it expected its sales volume to rise 7 percent abroad in the current quarter, and by that much or slightly more in the United States and Canada. But the prediction stirred a debate about whether Coke's high share price is justified. The company also plans an aluminum can shaped like a Coke bottle. [D2.]
 
Spring Cleaning for the Grand Hyatt
The Grand Hyatt on 42d Street is getting another remake, and "it won't be just new wallpaper," said Donald Trump, a co-owner. Business Travel. [D6.]

Advertisers love the National Collegiate Athletic Association's basketball tournaments, which have graduated to the ranks of major sports-marketing events. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]

A new strategy at Ann Taylor is pleasing Wall Street. Rather than discounting, the women's apparel chain is holding down its inventories and maintaining prices. Market Place. [D8.]

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE ECONOMY;
Buchanan, in Midwest, Vows to Protect American Markets

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, March 12

 BODY:
Patrick J. Buchanan said today that as President he would use tax and tariff policies to return "virtually the entire" United States steel market to domestic companies.
Demonstrating how far his economic ideas had veered from Republican orthodoxy, Mr. Buchanan declared that American steel companies had suffered from "the neglect of the Government." 
 Mr. Buchanan focused his attention on the Midwest, where Ohio and three other states vote on March 19. He is bidding for the support of blue-collar voters by stressing his economic ideas.
Those ideas, which he would enact through broad intervention by the Federal Government in domestic and international markets, form the most iconoclastic component of what Mr. Buchanan calls his "new conservatism of the heart."
Mr. Buchanan has said recently that he believes the United States economy should be "designed" for the benefit of its workers.
"This is our market, this is our country," Mr. Buchanan declared at a news conference here. "The Government of the United States should be defending the private industry of the United States."
In fact, the United States steel industry is already rebounding. Domestic companies are rapidly adding capacity and have recently taken business from foreign competitors.
As the domestic steel market grew from 1994 to 1995, steel imports fell from 30 million tons to 24.4 million tons, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, a trade group in Washington. At the same time, American exports made the biggest increase since 1940, from 3.8 million tons to 7 million tons.
But the new, smaller steel mills employ far fewer workers per ton of steel manufactured.
Mr. Buchanan argued today that foreign steel companies were heavily subsidized by their governments, giving them unfair advantage.
He visited Youngstown Steel Door, a privately held company that manufactures doors for freight trains. From a high of about 2,200 jobs in 1979, employment has fallen to 300 to 350 hourly and salaried workers, the plant's management said.
Employment has climbed slightly as the company has diversified into other steel products. Mr. Buchanan, wearing one of the company's blue windbreakers, praised the operation as an example of "American ingenuity and American ability."
"We've got to make America the industrial power of the world again," Mr. Buchanan told about 100 workers who gathered around him in the murky, cavernous plant. "We've got to get places like Youngstown booming again."

HEADLINE: Embattled L.I. Incinerator To Go Way of Shoreham

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: GLEN COVE, L.I., March 12

 BODY:
When Glen Cove's $40 million incinerator and its towering smokestack were built in 1983, its technology was heralded as the solution to the problem of shrinking landfills on Long Island and in other densely populated areas.
But the smokestack's emissions, including a light powdery ash that fell on a nearby playground, soon alarmed many residents of Long Island's North Shore, touching off years of litigation. After operating for eight years, the incinerator now stands like some extinct dinosaur overlooking Glen Cove Creek, a victim of determined opponents, tougher pollution laws and the changing economics of the trash-hauling industry. 
 Today, Mayor Thomas Suozzi announced that the incinerator would be abandoned and torn down, adding, "The incinerator war is over."
On an island where the $5 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant was scrapped because of safety concerns, experts were quick to see parallels between the solid-waste industry and the nuclear-power industry.
"At first, incineration was like a dream come true, an appealing alternative to environmentalists worried about dumping garbage and chemicals and everything else into a hole in the ground," said Mark McQuerrey, a lawyer who specializes in solid-waste laws. "But over the last 10 to 15 years, it's not only become too costly a process, but they've become politically unpopular. It's now a dying concept."
It has become cheaper to ship garbage to new landfills in Pennsylvania, Arkansas, Ohio and Illinois, Mr. McQuerrey said.
In Glen Cove's case, abandoning the incinerator will allow the city to cut its waste disposal costs in half. Initially, much of the savings will be used to pay $6 million to buy out a 20-year contract the city signed in 1992 with a company to operate the incinerator. But in time, Mr. Suozzi said, "We'll be making a profit."
The incinerator was closed in 1991 when the State Department of Environmental Cooperation described it as the worst-run incinerator in the state. Even though a new operator, Island Resource and Environmental Company took over in 1992, promising a cleanup and spending $22 million to improve the facility, the legal battle continued.
With Long Island running out of space to place its refuse, the operators of the incinerator planned to truck in vast amounts of trash as well as sewage sludge from all over the Island, reduce it to a small amount of ash and dump it in the remaining landfill or ship it to out-of-state landfills.
But many municipalities that had been shipping garbage to the Glen Cove incinerator soon found it cheaper to contract with carters who ship directly to new landfills in Ohio and Pennsylvania.
"The economics of the garbage business made these kinds of incinerators losing operations," said Larry Shapiro, a lawyer for the New York Public Interest Research Group, which helped Glen Cove close down the incinerator. "The permanent closing of this incinerator marks an end of an era in New York State."
Mayor Suozzi said the city had contracted a new carter to ship its garbage at $30 a ton, $45 a ton less than the city is paying under the current contract with the incinerator's operator, Island Recycling. Since the city ships 20,000 tons a year, the overall savings would add up to $900,000 a year.
Mr. Suozzi said the carting company could either sell the city's garbage to one of the five other municipal incinerators on Long Island, which are looking for additional waste to process, or ship it off Long Island. "It will go where they get the best price," Mr. Suozzi said.
The towns that operate the five incinerators welcomed as a major victory a United States Supreme Court ruling last month that helped insure a continuous flow of garbage. The Supreme Court let stand a lower court ruling that gave one of the towns, Smithtown, the power to control the disposal of garbage collected within its borders. At stake were millions of dollars in disposal fees the towns used to pay debts incurred to build the incinerators.
Garbage haulers, who wanted the right to seek lower rates elsewhere, had argued that the system violated interstate commerce laws.
Mr. Cowen said the Supreme Court ruling would no doubt be used by towns with incinerators across the country. "There is a lot of confusion out there," he said.

Some have estimated that abandoning the site will let the city cut waste disposal costs in half. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Denver Airport's 2 Deals Clouded by Rising Rates

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
The finances of Denver International Airport became even more complicated yesterday as rising interest rates threw a cloud of uncertainty over two deals -- including an unusual so-called Dutch auction -- aimed at lowering Denver's borrowing costs.
The Dutch auction and a $266 million refinancing of high-interest bonds issued in 1992, are scheduled to go to market today. But Denver officials and its underwriters, Goldman, Sachs & Company, were uncertain late yesterday whether these deals would go forward and at what amounts. 
 As part of the first stage of the Dutch auction, holders of around $1 billion in outstanding Denver airport bonds offered yesterday to sell their bonds back to the City and County of Denver. City officials said they might accept up to 10 percent of these tendered bonds, or about $100 million, and replace them with new bonds -- depending on market conditions today.
"Things are unclear right now because of market conditions," said Robert Gibson, director of financial management for the City and County of Denver. "We are now evaluating the response to our tender offer and we are looking at market conditions to determine what actions to take."
Originally, Denver had orchestrated a sophisticated finance plan. Some $1.9 billion in debt -- that was not callable until 10 years from now -- was eligible to be tendered in the Dutch auction. In addition, Denver had also planned to issue about $266 million in new bonds today to pay off high-interest bonds issued in 1992.
If that deal goes through, although with at least $100 million in bonds replaced in the Dutch auction, Denver would be in the market for $366 million or more today.
But with municipal bond interest rates rising, gaining nearly a half of a percentage point since last week, the city's bankers and officials are now uncertain whether Denver will save enough money by going to the market at today's higher interest rates to justify these deals.
According to the city's original plan, Denver is seeking to cut its borrowing costs on $150 million to $350 million of outstanding debt through the Dutch auction process. This process, which is rarely used in the municipal markets, calls for holders of around $1.9 billion in outstanding Denver airport debt to name a price in which they would sell their bonds back to the city -- and the city would then determine which of these bonds it would buy back.
Yesterday's announcement by the city that it would accept 10 percent of the $1 billion tendered in the Dutch auction indicates that the deal has already fallen short of its initial goal.
Rising interest rates have hurt this program in two ways: the market uncertainty has made many investors hesitate to offer their bonds back to the city at attractive prices, and the high interest rates that the city would have to pay for new bonds to replace that old bonds that were tendered make the whole deal less attractive.
"We are just looking at a lot of factors right now," Mr. Gibson said.
The interest rate rise presented some roughness to Denver's otherwise smooth sailing of late. Now, after the airport has been open for almost a year, its revenues are up, its costs are down and its bonds are rising in value in the marketplace.>

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE FRONT-RUNNER;
Dole, Dominant in Primaries, Faces New Battles in Capitol

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
Barring some completely unforeseen development, Senator Bob Dole, the Republican front-runner, faces a pair of prospects no one has ever faced before.
After a clean sweep at the polls, winning seven primaries out of seven held today, he seems all but certain to lock up his party's Presidential nomination no later than the California primary two weeks from today, which would make him the first Senate majority leader ever to be nominated by either party. And because the primary contest is winding down so early and the conventions are so late, he will have to navigate an uncharted stretch of four months between the effective end of the nominating contest and the Republican National Convention in August. 
 During that period, of course, he will have work to do in the Senate -- work that will involve him in political combat, but also in delicate negotiation with the man he will face in the general election, President Clinton.
Flying from San Antonio back to Washington on Monday night after his final rally before today's primaries, Mr. Dole sat in the darkened front cabin of his plane, intently studying a legislative calendar.
"Time to go back to work," he said in an interview. "We have about 80 legislative days left and a lot to do -- balanced budget, term limits, line-item veto, Medicare, Medicaid. In this atmosphere, it's going to be difficult to get it done."
To some degree, the campaign will be fought out during April, May, June and July at either end of Pennsylvania Avenue, not on the hustings. Part of the picture of Mr. Dole that voters take into the fall campaign will inevitably be formed then. By locking up the nomination, Mr. Dole will become the party's de facto leader, supplanting Speaker Newt Gingrich, at least for the moment, and the success or failure of the Republicans will mainly be his responsibility.
When the Republicans took control of Congress in the 1994 election, Mr. Gingrich and his Contract With America assumed dominant positions in Washington. But after flirting with the idea of running for the Presidency, Mr. Gingrich stepped back, and he has been only a marginal figure in the campaign to date. Much of the Contract With America has been bogged down in Congress, and it has figured little in the campaign, as issues like the flat tax and economic anxiety and abortion came to the fore.
Now all kinds of questions face Mr. Dole: Will he be able to work out a new relationship with Mr. Gingrich in which he takes the lead? Will the Republican freshmen in the House, far less pragmatic than he, follow his lead? Which issues will he emphasize? Will his relationship with Mr. Clinton break down under the stresses of partisanship?
Ever the realist, Mr. Dole said he knew there would have to be a lot of horse-trading, "some reciprocal political advantages, some for us, some for him." He said that term limits seemed unlikely to become law but that there was a good chance for the line-item veto, "if we can agree on an effective date." Mr. Clinton favors the measure, and in principle so do most Republicans, but some are reluctant to give such a powerful weapon to a Democratic President.
The Kansas Senator said it was his view that a balanced budget agreement should be possible that "lets him win and lets us win, a little each." Failure to agree on anything, he said, would amount to political Russian roulette: "Who do the voters blame then? Him? Us? Both of us? I don't know."
Just an hour or so before, in San Antonio, he had been denouncing Mr. Clinton for vetoing earlier budget legislation and urging his audience to "veto the President" in November.
There lies the conflict. Mr. Dole will have to find some way to deal with Mr. Clinton on legislative business in private while making the case in public that he should be replaced. It is not an easy circle for anyone to square.
In the closest parallel to the situation that is emerging this year, Lyndon B. Johnson presided as majority leader over a special session of Congress after his nomination as John F. Kennedy's running mate in 1960. But the agenda was much shorter, and President Dwight D. Eisenhower, who was not seeking re-election, had less at stake.
Still, it was an unhappy experience for the Democratic nominees. Proposals by Kennedy, then a Senator, were gunned down in the House, including an increase in the minimum wage and an early Medicare proposal. Trapped for hot, tedious weeks in Washington, Kennedy and Johnson watched as Richard M. Nixon ranged across the country, taking an early lead in Gallup Poll trial heats.
Mr. Dole said he subscribed to the old maxim of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's Postmaster General and political strategist, James A. Farley, that most people begin thinking about elections only after Labor Day. But he also said that he was searching for some way to avoid being pinned down in the capital while Mr. Clinton campaigned at will -- "something clever, to generate a little excitement," he said -- but he confessed that he had not yet found it.
"He's got the White House, and he'll be in the spotlight," Mr. Dole added. "Incumbency is a big advantage, and I'll have to counter it somehow."
Half facetiously, he said in Florida this week that reporters should refer to Mr. Clinton as a Presidential candidate and not just as President, because it was obviously better to hold the job than merely aspire to it.

HEADLINE: The New Drug-Price Squeeze;
H.M.O.'s Are Fighting Back in the Battle Over Costs

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
It took only a few weeks for Merck & Company, the nation's biggest drug maker, to note the damage after the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York told its 850,000 members that it would no longer pay for most of Merck's highly regarded but often expensive products.
Several of Merck's banner drugs abruptly lost customers. Take just one example. Sales of Vasotec, a heart and blood pressure treatment, plummeted in early 1994, going from 60 percent of the prescriptions for HIP members using this class of drug to fewer than 5 percent for those who could not use a substitute, according to executives of the big health maintenance organization. 
 Hoping to get its customers back, Merck sent a vice president and other executives to the health maintenance organization's Manhattan offices offering concessions, from price breaks to free educational programs that steer patients and doctors toward certain drugs.
But so far, the drug maker's efforts have been unsuccessful. And that, analysts say, is a powerful sign of the shifting power balance as drug manufacturers and managed care companies across the country square off in a battle over pricing and influence in the enormous $65 billion market for prescription drugs.
The battleground is the "formulary," a preferred list of prescription drugs that each managed care plan urges on its doctors and patients, often by saying it will only pay the full cost of medications on the list.
Health maintenance organizations wrest discounts and rebates from the manufacturers by contending they can push tens of thousands of patients toward one or another brand, or often a low-priced generic copy, at the expense of similar drugs.
For their part, the manufacturers are scaling back on rebates unless an H.M.O. can show that use of particular drugs actually increased. Some drug makers also offer package deals -- one overall price for important, one-of-a-kind drugs along with older products that can readily be replaced.
The drug makers still send thousands of salespeople to tout their wares to doctors, who in turn still write millions of prescriptions for people who pay out of pocket or have traditional, unrestricted insurance coverage. But with more than 56 million Americans now in health maintenance organizations, the formularies can be the key to market share.
In the battle to determine prices, the drug companies are ahead in most markets. Last year, the prices that health maintenance organizations pay for some types of older blood pressure drugs increased by as much as 31.6 percent, according to IMS America, a market monitoring firm. Drug securities analysts project further increases this year.
But with competition growing sharply among similar drugs in such multibillion-dollar categories as heart, antidepression and gastrointestinal therapies, the balance is shifting to the H.M.O.'s.
"As we get to end of 1996 and into 1997, we would expect the managed care organizations to gradually take more buying power and flex their muscles," Jerome R. Brimeyer, an analyst with Lehman Brothers, said.
Physicians complain that their professional role is often diminished in the back-and-forth, and all sides argue about whether patients are winners or losers. Managed care partisans quote a number of studies that say H.M.O.'s provide high-quality care, while critics say they have unhealthy financial reasons to deny needed care.
Even the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers Association, whose membership includes three companies -- Merck, SmithKline Beecham, and Eli Lilly & Company -- that own their own thriving managed care drug concerns, has doubts about highly restrictive formularies.
After a recent survey for the Tennessee Medical Association found that physicians in that state overwhelmingly objected to restrictions on prescriptions in the Tenncare program for the poor, Gerald J. Mossinghoff, president of the association, said the results were "evidence that patients are hurt by restrictions on prescription drugs."
Still, getting a grip on drug costs remains one of the health care industry's most pressing challenges. For many health maintenance organizations, drugs are the fastest-growing cost, typically absorbing 7 percent to 11 percent of expenditures. What is more, free or subsidized drug benefits are an important attraction in campaigns to recruit new members, especially for H.M.O.'s that are pursuing Medicare beneficiaries.
Indeed, some health maintenance organizations pay for almost all drugs, so they have little leverage in price negotiations. At the other extreme, the United Healthcare Corporation, the big Minneapolis-based managed care company, is planning a highly restrictive formulary -- only one drug in each category -- for its Medicare H.M.O.'s in Florida, Chicago, St. Louis and Rhode Island.
"We found that by picking one drug, the manufacturers were much more interested to come to us with a better price, because we were going to move market share." said Dr. Lee Newcomer, chief medical officer of United. Medicare patients who need drugs not on the free list will get a reduced price, he added.
The manufacturers, not surprisingly, say that even the most expensive drugs are cost effective because they reduce a patient's need for the even more costly services of doctors and hospitals.
It may take years of carefully tracking patients to prove this fully; while both the drug makers and health maintenance organizations are eager for answers, many H.M.O.'s refuse to let the drug companies into the medical records of patients, whose privacy is also an issue.
In most markets, the manufacturers have regained much of the ability to raise prices that they lost in the early 1990's, when drug costs suddenly became a national political issue. Last year, the manufacturers' profits rose 13 percent, on average, and pharmaceutical stocks soared.
As the drug makers played catch-up, the prices paid by H.M.O.'s rose 4.9 percent, on average, last year -- more than double the 1.9 percent increase in all drug prices, IMS America said.
Even Merck and Pfizer Inc., which have pledged to keep their average overall prices below consumer price inflation, announced increases of 4 percent or more for some important products. Presumably, manufacturers kept their promises by cutting prices on other products that faced heavy competition. According to the Commerce Department, consumer prices over all rose 2.5 percent last year.
Spokesmen for several drug makers did not respond to requests for comment on prices. Always a sensitive subject, they are now even more so, because of pending lawsuits by thousands of retail stores charging the drug makers with illegal price discrimination. A Federal judge recently gave preliminary approval to a settlement in one suit under which 15 drug manufacturers agreed to pay $408 million, without admitting any wrongdoing.
"The manufacturers' legal departments decided that the word 'price' would never be uttered, inside or outside the company," Mick Kolassa, a drug marketing and management researcher at the University of Mississippi, said.
But price is very much on the minds of the health-plan executives who today make the most significant decisions about drug purchases.
At HIP, Mohan Vodoor, vice president for pharmacy services, said that after consulting advisory panels of physicians and pharmacists, his staff had determined that certain drugs made by an assortment of companies were "therapeutically equivalent," not to mention cheaper, than Vasotec and a number of other important Merck products. The H.M.O.'s new formulary took effect in February 1994.
Originally, Merck insisted that HIP had to sign up for the company's entire product line if it wanted special prices, Mr. Vodoor said. But after a few months, Merck was willing to negotiate prices for groups of just two or three products, and by early 1995, the big drug maker finally offered to negotiate separately on any drug, he said.
Earlier, though, Merck had gone over Mr. Vodoor's head and made its pitch -- without success -- to a senior vice president at HIP. Then last year, the company sent in a team from its Medco managed care unit, offering to provide services such as getting in touch with physicians and pharmacists to help the H.M.O. keep control of costs.
"We took a look, but what they were offering didn't fit our needs," Mr. Vodoor said.
John Doorley, a spokesman for Merck, said the company declined to comment on its specific dealings with HIP. He said that it was working with "key customers like HIP NY, to improve our relationships," but he conceded that some H.M.O.s resented Merck's requirement.
Another front in the pricing wars is Washington. With the political heat turned down, the drug industry is lobbying Congress, trying to roll back the rebates that manufacturers are required to give to state Medicaid programs for the poor based on the "best price" at which they sell each product. Medicaid pays for 13 percent of all prescriptions, and the rebate requirement was designed to assure that drug makers did not profit at the taxpayers' expense while cutting prices to grab market share in the private sector.
The rebates can be substantial: California cut $273 million from the $1.5 billion drug bill for its Medi-Cal program last year.
The manufacturers are focusing on proposed Medicaid legislation that is stalled in Congress in their effort to get rid of the rebates. Still, the rebate rule shows how tricky it can be to squeeze drug costs out of health care.
Soon after the Medicaid rebates took effect in 1991, industry consultants say, the drug companies began reviewing their contracts with big H.M.O.'s and hospitals and paring back concessions. By raising the floor under the "best prices," they could charge more to private customers while reducing their rebates to the states.
 The chart also misstated the 1995 sales for the antibiotic, Zithromax. They were $399.5 million, not $339.5 million.

HEADLINE: Events: Architecture Shows, Talks and an Antiques Sale

 BODY:

Building New York
Rotunda of the Alexander Hamilton United States Custom House, foot of Broadway; (212) 683-0023, extension 15.
"Civics Lessons: Recent New York Public Architecture," an exhibition of photographs, drawings and models of 75 projects that were proposed or completed in the last decade, starts tomorrow and continues through May 2. 
 The projects -- initiated by 25 public agencies and designed by 55 architectural firms -- include the Custom House renovation, the Willink comfort station in Prospect Park and the New York Police Academy in the Bronx. The exhibition was organized by the American Institute of Architects New York Chapter and the New York Foundation for Architecture. Open daily, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. No charge.
On April 18, there will be a daylong symposium at the Downtown Athletic Club about issues raised by the exhibition. Reservations are required. Fee, including lunch, $40.
 
Antiques at the Armory
Seventh Regiment Armory, 643 Park Avenue (66th Street); (212) 472-1180.
An antiques sale starts Wednesday, from 1 to 9 P.M. Additional hours are March 21 through 23, noon to 9 P.M.; March 24, noon to 6 P.M. Admission is $10.
 
New York Architecture
Municipal Art Society, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street); (212) 935-3960.
A 12-session course on the history of architecture in New York City starts on March 27 and continues on April 17, May 15, May 29, June 12 and June 26. Each Wednesday night lecture will be followed by a Saturday afternoon walking tour.
The course will feature early Dutch New York; the 19th-century styles of Greek Revival, Gothic Revival and Victorian architecture; the golden age of skyscrapers, and urban renewal in the 1960's and recent developments. Reservations are required. Fee for the series, $125; each lecture, $10; each walking tour, $15.

HEADLINE: Denver Airport Completes Bond Auction

 BODY:
While it did not go exactly as planned, the Denver International Airport yesterday completed its Dutch auction -- a financing technique unusual in the municipal market that lowers the airport's borrowing costs.
The recent rise in municipal bond interest rates that began last week forced Denver officials to scale back the size of the auction, along with another bond refinancing that went to market yesterday. Together, the two deals issued about $243 million in refunded debt at rates ranging from 4 percent to 6.05 percent. These borrowings replace existing debt with higher interest rates. 
 This is about $100 million less than Denver had hoped for as recently as Tuesday and up to $200 million less than it had sought several weeks earlier. Despite this lower amount, Denver officials said that the strong investor interest in the Dutch auction might persuade them to use this financing tool to reduce debt costs again in the future.
In the Dutch auction, holders of more than $1.9 billion in Denver airport bonds -- nearly half all bonds outstanding -- were invited to sell their bonds back to the city. The investors who responded named a price, and the city selected the bonds with prices that it was willing to pay. Holders of $1.1 billion in Denver airport bonds offered their bonds and Denver chose to buy $114 million of them and replace them with bonds at lower interest rates.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Shaky Three

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
Three of the world leaders who gathered at Sharm el-Sheik in Egypt -- Shimon Peres, Boris Yeltsin and Bill Clinton -- are actively campaigning to remain in office. It is as if they were running mates on an international incumbency ticket, with each having an intense interest in helping the others win.
Can these three political musketeers bring it off together? Or will the weakness of any one of them help drag down the other two? 
 The calendar puts Clinton in the best position to help his global running mates. Election Day in Israel comes at the end of May, in Russia two weeks later, in the U.S. more than four months after that. The American President also has the greatest incentive to come to the ticket's support, because he has identified his policies with Peres's, and been a rooter for Yeltsin; their failure might well contribute to his own.
Therefore, to shore up Shimon Peres:
Clinton has invested heavily in identifying himself with the initiative begun by the Israeli. Despite Clinton's brief protocol appointment with the opposition leader Benjamin Netanyahu during today's stop in Israel, nobody doubts that the loftily named "peacemakers' summit" and subsequent visit to terror-tortured Israel is designed to stop the plummeting polls of Peres.
The ratings of Israel's Prime Minister will probably be blipped upward by the emergency visitation. Jews had to be somewhat reassured by the sight of Arab summiteers -- notably excepting Syria, which supports the terror process -- agreeing to a statement of "strong condemnation of all acts of terror . . . including recent terrorist attacks in Israel."
Getting Arabs to sign on to that has meaning. Credit Clinton with good arm-twisting to get that language, though it was vitiated by a promise to pay money to Arafat's organization even before he proves his ability to root out Palestinian terror. Israelis may not forgive Peres for gambling with lives by subcontracting antiterrorism to Arafat, but they have to notice how Clinton stands by his South Lawn guests.
To shore up Boris Yeltsin:
Clinton has his work cut out for him there. Yeltsin's polls remain in single digits for good reasons. His promises to end the carnage in Chechnya have been broken, with a recent rebel raid embarrassing the army; he has tightened his control of state television and fired free-market economists, alienating reformers; he has failed to protect Serbian war criminals, infuriating extreme nationalists.
But Clinton used his influence on the International Monetary Fund to extend Russia a multibillion-dollar loan, bolstering Yeltsin's prestige in the run-up to elections.
Next month, Yeltsin will host the U.S. President and other G-7 leaders at a summit in Moscow, partly to talk about nuclear safety, partly to appear side-by-side with Clinton on Russian and American TV, campaigning together in the same media-sensitive way the American did yesterday in Sharm el-Sheik and will today in Tel Aviv with Peres. To avoid embarrassing Yeltsin, Clinton will dismay Eastern Europe by downplaying NATO enlargement.
Clinton knows that Yeltsin will immediately take his election campaign to China, signing a treaty settling old border disputes while selling China more advanced warplanes. The U.S. President will be tempted to let the Russian carry a message to Beijing about Taiwan; such a Yeltsin role, playing Russia's new China card, might cause proud Russians to see Yeltsin as a global superpower broker.
Thus do the candidates in Washington, Moscow and Jerusalem work in unprecedented harmony. They believe it to be in their nations' interests and know it to be in their personal political interests.
The question in each case is this: Does the image of a leader bestriding the world scene decisively affect voters' behavior -- or will voters see this alliance of incumbents as merely a pose to distract attention from problems at home or worries about their leaders' characters?
My guess is already on the record: If Peres, Yeltsin and Clinton all lose office this year, I will collect the Pundits' Trifecta with its deliciously long odds. If all three leaders win, however, the lesson will be plain: In presidential politics, hands across the sea can wash each other.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Lower in Quiet Trading As Stocks and Bonds Calm Down

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar crept lower in quiet trading yesterday as American stock and bond markets settled down after three days of wild swings.
The German mark and Swiss franc extended gains against the dollar on expectations that neither European country would soon cut its interest rates.
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar slipped to 105.10 Japanese yen, from 105.25 yen on Tuesday. The dollar was quoted at 1.4703 German marks, down from 1.4745. The British pound fell to $1.5230, from $1.5235.
Stocks and bonds edged modestly lower yesterday, but there was no sign of the volatility that has gripped the markets since Friday's surprising report that more than 700,000 jobs were created in February.
The lull, however, may be temporary as the markets braced for any surprises in United States inflation reports scheduled for today and tomorrow.
"The market is still trying to reassess the state of the economy so we are anxious to see inflation and production data," said Bob Lynch, currency analyst at MMS International. "More important for the dollar is probably going to be German policy."
The mark rose against the dollar on widespread expectations that the Bundesbank would keep rates steady at its council meeting today despite plentiful signs of economic weakness and high unemployment.
"The market is pretty much of the opinion if they were to cut rates, it would be a surprise," said Steven Jury, chief dealer at the Union Bank of Switzerland.
Mr. Jury said the Swiss franc strengthened further a day after the president of the Swiss National Bank, Mark Lusser, said he saw no need to lower rates.
Currency traders said there was also some buying of Swiss francs, a traditional safe-haven currency, as a result of China-Taiwan tensions.
The dollar was little changed against the Japanese yen as threats to Taiwan from China weakened the yen.
The New Zealand dollar and the Australian dollar benefited from investment flows out of Japan and Taiwan, traders said.
The dollar stayed in a narrow range in New York trading. It dipped below 1.47 marks several times but quickly bounced higher.
"There is interest in buying under 1.47 marks," said Lizbeth Goldberg, assistant vice president at Bayerische Hypobank. "Funds were in buying at 1.4685."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Edge Lower; 6.68% Yield

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices edged lower in nervous trading yesterday as market participants awaited reports on inflation due out today and tomorrow.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 5/32 of a percentage point, to 91 9/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.68 percent, from 6.66 percent on Tuesday. Shorter maturities fared better, with some investors selling longer maturities to buy shorter maturities and reduce their length of exposure in an unsettled market. 
 Bond prices received some support early in the session from comments by a Federal Reserve official and by a report pointing to modest growth with low inflation.
The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, Jack Guynn, said late Tuesday that the chances of either slower or more rapid economic growth were balanced, and as a result he was comfortable with the current monetary stance.
Mr. Guynn's comments suggested that the direction of the economy had not fundamentally changed despite Friday's employment report, which pointed to surprising strength. That conservative view of the economy was echoed yesterday in the Fed's survey of business conditions.
The survey of the Fed's 12 regional districts, known as the beige book, found that the economy "grew modestly" in the first two months of the year, with wages and prices generally subdued.
Bond traders said the report was in line with expectations and did not give much guidance in deciding whether the employment report was overstated.
Still, the report curbed anxieties about wage pressures that the job report had rekindled.
"Basically economic growth is moderate," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. "Even more important, inflation is very subdued and there doesn't seem to be worsening wage-price pressures. This report gives us the peace of mind that we all needed after last Friday's jolt."
Today, the market turns its attention to the Government's reports on producer prices in February. Mr. Sohn said the market was expecting little change in the Producer Price Index, which measures the prices that manufacturers and farmers charge for the products they sell to retailers, distributors or other buyers. The Government reports on February consumer prices tomorrow.
"The bottom line today is that earlier this week market participants were concerned about the Fed raising rates because of the strong economy," Mr. Sohn said. "That fear has subsided. Now the hope of further cuts in interest rates is regaining momentum given the subdued inflation in the beige book."
Still, he added, "You'll need a strong heart to stay through this market."
In other market activity, the Treasury sold $9 billion of 42-day cash management bills at an average rate of 5.11 percent, a higher rate than the three-month maturity at this week's regular bill auction on Monday, which saw the average rate down to 4.95 percent. The bills were sold to raise cash to pay a cash-management bill maturing today.

HEADLINE: Canada, Backed by Mexico, Protests to U.S. on Cuba Sanctions

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
In a sign of the growing tensions between the United States and its trading partners over stepped-up American sanctions against Cuba, Canada said today that it had lodged a trade protest with the Clinton Administration, and Mexico immediately asked to join Canadian-American discussions on the issue.
Responding to a new American law that seeks to tighten the economic vise on Cuba by putting pressure on other countries not to do business with Fidel Castro's Government, Canada said it asked for consultations with the United States under the terms of the North American Free Trade Agreement. 
 Canada has extensive trade with Cuba, and has vigorously protested what it sees as unfair efforts by the United States to penalize Canadian companies and business executives who operate there.
Canadian officials said the law, sponsored by Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina and Representative Dan Burton of Indiana, both Republicans, and signed on Tuesday by President Clinton, could violate the free trade agreement in several ways.
In Ottawa, Canada's Trade Minister, Arthur Eggleton, said his Government would "seek clarification of U.S. intentions" in introducing the bill.
"Canada finds objectionable the Helms-Burton bill, which could interfere with companies engaged in legitimate business and which attempts to extend U.S. law to other jurisdictions," Mr. Eggleton said.
Mexican officials, expressing similar misgivings, said they supported the Canadian action, and wanted to take part in the consultations to get a clearer idea how the United States would carry out the legislation's most contentious measures.
A request for consultations is the first step in resolving trade disputes under Nafta, and could lead to a formal ruling on whether the American legislation violates the pact.
The legislation was passed by Congress and signed by President Clinton after the downing of two small civilian aircraft by Cuban fighters last month. Among other things, it allows American citizens to sue foreigners and foreign companies that "act to manage, lease, possess, use or hold an interest in" property confiscated by the Cuban Government from people who are now American citizens.
It also permits the United States to bar entry to foreign corporate officers and controlling shareholders who take part in using such property and foreign executives whose companies do business in Cuba.
The United States Trade Representative, Mickey Kantor, said the American position "is entirely consistent" with both the rules of Nafta and the world trade talks.
In an interview, Mr. Kantor said that under the trade agreement the United States reserved the right to protect its security interests and to bar from entry people who have committed crimes of moral turpitude under United States laws.
"The combination of those two, or either standing alone depending on the situation, would support our position," Mr. Kantor said.
Federico Salas, the minister for political affairs at the Mexican Embassy in Washington, said, "The Canadians have taken the initiative and we have requested to participate in these consultations." The European Union said last week that the law would "represent the extraterritorial application of U.S. jurisdiction and would restrict E.U. trade in goods and services with Cuba."
Russia also objected to provisions in the law linking American foreign aid to Russia to Moscow's cutting its military and economic ties to Mr. Castro.

LENGTH: 676 words

HEADLINE: New York City's Newest

 BODY:
New York City has heard warnings throughout its history about the burdens of its large population of immigrants. New estimates from the Census Bureau, showing migration patterns in and out of the city in the first half of the 1990's, may well reinforce fears that a rising flood of arrivals from foreign countries will increase the cost of schools and social services while the city's tax base keeps eroding. Examined more carefully, however, the patterns of immigration yield a strikingly more hopeful portrait. In fact, the influx of foreigners in the city is enhancing its economic vitality and rescuing whole neighborhoods from decline.
The large number of new immigrants, especially those from Asia and the Caribbean, are everywhere evident in New York City. But immigration levels were much higher in the past. The City Planning Department estimates that half the city's population is foreign-born or descended from a foreign-born parent, compared with nearly 80 percent in that category earlier this century. 
 Starting in the 1950's, the trend of upper- and middle-class people, especially whites, fleeing the city while the poor flood in has indeed eroded the city's tax base. But that pattern has changed in the last couple of decades. According to the Planning Department's population division, Puerto Ricans and native-born black citizens -- who constituted the greatest wave of newcomers in the postwar decades -- are now leaving the city in proportionately larger numbers than whites. An especially extraordinary change is taking place in the city's black population, with native-born black residents leaving the city and being replaced by immigrants from the Caribbean and elsewhere. The Planning Department estimates that about 40 percent of the city's black residents are foreign-born or descended from a foreign-born parent.
With its proud symbol of the Statue of Liberty, New York City certainly remains a beacon of freedom for refugees and the poor. But immigrants today are increasingly people with skills, entrepreneurial spirit and cohesive family structures who are less inclined to go on welfare or use public housing than current city residents. Except for Dominicans and Mexicans, all the foreign-born groups in the city have a lower percentage of people in poverty than the city's average of 19 percent. According to the Planning Department, the median household income for foreign-born black residents is more than $28,000, compared with $22,000 for native-born black residents.
Providing services to immigrants does cost the city money, particularly because they are a major factor in expanding school enrollment. But educating the children of immigrants amounts to an investment in the trained work force and taxpayers of tomorrow. There is also little doubt that many of these immigrants are working at lower wage rates than native-born New Yorkers, perhaps contributing to a stagnation or even decline in wages for native-born workers. But the work they do is also helping to keep businesses and retail outfits afloat and provide domestic help to middle-class families in which both spouses work.
New York, like other major cities, has its share of decaying neighborhoods, but think of what would have happened in many of them if there had not been immigrants. Some two million people left New York City in the 1970's, the period of its worst financial difficulties since the Depression. In that same period, 800,000 immigrants came to the city to seek opportunities. The city actually grew in size in the 1980's and is projected to grow again this decade. In neighborhood after neighborhood, immigrants have moved in, set up shops and revitalized community life.
The next time New Yorkers hear warnings of immigrants strangling its services and wrecking its economy, they should remember that the city remains a place of perhaps the greatest ethnic diversity in the United States, where immigrants of all kinds come to compete and seek opportunity. Their story is one of success for them and the city itself.

HEADLINE: Fed's Survey Finds Growth Is Moderate

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
The nation's economy grew modestly in the first two months of the year, with wages firmly in check despite an apparent spreading of labor-market tightness, a Federal Reserve survey found today.
But severe weather in the Northeast and other natural disturbances clouded the assessment. Analysts said they could find no significant difference from the preceding report issued on Jan. 17 that described the economy as "growing at a generally modest pace" in the final weeks of 1995. 
At a time when securities traders are studying every shred of economic evidence, the Fed's anecdotal survey of business conditions in all 12 of its regions prompted no discernible market reaction on its release at noon.
The question of whether a February pickup was just a bounce-back from the January blizzard or the start of something more vigorous "is not clarified at all" by the central bank's summary of the anecdotal information it solicited, mostly from the private sector, said Marilyn Schaja, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Signs of a pickup come from the Labor Department report last Friday of 705,000 additional jobs in February.
Some other analysts took the seemingly flat trend in today's report as a partial confirmation of suspicions that the jobs report represented a statistical fluke, overstating job gains in the rebound from January's blizzard-related decline.
"They didn't say it's better -- they said it's the same," said Lacy H. Hunt, chief United States economist at HSBC Markets in New York, referring to business activity described in the Fed's beige-book report. He noted that the economy grew at an annual rate of less than 1 percent during the fourth quarter of 1995.
Unchanged or even slightly stronger performance means "there is no resurgence in the economy actually taking place," he added.
The strong jobs report had been taken to mean that the Fed could not be expected to cut interest rates again, for fear of fueling inflation -- a perception that led to last Friday's 171-point market drop.
And even after today's report, Mr. Hunt and other analysts regard the employment figures as probably ruling out a cut in short-term rates at the Fed's next scheduled policy meeting on March 26. But he is not precluding a cut at the May session.
Leif H. Olsen, a Connecticut consultant and financial manager, also focused heavily on the discrepancy between the soundings in the beige book and the Labor Department's report of the biggest payroll expansion in more than 12 years.
"It comes much closer to telling the truth about what happened in February, continued low inflation and modest growth," Mr. Olsen said of the Fed sampling, which was prepared to aid policy makers at the coming meeting.
In its summary of the survey, assembled this time by the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston based on information collected before March 4, the central bank painted the usual mixed industry and geographic picture.
"Over half the districts cite moderate economic growth or continuing solid levels of economic activity," it said. "Most of the others mention recent improvements, largely reflecting rebounds from weather-related slowdowns earlier in the year."
Manufacturing was mixed, with activity level or growing more slowly in the Boston, St. Louis, Minneapolis, Kansas City and Dallas districts, the Fed found. Retailing generally improved but the February uptick did not appear in parts of the West and Midwest where continued sluggishness was evident in San Francisco, St. Louis and Minneapolis, the report said.
One of the clearer developments was that all districts reported increased activity in residential real estate, in most cases including higher sales. But while the market for new homes has improved in the New York metropolitan area, the upstate market remained depressed by employer downsizing and "pervasive" pessimism among consumers, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Today's report found little inflation pressure even though it found "tight labor markets in several districts" compared with January's characterization of "shortages of skilled workers" in some areas.
It said wages "are reported to be increasing at a modest pace" while retail prices, if up at all, were just slightly higher. And prices of most commodities were "steady, stabilizing or increasing very little; a few are falling."
Other developments in the survey were the highest shipments in more than a decade from iron mines in the Minneapolis district, an "especially severe" drop in commercial borrowings at banks in the Cleveland district, slower business in both exports and imports at Richmond-district ports, a significant rise in European and Brazilian but not Mexican tourists in Florida and heavy drought damage to the winter wheat crop in the Midwest.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mostly Higher Despite Drop in Dow

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Although the Dow Jones industrial average eased yesterday, stock prices generally rose.
"The Dow has been outperforming the general market so far this year, so the day's correction was due," said Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist of Everen Securities. "Evidence was building of gradual economic strengthening and less chance that the Fed will cut interest rates later this month." 
 One such piece of evidence came yesterday when the Federal Reserve issued its so-called beige book report showing moderate growth in the economy during the last two months. This report will be a major focus when the Fed's policy-setting committee meets on March 26 to discuss rates.
In yesterday's mixed market performance, the Dow Jones industrials declined 15.17 points, to 5,568.72, but the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks gained 1.46 points, to 638.55, and the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index jumped 15.59 points -- or almost 1 1/2 percent -- to 1,088.64.
Advances far exceeded declines on the New York Stock Exchange, 1,536 to 884. Turnover on the Big Board was 413 million shares, down from the 461.5 million shares traded on Tuesday and even below the most recent three-month daily trading average of about 423 million shares.
Technology stocks surged amid the perception by traders that the economy was not likely to wilt in 1996. Microsoft, which was upgraded by Merrill Lynch, increased 5 1/8, to 100 7/8; I.B.M. rose 1 5/8, to 115 7/8; Compaq gained 3/4, to 37 3/4, and Hewlett-Packard advanced 1, to 94 3/4. The Morgan Stanley high-tech index was up 6.79 points, to 320.33.
Oil service issues once again enjoyed investor attention, as gasoline inventories plunged to a two-month low. Schlumberger closed at 78, up 3 1/2; Halliburton closed at 56 1/4, up 3; Dresser Industries closed at 28 7/8, up 1 1/8, and Baker Hughes closed at 27 7/8, up 1 5/8.
Machine tool stocks also benefitted from the anticipation of an economic pickup. Cincinnati Milicron advanced 5/8, to 28 3/8, and Giddings & Lewis climbed 1, to 18 3/8.
However, tobacco stocks plunged on the news that the Brooke Group's Liggett unit had agreed to settle a class-action suit over nicotine addiction. Philip Morris, which fell 4 3/8, to 98, was responsible for more than 12 points of the drop in the Dow. Other decliners included RJR Nabisco, off 1, to 33 7/8; American Brands, off 3/4, to 44, and UST, off 1/2, to 34 5/8. In contrast, Brooke soared 1 1/2, to 9 7/8.
Drug issues slumped, as portfolio managers rotated their funds into cyclical sectors. Merck declined 1 1/2, to 61 5/8; Pfizer dropped 1 3/4, to 62; Eli Lilly gave up 1 1/4, to 62 1/4, and Schering-Plough fell 7/8, to 58 3/8.
Some alcoholic beverage companies were also lower. Anheuser-Busch closed at 65 3/8, down 2 1/4, and Brown-Forman class B shares closed at 38 1/8, down 3/8.
Two big retailers moved into plus territory on favorable news. J. C. Penney increased 1 1/4, to 50 1/4, after raising its dividend by more than 8 percent. And Toys "R" Us advanced 1 5/8, to 27 5/8, after telling analysts that management was optimistic about this year's profits.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: LOOKING FORWARD;
With Dole Cashing In, Both Sides Say All Bets Are Off for Fall

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: MIAMI, March 13

 BODY:
Senator Bob Dole's emergence as the likely Republican nominee has led both parties to re-evaluate just how much of an advantage, if any, President Clinton would have over him in November.
Prominent Democrats who had expected Mr. Clinton to coast to re-election say they are beginning to reconsider Mr. Dole now that he is having some success putting the bruising primary battle behind him after his sweep of Florida, Texas and five other states on Tuesday. 
 "These things have an ebb and flow, and right now the flow is that Dole's going to get his day in the sun a little bit," said James Carville, a strategist for Mr. Clinton. "I've detected too much Democratic glee for my taste right now."
But one who is still gleeful is Mark Mellman, a Democratic pollster. "Dole is a substantially weakened opponent as a result of his performance in the primaries," he said. "His inability to articulate -- period -- is indelibly printed on people's minds."
Though it is in their interest to present a united front, even Republicans who for months fretted that Mr. Dole was no match for Mr. Clinton are now tempering their concerns.
With the outcome of the primaries essentially a foregone conclusion, Mr. Dole, who was prone to stumbling on the campaign trail, can now spend more time in an atmosphere that better suits him: the well of the Senate. Mr. Dole's advisers said the Senator would now play to his strengths as majority leader and emphasize issues like the budget, overhauling welfare and cutting taxes as he casts Mr. Clinton as failing to deliver to the American people.
"Clinton's trying to run against a do-nothing Congress," said Scott Reed, Mr. Dole's campaign manager, "so we'll make the case that we're running against a do-nothing President."
Mr. Clinton, who does not share Mr. Dole's talents as a legislative mechanic but is considered a more adept campaigner, is doing his best to stay above the political fray. His staff continues to push back the date that Mr. Clinton will formally announce his re-election campaign. And one after another, White House aides refuse to be quoted publicly sizing up Mr. Dole.
But privately, strategists on both sides say they are preparing for a hard-fought contest, and they discount polls that for months have put Mr. Clinton ahead in a one-on-one matchup. One uncertainty is that with the primary season ending far earlier this year than usual, and the national conventions not beginning until late August, the contours of the election could greatly change, and change again, before November.
"It's natural for Dole to look pretty damaged at this point -- he has just run the gauntlet and been paddled like a fraternity brother," said Charles E. Cook Jr., a nonpartisan analyst. "But eight months is a lifetime. I think this thing is going to get real close."
This much is certain: Americans generally sound dissatisfied with both Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole. Forty percent of Republican voters and 46 percent of Democrats said they would like to see a third-party candidate in the race, according to a CBS News poll of 1,265 adults nationwide conducted on Sunday and Monday.
In fact, several recent polls offer signs of the strengths and weaknesses of both candidates. The surveys show that people continue to have doubts about Mr. Clinton's leadership skills and his character, though they like him more than they did a year ago, and are generally more upbeat about the economy.
By contrast, voters are concerned that at age 72, Mr. Dole may lack the stamina to be an effective President, and they are concerned that he has no vision. Still, voters generally consider Mr. Dole's longtime experience in Government a plus.
Florida, where Mr. Dole won an overwhelming 57 percent of the vote on Tuesday, is an important testing ground for the relative strengths and weaknesses of both men. While President George Bush won this state in 1992, the margin was small, and Democrats are beginning a major effort to win here in November.
A recent Mason-Dixon poll in Florida found that after months in which Mr. Dole was well ahead, Mr. Clinton has risen to the point where he and the Senator are in a statistical dead heat. Yet there are signs that this fresh strength will not last.
"Unfortunately for Clinton, both the G.O.P. squabbling and voters' interest in it are likely to diminish considerably now that Dole is overwhelmingly favored to win the G.O.P. nod," said Robert Joffee, a vice president of Mason-Dixon, a national polling company.
Another possible trouble spot for Mr. Clinton is Texas, which he also lost in 1992. Two statewide polls released last week show that Mr. Dole holds a substantial lead over Mr. Clinton in the state, even among self-described Democrats.
One close adviser to Mr. Clinton, speaking on the condition on anonymity, said that while the President was a better campaigner, Mr. Dole would "play this whole thing of experience and maturity and solidity."
The adviser added: "With a fairly good economy, what's left to go after? The character issue."
The Republicans are viewed as having some advantages in amassing the 270 electoral votes needed to win the White House. For one thing, Mr. Clinton won several Southern and Western states in 1992, like Georgia, Louisiana and Colorado, that strategists say he may have trouble hanging onto because voters in those states perceive that he has moved to the left since he was elected.
And even if Mr. Clinton wins California, he will likely need to capture the industrial heartland -- states like Ohio, Illinois and Michigan -- which vote in primaries next Tuesday and are increasingly Republican havens.
The CBS News poll found that 63 percent of all voters see Mr. Dole as losing against Mr. Clinton in November. If there is a two-candidate race, Republican voters are split over their expected outcome, with 49 percent saying Mr. Dole will win, and 43 percent viewing the President as likely to prevail.
The poll, which has a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points, also found that 69 percent consider Mr. Dole's three-decade career in Washington a positive factor, while only 21 percent said it was a drawback.
But in a finding that could be damaging to Mr. Dole, many people who voted in Florida and Texas on Tuesday said they were fairly distrustful of the Federal Government. Sixty percent of Floridians and 68 percent of Texans said they see the Government as trustworthy only some of the time.
Although he says Mr. Dole's weaknesses are significant, even Mr. Mellman, the Democratic strategist, expects the race to tighten. "It's still likely to be a close race," he said, "because they usually are in a country that's pretty evenly divided between Democrats and Republicans."
