HEADLINE: Census Sees a Profound Ethnic Shift in U.S.

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
 Fueled by immigration and higher birth rates among Hispanic women, the United States is undergoing a profound demographic shift, and by the middle of the next century only about half of the population will be non-Hispanic whites, the Census Bureau predicted today.
By 2050, the bureau said, immigration patterns and differences in birth rates, combined with an overall slowdown in growth the country's population, will produce a United States in which 53 percent of the people will be non-Hispanic whites, down from 74 percent today. 
 In contrast, Hispanic people will make up 24.5 per cent of the population, up from the current 10.2 percent, and Asians will make up 8.2 percent, an increase from the current 3.3 percent. The percentage of the black population will remain relatively stable, rising to about 13.6 percent by the year 2050 from the current 12 percent.
The population as a whole will rise to about 394 million from 262 million, an increase of 50 percent, the bureau said. Even with that increase, it added, the country would be going through some of the most sluggish population growth in its history.
Over all, the report suggests that the United States is experiencing one of the most dramatic shifts in its racial and ethnic makeup since the trade in slaves transformed the racial composition of the South and the waves of immigration from Eastern and Southern Europe in the late 19th and early 20th centuries gave an ethnic flavor to industrialized urban areas of the Northeast and Midwest.
"The world is not going to be the same in 30 years as it is now," said Gregory Spencer, director of the Population Projections Branch at the bureau. To put the growth rates of the Asian and Hispanic population in perspective, the report noted that the two groups were expected to have annual growth rates of 2 percent to the year 2030. In comparison, even at the zenith of the Baby Boom, the country as a whole never grew by 2 percent a year.
The report, "Population Projections of the United States by Age, Sex, Race and Hispanic Origin: 1995 to 2050," noted that its projections were simply projections. Changes in legislation regarding immigration, changes in fertility rates, and breakthroughs in medical care that could extend life expectancy could alter future estimates.
Though the United States is the fastest-growing country in the industrialized world, the report indicated that the nation was about to embark on a sharp slowdown in the rate of its population increases. Indeed, the report said that after 2025, the United States would grow at a slower rate than any time in its history, mainly because of declining birth rates and an increased number of deaths as the population ages.
But with that slowdown will come more diversity, a phenomenon that will present a host of new economic business and social issues. For example, the report noted that by the year 2030, the non-Hispanic white population would make up less than half of the people under the age of 18, but three-fourths of those over 65.
Given this, questions of the mix of tax revenues distributed to public education or Social Security or Medicare could easily take on a racial and ethnic tinge.
"You might have somewhat poorer Hispanics being asked to pay for the benefits of relatively well-off white Baby Boomers," said William H. Frey, a research scientist with the Population Studies Center at the University of Michigan. "It's not clear what the political dynamic of that will be. It may not just be the boomers verses the busters."
The Census Bureau report is likely to fuel the debate over immigration.
The report's population-growth projections are, in part, based on an annual net increase in immigrants -- both legal and illegal -- of 820,000. Both the Clinton Administration and Republican sponsors of bills being debated in Congress support changes in the immigration law that would reduce legal immigration by about one-third. Leaders of both parties advocate vigorous efforts against illegal immigration.
Much of the debate has focused on whether immigrants take jobs from unemployed citizens but its subtext concerns population growth in general and ethnic diversity in particular.
Organizations such as the Carrying Capacity Network and Negative Population Growth and the Federation for American Immigration Reform argue that immigration should be curbed because the country is approaching its limit in terms of a manageable population.
Dan Stein, executive director of the federation group, said: "The most important part of the story is that this is happening and no one has asked the country is this what we want. Do we really want another 100 million people?"
For their part, pro-immigration organizations say the country can accommodate a higher population with little difficulty. They say they fear their opponents are worried not about the number of added residents, but rather their ethnic backgrounds. "We are all against illegal immigration," said Lisa Navarete, a spokeswoman for the National Council of La Raza, a Hispanic civil rights group. "And when it comes to legal immigration, we are not being flooded with people."
The Census Bureau reports indicate that the number of births to non-Hispanic whites is expected to drop throughout the rest of this decade and begin a slow rise in the next century. In contrast, births to women of Hispanic and Asian descent are projected to more than triple by the year 2050.
In addition to higher birth rates, the median age for these groups is younger than for non-Hispanic whites and, as a result, they have more women of child-bearing age. Cultural mores relating to family size also come into play. For example the fertility rate of Hispanic-American women born in Mexico is 147 births per 1,000 women, much higher than that of non-Hispanic whites and of Hispanic women born elsewhere in Latin America.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Planning could help in upheavals like the arms industry cutback.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
OUT of sight, out of mind? The virtual collapse of Southern California's mighty arms industry, with the largest regional job losses since the Great Depression, is no longer on the national radar screens. Unemployment in Los Angeles County has edged down to 8.6 percent today from 9.4 percent in 1994. Besides, downsizing is hardly a problem unique to Southern California or to military contractors: the drive for enhanced productivity is hitting every big business from banking to textiles to retailing.
But planning specialists at Rutgers University's Project on Regional and Industrial Economics and the nonprofit Economic Roundtable in California argue that the long road back for Los Angeles offers lessons that should not be ignored. For one thing, said Ann Markusen of Rutgers, it says a lot about what sort of government intervention works in coping with economic dislocation. It also underscores the risks in leaving the military-industrial complex intact -- arguably even stronger -- after consolidation. "If the contractors don't diversify, you'll end up with even more pork in the defense budget," she said. 
 While just about everyone knows that Los Angeles took a hit from Pentagon cutbacks, few people who don't live there understand the magnitude. The county with the most military-related production lost roughly half of its high-paying military-related jobs from 1990 to 1995. What's more, the Rutgers-Economic Roundtable's newly released report, "Post Cold War Frontiers: Defense Downsizing and Conversion in Los Angeles," estimates that contractors' revenues fell to $10.2 billion in 1994 from $16.8 billion in 1988
Adding to the county's woes, the Pentagon cuts came amid a broader regional decline driven by high land and housing costs, tightening environmental regulation and festering inner-city problems. Indeed, the authors argue that the big military buildup of the Carter-Reagan years masked serious weaknesses in the regional economy -- weaknesses that had already hollowed out the manufacturing base of older American cities.
The prevailing wisdom in Los Angeles -- and Washington -- is that Southern California neglected the basics of capitalist hygiene. After decades of living well off Federal largesse and the natural attractions of the region, local government lost sight of what keeps free enterprise healthy. From this perspective, what Los Angeles needs is less regulation, lower taxes and improvements in infrastructure that help business.
And how do military contractors fit into this picture? Hazily, if at all. They are the equivalent of dying Soviet enterprises, clumsy dinosaurs that evolved to satisfy the needs of a single and increasingly reluctant client. Seen through this lens, the policy of encouraging mergers among arms companies offers the tidiest way of coping with a long-term liability to the regional economy.
But the evidence, the authors of the report argue, suggests a more complex picture. Among the big contractors, Rockwell, GM Hughes and TRW have been relatively successful at converting production capacity to civilian use. Hughes, for example, is broadening its base in communications satellites, while TRW is pressing ahead in advanced vehicle and highway systems.
It is no coincidence, the authors say, that all four had substantial experience producing for nonmilitary markets. By contrast, Northrop Grumman, McDonnell-Douglas and Litton are consolidating capacity and jobs to remain specialized military contractors.
To the Rutgers-Economic Roundtable group, the message is clear: what's needed is smarter government, not less. Carefully planned state and Federal subsidies can preserve high-paying jobs and diversify the local economy. Nothing could be more counterproductive, they say, than the Pentagon's enthusiasm for mergers as a means of cutting military production capacity.
Consolidation will lead to even less competition among military suppliers. Worse, perhaps, it will strengthen the hand of liberal and conservative politicians alike who have come to treat military spending as a jobs program. Consider, Ms. Markusen says, the successful lobbying to continue production of Northrop Grumman's B-2 bomber, an incredibly expensive weapon designed to mop up secondary targets after a nuclear cataclysm.
Are they right? Regional planning -- in particular, economic planning -- is a hard sell in America, and not without reason. By some interpretations, one great strength of the economy is its capacity for unplanned self-renewal. No one in Washington, after all, decided to replant the orchards around San Jose in silicon.
But the era in which rapid economic growth and mobility covered a multitude of social sins may be coming to an end. Americans may not be good at planning economic change. But then again they aren't good at living with the insecurity and waste of the upheavals of the last few decades.

HEADLINE: Pension Insurance Fund Deficit Is at Its Lowest Level Since 1981

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
The deficit in the Government's single-employer pension insurance fund fell by $925 million last year to the lowest level since 1981, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation announced today.
In its annual report to Congress, the Government's pension insurance agency attributed the improvement to a record $2 billion in investment earnings and to the fact that no major pension plan was terminated. 
 "The Federal insurance program protecting pensions of the nation's work force has been restored to a level of financial strength unseen in more than a decade," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, the agency's board chairman, said in a statement.
The program insures about 33 million pensions in plans sponsored by a single employer and covers about one-third of the nation's work force.
Still, Mr. Reich noted that the decline in the insurance agency's deficit reflected economic conditions that were subject to change, and said, "We must view this improvement with caution, remaining vigilant in assuring a sound pension system."
The deficit in the single-employer program was $315 million, the difference between assets of $10.4 billion and liabilities of $10.7 billion. It was the smallest imbalance since the gap between assets and liabilities was $189 million in 1981.
The deficit totaled $1.24 billion in 1994, after peaking at $2.9 billion in 1993.
The pension agency also reported that its multi-employer program covering nine million people had a net surplus of $192 million last year.
The agency said its improved financial condition mirrored a similar gain among the pension plans it insures. Inadequate funding of such plans dropped to about $31 billion from $71 billion a year earlier.
The agency paid about $763 million in benefits to more than 182,000 people whose companies had failed to honor their payments last year, an increase of about 5 percent from 1994.
It said it received $860 million in revenue from the insurance premiums paid by companies with covered pension plans. The agency receives no funds from general tax revenues.
Including those people receiving benefits, the agency was responsible for the pensions of about 392,000 workers in 2,094 terminated pension plans.

HEADLINE: As Albany Cuts Funds, Lobbies Spend More

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 13

 BODY:
Scrambling to save their piece of the shrinking state budget, corporations and interest groups spent $46.9 million to lobby state government in New York last year, a 17 percent increase over 1994 and the largest rise in nearly two decades, a state commission said today.
Hospitals and other health-care providers were among those at the top of the list, in large part because they undertook expensive efforts to beat back Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to reduce the state's Medicaid costs. Unions for state workers and teachers, which feared layoffs and cuts in money for education, also made large expenditures. 
 The Greater New York Hospital Association was first at $1.18 million, and the Health Care Association of New York State was fourth at $1.04 million. After their lobbying of legislators and their buying of television and other advertising to attack budget cuts, Mr. Pataki's proposed reduction in the state's Medicaid bill last year was pared from nearly $1.5 billion to $700 million.
The increased spending stirred new calls for reform of New York's lobbying laws, which have changed little in decades and are more lax than those of many states. It also focused attention on the rise in lobbying in state capitals nationwide, which until recent years was far less sophisticated than the lobbying campaigns mounted in Washington.
Ten years ago, corporations, unions and other interest groups spent $15.1 million on lobbying state government officials in New York, less than one third the amount spent last year, according to the New York Temporary State Commission on Lobbying.
That money typically went to pay lawyers who glad-handed legislators in the back rooms of the Capitol or tried to sway their opinions over a leisurely lunch. But with governors seeking to squeeze budgets and the Republicans who control Congress fighting to give greater responsibilities to state governments, lobbying tactics at the state level in New York and many other states are growing more aggressive.
These days, for example, state lobbyists buy television ads, something that was unheard of just a few years ago.
One study found that between 1980 and 1990, the number of interest groups lobbying at the state level nearly doubled, to an average of about 620 per state, said Prof. Michael J. Malbin, director of the Center for Legislative Studies at the Rockefeller Institute in Albany.
"Since Ronald Reagan became President there has been more emphasis on policy making at the state level," Mr. Malbin said. "So, more people have a stake in trying to track what's going on and trying to influence it. And the proliferation of interest groups at the national level has made it easier for them to replicate and to decentralize when it became time to do so."
Instead of just talking to legislators, lobbyists here and in other state capitals are devoting a significant chunk of their lobbying budget to advertisements that are intended to get the public to pressure state officials. Much of the money spent by health-care groups last year, for example, was funneled to television commercials that sought to raise alarms about Mr. Pataki's cuts.
The lobbying commission said that expenditures for advertising rose from about $250,000 in 1994 to more than $6 million last year.
The third-ranking group on the lobbying commission's list, AT&T, spent $1.16 million, mostly on advertisements that focused on influencing a State Public Service Commission debate on rates for Nynex. AT&T was concerned that the commission would allow Nynex to set high rates that would keep AT&T out of the regional telephone market, said David E. Roos, AT&T's lobbyist in Albany.
Officials of the state lobbying commission said that the increase in television advertising was one reason that the lobbying expenditures of four groups reached more than $1 million last year for the first time. The total last year for all groups was $46.9 million, up from $39.1 million in 1994, which, adjusted for inflation, represents a 17 percent increase.
Kenneth Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, which represents 174 hospitals and nursing homes in the New York City area, said that the push to cut health-care costs had forced his group to protect itself. It concentrated much of its money on advertising, he said.
"The hospital community is being clobbered by budget cuts and proposed budget cuts both in Albany and in Washington," he said. "From our point of view, we would prefer not to spend this money. The problem is that given that these issues are so enormous, the only thing that we can do is go to the public and let them know what it is about."
Morris H. Klein, chairman of the state lobbying commission, said that last year, 1,156 interest groups registered with the commission, up from 1,099 in 1994. Mr. Klein and several organizations that lobby for government reform used the announcement of the expenditures to press the Legislature to revamp the state's lobbying laws.
Blair Horner, legislative director for the New York Public Interest Research Group, called the increase in lobbying last year staggering.
Mr. Horner said that the Legislature should strengthen the powers of the lobbying commission, which it established in 1977 as a temporary agency and whose authority it must renew periodically. He said New York should follow other states and ban campaign contributions by interest groups that also lobby heavily.
He pointed out that lobbying by groups at the top of the commission's list carried more weight because of their campaign contributions. The state teachers' union, for example, spent $1.17 million on lobbying and $402,000 on campaign contributions. The Health Care Asssociation of New York State channeled $112,000 into campaign contributions, in addition to its $1.04 million on lobbying.
"We have among the weakest laws restricting lobbying practices in the country," Mr. Horner said. "Twenty states restrict lobbyists' ability to make campaign contributions. The nation is way ahead of New York."

HEADLINE: Grass-Roots Fight Emerges on Hospital Plan

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani selected the first city-run hospitals to be put up for sale, he chose three that were considered the most marketable. Because they were in neighborhoods with medical alternatives, they were also considered the least likely to generate community opposition, or so his advisers told him.
What the officials did not anticipate was that advocates for the hospitals -- Coney Island Hospital, Queens Hospital Center and Elmhurst Hospital Center -- would rise up to fight the sales. 
 The Community Advisory Board of the Queens Hospital Center in Jamaica, the most vociferous of the opponents, has filed a lawsuit to prevent the sale. Twenty-five Brooklyn groups have formed a coalition that has held half a dozen rallies as well as monthly meetings in an effort to keep Coney Island Hospital in public hands. The Elmhurst Hospital Community Advisory Board in Queens has developed a proposal calling for it to become independent.
The effectiveness of the grass-roots protests is difficult to gauge, but by most accounts they have proved to be one more stumbling block to the Mayor's troubled attempts to sell or lease to private operators some or all of the city's 11 municipal hospitals. With Mount Sinai withdrawing from the bidding process on Tuesday, and a suit filed last week by the City Council over the sales, neighborhood groups have redoubled their effort to lobby elected officials to oppose privatization of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which operates the city hospitals.
"It was a morale booster," said Peg Graham, executive director of the Campaign to Save Our Hospitals, a Manhattan-based group of clergy and civic and union leaders formed two years ago to help communities organize against hospital privatization. "It gives us reason to do more lobbying and targeting of our City Council members so that when they do win their lawsuit and vote on privatization, they will stop the Mayor."
She added that Mount Sinai's withdrawal underscores the group's concerns about the lack of a comprehensive plan, including the economics of privatization and how to provide care.
Assemblyman William Scarborough, coordinator of Friends of Queens Hospital Center, the advisory board's fund-raising arm, summed up opponents' prevailing view.
"There is no guarantee that the poor will not be refused hospital care," Mr. Scarborough said. "They will be out in the streets. The scary thing is what's happening to the economy with downsizing and privatization, you have the potential for a crisis that could hurt every segment of society."
The fight at Queens Hospital, a deteriorating 20-acre complex whose future is the most threatened by a change of hand, began as soon as the Mayor announced his proposal in February 1995. Rory I. Lancman, chairman of the hospital's advisory board, was then a 25-year-old student at the Columbia University School of Law. He bowed out of his statutory interpretation class after hearing word, dashed to the computer lab, fired off a press release and headed to City Hall to attend the Mayor's news conference.
Vowing to fight the proposal "with every fiber of our being," Mr. Lancman filed a suit last September charging that the Giuliani administration failed to comply with the law by not consulting with advisory board members. The suit, now under appeal, was dismissed on the ground that such boards have no policy-making power. About 100 supporters showed up at a January dinner dance in St. Albans, raising $6,000 for the court battle.
All 11 of the city's hospital advisory boards, whose purpose is to safeguard the interests of their communities, have joined the appeals effort, contending that they have a right to inclusion and information in the privatization process.
For its part, the City Council suit charges that the administration has declined to provide specifics about how the city would care for indigent and uninsured patients. It also addresses a larger issue. The Giuliani administration, which says the hospitals would be managed more effectively if removed from city government, argues that the Mayor has the power to sell the hospitals; the Council disagrees.
"This definitely bolsters our case," Mr. Lancman, now a lawyer at a Wall Street firm, said of the City Council suit. "There has been a lot of secrecy surrounding this, and we are entitled to know the answer to numerous questions, which City Hall has so far failed to answer."
Speaking for the administration, Jeffrey D. Friedlander, first assistant Corporation Counsel, which represents the city in the suit, said that "consulting will be done at the right time" and noted that the administration is just as concerned with providing good health care as the City Council and the Queens Hospital advisory board.
Queens Hospital treats 325,000 patients each year, nearly 40 percent of them uninsured. Most patients come from the largely middle-class southeast part of Queens, which has pockets of poverty and a large Caribbean and South Asian immigrant population. An imposing hodge-podge of brick buildings straddling the border of Flushing and Jamaica, it has been scheduled for renovation for 20 years, but plans were scrapped last summer because of the fiscal crisis.
Many health analysts believe that, because of its proximity to Elmhurst Hospital, which is newly renovated and duplicates some services, Queens Hospital would be better downsized or even eliminated. The advisory board's virulent opposition can be partly attributed to the specter of lost jobs and a threat to the very existence of the hospital. A hard-nosed private hospital, considering the Elmhurst-Queens package, might just decide to do away with much of Queens.
Last year, Elmhurst Hospital, which is in the final phase of a three-year, $250 million renovation, treated 534,000 patients, only 7 percent of them uninsured. Its board has proposed to city officials that the hospital become a not-for-profit, self-governing facility, independent of the city as well as any other hospital.
It is Coney Island Hospital, widely considered well run and well maintained, that is thought to be the most marketable of the three. Last year, it treated 412,000 patients, 36 percent of them uninsured, in a primarily working-class population.
But opposition has been strong in Coney Island, where the hospital is seen as a centerpiece to the neighborhood, with its elderly patrons and burgeoning population of Russian Jews and people from Caribbean nations. Both the Coney Island Hospital Advisory Board and the area's community board have passed resolutions opposing privatization.
A coalition of community groups, ranging from Jewish organizations to senior centers, have been actively campaigning against the proposed sale, holding demonstrations, distributing fliers, shooting off letters to public officials.
Georganna Deas, 47, president of Coney Island Pride, a seven-year-old community organization, has been using the hospital's services for 25 years. An unemployed maintenance worker with no health insurance, she is fearful about the hospital's future not only for herself but for others like her. As reinforcement for her case, she pointed to the area's sprawling housing projects.
"We are the working poor, and I'm concerned that we won't have this type of ongoing care," said Ms. Deas. "Emergency care is not enough for people with AIDS. We feel like we are in a precarious situation and we are afraid."
The city has encountered such community resistance before: In 1980, the closing of Sydenham Hospital in Harlem led to sit-ins and clashes with the police, although it was long thought to be the most costly, inefficient and unnecessary hospital in the municipal system.
To many residents, hospitals are valued just as places where the bones of their children have been reset after a fall on a bicycle, and where sick relatives have been nursed back to health.
Audrey Orr, 69, of Hollis, has been a member of the Queens Hospital Advisory board for 21 years. She had a severe asthmatic attack in 1963 and was pronounced dead. But a tracheotomy in the emergency room allowed air to flow into her lungs.
"This hospital has a lot of memories for me," Mrs. Orr, a retired I.B.M. data processor said. "Privatization is not going to do anything whatsoever. No one has indicated who will take care of the indigents. They are trying to play Russian roulette with the lives of the people of our community."

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN EGYPT: THE OVERVIEW;
World Leaders Join in a Condemnation of Terrorism

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, March 13

 BODY:
Invoking the solemn shared history of three religions, leaders of 27 nations, including a broad swath of the Arab world, joined today in a sweeping condemnation of the recent suicide bombings in Israel and vowed to cooperate in fighting terrorism and promoting peace throughout the Middle East.
In a hastily organized one-day meeting sponsored by the United States and Egypt at this Red Sea resort, President Clinton and leaders from countries as diverse as Russia, Saudi Arabia, Japan and the Western European powers pledged to work together to prevent terrorist organizations from recruiting members, raising funds or supplying arms on their soil, and to share training and equipment "to cooperate in cutting them off." 
 "We are at a watershed," Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel said at the meeting, which amounted to a giant show of support for his peacemaking efforts. "Our region is going through a period of transition. The dark days are at an end. The shadows of its past are lengthening. The twilight of wars is still red with blood, yet its sunset is inevitable and imminent."
By almost any measure, it was a landmark event, if largely symbolic, drawing presidents and prime ministers together with sheiks, princes and kings from 14 Arab nations from North Africa to the Persian Gulf, whose mere presence in the same room with an Israeli Prime Minister would been unthinkable not so long ago. Today they raised their linked hands aloft with his.
Indeed, this scuba-diving port at the tip of Sinai was the staging area for Egypt's blockade of the Strait of Tiran before the 1967 war with Israel, yet today bikini-clad sunbathers shared the sand and sidewalks with the parade of dignitiaries.
But there were cracks in the facade of solidarity. Two of the most important countries in the region, Syria and Lebanon, declined invitations altogether. And the Saudi delegate, whose presence and handshake with Mr. Peres was praised by American officials as the most significant appearance of the day, mixed his condemnation of the attacks on Israeli civilians with a sharp warning against over-broad retaliation against Palestinians.
"Collective punishment, closure and every type of violence against innocent people will in turn generate more violence," said the Saudi Foreign Minister, Saud al-Faisal, referring to Israel's sealing of border settlements in the wake of the bombings, which have killed 62 people, including the bombers, since Feb. 25.
Later, Mr. Clinton and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt took pains to say they believed the closings would not be long-lasting, and Mr. Clinton justified the measures as reasonable "at a time when it's hard to tell who may be wrapped in plastique" explosives. The communique the two men issued at day's end said the participants had agreed to continue both economic and political support for the peace effort, "with special attention to the current and pressing economic needs of the Palestinians."
Mr. Clinton expressed disappointment at Syria's absence, but dismissed it as "part of a general pattern of going their own way." He acknowledged that today's meeting was only a first step and insisted, "You can focus on what didn't happen today, but if you do, it will blind you to what has happened, which no one would have conceived of happening even a few months ago."
For his part, Yasir Arafat, the president of the Palestinian Authority, vowed "that we are confronting and will continue to confront terrorism and to uproot it from our land, because our dream of freedom, independence and self-determination cannot bear fruit and be realized amid a sea of blood and tears."
After the meeting, Mr. Arafat told reporters that "the Israelis informed us that there has been a partial lift of the security cordon and we hope that during the next few days there will be a total lift of the blockade."
Senior Clinton Administration officials said the mere fact of the meeting and the diversity of its cast were its principal achievements.
"Israel and many of these Arab countries haven't worked on anything openly and above the table," one American official said.
The gathering also had the effect of bolstering Mr. Peres's sagging political standing as he heads into elections back home at the end of May, and of burnishing Mr. Clinton's foreign policy in the face of his own re-election challenge. Again and again today, Mr. Clinton heard the other leaders praise him as a statesman and peacemaker in the most glowing terms.
Just what practical results the meeting will produce is another question. This afternoon, the White House announced that the State Department's special Middle East envoy, Dennis Ross, would convene the first working session of the group's anti-terrorism efforts in about two weeks in the United States, to discuss the details of cooperation and report back to the participants in 30 days.
Mr. Clinton is to hold more talks with Israeli officials in Jerusalem on Thursday on how the United States can more effectively share intelligence about terrorism with countries throughout the region, and Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher and the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, John M. Deutch, are to hold further talks on Friday.
Today's meeting, under a crystalline sky on a seaside plain where the mountains of Sinai plunge down to the sea, mixed high pageantry and symbolism with a carnival air.
Sinai is rich with the region's shared cultural and religious history and most of the leaders made reference to those traditions -- Jewish, Christian and Islamic. Mr. Clinton recalled Moses' receipt of the Ten Commandments on Mount Sinai, Mr. Peres cited biblical injunctions against violence and Mr. Arafat declared that Muslim teachings rejected both suicide and murder.
"I'm not going to say it was one big love-in," an American official said of the meeting. "But these kinds of symbols can't be overestimated at this point."
On the way to Egypt, Mr. Clinton shared one potent American symbol of his own with King Hussein of Jordan, giving him an 11-hour ride on Air Force 1. The King, who by coincidence had been visiting the United States and who is a certified jet pilot, compared the Boeing 747 with his own L-1011, allowing that Mr. Clinton's plane had "more power and thrust," said the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry.
"He was in the cockpit for takeoff, but did not attempt to wrest control from the United States Air Force, which was probably wise on the King's part," Mr. McCurry said.

Hamas Defends Bombings
 JERUSALEM, March 13 (By The New York Times) -- Thrown on the defensive by the show of international resolve to fight terrorism at the summit meeting in Egypt, the militant Islamic group Hamas sought to justify its bombingstoday, calling it legitimate resistance to Israeli occupation.
In a memorandum addressed to world leaders gathered at Sharm el Sheik, Hamas asserted that its recent suicide bombings were aimed at soldiers and that civilian casualties were "unintentional," adding that it was prepared to cooperate with efforts to broker a cease-fire.
Hamas argued that United Nations resolutions recognize the right of armed resistance to military occupation.
"The Palestinian people has had no choice but to take up arms to defend itself, combat Israeli terrorism and fight the occupation," it said.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: DEPARTURE;
FORBES PLANNING ON DROPPING OUT OF THE CAMPAIGN

BYLINE: By ERNEST TOLLERSON 

 BODY:
Steve Forbes, the publishing magnate who had challenged the Republican establishment on Capitol Hill with his call for a radical restructuring of the tax system, will drop out of the race for the Republican Presidential nomination today, his campaign manager said yesterday.
Mr. Forbes's decision came after he had spent $25 million to $30 million of his personal fortune, a record amount, in a quixotic quest for his party's nomination. In the end, he managed to win a mere 71 Republican convention delegates, less than 10 percent of the 996 needed to prevail. Calculated against the cost of his campaign, Mr. Forbes spent $352,112 to $422,535 for each delegate he gained. 
 Mr. Forbes first hinted that he was having second thoughts about continuing his candidacy on Tuesday night after his poor showing in the Super Tuesday primaries, each of which was won by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas. Mr. Forbes finished a distant second in Florida and third in the other six contests.
William Dal Col, the Forbes campaign manager, said Mr. Forbes realized that the days before next Tuesday's primaries in the Midwest would not be enough time for him to mount a credible challenge that might result in a primary victory or close second to Mr. Dole, the presumptive front-runner.
"He's too much of a realist," Mr. Dal Col said. "He looked at it pragmatically and made his decision." He said Mr. Forbes informed him of his decision at about 10:45 yesterday morning in a brief conversation. Mr. He quoted Mr. Forbes as saying, "I've made a decision that it's time to get out."
Other close advisers, including former Senators Malcolm Wallop, Bob Kasten and Gordon J. Humphrey, were informed at midday in person or by telephone. Jack F. Kemp, the former Congressman from Buffalo and Housing Secretary in the Bush Administration who had recently endorsed Mr. Forbes's candidacy, was also told yesterday.
Reacting to word of Mr. Forbes's intentions, Mr. Dole was quoted by The Associated Press as saying yesterday, "No doubt about it, it helps."
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, a childhood friend of Mr. Forbes who urged him on Monday to abandon the race, said his withdrawal was "in the best interests of a unified Republican Party." She said she intended to invite Mr. Forbes, who is a resident of New Jersey, to be a member of the state delegation committed to Mr. Dole at the Republican National Convention.
While Mr. Forbes has barely 16 percent of the votes cast during the Republican primary season, and a tenth of the delegates amassed by Mr. Dole, his candidacy nevertheless managed to remind Republicans nationwide that the supply-side wing of the party, however small, was still alive and well. His pro-growth-hope-and-opportunity banner inadvertently became a devastating critique of the Capitol Hill Republicans' Contract With America.
The Forbes candidacy managed to broaden the national focus of debate from just a discussion of cutting the deficit and balancing the Federal budget to include the question of what kinds of policies will produce a better economy, more jobs and economic security.
"Steve understood that the Republicans made a tactical error in approaching Medicaid/Medicare debate the way they did," said Ken Tomlinson, the former top editor of Reader's Digest, and an adviser to Mr. Forbes. Mr. Forbes's candidacy, he said, showed the party that it could champion conservative principles without advocating "root canal" Republicanism.
While flying from the Midwest to New Jersey on Tuesday night on his chartered campaign plane, Mr. Forbes discussed the same theme at length in an interview: "You can't govern by polling. You can't govern by focus groups. The Contract has a lot of sensible ideas but you have to give it coherence, an overview. And by emphasizing the budget so much instead of combining it with some of the tax and other positive changes, they left themselves open."
He continued: "What they did was say 'Gee, Ross Perot said the balanced budget was important. Ross Perot won 19 percent of the vote.' They didn't realize that people voted for Perot because they saw him as a lever to register that they wanted a change. It was a genuine protest vote. Again they lost sight sometimes, some of them, that a balanced budget is supposed to be a means to an end, not an end unto itself."
Depending on circumstances, Mr. Dal Col said that Mr. Forbes, who is 48, could be a Presidential candidate in the year 2000. "He's built a base, he's a bright, articulate spokesman," Mr. Dal Col said. "He clearly outlasted the professional politicians. He proved what he can do and it's a base to build on in the future."
The base Mr. Dal Col referred to was his clear-cut victory in the Arizona primary and a more ambiguous one in Delaware, where Mr. Forbes and Alan Keyes were the only ones to campaign in person.
Other observers were less certain about Mr. Forbes's future viability as a candidate or public policy figure. "The grass-roots support for supply side economics is relatively small, " said Alan Brinkley, the Columbia University historian. "I don't think this is a popular proposal shared by many outside of elites of any kind."
In the interview on Tuesday, Mr. Forbes expressed interest in speaking at the Republican convention in San Diego, but it was clear that this was not his highest priority. Asked what role he would like to play, he said: "I look beyond the convention. I'll be directing my message to voters, to citizens."
In recent days, Mr. Forbes had added appeals to independents and pro-growth Democrats in his stump speeches, which focused on his advocacy of a 17 percent flat tax. "That's how you create a realignment," he said on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: NEWS ANALYSIS;
Why Dixie Was Buchanan's Waterloo

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, March 13

 BODY:
After his victory in the New Hampshire primary last month, Patrick J. Buchanan's campaign rumbled southward, and it seemed to many that he was steaming toward fertile ground.
But three weeks later, it is the South, a region so often stereotyped as a hotbed of Bible-thumping populism, that has effectively marginalized Mr. Buchanan and insured the Republican Presidential nomination of Senator Bob Dole. 
 With Mr. Dole's victories on Tuesday in Texas, Florida, Mississippi, Tennessee, Oklahoma and Louisiana, and his triumphs in the last week and a half in South Carolina and Georgia, Southern Republicans showed themselves to be pragmatists who place a heavy emphasis on electability and who seek to balance social conservatism with economic conservatism.
With the benefit of hindsight, political scientists and Republican strategists in the region said today that they were not all that surprised. After all, they said, it was also the South that stopped Pat Robertson's momentum in the 1988 Republican primaries and derailed Mr. Buchanan's effort to swipe the 1992 nomination from George Bush. And, with a few exceptions, the South was also decidedly inhospitable toward Ross Perot in the 1992 general election.
After so many decades without influence, in national and local politics alike, the newly empowered Republicans of the South seem to understand the importance of winning. As a group, they are reluctant to throw away their votes on protest candidates or to support those they believe may be too extreme, either for the Southerners' own tastes or to win a general election.
"In every Southern state, with the possible exception of Louisiana, the pragmatic conservatives outnumber the doctrinaire conservatives," said Lanny Griffith, a Republican strategist who ran Lamar Alexander's unsuccessful campaign in the South. "I think it has something to do with the time that people have spent concentrating on winning. Nobody has ever been able to take power or winning office for granted."
In Texas, where Mr. Dole defeated Mr. Buchanan by 56 percent to 21 percent on Tuesday, the state Republican chairman, Tom Pauken, said that even voters attracted to Mr. Buchanan's politics had concluded that infighting was hurting the party and that Mr. Dole had the best chance to win in November.
"It doesn't mean that Texas all of a sudden has become a centrist or moderate state," Mr. Pauken said. "But it means that most of the conservatives in Texas want to get rid of Bill Clinton and believe that Bob Dole, of the current crop of candidates, has the best chance of doing it." Mr. Dole, he said, was "everybody's second choice."
Although Mr. Buchanan had tried to paint Mr. Dole as a liberal, the Senator succeeded in the South because even those voters who preferred another candidate found him acceptable, particularly on social issues like abortion.
Strapped for time and resources after third-place finishes in Iowa and New Hampshire last month, Mr. Alexander, former Governor of Tennessee, never became well enough known outside his home state to be a factor in the region. And when voters peeled away from Mr. Buchanan after determining that he was either too extreme or otherwise unelectable, they found in the Dole campaign a comfortable place to rest, according to surveys of voters leaving the polls in several Southern states.
The most striking shift since the voting in Iowa and New Hampshire has been among voters who consider themselves part of the religious right.
In the New Hampshire primary, 54 percent of that group voted for Mr. Buchanan, and only 11 percent for Mr. Dole, according to a survey taken by the television networks and The Associated Press. But Mr. Dole won 40 percent of that vote in South Carolina and 36 percent in Georgia. On Tuesday, he won 46 percent of it in Texas and 52 percent in Florida.
Merle Black, a political scientist at Emory University who writes frequently about Southern politics, said Southern Republicans wanted "a presentable conservative."
"The notion that Buchanan would do well in the South was based on an image of the South as an impoverished Dogpatch where the rawest kind of emotional, nativist appeals will rally the people to your side," Mr. Black said. "But the most effective politicians in the South are those that can balance social and economic concerns, and there's nothing balanced about Pat Buchanan."
Former Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina, whose endorsement and organization helped Mr. Dole win there, said Mr. Buchanan had suffered from a protectionist economic message that held limited appeal in the region.
Unemployment rates in most Southern states fall below the national average, and the region has outperformed the nation in job growth in each of the last 15 years.
Many of the new jobs have been created by foreign investment and by exports, making Southerners wary of talk about raising tariffs and closing borders. And many of those jobs have been filled by transplanted Northerners, who bring their own accents and typically mainstream political views to the suburbs of Atlanta, Nashville, Tampa and Greenville.
"People just have a total misimpression of what Southern states look like these days," said Susan A. MacManus, a professor of political science at the University of South Florida-Tampa. "There's been a huge infusion of growth in recent years, and that's been ignored in analyzing the rise of Republicanism. These people just don't have the Deep South mentality."

HEADLINE: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;
American Envoys' Killers Are Freed in Lebanon

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 13

 BODY:
An appeals court today freed two Lebanese men convicted of kidnapping and slaying two American diplomats and their driver in 1976, at the height of Lebanon's civil war.
The three-judge panel ruled the slayings of Ambassador Francis E. Meloy, his economic counselor, Robert O. Waring, and their Lebanese driver, were covered under a 1990 amnesty for political crimes. 
 Presiding Judge Moueen Osseiran ordered the men, Bassem Farkh, 39, and Namek Kamal, 46, freed. They were sentenced to death in 1994.
Prosecutor General Adnan Addoum argued for the death sentence to be upheld. But defense lawyers said the two men had no role in the murders, and were only low-ranking members of a Palestinian-backed Communist militia.

HEADLINE: Should Downsizing Lead to a New System?;
Good News: New Jobs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
If your objective is to scare readers, you scored a coup with "The Downsizing of America." Between 1980 and 1994, while the population grew about 13.5 percent (rising from 226.5 million to 257 million), civilian employment increased about 24 percent (from 99.3 million to 123.1 million). In 1994 the unemployment rate was 6.1 percent, versus 7.1 in 1980. It's sad when some people lose their jobs. But we can be glad that many more are getting new and better jobs.
 
ARTHUR M. YORK
Stamford, Conn., March 6, 1996

HEADLINE: Should Downsizing Lead to a New System?;
New Ethical Issue

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The series on the changing patterns of employment and corporate life in America helps explain a number of reactions to the new pleas for isolationist policies. But it does not help explain that masses of new middle classes (although many still lower-middle) are being created around the world. Nor does it help us face the ethical issue of who the "we" is in a post-nationalist era of geo-economics. 
 Has it not been clear from the effects of the Depression, the alliances formed to fight National Socialism and the more recent fall of the Berlin wall that fenced-in societies would and should be drawn into new levels of interaction, and that much of the violence of this century is a reaction against the idea of "them" versus "us"?
When we now seek to "protect our own," the "us" is radically expanded and the possibility of a deeper recognition of common humanity is on the horizon.
 
MAX L. STACKHOUSE
Professor of Christian Ethics
 Princeton Theological Seminary
Princeton, N.J., March 3, 1996

HEADLINE: Should Downsizing Lead to a New System?;
A United Response

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The only thing we'd add to your March 3-9 series is the importance of a mutual and united response. 
 Our group is a coalition of more than 50 labor, religious and community organizations and individuals with stories like those you featured. In January, we overflowed Faneuil Hall in Boston with more than 1,000 people, including half the Massachusetts Congressional delegation, to hear from blue-, pink- and white-collar workers, mothers on public assistance, immigrants and even economists.
Our purpose was to build support for efforts by the Progressive Caucus to require Congress and the President to promote good jobs, and the efforts to eliminate corporate welfare, raise the minimum wage and cap the tax-deductibility of executive compensation.
These proposals are only a start in trying to close the gap between people who are suffering and policy makers. When other states have joined us, we will begin to see things change.
 
TRUDY BAUER

HEADLINE: The Great Safire Disconnect

 BODY:
To the Editor:
William Safire, in his utilitarian defense of corporate downsizing ("The Great Disconnect," column, March 11), argues that layoffs provide "the greatest good for the greatest number," with "good" defined as low unemployment rates and high mutual fund prices. The problem is that many Americans define the quality of their lives and of their society in terms other than these. 
 No one argues that companies should honor commitments to job security all the way to bankruptcy court. But the power imbalance between employer and worker in our employment-at-will system leaves employees highly vulnerable to personal economic upheaval.
This is not a problem if you define quality of life through macroeconomic indicators. But it is a problem if you are concerned about the well-being of individuals and the stability of their communities.
Public policy can temper the ruthlessness of markets with incentives for companies to give workers some control over their working lives, with modest commitments to job security or retraining. This is neither antithetical to capitalism nor a threat to the Republic.
 
BRUCE BARRY
Assistant Professor of Management
Vanderbilt University
Nashville, March 11, 1996

HEADLINE: The Great Safire Disconnect

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re William Safire's March 11 column: Even if you do not agree with the popu-libs, you have to listen. They aren't creating the anger, they are simply recognizing it and making use of it. Where the French riot and the Bosnians kill one another, Americans vote. There is a real danger of having "corporate morality" legislated if we do not listen. 
 What is good for the economy is good for the stock market, but a good stock market does not necessarily reflect a good economy. All those nervous, laid-off workers are taking their severance packages and pumping up the market with mutual-fund contributions. Higher price-earnings ratios by virtue of bid-up stock, not increased earnings, aren't good.
As for "the sacrifice of the relative few in these prosperous times," just go to the market, fill a basket, then engage others at the checkout in conversation. I'd wager it would be difficult to locate anyone who wasn't nervous.
 
KATHERINE M. COOPER
Westport, Conn., March 11, 1996
 
The writer is chairman of Cooper Capital Inc., investment advisers.

HEADLINE: The Great Safire Disconnect

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Has the time come to downsize William Safire? His March 11 column on the economy merely regurgitates standard economists' pap. One of its most toxic components is the thought that while Social Security now taxes current workers to pay retirees, pension funds based on stock holdings do something different. They don't. 
 Both the share-price rises and the dividends that increase fund payouts require keeping current wages low and downsizing often. (So do chief executives' fat salaries.) A company that cuts, say, research spending today may well damage all our futures, but, by looking good on the bottom line, it benefits current pensioners.
 
MICHAEL H. GOLDHABER
Oakland, Calif., March 11, 1996

HEADLINE: Events: Architecture Shows, Talks and an Antiques Sale

 BODY:

Building New York
Rotunda of the Alexander Hamilton United States Custom House, foot of Broadway; (212) 683-0023, extension 15.
"Civics Lessons: Recent New York Public Architecture," an exhibition of photographs, drawings and models of 75 projects that were proposed or completed in the last decade, starts tomorrow and continues through May 2. 
 The projects -- initiated by 25 public agencies and designed by 55 architectural firms -- include the Custom House renovation, the Willink comfort station in Prospect Park and the New York Police Academy in the Bronx. The exhibition was organized by the American Institute of Architects New York Chapter and the New York Foundation for Architecture. Open daily, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. No charge.
On April 18, there will be a daylong symposium at the Downtown Athletic Club about issues raised by the exhibition. Reservations are required. Fee, including lunch, $40.
 
Antiques at the Armory
Seventh Regiment Armory, 643 Park Avenue (66th Street); (212) 472-1180.
An antiques sale starts Wednesday, from 1 to 9 P.M. Additional hours are March 21 through 23, noon to 9 P.M.; March 24, noon to 6 P.M. Admission is $10.
 
New York Architecture
Municipal Art Society, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street); (212) 935-3960.
A 12-session course on the history of architecture in New York City starts on March 27 and continues on April 17, May 15, May 29, June 12 and June 26. Each Wednesday night lecture will be followed by a Saturday afternoon walking tour.
The course will feature early Dutch New York; the 19th-century styles of Greek Revival, Gothic Revival and Victorian architecture; the golden age of skyscrapers, and urban renewal in the 1960's and recent developments. Reservations are required. Fee for the series, $125; each lecture, $10; each walking tour, $15.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Strolling Through Political Art's Past

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:
A few years ago, the New York State Council on the Arts issued a call for exhibitions addressing the still underrecorded history of alternative movements in American contemporary art. Two shows that resulted are now on view in SoHo, at Exit Art/The First World and the Drawing Center.
Despite their shared source of inspiration, however, they make an odd pair. One is big, the other small. One feels confidently expansive; the other looks scrappy and unsure of itself. And they often seem to be talking about different things: the underground press on the one hand, the New York art world on the other. 
 But the real problem lies in how they're alike. Both deal with "political art," yet neither makes an attempt to define the term or to evaluate the strengths and limitations of this ever-embattled genre. They settle instead for a critically neutral and half-nostalgic stroll through the past.
That stroll is, to be sure, an exhaustive workout in the case of "Counterculture: Alternative Information From the Underground Press to the Internet" at Exit Art. Organized by Brian Wallis and Melissa Rachleff, the show is a monumental accumulation of some 2,000 examples of politically radical newspapers, magazines and posters produced in America from the early 1960's to the present.
The work, ferreted out of closets, scrap books and library archives for the occasion, covers virtually every inch of Exit Art's substantial wall space. It is chronologically arranged and much of the most interesting material comes at the beginning, with the protest movement of the 60's.
That brief, explosive crosscultural moment, in which barriers of gender, class and race at least appeared to dissolve in a collective wave of anger and idealism, was, of course, extraordinary. And it produced a distinctive and influential visual style.
But it was a style that initially had little or no connection to the art world of the time, vanguard or mainstream. In fact, the first half of "Counterculture" is the story of the low-art medium of graphic design from which grew, on the cheap and often on the fly, a potent generational language.
That language literally blossomed with the rise of Flower Power, the passive-aggressive countercultural banner under which politics, drugs and free love merged. And any one of the dozens of tabloids on view in Exit Art's front room -- The San Francisco Oracle, The Berkeley Barb, The East Village Other -- with their mix of psychedelia and sloganeering could stand for the rest.
Other graphic work from the period, such as that produced by the Black Panthers, was deliberately less ingratiating, and by the end of the decade the political climate had in general grown harsh. The text-heavy manifestos of radical splinter groups like the Weather Underground and the bummed-out underground comics of R. Crumb and Art Spiegelman have a nasty, frankly paranoid charge that leaves pipe-dream utopias behind in the dust.
With the late 70's and 80's, things change again. Punk publications turn paranoia into a theatrical posture and the line between fashion and politics, always slender, more or less vanishes. Tie-dye and love beads are exchanged for black leather and flesh-piercing pins, and Aquarian Age givens -- the idea of students as an oppressed minority, for instance -- reappear as sendups.
It is around this point in the show, too, that political subject matter passes into the purview of the art world. Out of nowhere in particular comes a smattering of protest work by painters and sculptors, some of it created in the 60's by the Art Workers Coalition. The show concludes with a gathering of design-savvy posters addressing the AIDS epidemic. In this recent material, production values are high, but the still-incendiary issues of class and ethnicity have subsided. What's left is a polished, estheticized vehicle for political sentiment that's hard to imagine appearing anywhere outside the predominantly white and academically inclined art world itself.
Which is roughly where the show at the Drawing Center comes in. Titled "Cultural Economies: Histories From the Alternative Arts Movement NYC" and organized by the artist Julie Ault, it documents an oblique offshoot of the underground history detailed at Exit Art.
Like "Counterculture," it relies heavily on print media, to which it adds paintings, sculptures, photographs and other art objects. Specific institutions, most of them long gone, are represented (Fashion Moda in the South Bronx, ABC No Rio on the Lower East Side among them), as are collaborative protest groups (Guerilla Girls, Gran Fury) and several fine individual artists (including Jane Dickson, David Wojnarowicz and Martin Wong).
But the results feel wan and unconvincing. The show's confusing organization is partly to blame, as is its scattershot historical account. And much of the art chosen -- almost all of it by Ms. Ault's contemporaries -- looks thin in this half-hearted context. (Some of the best work of the early 80's was conceived precisely not to appear in pristine SoHo spaces like this one).
Most problematic, though, is that the art world hermeticism that afflicts the second half of "Counterculture" at Exit Art is also evident here. Many of the alternative spaces and the art they nurtured were created in impoverished immigrant neighborhoods, but little sense of grass-roots energy or street-level radicalism comes across.
Granted, "Cultural Economies" and "Counterculture" have set themselves daunting documentary tasks. In their different ways, they have made a start on a history and that's important, particularly at a time when political art is both yesterday's news in the art world and the target of a war of attrition by political powers that be.
But yesterday's news is always worth a hard look, not just to fight off nostalgia (which shows like these inevitably elicit), but to get some actual sense of what went right and what went wrong. How, without that kind of rigorous, complicated, self-critical evaluation, can the necessary project that "political art" is ever move ahead?
 
"Counterculture: Alternative Information From the Underground Press to the Internet" remains at Exit Art/The First World, 548 Broadway, at Prince Street, in SoHo, through April 20. "Cultural Economies: Histories From the Alternative Arts Movement NYC" remains at the Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, near Grand Street, in SoHo, through April 6.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A 1971 copy of The East Village Other, from "Counterculture." (Exit Art/The First World)

HEADLINE: In America;
Torture by H.M.O.

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
From the New England Journal of Medicine comes the story of a North Carolina family that was devastated by the inflexible and thoroughly inhumane decisions of a national health maintenance organization.
A three-month-old girl was referred by the H.M.O. to a pediatric-oncology group at the University of North Carolina Hospitals in Chapel Hill. 
 (The H.M.O. was not identified in the article, which appeared in the Feb. 22 issue of the journal. I am withholding its name at the request of the authors, Dr. Brent Weston, a staff physician, and Marie Lauria, a clinical social worker. H.M.O.'s have been known to retaliate against critics. A respected Cambridge physician, Dr. David Himmelstein, recently was fired "without cause" by U.S. HealthCare after he criticized certain managed-care practices on television and in print. He was reinstated after a public outcry.)
The three-month-old girl was diagnosed with leukemia. A bone marrow transplant, with her older sister as the donor, was recommended. The H.M.O. approved the transplant and asked for help in arranging a transfer of the baby to a hospital in another state that had been designated by the H.M.O. to do all bone marrow transplants in the region.
Dr. Weston and Ms. Lauria wrote that it soon "became clear that treatment out of state for several months would be detrimental to the family. Both parents were distraught. The father would not be able to be involved because of employment restrictions. The mother, who obviously needed to be with the infant, would lose her position and be forced to take a lesser job with a pay cut.
"The older sister, who was having serious behavioral problems, would have to be separated from her mother for a prolonged period. The expenses associated with an extended stay in a city where the family had no relatives or friends would be difficult for the family to manage. There are two excellent transplantation centers nearby in our own state and we were asked to request that the H.M.O. make an exception to its policy on selecting a transplantation center."
They asked, but such humanitarian concerns are not what corporate care is about. In the competition with profits, patients must always lose. The H.M.O. said no. There would be no exception. The transplant would have to be done out of state.
Dr. Weston and Ms. Lauria were cautioned by their colleagues not to push the H.M.O. too far. A transplant specialist warned them against offending the carrier "because we are in the running for the next contract."
Others suggested, sympathetically, that they wise up to "the new medical-economic reality."
The H.M.O. complained about their interference with "the client-carrier relationship."
The entire experience was disorienting. The expanding universe of corporate care is a very strange environment for health professionals concerned primarily with the needs of their patients.
The baby was taken out of state for the transplant and was not returned to the care of her physicians in North Carolina for six months. The older sister was sent to live with relatives in a different state. The mother was demoted. Compounding all other problems, the father lost his job.
Several weeks ago the baby suffered a relapse. When a second transplant was contemplated, the H.M.O., for reasons having nothing to do with the quality of care, recommended a different transplant center in yet another state.
Dr. Weston and Ms. Lauria were appalled. None of the factors that had made the first transplant such an enormous problem had changed. "In addition," they wrote, "the first transplantation center had established an ongoing relationship with the family."
Now the family would have to start all over, at a different center in a different state.
This time, in order to keep the family together, the mother quit her job, gave up her H.M.O. coverage, and applied for Medicaid.
"The parents have lost their home and their savings," wrote Dr. Weston and Ms. Lauria, "and the older sister has had increasingly severe behavioral problems."
That, of course, is the family's problem. Corporate care is about the bottom line. There will be no exceptions.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Little Change In Bond Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended little changed yesterday, paring back earlier gains made after a Government report showed no mounting price pressures in the economy.
The price of the 30-year bond settled down 3/32, to 916/32, leaving its yield unchanged at 6.68 percent. 
 "The market is extremely fragile and appears to be hanging on by its fingernails, hoping to get some good data," said Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston.
Prices rose after the market was surprised by a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent in the Producer Price Index. Many economists had expected no change or an increase of one-tenth of 1 percent. The data indicated that inflation at the manufacturing level was stable even if last Friday's employment report suggested that economic growth was rebounding strongly. The producer prices report rekindled hopes that the Federal Reserve would still be able to cut short-term interest rates this spring.
That view was bolstered by the weekly report on initial claims for state unemployment benefits. Jobless claims for the week that ended March 9 rose by only 353,000, from 363,000 the week before, and was below the 365,000 that had been forecast by economists. The data provided some comfort for a market still smarting from last Friday's report, which showed that more than 700,000 jobs were created in February.
Despite the favorable data, the market remained nervous ahead of a number of Government economic reports scheduled for today, on consumer prices, industrial production and capacity utilization.
"The market is still spooked by the thought of an accelerating economy, and thus will need a host of economic statistics indicating moderate growth with no inflationary undertones before relinquishing the fear factor," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management.
William J. Michaelcheck, chairman of the Mariner Investment Group, a money management firm, said, "The market has calmed and repriced to a new level after the employment number last week."
"I think the market is now waiting for validation of the economic strength or the data to refute last week's employment numbers," he said. "Every number has a few suspects."
Mr. Fine said the Consumer Price Index for February was unlikely to upset the market, but both the industrial production and capacity utilization reports could be expected to show strong gains from weather-depressed January levels.
"To make matters even more confusing," Mr. Fine said, "the G.M. strike and subsequent shutdown of assembly plants could well have a noticeable impact on various economic statistics depending on the length of inactivity, starting with the initial claims statistics next Thursday.
"But after all is said and done, one can reasonably conclude that inflation continues to appear subdued, benign and nonthreatening, economic growth is proceeding at a moderate pace, and the Federal Reserve is likely to keep monetary policy unchanged over the near term."
In the corporate market yesterday, Litton Industries sold $400 million of debentures in a two-part transaction through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Underwriters offered $400 million of debentures due in 2026 at a price to yield 7.787 percent and $100 million of debentures due in 2006 at a price of par to yield 6.98 percent.
The debt is rated Baa3 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB+ by Standard & Poor's and Duff & Phelps Credit.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Trading Is Lackluster As Stocks and Bonds Settle Down

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar finished slightly higher yesterday against the mark and yen after a lethargic trading session largely unaffected by new United States economic data.
The dollar finished mixed against other currencies. Its rise against the German and Japanese currencies came as American stock and bond markets remained steady for the second straight day after several sessions of volatility. 
"It's difficult to know why the market is in such a status quo mode," said Steve Jury, chief foreign exchange dealer at Union Bank of Switzerland. "There is a lot of confusion. People do not have much of an opinion of what is going to happen next. We are in a stalemate."
In late trading in New York, the dollar was quoted at 105.50 yen, up from 105.10 late on Wednesday, and at 1.4708 marks, up from 1.4703.
Some traders said the dollar was kept afloat against the mark partly because of fears that a big hedge fund would enter the market, overwhelming smaller orders, if the dollar dipped as low as 1.4680 marks.
The fund was thought to have bought dollars on Wednesday, said Brian Garvey, a currency strategist with IDEA, an analytic service. Whenever the dollar approached 1.4680 marks, traders bought it back up for fear that the fund would overwhelm the market and their orders would fall by the wayside. The dollar never fell below 1.4697 marks.
Traders were also influenced by a rumor that the French Government was considering shuffling the Cabinet. That prompted a shift to marks and away from French francs. Traders also bought the mark against the Italian lira.
The market, which has been looking for new data to give it direction, saw a fall in the Producer Price Index in the United States as negating inflationary worries inspired by high employment numbers reported last week.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday, were: 1.1869 Swiss francs, down from 1.1872; 5.0445 French francs, up from 5.0375; 1,565 Italian lire, down from 1,567; and 1.3680 Canadian dollars, unchanged.
The British pound was quoted at $1.5292, up from $1.5230.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Dayton Hudson Net Falls, But Is Above Expectations

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The Dayton Hudson Corporation posted sharply lower fourth-quarter earnings yesterday.
Dayton Hudson, the parent company of the Target discount chain, earned $228 million, or $3.08 a share, in the fourth quarter ended Feb. 3, down 18 percent from $279 million, or $3.81 a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. Revenue rose 14 percent, to $8 billion from $7 billion. 
 The results were slightly higher than Wall Street's expectations of earnings of $3.06 a share, according to a survey of analysts by Zacks Investment Research. Shares of the company rose $1.875 each yesterday, to $81.625.
Still, it was the second consecutive fourth quarter, which is usually the most profitable period for retailers, that earnings have not increased under Robert Ulrich, who became chairman and chief executive in 1994.
"We're certainly very disappointed with our 1995 results," the company's chief financial officer, Douglas Scovanner, said.
Dayton Hudson, based in Minneapolis, said it expected results to recover this year and said it was already seeing improvement. Same-store sales, or sales at stores open at least a year, climbed 8.4 percent in February.
But if performance at its Mervyn's department store unit does not improve, "we would certainly entertain some other concepts or some other ideas," Mr. Scovanner said.
He declined to identify the options, saying that the company wanted to keep Mervyn's. But Wall Street analysts and some shareholders say the expect the unit will be spun off or sold, especially if a rebound does not occur soon.
"In our opinion, the strategic decision has already been made to shed Mervyn's," said Saul Yaari, an analyst with Piper Jaffray Inc. "Dayton Hudson is buying time to dress up the division for for a sale or spinoff."
Mervyn's has been hobbled in recent years by California's weak economy and by competition from the J. C. Penney Company.
But Mr. Scovanner said Dayton Hudson wanted to to retain Mervyn's in order to maintain a diverse retailing base.
Dayton Hudson's three retailing divisions help shield the company from swings in the economy because they draw consumers from different income levels. Cash generated by Mervyn's and the department store division, which includes Marshall Field's, Dayton's and Hudson's, helps finance the rapid expansion of Target, which competes with Wal-Mart Stores and Kmart.

HEADLINE: Credit-Card Delinquencies Rise; Price Report Shows No Inflation

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
The ranks of consumers who have fallen behind on credit-card payments edged up to match a 10-year high in the final quarter of 1995, a sign of growing household distress that some economists argue threatens to bring the five-year-old economic expansion to an end.
Meanwhile, prices paid to factories, farmers and other producers fell in February for the first time in eight months, easing fears that the big jump in new jobs last month might lead to higher inflation. 
 But the bond market drew scant comfort from the two reports, as other economic indicators, including a sharp decline in first-time jobless claims last week, suggested that prospects for a revival of economic growth were improving. The yield on benchmark 30-year bond, which often gains ground on news of low inflation and a higher risk of recession, was unchanged at 6.68 percent.
With the current outlook so cloudy, experts are hoping that fresh reports on consumer prices and industrial production scheduled for Friday will help bring the picture into sharper focus.
Several analysts expressed particular concern about the rising delinquency rates, as consumers also fell further behind on mortgages, home equity loans and auto loans.
Though increasing less rapidly than earlier in the year, the rise in consumer delinquencies is "still alarming," said James Chessen, chief economist at the American Bankers Association. He said additional problems would show up if consumer borrowing kept outpacing disposable income.
The bank group's survey found 3.34 percent of credit-card accounts overdue 30 days or more, up from 3.3 percent during the summer and from 2.93 percent in the final 1994 quarter. In dollar terms the rise was larger, to 4.45 percent from 4.21 in the latest period.
The delinquencies on home equity and auto loans, while also higher, remained generally below recent peaks, the association found.
In a separate report, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said slightly more homeowners were behind on their mortgages during the October-December period, the third straight quarterly rise.
The Government figures on inflation at the producer, or wholesale, level were even better than analysts had expected. This encouraged some economists to keep alive their faint hopes that the Federal Reserve would still decide to make another cut in short-term interest rates at its next policy-making meeting at the end of the month or later this spring.
The Labor Department said the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods fell two-tenths of 1 percent in February, the first decline since June, as energy products reversed a sharp January advance.
Even more encouraging, analysts said, was a lack of inflation at earlier stages of the production pipeline. The prices of intermediate goods apart from the volatile food and energy components -- a gauge closely monitored by the Federal Reserve -- have now declined five straight months.
This is in sharp contrast to the situation in early 1995, when intermediate goods, like plywood, were advancing briskly and analysts worried that these pressures would ripple through the economy. Instead, the price increases failed to stick, dissipating at later stages in a climate of intense competition.
But the impact of last Friday's bond-market debacle resulting from the Government's report of huge February job growth showed up in today's weekly tally of interest rates by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
Freddie Mac said that rates on 30-year conventional mortgages soared to 7.83 percent this week from 7.38 percent last week, an exceptionally big move that lifted the rate to the highest point since late August. Rates on one-year adjustables, the company said, climbed to 5.55 percent from 5.4.
This jump promptly caused a sharp reduction in mortgage applications, especially for refinancings, said Paul S. Reid, president of the Mortgage Bankers Association.
But other indicators pointed to evidence that the economy might be gathering some strength again. The Labor Department said that first-time claimants for unemployment insurance fell by 10,000 in the week ended last Saturday, to a total of 353,000, well under what most analysts had expected. The four-week average fell by 7,000, to 364,000, after having exceeded 380,000 in mid-February.
The bankers' delinquency survey showed that consumer installment debt, still swelling at a double-digit rate in January, had climbed to near-record proportions of disposable income. At 19 percent, this ratio is now just short of what it was in the late 1980's and is well above the 16.2 percent to which it fell in 1992.
"The consumer is in recession," said Lawrence J. Sterne, director of research at Economic Analysis Associates, a Greenwich, Conn., firm specializing in the financial behavior of households. "There's some real income stress out there."
