HEADLINE: NYC;
Keeping a Plant In the Bronx Is Job No. 1

BYLINE: By Clyde Haberman 

 BODY:
ASKING Jose Alvarez if he is worried about his future is a bit like asking if he is alive. Why waste the question, that's how obvious the answer is, he said.
For 16 years, he has been a maintenance man at Farberware, the century-old maker of pots and pans in the South Bronx. But now the company has been bought by a Boston silverware manufacturer, and the 700 jobs at its squat, red-brick plant -- sandwiched between Bruckner and Southern boulevards -- are more in doubt than the future of Middle East peace talks. Worried? 
 "What do you think?" Mr. Alvarez said during a break the other morning. "They're talking about moving somewhere else, maybe in a few months. I'll have to go on unemployment."
As best as can be determined, no decision has been made by Farberware's new owner, the Syratech Corporation, which bought the company from U.S. Industries, a conglomerate based in Iselin, N.J. But anyone ready to bet his last dollar on those Bronx jobs surviving can probably be persuaded to buy a bridge or two across the East River.
Leonard Florence, the Syratech chairman, said he cannot make a profit in the South Bronx unless the city and state help him lower the costs for essentials like electricity, water, sewage and labor. Otherwise, Mr. Florence said, the only alternative is to "outsource" -- the term of art these days for shipping jobs off to Arkansas or Hong Kong or anywhere else where people are ready to labor for even less than the prevailing $10 an hour on Bruckner Boulevard.
THIS is not a swipe at New York, he insisted. Nor is there reason to suspect a bluff to squeeze the city and state for tax breaks. It seems to be strictly business. "If you can show us how to make a return on our investment there, we'll look at it," Mr. Florence said.
Showing him how has turned into an important test of New York's stated resolve to make itself a jobs-saving, business-friendly place, a task that falls to an assortment of officials. They include the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer; the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, John S. Dyson; his state counterpart, Charles A. Gargano, and the president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, Charles Millard.
It would be nice, not to mention helpful, if they all admired one another and could work closely together on the issue. That, unfortunately, is far from the case. About the only detectable consensus thus far is that it is vital to keep Farberware where it is.
How vital?
In the big picture, 700 jobs may not seem like much. But the Bronx, where health care is the dominant field, has only about 14,000 manufacturing jobs left. So Farberware, which moved to that borough from Brooklyn in 1944, accounts for a hefty 5 percent of the total.
MOST of its workers live nearby in Port Morris and Mott Haven, where employment choices are not exactly plentiful. And as their jobs go, so go neighborhood businesses like the restaurant across the street and Victor Flores's tire shop down the block. Mr. Flores gives a thumbs-down when asked what life without Farberware would be like for him.
"This is a vignette of the whole national issue of off-shore sourcing," Mr. Dyson said. "But it is not the result of an unkind God. It is the result of actions taken over the last 50 years that add up to a whole set of costs in New York that are out of whack with what the same services go for elsewhere."
The Deputy Mayor and Mr. Florence met this week, mainly to lay out the problems. All the sides have yet to sit down together, and solutions, assuming they exist, are well down the road. Take electricity, to cite but one issue. Syratech dismisses the Bronx rates as prohibitively high -- 20 cents per kilowatt hour, it says -- but Mr. Ferrer responds that 11 cents is closer to reality. Whatever the true figure, Mr. Florence wants it lowered.
One idea making the rounds is to stretch the city's new Federal Empowerment Zone so that it encompasses the Farberware plant, which lies just outside it now. The zone cuts across northern Manhattan and a sliver of the South Bronx, its purpose being to spark private investment through lower taxes and a small infusion of Government money. Maybe a lure of Federal tax credits for employees living in the zone would persuade Farberware's bosses to stay put.
At least that's the theory. But who knows if Washington will agree to redraw the lines, or if that will be enough for Syratech?
Count Nestor Lopez among the optimists. Mr. Lopez has been a Farberware driver for 17 years, and he said, "I don't think they'll move. I got my Jesus up there helping."
No disrespect, but this time some temporal intervention will also be needed.

HEADLINE: In Search of New Commodities;
U.S. Futures Exchanges Try to Regain Lost Ground

BYLINE: By BARNABY FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 14

 BODY:
When Wall Street swooned last Friday, worried investment managers sought cover here, where the nation's largest futures exchanges give them an opportunity to hedge their risks.
But while the Chicago Mercantile Exchange recorded its second-busiest day ever, such spikes in trading cannot mask the disquiet gripping both the Merc and its bigger crosstown rival, the Chicago Board of Trade. 
 Over all, trading levels on United States futures and options exchanges fell last year, even as activity expanded abroad, continuing a 20-year boom in futures trading worldwide. Besides global competition, the American exchanges face the challenge of the more private "off exchange" market, where banks and other big futures players trade directly with each other, often more cheaply than in Chicago's pits.
And so the Merc, the Board of Trade and other leading American exchanges are engaged in some of the most ambitious new-product development campaigns in their history, shouldering new risks in hopes of defending their central role in the futures business.
The Board of Trade is offering insurance contracts for hurricanes and other future catastrophes, and it has begun trading waste paper and other recyclables, hoping that they will one day grow into markets big enough to require their own futures and options.
The Chicago Merc is pushing hard into futures tied to the volatile currencies, debt, and stock markets of developing countries. The New York Mercantile Exchange, better known as Nymex, last month announced plans to began trading electricity futures, anticipating the day when deregulation of utilities will create more risks of rate swings. The Merc and the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York recently introduced competing milk futures and options contracts, spurred by the trend toward less regulation in the dairy industry.
These and other exchanges are also considering creating futures on such staples of commerce as water rights, coal and real estate. And they are forming international alliances like the Board of Trade's recent deal with the London International Financial Futures Exchange, which will allow each exchange's members to trade the other's most popular products on their own floors.
"Bill Gates taught it to I.B.M., Sam Walton taught it to Sears, and the Internet is teaching it to the Encyclopaedia Britannica," said Richard Sandor, a former professor who helped design the Board of Trade's key contracts and is now a director of the Chicago Merc.
"There are no franchises you can rely on any more," he said, "and the exchanges, like every other business, have to innovate to survive."
The futures exchanges have reinvented themselves repeatedly through the years. While the Chicago Board of Trade, for instance, still handles the agricultural products that occasioned its birth more than a century ago, contracts for Government bonds and notes now account for three-fourths of its business. "It's the relentless issuance of Government debt that's fueled our market," Patrick Arbor, the board's chairman, said.
No wonder, then, that one of Mr. Arbor's current headaches is the possibility that Congress and President Clinton may shrink the debt market by negotiating a plan for balancing the Federal budget.
While the success of the new products will affect the prosperity of those thousands of traders whom are shown screaming at each other in trading pits on the odd occasions when the exchanges show up in newscasts, far more is at stake as well. In the last 20 years, futures have assumed a pivotal role in the world economy. There are 75 futures and options exchanges around the world, trading more than a billion contracts annually, up from just a handful trading fewer than 30 million contracts in 1975.
If banks, pension funds and other investors could not easily use bond futures contracts to manage their risks, the Government would have to pay much higher interest to convince them to buy bonds. The result would be battles over Government spending and taxing that would make the conflict currently paralyzing Congress seem tame.
Similarly, stock index futures like the Chicago Merc's contract for the Standard & Poor's list of 500 major stocks have become so indispensable that trading in those underlying stocks nearly halted when a flood forced the Merc to close for a day in 1992. According to the exchange, the dollar value of trading in the index is 60 percent more than that in the stocks themselves.
While trying to increase their revenues, some exchanges are also merging to cut costs. Nymex, the world's leading energy futures exchange, recently acquired the Commodity Exchange of New York, which specializes in copper and precious metals futures. Both exchanges operate from the World Trade Center in Manhattan.
Here in Chicago, the Board of Trade and the Merc early this month began to study the money-saving benefits of at least a partial merger, though past efforts to combine the rivals have collapsed. And both exchanges are looking to set up subsidiaries to pursue "off exchange" business from customers who want something other than standardized futures contracts.
The most heavily traded futures contracts throughout the world are hedges against unexpected movements in interest rates, currencies and other financial instruments either issued by governments or heavily influenced by them. Most others are in traditional commodity arenas like mining and agriculture that are driven by Government subsidies and trade policies.
As a result, most new-product efforts respond to recent or expected Government policy changes. Usually, the exchanges go after niches, like the new milk futures. There, declining Government support prices for milk have made prices more volatile, creating interest in futures and options among dairies, their major customers like candy companies, and even some farmers.
The Board of Trade's corn yield contracts are a more radical leap. The first yield contract, introduced last summer, was priced at $100 times the average bushels an acre of corn grown on Iowa farms: for example, approximately $13,000 in recent trading for a September contract. Last month, the board added contracts for average corn yields in Ohio, Illinois, Indiana, Nebraska and the entire country, though it does not expect any significant trading until the spring planting season.
All previous crop contracts have been based on projected prices. That made sense as long as the United States dominated world agriculture, because prices and yield were fairly closely linked. When yields were high, the bumper crop drove down prices everywhere. In a bad year, supplies would be short and prices would rise.
Now, with the American share of the world market much smaller and trade much freer, Midwest farmers can be hammered if domestic yields are meager but prices remain low because of, say, reports of projected bumper crops in South America. To manage that risk, an Illinois farmer can now sell futures pegged to an average-sized corn crop in Illinois. If he and most of Illinois have a bad year, he generates less than expected from his fields, but offsets that with profits from those futures.
The Board of Trade hopes to expand the yield contracts into soybeans and wheat if the corn yield futures succeed. But the odds are against that success.
That's because the vast majority of new products fail to catch on -- about 80 percent by the Board of Trade's reckoning -- although many limp along from year to year with no one bothering to delist them. Among the more recent flops: the Board of Trade's barge futures and the Merc's broiler chicken futures.
"There haven't been any home runs since the early 1980's," said Todd E. Petzel, a fund manager who left the Chicago Merc at the end of January after years as head of its product-development effort.
Part of the problem is that it is hard to attract customers until they see the success enjoyed by the pioneering traders. As the uptick in insurance trading after the Florida hurricanes of 1994 demonstrated, it sometimes takes disasters to give momentum to new products.
The learning curve is steepest if the niche market is new to futures, like the insurers to whom the Board of Trade is trying to sell its catastrophe contracts. The need is clear: insurers are scrambling to manage their exposure in an era when the frequency and intensity of natural disasters seem to be increasing. But it is not obvious to many insurers exactly how to figure out the true value of the contracts without a track record.
Wary customers are only the last hurdle. Well before that, exchanges must get their own members to participate in developing and backing the new products.
The major exchanges are not-for-profit organizations owned and largely governed by their members. In the case of the Board of Trade, Mr. Arbor must seek reelection every two years. He faces an electorate of giant corporations like Merrill Lynch & Company and Cargill Inc., small local traders, grain specialists and bond traders -- some of those wealthy longtime players, others young, poorly capitalized newcomers -- all with conflicting interests and differing views of how to invest in the future.
Even if an exchange can convince members to invest in developing a new contract, convincing traders to handle it is always ticklish. "To most traders, long term is five minutes," said Patrick J. Catania, the Board of Trade's senior vice president in charge of market and product development. "They look for instant results in defining success."
Many exchanges recruit traders for new products by granting temporary permits or selling seats with limited trading rights at bargain prices. That is what the Merc did in January, selling 50 seats in its new emerging-markets division for $30,000 each. At that price, a trader can make a living with far less business than a Merc member who is paying off the cost of a full seat, now about $700,000.
But designing the terms of the limited seats is nearly as challenging as designing the contracts themselves. Full members are loath to give up their control over what could turn out to be a great trading opportunity -- somewhere down the line.
 
How Futures Work: A Sample
Futures and related contracts like options are known as derivatives because their value is derived from an underlying commodity like a Treasury bond, stock share, coffee or oil. Futures involve the obligation to buy or sell a specific quantity of a commodity on a set date at a set price. Options are the right but not the obligation to strike such a deal.
One simplified example: A bank holding $10 million of 30-year bonds that are paying an average interest rate of 7 percent sells $10 million worth of futures contracts in the trading pit for 30-year bonds. If interest rates rise, the bonds are less attractive and may tumble in value to, say, $9.5 million. But the decline is offset by the value of the commitment the bank holds from the futures buyer to pay $10 million for such bonds on the contract delivery date.
 If interest rates fall, the 7 percent return on the bank's bonds looks better, and the bonds might rise in value to $10.5 million. But the bank will lose $500,000 meeting its commitment to sell such bonds to that buyer for $10 million on the delivery date.
Thus, by selling futures, the bank sacrifices potential gains in its bond portfolio for protection against losses.

HEADLINE: Senate Panel Creates 2 Bills On Legal and Illegal Aliens

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
By a surprisingly wide margin, the Senate Judiciary Committee agreed today to consider new restrictions on legal and illegal aliens in two separate bills rather than one, imperiling large proposed cuts in legal immigration.
After two weeks of jousting, the panel voted, 12 to 6, to strip the more politically charged cuts in skilled foreign workers and family visas, and deal with them separately after addressing stricter enforcement measures against illegal aliens. 
 Six of the committee's 10 Republicans, including the panel's chairman, Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, turned a deaf ear to the pleas of the legislation's main author, Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, to deal with legal and illegal aliens together.
"This is the way this legislation should be taken up," said Senator Spencer Abraham, a Michigan Republican who led the effort to split the bill.
Mr. Simpson played down today's vote, saying: "This won't affect anything. We'll go to the floor with both measures." But others who support deep cuts in the numbers and types of immigrants who enter the country legally said Congress's compressed election-year schedule as well as opposition from a broad coalition of business and pro-immigration groups would make their task more difficult.
Mark Krikorian, executive director of the Center for Immigration Studies, a group that supports cuts in legal immigration, said: "Senators will not have the time or the political will to deal with two separate bills. Since illegal immigration excites people the most, that's what's going to come first. Legal immigration will just shrivel up."
Supporters of legal immigration say current law insures a plentiful supply of skilled immigrants to serve as a wellspring of economic innovation. But critics say foreign workers are taking jobs from Americans and placing huge burdens on public services in states with large numbers of aliens like California, Florida and New York.
The House Rules Committee decided today that an amendment to divide its immigration bill into two parts could be offered next week. It is unclear what effect the Senate decision will have on the House amendment.
Lawmakers said they also expected a heated debate in the House and Senate over requiring employers to use an automated system to verify the legal status of job applicants. Supporters say this is necessary to crack down on illegal aliens with bogus documents. But critics, including liberals and libertarians, argue that such a system is a dangerous step toward an intrusive national identification card.

HEADLINE: Stocks Advance on Hopes For Rising Company Profits

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market rose modestly yesterday as traders bet that an expanding economy would push corporate profits upward.
Many traders sold some shares late in the day in anticipation of today's "triple witching," when futures and options on stocks and stock indexes expire simultaneously. 
 In addition, bond prices remained in a very narrow range for most of yesterday's trading. "With a benign bond market, the path of least resistance for stocks is higher," said Richard Cripps, chief market strategist for Legg Mason. "And the Producer Price Index number gave confidence that the Consumer Price Index is going to be a friendly number."
The Labor Department reported yesterday that producer prices unexpectedly fell two-tenths of a percent last month, the first decline in eight months and indicating an absence of inflation. It is scheduled to release its report on consumer prices today.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 17.34 points, to 5,586.06, after rallying more than twice as much earlier in the session. When the Dow was up 50 points at 2:51 P.M., the New York Stock Exchange's "downtick rule" was triggered in an attempt to stabilize the market by curbing stock-index arbitrage.
Among the broader indexes, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 2.32 points, to 640.87, and the Nasdaq composite index advanced 2.43 points, to 1,091.07. The Dow Jones transportation average climbed 36.35 points, to a record level of 2,154.22. Advancing issues topped decliners on the Big Board by 1,449 to 929, while volume soared to an exceptionally heavy 492.6 million shares, from 413 million shares on Wednesday.
Oil stocks climbed after the price of crude oil jumped above $21 a barrel for the second time in three years. Phillips Petroleum, which was upgraded by Merrill Lynch, rose 3/4, to 39 3/8; Texaco added 1 3/8, to 84 1/2; Exxon advanced 1, to 81, and Chevron increased 1, to 56.
American Express led the financial services sector higher, adding 2 1/4, to 47 1/4. Other gainers included Citicorp, up 2 13/64, to 78 5/8; Chemical, up 1 1/2, to 68 1/4, and Federal National Mortgage, or Fannie Mae, up 1/2, to 31 1/4.
The retail sector benefited from rotation by portfolio managers. Kmart closed up 5/8, at 9 1/2, its highest price since last October. Dayton Hudson closed at 82 5/8, up 1 7/8, after stating that earnings for the quarter ended Feb. 3 exceeded expectations. Wal-Mart closed at 23 5/8, up 5/8.
Monsanto gained 4 5/8, to 149 5/8, after announcing plans for a stock split and an enhanced share buyback program. Others in the chemical group showing advances included Dow Chemical, up 2 1/2, to 88 5/8, and Georgia Gulf, up 2 1/4, to 35 1/2.
However, tobacco issues slumped for a second day amid new legal pressures on cigarette manufacturers. Philip Morris, which slumped 5 1/2, to 92 1/2, once again was responsible for holding back the Dow industrials. RJR Nabisco dropped 1 1/4, to 32 5/8, and UST fell 1, to 33 5/8. The S.& P. tobacco index plummeted 84.41 points, to 1,609.83.
Some communications equipment concerns also finished lower. DSC Communications closed at 28, down 7/8; Cisco Systems ended at 45 15/16, down 3/16, and Oracle closed at 48 1/8, down 1 1/2.
Earnings-related news pushed down the prices of a number of companies. Office Depot gave up 2 3/4, to 20 1/2; Big Flower Press fell 4 7/8, to 10 7/8, and Active Voice dropped 5 1/4, to 13.

HEADLINE: CLINTON, IN ISRAEL, STRESSES SUPPORT FOR PEACE EFFORT

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 14

 BODY:
By turns politician, preacher and professor, President Clinton raced from the peak of Mount Herzl here to the heart of coastal Tel Aviv today to convince Israelis that the United States stood squarely behind them and their endangered peace.
The formal centerpiece of Mr. Clinton's brief visit was his commitment of $100 million to supply Israel with training and technical assistance in the fight against terrorism. 
 American officials said the aid would include advanced bomb-detection devices, X-ray systems, robotics for dealing with suspected bombs and advanced thermal and radar sensors. They said $50 million of the funds would come from the Pentagon's 1996 budget, and the rest would be added to next year's budget.
American foreign aid to Israel is $3 billion a year, of which $1.2 billion is economic assistance and $1.8 billion military.
Mr. Clinton was less precise on the possibility of a formal military treaty with Israel, which would be troubling for both Israel and the United States. The President said only that the two sides would immediately begin negotiating a agreement to combat terrorism, and urged reporters not to "jump ahead."
The pledge of $100 million, coming on the day after world leaders gathered in Egypt to condemn terrorism, was part of a broad effort by the Clinton Administration to revive Israeli faith in peace with the Palestinians after four suicide bombings in which 62 lives were lost.
"The message of the pact to the people of Israel should also be quite clear," Mr. Clinton said at a news conference in Jerusalem. "Just as America walks with you every step of the way as you work toward peace, we stand with you now in defending all that you are and all that has been accomplished."
The President's 22-hour visit was clearly intended to bolster Prime Minister Shimon Peres's damaged standing before the national elections on May 29. It included a meeting with the entire Israeli Cabinet; a visit to the national cemetery on Mount Herzl to lay a wreath at the tomb of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, and to pay respects at the graves of 10 victims of terror attacks, and meetings with the opposition leader Benjamin Netanyahu and with Israeli students in Tel Aviv.
Following criticism from the Mayor of Jerusalem, Ehud Olmert, that the schedule did not pay sufficient attention to that city, Mr. Clinton joined Mr. Olmert in visiting a Jerusalem school that lost four pupils in the recent wave of terror attacks.
At every stop, the theme was the same, urging Israelis to stay the course. At the assembly with thousands of students in the Center for the Performing Arts in Tel Aviv, Mr. Clinton was greeted with a long standing ovation, and he was introduced by Mr. Peres as "one of the greatest Presidents that the United States has ever had."
Repaying the compliment, Mr. Clinton told the students that to succeed, they first had to follow the advice of the Prime Minister. Clearly savoring the warm reception, the President was at times the teacher -- tutoring the students on the importance of "learning how to learn" -- and at times the preacher, citing psalms to drive home his message.
"Israel is not alone, America stands with you, and with every passing day, so do more people, here and abroad," he said. "But we will not rest until, in the words of the psalm, 'There is peace within Israel's walls and security in her towers.' And we know that Israel will never give her enemies the victory they seek, never abandon the hope of peace, never lose 'a tikvah leshalom' " -- a hope of peace.
Although the politics of the visit was transparent, and many of the scenes were certain to reappear in the campaign advertisements of both Mr. Peres and Mr. Clinton, the powerful personal gesture of support from an American President made a distinct impression. In Israel, as at the summit meeting in Egypt, Mr. Clinton made it clear that he was throwing his support and sympathy behind Israel, and not only behind a process or a region.
The President made no effort to balance his backing for Israel with a gesture toward Yasir Arafat or the Palestinians, as visiting dignitaries usually do, and he publicly supported Israel's severe measures in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, including the siege of Palestinian settlements.
Mr. Clinton argued that an objective of the "terrorists" was to compel Israel to punish all Palestinians. "It's a deliberate attempt by them to make the Palestinians as miserable as possible," he said.
In an article titled "Clinton, the Last Zionist," Nahum Barnea -- a commentator for the popular newspaper Yediot Ahronot who lost a son in one of the suicide bombings -- said Mr. Clinton was the first recent American President not to feel compelled to be "balanced" in his relations with Israel.
"There are other countries around the world which were hit by terror and have paid a similar price," Mr. Barnea wrote. "But none of them have received the comprehensive, warm, unconditional support that Israel has received from the American President."
While Mr. Clinton made his tour, the Israeli Army invited reporters to the village of Rafat in the West Bank to watch the demolition of the house of Yahya Ayyash, the Hamas bomb-maker known as the Engineer, who was killed in January. Three of the recent suicide bombings were said to be revenge for his killing.
Although Mr. Clinton's schedule was clearly tilted toward Mr. Peres, the main architect of Israel's peace policy, the President did meet with Mr. Netanyahu, the leader of the opposition Likud, whose ratings have risen sharply since the suicide bombings. After the meeting, Mr. Clinton insisted that the United States would cooperate with any leader elected by the Israelis.
Mr. Clinton's visit was accompanied by some of the stiffest security anyone could remember in peacetime because of fears of another terrorist strike while he was here. The Jerusalem-Tel Aviv highway was sealed off for his passage, as were the areas he visited.
His visit passed without incident. But Mr. Clinton acknowledged at his news conference that there could be no guarantee against more attacks.
Asked whether the measures he and the Israelis were taking could stop a determined bomber, Mr. Clinton said, "No, no one can do that."
"What we are trying to do is to reduce the risks, to reduce the likelihood of this, to prevent more of these things from happening, to catch more of the wrongdoers," he said. "We can absolutely do that, and that should be the focus."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In Israel yesterday, President Clinton met with the leader of the opposition Likud party, Benjamin Netanyahu. Mr. Clinton's visit was intended to show American support for pressing on with the Mideast peace effort. (Retuers)(pg. A9)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Ire and Votes: U.S. Vents Its Rage at Cuba In Trade Law

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
The bill that President Clinton signed this week penalizing foreign companies doing business with Cuba illustrates two of the most controversial trends in American trade policy.
The measure, which set off howls of protest from American trading partners, represents the latest of many attempts to extend the reach of United States law beyond the country's borders. 
 And it marks the fourth battle in 14 months between the Americans and the recently created World Trade Organization, the body that Washington did much to promote but which it now often seems reluctant to use or respect. The United States had billed the organization as the cornerstone of a reformed trading system that emerged from the Uruguay Round of negotiations that produced a new international trade accord near the end of 1994.
Since the World Trade Organization opened for business in January 1995, the United States has refused to join in the agreement it negotiated on freeing trade in financial services, saying that those provisions do not go far enough.
It has also ignored the organization's dispute-settlement procedures in a quarrel with Japan over auto parts, preferring to threaten Tokyo with sanctions.
And it is appealing an order to develop a plan to change a key feature of the Clean Air Act, which, the trade organization ruled, discriminated against gasoline imported from Venezuela.
Now the new law seeks to punish foreigners doing business with Cuba, an apparent violation of their right to trade freely under the Uruguay Round accords. Another bill, sponsored by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, would do the same thing to foreign companies selling oil and gas equipment to Iran and Libya. It is expected to soon win Congressional approval.
"The fundamental issue is whether the U.S. is willing to deal with a multilateral trading system in cooperation with other countries or whether it is veering off toward a more unilateral approach," said Jeffrey E. Garten, a former Clinton Administration Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, who is now dean of the Yale School of Management.
And Geoffrey Faux of the Economic Policy Institute in Washington observed: "The Administration has obscured the reality of the sovereignty loss implied by free trade. Free trade is good if it promotes exports and jobs, but constraining when it gets in the way of military and political objectives."
That inherent conflict becomes more apparent in a Presidential election year, when trade issues sometimes become entangled in sensitive foreign policy matters, as they have this year, several trade experts said.
In fact, President Clinton had fought tooth and nail against the law in question, the Cuba Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act, until Cuba's downing of two civilian aircraft late last month seemed to make further resistance untenable. The Administration now maintains that the law is necessary to protect the country's national security interests.
It allows Cuban-Americans to file suits in American courts against foreign companies that benefit from expropriated Cuban property. The suits can seek punitive damages. The law also allows the banning from the United States of the officers of such companies and the barring of imported goods containing Cuban sugar and produce.
Mr. Clinton's price for signing the bill was a clause allowing him to suspend the right to bring such suits for periods of six months if he deems this to be in the national interest. Whether the President can afford to order such a suspension, affecting Cuban-Americans, in an election year is a matter of speculation.
The legislation's aim is to snuff out a small foreign investment boom -- mainly from Canada, Mexico and Spain -- that Cuba is now enjoying, denying it badly needed foreign exchange and in the process trying again to bring about the downfall of President Fidel Castro.
For other countries, however, the bill represents an attempt to export the United States' longstanding trade embargo against Cuba.
"The extraterritoriality of this act is objectionable because it seeks to use American courts to change other countries' policies," said Robert L. Muse, a Washington-based trade lawyer.
"We remain strongly opposed to this legislation," said Peter Guilford, trade spokesman for the 15-nation European Union, the world's largest free-trading area. "One of the principles of the W.T.O. is that you don't export your laws and your principles to other countries."
Europe's chief trade negotiator, Sir Leon Brittan, is scheduled to discuss the matter next week with Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada and with Administration officials in Washington.
Although Cuba said it had formed 225 joint ventures with foreign companies by the end of 1995, most are small-scale tourist projects. Those of an industrial nature are thought to number only a few dozen.
Nevertheless, several foreign-owned multinational companies with important American interests could be vulnerable to suits under the new law, Mr. Muse said. He cited the big British confectionery concern Tate & Lyle, which buys Cuban sugar, and the British-American Tobacco Company, a unit of B.A.T. Industries P.L.C., which makes cigars in Cuba and has a subsidiary in Kentucky.
As many as 300,000 Cuban-Americans now have the right to sue, Mr. Muse estimated, adding that claims against the American assets of foreign companies doing business in Cuba could reach $95 billion.
"When the world realizes the scale of the threat, there will be a universal outcry against this pernicious bill," he declared.
Still, some European diplomats have expressed reluctance about filing a complaint under the World Trade Organization's dispute-settlement mechanism, fearing that such a move might only make a bad situation worse.
That is because the United States, in its arguments, could be expected to invoke Article 21 of the world trade agreement, a rarely used provision that allows members to take trade actions to protect their "essential security interests."
The risk, specialists say, is that a trade-dispute panel might feel unqualified to make a political judgment about American security needs, creating a devastating precedent for other countries to cite when flouting trade rules.
And that, said Gary C. Hufbauer of the Institute for International Economics in Washington, "could blow a huge hole in the Uruguay agreements."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Sharm el-Sheik Reality

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
It would take a heart of stone not to be moved with hope at the sight of the presidents, prime ministers and kings gathered at Sharm el-Sheik to denounce Hamas terrorism. Yes, and it would take a brain of mush not to see that the conference evaded major realities of fighting Hamas terrorism, and created a new one.
The hope is that because President Clinton has promised big results from the pageant, the participants will deliver antiterrorist achievements -- preferably before more bombs explode in Israeli streets. 
 But no matter how national leaders and human yearnings pump up the hopes, the conference will be just symbolism until somebody puts antiterrorism results where the conference mouth was. Somebody -- Mr. Clinton, Prime Minister Shimon Peres, the Saudi King, the German Chancellor, somebody. Maybe Yasir Arafat -- no, too foolish a thought.
But what the conference evaded or slid by remains real, not symbols.
The overriding reality is Israel's responsibility to defend its people against terrorism.
The Oslo agreement of 1993 brought benefits for Israel and Palestinians. For Israel: acceptance, if not recognition, from many Muslim states. For Palestinians: the road to independence.
But the Labor Government committed an error that almost literally has been ticking away ever since. It turned over the fight against terrorism from surrendered territories to the Palestine Liberation Organization, for decades a fount of terrorism.
Mr. Arafat had the tools to fight terrorists -- about 30,000 troops, economic and military aid pouring in from the West. Instead he gave them safe haven.
But there's none for Israel. Neither Mr. Peres's Labor Government nor the opposition Likud would try to retake land given up. But Likud would give up no more until Israel established on-the-spot responsibility for antiterrorist action in Gaza and the West Bank.
Mr. Peres hopes the conference can save him from that decision at least until the May elections. And he hopes Mr. Clinton's preference for him over Likud will swing enough Israelis to elect him.
Another reality touched on too lightly was the funding of Hamas and allied terrorists. It comes mostly from Iran, Libya and Syria. But now money comes also from private U.S. donations, as shown repeatedly by the Washington investigative journalist Steven Emerson.
For years, the U.S., plaintively and futilely, has asked Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Japan, all conference members, to stop the trade billions they pour into the countries that empower Hamas.
But can we expect one little favor? The next time terrorist killers like those taken from the Achille Lauro fall into Italian hands would Rome please not give three out of four of them leaves from jail so they can skip the country, one after another? That would be nice.
Some Arab states at the conference that also had been funding Hamas said "no more." Why anybody should believe them escapes me, since the U.S. Congress itself sees nothing wrong with funding Hamas.
Congress is destroying a bill that would have blocked money for terrorist groups. It is being done in by a combination of the gun lobby and the American Civil Liberties Union; together, new horizons beckon.
Now, about Mr. Arafat. Never did he give up his talk of holy war, of the martyrdom of terrorists -- until the spiritual atmosphere of the hotel at Sharm el-Sheik brought, presumably, epiphany.
As Hamas bombs were going off in Israel and later, Mr. Arafat's chief of security in Gaza held regular meetings with Hamas's chief of military operations, according to Yigal Carmon, a former counterintelligence adviser to Israeli prime ministers.
After the bombings, Mr. Arafat said right-wing Jews had helped Hamas. His aides keep talking about the "option" of renewed conflict with Israel. The other day, at a Washington hearing, his representative passed around a statement on a letterhead showing all Israel as Palestinian territory.
So -- at Sharm el-Sheik, Mr. Arafat received promises of lots more American help in addition to the hundreds of millions he has spent, or socked away.
That is the new Arafat reality. He was not skipped over at the conference. The man just won it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Republicans Agree on Plan For a Line-Item Veto
Congressional Republicans agreed on a version of a line-item veto for the President that would shift much of the power of the purse from Congress to the White House. It would give the President the power to remove items from spending bills one by one, without vetoing or approving the measure as a whole.
The Republicans have not decided when the measure would take effect. They are not eager to empower President Clinton. [Page A1.]

HEADLINE: G.M. Strike Closes Plant In Tarrytown

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

DATELINE: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., March 14

 BODY:
Ripples from the distant General Motors strike in Ohio finally reached here today when the company shut down its gargantuan assembly plant looming over the Hudson River. But given the uncommon predicament of the 2,000 workers, the shutdown was as much insult as injury.
Workers at the plant, which has been here for eight decades and now assembles Chevrolet, Oldsmobile and Pontiac mini-vans, have known for more than three years that it will shut down for good on June 28. In that time they have been bracing for a tumultuous change in their lives. 
 But they got an earlier taste than expected of things to come when G.M. sent workers home for an indefinite period because the factory -- like others around the country -- had run out of brake linings manufactured in the strikebound Dayton factories.
"First we were told we would work until June," said Maria Sieradzki, an assembly-line inspector in North Tarrytown who has been with G.M. for 11 years. "Now we could be closed sooner."
On Tuesday, the auto maker shut down its Linden, N.J., factory, which has 2,200 workers assembling trucks and four-wheel-drive vehicles. In fact, by 4 P.M. today, when an assembly plant in Bowling Green, Ky., also closed, 24 of G.M.'s 29 vehicle assembly plants were shuttered and 111,550 of its 240,000 workers were idle.
As their cars streamed out of the G.M. parking lot for the last time this week, and maybe longer, laid-off workers said they needed every day's pay to prepare for the life they will lead after June 28.
A majority of the 1,866 unionized workers at the plant here -- whose 2.5 million square feet make it bigger than the World Trade Center -- will be transferred to plants in Georgia and Maryland or be placed on a waiting list for work at the Linden plant. Many of the most senior people will retire.
Some of the transferred workers will need money to pay for moving, even though General Motors is providing moving allowances of $20,000 for those going to Georgia and as much as $60,000 for those going to a less desirable site in Baltimore. Others, like Joseph Leveille, a paint mixer whose stained hands showed he had recently been working on red cars, spoke of more immediate expenses, like mortgages and utility bills.
In Linden, where workers today picked up last week's paycheck and their 1995 profit-sharing checks of $814, Linda Heicklen, who has been tightening lug nuts on wheels for 19 years, breathed a sigh of relief. "That should help carry us through till we get back to work," she said.
But William Washington, 48, of Irvington, was angry.
"The bottom line is even if you get a profit-sharing check, you're still out of a job," said Mr. Washington. "Most of us still have mortgages and car payments and big bills. Profit-sharing helps for maybe a week."
Many workers said they were counting on unemployment benefits to help them get through the shutdown, but General Motors said today that it would fight workers' efforts to win such benefits, arguing that the shutdown was the result of a strike.
In North Tarrytown, the workers sympathized with the Dayton strikers, who walked off their jobs because General Motors has been farming out manufacturing of parts to cheaper, nonunionized plants in the United States and abroad in a process known as outsourcing.
"I support the strike because they're killing the union and killing jobs," said Harry Stevens, a worker with 33 years on the assembly line. "Outsourcing shouldn't be done."
The message was stressed in both North Tarrytown and Linden through signs placed at the employee parking-lot entrances. "No Foreign Vehicles Permitted," the sign in Linden said. "This Parking Lot Reserved for American Vehicles Only."
Otto Rivera, shop chairman of Local 664 of the United Automobile Workers, saw Machiavellian motives in today's shutdown. He pointed out that the national union's three-year contract with G.M. expires in September, and G.M., he said, may be showing its muscle now.
"Maybe this is just a power play," he said. "They're trying to flex some muscle before the negotiations. They're letting us know where they're coming from."
G.M. decided on a permanent shutdown of the North Tarrytown plant in February 1992, when there were 3,450 workers there. The decision came as G.M.'s share of the automobile market was declining and when mini-vans were not selling as briskly as hoped. Since then, the fortunes of both G.M. and the mini-van have turned around, but the company has not gone back on its decision. It agreed only to a one-year extension until this summer.
Among the workers idled today are 615 temporary workers who were hired to fill assembly jobs of workers already transferred.
For Alton Armwood, a temporary worker who receives $120 a day and is getting engaged in April, today's shutdown was a blow to his spirit as much as to his wallet.
"I like to work," he said, "I'm not used to just staying home and doing nothing. I'm used to getting up at 4:45 A.M."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A Melancholy farewell at the General Motors plant in North Tarrytown: Otto Rivera, a local union head, waved to workers leaving yesterday in midafternoon. He said he saw Machiavellian motives in the plant's shutdown. (Jim Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Across Nation, Scores of Workers Affected

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio, March 14

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation and its outside suppliers have laid off tens of thousands of automobile parts workers across North America as a nine-day-old brake-factory strike here continues to cripple the world's largest auto maker.
G.M. announced today that it had temporarily laid off 47,900 parts workers this week, in addition to the 70,750 assembly plant workers idled by the strike so far. A shortage of brakes has forced G.M. to close 24 of its 29 assembly plants in North America, including a mini-van factory in North Tarrytown, N.Y., that shut down today and laid off 2,000 workers. 
 Even G.M. does not know exactly how many workers have been laid off by its 1,600 suppliers. But executives in the auto parts industry said today that they were increasingly feeling the effects of the strike, after trying for the first week of the work stoppage to keep their factories busy producing extra parts for their inventories.
TRW Inc., based in Cleveland, laid off 350 workers today at a Mexican seat-belt factory. Allied Signal Inc., based in Morristown, N.J., has laid off 570 workers at air-bag and seat-belt factories in Tennessee, Michigan and Alabama. And Johnson Controls Inc., based in Milwaukee, has closed car-seat factories in Tennessee, Louisiana, Ohio, Indiana and Maryland, laying off a total of 1,100 workers.
All these companies said they planned to rehire their workers when G.M. reopened its factories.
There was little if any progress today in efforts to end the strike by close to 3,200 members of the United Automobile Workers union at two G.M. brake factories here that supply parts for almost all of G.M.'s cars and trucks. Negotiators for G.M. and the union did not even meet here today, although informal talks continued in Detroit.
G.M. announced this evening that it would ask state employment departments across the country to deny unemployment benefits to U.A.W. workers laid off because of the Dayton strike. G.M. has occasionally taken similar action in previous strikes. although not in the last several years. Most states have rules either barring unemployment benefits to striking workers or requiring that they be on strike for many weeks before becoming eligible.
"Since G.M. is assessed the cost of state unemployment compensation, we don't believe we should finance a strike against ourselves," said John F. Mueller, a company spokesman. About two-thirds of the laid-off workers belong to the union. Each state will make a separate decision on whether to grant G.M.'s request.
Reg McGhee, a U.A.W. spokesman in Detroit, said the union would review G.M.'s move but had no immediate reaction.
The dispute here is over the auto maker's decision to hire few high-wage U.A.W. workers in Dayton while pushing the current workers to put in seven-day weeks and subcontracting brake work to lower-cost, nonunion companies. Harry J. Pearce, G.M.'s vice chairman, said in an interview earlier this week that the company needed to hold down its parts purchasing costs.
Because the current work stoppage started in Dayton, G.M.'s suppliers here have suffered the most.
A few workers sat idle this morning on the front steps of the Mayo Plating and Manufacturing Inc. warehouse here, a huge, steel-sided building with pink and white walls that stand out in the gray and brown desolation of Dayton's industrial south side in late winter. Until last week, 75 workers here cleaned and sorted bright orange, blue and black plastic trays the size of card tables. The trays are used to carry parts from suppliers to assembly lines, and have slots that match various sizes and shapes of parts.
Mayo laid off 40 of the 75 workers here on Tuesday, and may lay off 20 more on Friday if the strike does not end soon, said Harry L. Mayo Jr., the general manager of the company. The Dayton-based business sorts trays for 200 G.M. suppliers in southeastern Ohio, and all of them are worried, he said.
"Everybody is cautiously scaling down, with the assumption that things may pick back up and you have to be ready," he said, adding that if the strike lasted into next week, "That's when you'll see a cataclysmic effect."

HEADLINE: Transit Chief Warns of Cuts In Service

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
After months of assurances from transit officials that there would be no more cuts in subway and bus service until 2000 or beyond, the new president of the Transit Authority warned yesterday that he might have to cut service to balance the authority's budget.
The warning by Lawrence G. Reuter, who took over the Transit Authority on Monday, came just a few months after declining city, state and Federal subsidies led to the first widespread service cuts in two decades and the first fare increase in almost four years. In calling for the fare increase, transit officials had said it was part of a financial plan that would prevent the need for any additional service cuts for five years. 
 But in a wide-ranging interview with reporters yesterday, Mr. Reuter said, "there could be some service reductions." He stressed that he would look first at cutting administration and wringing cost-cutting concessions from the unions.
Cutting service, he said, would be considered only "as the last resort to balance the budget." He did not say when that decision might have to be made, though with this year's budget looking fairly secure, it appears certain that such cuts would not happen for some time.
Mr. Reuter, who oversaw service cuts as chief of the Washington transit agency, later said that he meant that service cuts would be considered "only if factors outside of our control affected the financial plan," like further reductions in Federal aid.
Mr. Reuter's assessment of the Transit Authority's fiscal health was stark. "We've got some very serious and tremendous challenges, as I look at the financial situation," he said. "There will be some downsizing of the organization. I think ultimately, there will be some service changes."
He said that he would not allow the transit system to fall into disrepair, but that if all else failed, he might have to consider steps like eliminating lightly traveled bus lines and closing little-used subway stations. He also said he would study whether it made sense to continue operating the Franklin Avenue Shuttle, a short, decrepit subway line in Brooklyn with a small ridership that has been proposed for closing several times, but saved each time by neighborhood protests.
His remarks were a shift from what has been heard recently from the leaders of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Transit Authority's parent agency. Mr. Reuter's boss, E. Virgil Conway, the M.T.A. chairman, has insisted that there will be no service cuts at least through the end of 1999, and he repeated that assertion yesterday.
Zenia Mucha, a spokeswoman for Gov. George E. Pataki, said, "Both Mr. Conway and Mr. Reuter have assured us that the current financial plan will not result in any need for a cut in service."
Since 1989, the authority's staff has dropped by 5,000, to about 38,000, and 1,500 more jobs are slated for elimination this year. In the same period, its operating budget, which is about $3 billion a year, has shrunk by about 20 percent when adjusted for inflation.
In the last year, the Transit Authority has lost about $300 million a year in city, state and Federal subsidies. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani eliminated most of the city's support for free student transit passes, Congress cut all mass transit subsidies and may eliminate them entirely, and Governor Pataki reduced support for the Transit Authority while increasing it for every other transit agency in the state.
Last year, the M.T.A. ordered a round of budget cuts that included less service on 11 subway lines, elimination of several bus lines and reduction in the cleaning and maintenance staffs. It also raised the fare 25 cents, to $1.50.
Mr. Conway proposed the fare increase last August as part of a five-year financial plan that he said would mean no more service cuts or fare increases at least through 1999. It also promised $7.3 billion in capital improvements from 1997 through 1999, despite the state's signaling that it would contribute no new money to that effort. The capital program would be paid for largely by borrowing billions of dollars, and by diverting billions more from sources of money that are now used for day-to-day operations.
All this would be accomplished, Mr. Conway said, by cutting costs by $500 million a year, without any harm to service and with none of the deferred maintenance that led to the subway system's near-collapse in the 1970's. Much of that savings is expected to come from labor, and in fact, the Transit Authority's 1996 budget assumes that by the middle of the year, the unions will have agreed to $100 million a year worth of concessions like changes in work rules and allowing part-time employees.
Almost from the day it was released, Mr. Conway's plan was derided by former transit officials and riders' groups as a prescription for higher fares, poorer service, deferred maintenance, a mountain of debt or a combination of those factors.
Some of the sharpest criticism came from Robert R. Kiley, who, as M.T.A. chairman from 1983 to 1990, presided over the rebuilding of the subway system from its nadir.
"Reuter knows what everyone else knows about the finances, and he's being honest, saying cutting service is the last he wants to do, but he can't rule it out," said Mr. Kiley, who is now the executive director of the New York City Partnership, an alliance of corporate executives.
Informed of Mr. Reuter's remarks yesterday, Beverly J. Dolinsky, executive director of the Transit Riders Council and a nonvoting member of the M.T.A. board, said: "This is what we've been saying all along. It's a huge amount of money they've got to come up with, and I don't know how they're going to do it."
Ms. Dolinsky predicted that there would be no cuts before the gubernatorial election in November, 1998, because "Virgil is the Governor's person."

HEADLINE: Clinton Plays Politics In Minority Contracts

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Clinton Administration's imposition of a three-year moratorium on any new Federal programs that reserve some contracts for companies owned by ethnic minorities and women (news article, March 8) sends an alarming message to the nation's black-owned businesses: that the enforcement of measures designed to increase the participation of African-Americans in the business of the Federal Government might be sacrificed for political expediency this election year. 
 Along with the refusal to commit desperately needed resources to the economic revitalization of the nation's cities, this is another step toward a devastating divestiture of economic resources away from black communities.
The Administration's moratorium concedes undeserved moral ground to the Republican Party on the issue of affirmative action.
It also gives pause to African-American voters whose enthusiastic turnout in November will be critical to President Clinton's re-election chances.
 
EARL G. GRAVES
New York, March 11, 1996
 
The writer is publisher of Black Enterprise magazine.

HEADLINE: New Jersey's Tax Cuts Have Worked

BYLINE: By Timothy J. Goodspeed and Peter D. Salins; Timothy J. Goodspeed is a professor of economics at Hunter College. Peter D. Salins is a professor of urban planning at Hunter and a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute.

 BODY:
States around the country are cutting taxes, and no state has received more attention than New Jersey, where Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's income tax cuts have made her a rising Republican star. But because all states pass most of their revenues back to local governments, critics say that states' cuts will force local property taxes to rise -- leaving taxpayers no better off.
A study we have done on New Jersey's taxes for the Manhattan Institute indicates that such criticism is unjustified. We found that in the majority of towns and cities, property taxes have not risen since Governor Whitman's cuts took effect. Even in the municipalities that have raised taxes, property owners are still saving money and will continue to do so. 
 If there is any place where cutting state taxes would force cities and towns to raise their own levies, it is the Garden State; 90 percent of state income tax money goes directly to municipalities, which spend most of it on schools. Local governments' only other source of tax revenue isproperty taxes.
Yet even before the recent cuts, there was little relationship between state and local taxes. Between 1985 and 1990, local property taxes grew steadily 6 percent to 8 percent each year, adjusted for inflation. But over that period state income taxes fluctuated widely, increasing by more than 20 percent in real terms in 1987 and falling the next year by 5 percent.
Likewise, higher income taxes haven't meant lower local taxes. In 1991, Gov. Jim Florio raised income taxes sharply -- revenues increased by 10 and 17 percent in 1991 and 1992, respectively. Property taxes did fall slightly in 1991 but then increased at a steady real rate of 1 percent to 2 percent each year through 1994.
So how will lower income taxes affect local governments? Our study of 509 school districts from 1991 through 1995 shows that reduced state revenues will cause overall property taxes to go up slightly but that the rise will be far less than the state tax savings. If present trends continue, for every dollar the average New Jerseyan's income taxes are cut, he or she will have to pay only an extra 22 cents in local taxes.
In fact, in 1995, the first full year of the Whitman tax cuts, the property taxes of 310 of the 509 districts did not go up at all (when adjusted for inflation).
Why don't reductions in state aid force local taxes to shoot up? Because local officials are likely to spend as much as they can when the entire state's taxpayers are picking up the tab. But when state aid declines, local taxpayers are reluctant to pay more, so municipalities tighten their belts.
Yes, in some towns this has led to lower spending on schools. Yet our data show that in 93 districts school spending did not fall, even after state taxes were cut. Many of these were the state's poorest communities, which receive more state aid than wealthier districts. But even many middle-income and affluent towns have been able to hold expenditures steady. A typical household in Summit, a wealthy town, saved about $210 in state income taxes in 1995, but its property taxes didn't go up and school spending didn't fall.
So New Jersey taxpayers can look forward to the best of all worlds: sharp reductions in state income taxes, modest increases in local property taxes and plenty of leeway to determine how much they -- not other state taxpayers -- should spend on schools and other local services. Other states would do well to ignore the critics and learn from New Jersey that they can cut state taxes without forcing up local taxes.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises vs. Mark and Yen Over Taiwan Tension Rumors

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar ended higher against the German mark and Japanese yen yesterday after seesawing on fresh economic reports and rumors related to tensions between China and Taiwan.
Early in the day, the dollar fell sharply against the mark, hit mainly by one large seller, dealers said. The dollar also came under pressure from a selloff in the bond market after economic data pointed to strength in the economy. 
 The dollar then revered course. A brief dip below 1.47 marks spurred strong buying interest, which turned the dollar around to make highs for the day at 1.478 marks.
Some of the buying was fueled by rumors in the market of an incident involving a United States vessel or aircraft in the Taiwan Strait, where China has been conducting war games to discourage any move by Taiwan toward independence.
The rumors were quickly put down by the White House, which said it had no evidence of any such incident. The dollar came off its highs shortly after the statement. Traders often buy dollars as a secure investment during times of turmoil.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar edged up to 105.93 Japanese yen from 105.50 yen on Thursday. The dollar was quoted at 1.4725 German marks, up from 1.4708 marks. The British pound fell to $1.5265 from $1.5292.
Treasury prices fell sharply after several economic reports, pushing the yield on the 30-year bond to 6.74 percent, from 6.69 percent Thursday. In one, the Federal Reserve reported industrial production jumped 1.2 percent in February, the biggest rise in nearly eight and a half years. The report indicated that the economy was too strong for the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates, as the bond market had expected. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell, pushing its yield up to 6.73 percent from 6.68 percent.
"The selling off the industrial production, with bonds coming down, weighed on the dollar," said Richard Marrow, a currency dealer at Midland Bank.
In other currency trading in New York yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.1855 Swiss francs, from 1.1869 on Thursday, and to 5.0430 French francs, from 5.0445. It also fell to 1,562 Italian lire from 1,565.

HEADLINE: Technology Stocks Rally, But Dow Falls 1.09 Points

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks closed one of the most active sessions ever with small losses yesterday on trading that was largely linked to the expiration of futures, index futures and stock options, known as a triple witching.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed 1.09 points lower at 5,584.97 after bouncing back from an early morning loss of 35 points. For the week, the Dow was up 114.52 points. 
 In the broader market, declining issues led advances, 1,249 to 1,111, on very heavy trading of 536.9 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange -- the sixth-most-active trading session ever.
Analysts said technology stocks powered ahead on speculation the group would turn out more solid earnings.
The Nasdaq composite index, which has many high-technology shares, rose 8.52 points, to 1,099.59, despite earnings reports from Micron Technology and Oracle that fell short of expectations. Micron rose 3 1/2, to 32 5/8, and Oracle rose 3/4, to 48 7/8.
On the Big Board, I.B.M. rose 3, to 119 7/8, Compaq added 1, to 39 3/4, and Motorola climbed 1 3/4, to 55 5/8.
"Techs are trying to regain the leadership role they held for most of 1995," said Guy Truicko, equity portfolio manager at Unity Management Inc. He said technology stocks were expected to benefit from an improving economy.
There was more good news about the economy.
Industrial production rebounded sharply in February after a storm-weakened January, and consumers grew more optimistic in March, economic reports showed.
Separately, the Labor Department said consumer prices rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent last month, suggesting inflation remained well in check.
Production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities jumped 1.2 percent after a revised four-tenths of 1 percent drop in January, when blizzards caused many plants on the East Coast to close. The jump was the biggest since a rise of 1.3 percent in October 1987, the Fed said in its report.
A separate survey by the University of Michigan said its consumer sentiment index jumped to 95.7 in March from 88.5 in February, implying a possible rise in spending ahead that would fuel growth and lessen the need for more rate cuts.
Economists said the data were in tune with the surprisingly strong February jobs report released the previous Friday.
The upbeat reports, which reduced the chances that the Federal Reserve would lower interest rates soon, hurt the bond market.
The 30-year bond dropped 18/32, to 9019/32, sending its yield up to 6.73 percent, from 6.68 percent on Thursday. It was the highest yield since Aug. 24.
"The bonds are down on the news about the economy, but the big story continues to be that the stock market is somewhat immune to the weakness in bonds," said Ricky Harrington, technical analyst at Interstate/Johnson Lane.
Richard Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason Wood Walker, said a decoupling of stocks and bonds would be negative.
"That's what happened in 1987" before the market crash," he said, adding, "That would highlight the extended valuation in stocks."
Stronger technology shares included Hewlett-Packard up 4 1/4, to 99 7/8, and Microsoft up 2 3/4, to 102 3/8.
Semiconductor makers were aided by a stabilization of memory chip prices. Intel rose 2 3/4, to 58 7/8; Texas Instruments added 2 7/8, to 52 1/2; LSI Logic climbed 2, to 28 1/4, and Applied Materials jumped 2 5/8, to 34 5/8.
Among individual issues, Philip Morris rose 2 7/8, to 95 3/8, rebounding from a 9-point loss in the last two sessions.
Tobacco shares have been hit by news on Wednesday of the agreement by Liggett Group to settle its part in the biggest liability case pending against the tobacco industry.
Lidak Pharmaceuticals plunged 23/16, to 2 1/2, after preliminary test results showed little difference between its oral herpes treatment Lidakol and a placebo.
Prism Solutions, a designer of data warehouse management software, soared 7 1/2, to 24 1/2, in its first day of trading.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 0.56, to 641.43. The American Stock Exchange index was off 0.27 at 561.51.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index of all listed common stocks fell 0.01, to 343.39. The average share was unchanged.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of New York Stock Exchange, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 6,315.527, up 8.864, or 0.14 percent.

HEADLINE: Jet Skis vs. Peace on Islands in Battle of San Juan County

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN

DATELINE: FRIDAY HARBOR, Wash., March 14

 BODY:
Over the last decade, the drone of Jet Skis, Wave Runners and other high-powered wet bikes has come to virtually every waterway in the United States, bringing with it a conflict that may be the recreational equivalent of smoking versus nonsmoking in public spaces.
But it was not until these small personal watercraft began buzzing around quiet bays and sheltered inlets of the San Juan Islands that what may be the most polarizing of all Jet Ski battles was joined. 
 A county of 172 islands at the far northwestern corner of the contiguous states, the San Juans are known for their mischievous resident orca whales in the water and quirky resident iconoclasts on the land. These islands, connected only by boat or float plane to the mainland, seem to embody the liquid Northwest.
On any given day, the cold waters of San Juan County are plied by tiny kayaks and luxury yachts, cedar canoes and 19th-century schooners, salmon trawlers and tour boats -- even the occasional rustbucket Navy vessel, long-retired and sold as surplus. But one thing that is no longer here are personal watercraft.
In one of the most sweeping measures enacted anywhere against such craft, San Juan County last month banned all Jet Skis and similar vessels from its waters. The future of San Juan County, its way of life, its solitude and tourism-based economy, its surfeit of writers, artists and other solo-minded entrepreneurs -- all is at stake in the battle to keep the zippy little boats out of the islands, county commissioners said.
What they are seeking, they say, is a Jet Ski-free archipelago.
"We acted to pre-empt something that was threatening the very lifeblood of this county," said Rhea Miller, one of three San Juan County Commissioners, the governing body of the islands. "We are a very unique place on the face of the earth. You take away what makes this place special, and you're just like any other place in America."
Across the country, other cities, counties, parks and governing bodies have tried to limit the jet-fired small craft, which can reach speeds of more than 60 miles an hour. But industry officials say no jurisdiction has gone as far as San Juan County -- with an outright ban.
It comes as personal watercraft sales have reached record highs, with nearly a million units sold for at least $4,000 a piece, accounting for 34 percent of all boat sales last year. And the industry, including corporate giants like Kawasaki and Yamaha, has taken up the battle.
Two weeks ago, the personal watercraft trade association, joined by individual dealers, filed suit against San Juan County, seeking an injunction. A threat to jet skiers in one area is a threat to all, they said, a point that gives the San Juan battle significance to the other areas awaiting the outcome.
"It's as if one city banned the sale of Chevrolets," said John Birkinbine, the executive director of the Personal Watercraft Industry Association, a trade group based in Chicago that represents the six major manufacturers of personal watercraft. "What they've done is discriminatory. I don't know of anything that could be more extreme."
Industry officials say the ban, which carries fines up to $200, prohibits people from "exercising their fundamental constitutional rights of interstate travel."
San Juan County's prosecutor, Randy Gaylord, says there is no interstate travel ban -- people are free to come and go among the islands. What is banned is one mode of travel -- Jet Skis and similar craft, he says.
"This is a question of local control -- of how counties can protect their health, safety and general welfare," Mr. Gaylord said. "We're a small county, and a small office. We don't have a lot of horsepower to fight these people. But we think we're on solid ground."
Echoing the sentiments of nearly one-fourth of all registered voters in this county who signed a petition asking for the ban, Mr. Gaylord said, "There are plenty of places where you can operate these craft, so you don't need to invade the last few special places as well."
All this fuss may seem out of place for a fight that some say is little more than a battle of one toy over another. Not so, say islanders, who see it as a stirring David vs. Goliath battle. In the ordinance banning the craft, a passage from Washington State's labor department is cited, noting that the island economy is based on its reputation as a "tranquil oasis."
A full 40 percent of the 12,000 or so people who live in San Juan County are self-employed, typically working out of their homes, county officials said. Those people need peace and quiet to work and think, they say.
"I used to live in Key Largo, Fla., and jet skiers took over there," said Jim Skoog, a writer, sailor and boat builder who led the petition drive along with another islander, Mary Ann Anderson. "Then I lived in Australia, and saw what happened there. I moved here for the very qualities that attracted other people -- the tranquility, the lack of urban background clutter."
People who ride Jet Skis, Mr. Skoog said, "are nautical illiterates -- despised by almost all other boaters. All you need to ride one is a bank card."
Newer models make only about as much noise as a vacuum, industry officials say.
But opponents say the sound is unbearably magnified when the jet skiers travel in groups, whooping and jumping out of the water. Also maddening, they say, is the repetition of listening to a jet skier making endless laps and circles.
"It's the incessant, whining pattern of these things," the county commissioner, Ms. Miller said in an interview. "There's a pitch that's extremely irritating."
As deaths have risen, safety was cited in the San Juan ordinance. In 1994, the last full year for statistics, the Coast Guard reported that 56 people nationwide were killed from accidents involving personal watercraft -- up from 35 the year before.
Mr. Birkinbine said that more people died from canoe accidents that year -- the deaths were reported at 59 -- than from personal watercraft. And while it is true that in some states the minimum age to ride personal watercraft is 12, the industry favors raising that to 16, he said.
In the debate over the ban, a lone commissioner, Thomas Starr, argued against it. As a motorcycle rider himself, Mr. Starr said there is a special thrill to getting out in open territory, at a fast speed.
"We all have different interpretations of our pursuit of happiness," Mr. Starr said.
Even with its small, three-person legal staff, the San Juan County prosecutor's office plans to fight the industry lawsuit as far as necessary. It is of such interest here, he said, that people have been making donations to the prosecutor's office.
But the makers of personal watercraft say this county, sitting at the edge of the continent, cannot fight progress. "Other opponents have faded away as they have become more like us," Mr. Birkinbine said. "Times change, and they will just have to get used to it."
