HEADLINE: Sudanese Vote, Sourly, as Islamic Fervor Chafes

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, March 14

 BODY:
Like many northern Sudanese, Siddiq Sidahmed Hassan considers himself a good Muslim. He favors traditional flowing Arab clothes, as white as pure faith, and prostrates himself to Mecca five times a day without fail.
But the 49-year-old shopkeeper does not share his Government's conviction that Islam should be spread to other countries or that the United States is evil. He fondly recalls working for an American oil company, and carries a laminated card in his breast pocket that shows he is a longstanding member of the Sudanese-American Friendship Society. 
 "Most people in the Sudan do not hate the United States," he said. "At first this Government was popular, but after one or two years it lost most of its popularity because they used the Islamic religion very badly."
Mr. Hassan's attitudes reflect a deep ambivalence among many citizens toward the Islamic military leaders who seized power in 1989.
Diplomats say that ambivalence pervades even the Government's upper echelons, where there is a quiet debate between pragmatists who want to mend fences with the West, and ideologues who preach holy war against America and Israel.
For the first time since the coup,the Sudan has been holding elections, which began on March 6 and will end on Monday. To hear Sudanese leaders tell it, they are trying to transform the military Government into a nonpartisan and strictly Islamic democracy, free of the sectarian politics that have hobbled the country.
The outcome is not in doubt. Lieut. Gen. Omar Ahmed al-Bashir, the current President, is sure to win among 42 candidates, most of them unknown because political parties are banned and the campaign lasted only 12 days. Several leaders of the former Government have denounced the vote as a sham.
But the polling also seems intended to persuade the world that the National Islamic Front, led by Hassan al-Turabi, has won a popular mandate with its brand of Islamic government, diplomats said.
"The election is one element of the leadership's attempt to be accepted again," said one diplomat. "They need to break up the isolation. They need hard currency to stay in power."
All week the turnout of voters has been low, and the mood in the dusty, oven-hot capital was sour and cynical. In interviews, Sudanese lawyers, students, intellectuals and merchants said the Government had become more unpopular not only because its Islamic bent had crimped personal freedoms, but also because the economy was limping along, hampered by devaluation and inflation.
Diplomats and Sudanese politicians said it was unclear how much support Dr. Turabi enjoys for his version of a strict Islamic state. Although Islam was always deeply imbedded in the society of the north, most Sudanese are Sufis, who are known for tolerance rather than militant fundamentalism.
To be sure, the Sudan has become more conservative on the surface since the National Islamic Front embarked on building a Government ruled by Muslim law.
Khartoum's bars and discos are shuttered. Women who dare to walk the streets in slacks or without a head-covering are often stopped by the front's security force and taken to police stations. Young couples courting in public say they are frequently harassed as well. College students said the police break up parties in private homes and confiscate liquor, and have at times horsewhipped the organizers.
The nation's laws now embrace sharia, a Koranic code that includes harsh penalties for some crimes, like death by hanging for adulterers and the amputation of a hand for thieves.
Some here say the Islamization has been largely cosmetic. Judges have proved reluctant to impose the penalties sharia prescribes, and it is difficult to prove a crime under the law. To prove adultery, for instance, four grown men must witness the sex act at the same time.
"I have not heard of anybody who was hanged or stoned to death because of adultery," said Chief Justice Obeid Hag Ali, explaining that sharia is "more of a threat intended to regulate society."
The fundamentalism is thriving in some rural areas, however, especially among the poor.
In Ombuda, a village outside Khartoum, the faithful send their children to Koranic boarding school.
On a recent afternoon, 762 pupils between the ages of 3 and 16 squatted in the shady spots of a sweltering dirt courtyard. For three hours at a stretch, they studied Koranic verses. Some younger children wore shackles around their ankles.
"They tried to run home," explained a teacher. "Their parents said they should wear the shackles until they learn the Koran."
At Niilen University in Khartoum, some true believers in the National Islamic Front could be found in a cafeteria. Duria Tajelsir, 21, a computer science major from the small town of Shendi, echoed the views of her three companions when she said: "I would like to build an Islamic country. It's our instruction from God."
But in other ways, the Government has modernized society, diplomats said. By most measures, it has done a better job than previous administrations in meeting basic needs. Electrical power is plentiful, the telephones work, the streets are fixed, crime is down and the marketplaces are full of essential goods.
Few here think the Government is likely to be challenged soon, diplomats said. The National Islamic Front is too well organized and entrenched, with its own militia and a separate security service outside of the police and military.
Still, its popularity has plummeted. The Government's support for militant Islamic groups like Hamas has left it increasingly isolated from Western democracies, hurting the economy and reducing foreign aid and investment.
For average Sudanese, this new era of militancy has meant, more than anything else, that their money is becoming worthless. In the 1970's, the Sudanese pound was worth about $3; today, it takes about 1,300 pounds to buy a single dollar.
To make matters worse, merchants and business owners complain that a small group of Islamic business people with connections to the ruling party are reaping huge profits and getting special breaks on tariffs and loans, while others struggle to get by.
"Nothing works but their companies," said Shomo Ibrahim Shomo, 48, who owns a stationery store in Khartoum. "They get exemptions from customs."
For the Sudanese Government to survive, many here say, it must attract hard currency and foreign investment, and to do that it must patch up its relations with the West.
"Sudan can't survive without foreign investment," said a senior Sudanese economist. "Investment won't come in such a climate. People who control the world market do not want to invest in Sudan."
Diplomats say there are signs the Government has debated loosening its ties with Islamic militants in an effort to avoid United Nations sanctions and regain American economic aid, which was cut off in 1993 after the State Department added the Sudan to a list of countries that sponsor terrorism. But there is no evidence of such a change, and the Foreign Minister said this week that Palestinian Hamas officials would continue to receive refugee status.
The economic problem has been aggravated by the continuing war against Christian and animist rebels in the south, diplomats said. The World Bank has estimated that the Sudan needs $600 million to $800 million in foreign exchange each year to keep basic services operating and to continue the war. The best estimate is that the country is earning about $350 million.
For his part, Dr. Turabi has put a brave face on the problem, saying the Sudan is rich enough to be self-sufficient. He boasts that isolation will force the country to develop its own industries.
"Economic isolation is very positive," he said in a recent interview. "Every new rise of civilization is encircled at first."
But other ruling party members sound more conciliatory. Ghazi -Salaheldin Atabani, president of the National Congress, the nation's top political body, said the Sudan had been courting Asian countries as relations with the West foundered over terrorism. But he added that after the vote, the Sudan will probably move to improve relations with Europe, and possibly even with the United States.
"I would envision some fence-mending with the West itself," he said. "We are not in principle against fence-mending."

The women wear casual Western clothing on campus, but they must cover themselves with traditional Muslim garb when they venture outside the school if they want to avoid harassment by the authorities. HEADLINE: In Heavy Smoking, Grim Portent for China

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 15

 BODY:
Rushing down a Beijing alleyway where a north wind was kicking up dust among the vegetable stands and cigarette vendors, Huang Jinhui, 25, paused to explain to a stranger why he smokes.
"Man must smoke," said Mr. Huang, a young barber from Sichuan Province in central China. 
 "I know that smoking is not a good habit, that it's harmful to your health," he added. "But I have no choice. To carry on social relationships and to do business, I have to smoke."
In a nearby alleyway restaurant, where the tables were littered with empty beer bottles and oily plates and the air was a gauze of tobacco smoke, Fu Li, a young woman from Henan Province, fiddled self-consciously with her cigarette.
"In the very beginning, it was just for fun," she said of her habit. "When you play mah-jongg with friends, if someone offers you one, you cannot refuse. I never really think about the consequences."
Few Chinese do, but that may be changing.
China today has the biggest smoking habit in the world, with an estimated 300 million smokers out of 900 million adults, accounting for 30 percent of the world's consumption of tobacco.
The per-capita consumption of Chinese smokers still lags behind some industrial countries, where as many as 22 cigarettes a day is the norm among smokers, but China is rapidly catching up. The average Chinese smoker went from 12 cigarettes a day a decade ago to 16 today.
The governing Communist Party, which has built its legitimacy on doing a better job for the social welfare of the 1.2 billion Chinese than all the emperors and dictators of old, will soon be confronted with an epidemic of lung cancer and respiratory and heart diseases that threatens to overwhelm its health establishment.
The Government has recently begun to mobilize a national campaign against smoking. But this effort runs against a powerful tide of interests vested in the vast state-owned tobacco monopoly, which has become the world's largest cigarette producer and whose tax revenues are the Government's single greatest income source -- $8.6 billion in 1995.
"The tobacco industry is the No. 1 pillar of China's economic development, and so it is going to be a little difficult for us to get the smoking levels down in the near future," said Zhou Wei, a Public Health Ministry official assigned to combat smoking.
The Government has banned tobacco advertisements from television, magazines and newspapers, but sports events are festooned with the trappings of tobacco products, as are billboards throughout the country. Beijing, Shanghai and other major cities will try to enforce a ban on all smoking in public places, but health advocates, not to mention ordinary Chinese, are skeptical.
The consequences of China's growing fondness for tobacco appear to be staggering.
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta say lung cancer rates are increasing 4.5 percent a year in China and estimate that by 2025, two million Chinese will die of smoking-related illnesses each year -- four times the number of deaths today.
China's smoking explosion has come much later than the West's, and so too will the medical consequences.
"In the West, we didn't see the full male lung cancer epidemic until the 1980's," said Richard Peto, an epidemiologist at Oxford University. Those cancers, he said, were spawned by the postwar increase in smoking, between 1945 and 1965, and by the time the crisis hit, smoking rates already were in decline. In China, per-capita tobacco consumption continues to rise.
"In the mid-1980's, I predicted that the risks from smoking in China were rather less than among British or American smokers," said Dr. Peto, largely because daily consumption levels were only half what they were in Western countries.
"But with more detailed evidence now available," he continued, "we are saying that the risk is not less than for British or American smokers, and therefore at least 50 million of the children now living in China will be killed by tobacco."
When the Communists swept into power in Beijing in October 1949, China's male population represented about 10 percent of the adult population in the world and smoked about 10 percent of the cigarettes consumed. Today, Chinese men are still roughly 10 percent of the world population, but they consume nearly a third of the world's cigarettes.
Some 61 percent of adult males smoke in China, but only 7 percent of the women, according to the World Health Organization. (By comparison, 28 percent of American men smoke, and 24 percent of women.)
But that big disparity between the sexes, too, is changing. More and more college and high school-age girls are embracing Western notions of women's independence, and cigarettes, along with bright makeup and tight jeans, have become symbols of the modern Chinese woman.
"China is about at the stage where the United States was in the 1940's and 1950's, where you have got very high male smoking rates and very few women smokers," said Judith Mackay, a Hong Kong-based doctor.
As young women take up the habit, it will only get worse.
"If the Chinese smoke like Americans, then they will die like Americans," Dr. Peto said.
Xiping Xu, an expert on China at Harvard University's School of Public Health, said: "My biggest concern is that more and more high school and college students are smoking. There is a lot of social pressure, and even the girl students are smoking."
It has not helped that many Chinese icons, including Deng Xiaoping, the country's 91-year-old paramount leader, are lifelong smokers.
Mr. Deng, whose health has seriously declined since 1993, is believed to have finally given up the habit, but his public image as a hard-grit revolutionary who rolled his cigarettes in newspaper engenders more admiration in China than opprobrium.
Prime Minister Li Peng, however, has adopted a higher anti-smoking profile. As 3,000 delegates to China's National People's Congress, or parliament, gathered in the Great Hall of the People last week, Mr. Li chastised 100 deputies from Shandong Province when he found cigarettes for sale in their meeting room. "Selling cigarettes here?" he asked, noting that Beijing was preparing to enforce a ban on smoking in all public places and that this year's session of the parliament was supposed to be smoke free.
Wang Jinquan, who works for Beijing's housing department, said: "I started to smoke when I was in high school. My father died at that time, and I felt so bad, people told me to smoke and relax."
Looking more harried than relaxed, Mr. Wang added: "In our hometown almost every person smokes. You know, it is easier to make business, or to make friends, when you draw out a cigarette and offer it to others. Without cigarettes and drinks, you can't get anything done in our town."
Even among doctors, smoking is on the increase in China.
Li Chunjiu, 58, a surgeon at Beijing Hospital, says he got his smoking habit from a fear of snakes.
When a huge flood struck central China five years ago, Dr. Li joined a team of 10 doctors and nurses who rushed there to help. But news that the flood zone was crawling with snakes set him shivering.
"I heard that snakes are scared of cigarette smoke and the local farmers even lay tobacco leaves on the paths to keep the snakes away, so that is why I started smoking at the time," he said. "But I haven't been able to quit."
A pack of Chinese cigarettes costs as little as a nickel in the Chinese countryside and in the cities the best brands are less than 50 cents. Foreign brands, like Marlboro and Winston, cost more than $1.50 a pack because of high tariffs, which in turn have given rise to a robust smuggling industry.
For all their attraction, foreign brand cigarettes have only a tiny share of the legal Chinese market, 2 percent or less, said Robert Fletcher, chairman of the Tobacco Institute in Hong Kong. Still, policy advocates fear the aggressive marketing and advertising schemes of Western tobacco giants.
Should China drop its barriers to foreign tobacco to enter the World Trade Organization, American and British tobacco companies are prepared.
"It wouldn't matter if every single smoker in America quit tomorrow," Dr. Mackay said, "because the tobacco companies would have found a much bigger market."

HEADLINE: Journal;
The 'Too Jewish' Question

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
As the upwardly mobile mobbed Sotheby's last week to get their hands on the American consumer's ultimate porno -- the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis auction catalogue -- I was some blocks away on the Upper East Side contemplating Barbra Streisand's nose.
Ms. Streisand's nose was enshrined at the Jewish Museum on Fifth Avenue on a huge canvas titled "Four Barbras (the Jewish Jackie Series)" -- a spoof of Andy Warhol's silk-screen Jackie O. series, with a repeated head shot of the star, seen in profile, substituting for the First Lady. Jackie Kennedy and Barbra Streisand, it must be remembered, became famous at the same time, at the dawn of the 60's. But Ms. Streisand never joined Jackie and Liz and Marilyn in the glamorous Pop Art pantheon of the era, as defined by Warhol. Her nose, perhaps, just wouldn't do. 
 "Four Barbras" is part of an exuberant -- some might say exuberantly tasteless -- exhibition that has the potential to mortify American Jews as much as Philip Roth did in the days of "Goodbye, Columbus" and "Portnoy's Complaint." The Jewish Museum's show is called "Too Jewish?" and its contents seem determined to affront assimilated, often secular American Jews by demanding to know to exactly what lengths they'll go to avoid appearing "too Jewish." I doubt anyone will confuse the works on display with Rothkos or Gottliebs, but as acts of provocation at this moment in American Jewish history, they sting.
Among the other pieces in "Too Jewish?" is "Chanel Hanukkah," in which a gold Chanel handbag becomes a menorah, with a row of lipsticks substituting for candles. On a TV monitor a teen-age daughter on "The Goldbergs" in the 50's sobs to her mother, Gertrude Berg, about the ugliness of her nose. The girl would no doubt rather look like Barbie -- though, as another display in "Too Jewish?" reminds us, the doll that has intimidatingly served as "the ultimate gentile goddess" for generations of American girls was in fact created by "a nice Jewish lady" who submerged her ethnicity to create an icon in the image of Sandra Dee.
If the more assimilated of my two Jewish grandmothers were still alive, I think "Too Jewish?" would kill her. When I was growing up in the 50's, she was so determined not to be too Jewish that when she wished to identify someone as Jewish in conversation she wouldn't say "Jewish" but would identify the poor soul as "one of us," in the same whisper in which she spoke of cancer. The pictures at the Jewish Museum -- an enormous Pop Art portrait of a box of Manischewitz "American" matzohs, for instance -- never whisper a Jewish identity; they shout it.
In 1996, the shouters may have a point. At a time when anti-Semitism on both the white right and black left is a real phenomenon, mightn't American Jews be more openly visible in our culture, especially mass culture, if only to defend their turf?
As Entertainment Weekly reported last year, "Jewish characters are practically nonexistent" in Hollywood movies, appearing less frequently than every other minority, whether religious, racial or sexual. On TV, Jewish men from "Seinfeld" to "Mad About You" are only faintly so and, in the grand tradition of the late, great George Burns (ne Nathan Birnbaum) and Gracie Allen, are never married off to Jewish women. That Jewish titan of fashion Ralph Lauren clothes America in the quintessence of WASP.
So what else is new? you might ask. But in the aftermath of a primary season in which a major Presidential candidate's anti-Semitic rhetoric went unchallenged, even unremarked, by his opponents, American Jews can't be blamed for wondering if we're a little too invisible for our own good. Though his G.O.P. rivals assailed Pat Buchanan for his "extreme" economic views and foreign policy, the extremity of his views about Jews (as well as his race-baiting embrace of the Confederate flag) was answered by silence. And, as Norman Podhoretz wrote in The Weekly Standard, to oppose Mr. Buchanan "only because he is a protectionist and an isolationist is inescapably to suggest that anti-Semitism is of no great importance as compared with these other issues."
Would the silence have been so deafening if Jews, like every other minority, were constantly in the country's face, noses and all? We are living in a time when being too Jewish in America maybe wouldn't hurt.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
World Bank Moves to Cut Poorest Nations' Debts

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
The World Bank has offered to reinvest part of its $1.3 billion annual surplus in a new trust fund that would be set up to reduce the debts of the world's poorest nations.
The bank is asking the International Monetary Fund and other lenders to contribute to similar undertakings. 
 At the Halifax, Nova Scotia, summit meeting last June, the Group of Seven major industrial countries asked the World Bank and the I.M.F. to break precedent and relieve these struggling countries. In the past, individual lenders offered debt relief, but not the multilateral agencies.
The situation of Uganda is typical. It spends $3 per inhabitant on health annually, and about $17 a person on debt repayment, mainly to multilateral creditors, according to a study by Oxfam International, a private aid organization lobbying for debt relief. The debt burden chokes off the nation's economic growth.
Although the proposed size of the trust fund was not disclosed, it would be financed by the regional development banks as well as the World Bank and other donors. World Bank officials say they expect it to have annual outlays of around $400 million.
The proposal to cope with the developing world's debt problems addresses the first of two primary challenges facing James D. Wolfensohn, the World Bank's president since last June. His second challenge is to persuade a skeptical Republican Congress to vote America's share of the World Bank's low interest rate lending specifically devoted to these very poor and heavily indebted countries that cannot afford to borrow at market rates.
While the United States, Britain and Canada were generally favorable toward the comprehensive debt relief plan, Germany, France and Japan took a more cautious approach when the World Bank's directors discussed the initiative for the first time on Wednesday, diplomats said.
However, in a statement approved by the directors, Mr. Wolfensohn said later that the executive board had "concluded that the proposal represents an important and comprehensive step in the right direction."
The plan will now be discussed by the I.M.F.'s directors next Wednesday and then by world finance ministers attending the annual spring meetings of the World Bank and the I.M.F in Washington next month. A resolution may be reached then, or may await the next Group of Seven summit meeting in June, in France.
The World Bank and the I.M.F. believe that some 20 of the poorest developing countries, whose debts are in excess of 200 to 250 percent of their annual export earnings, may qualify for relief under the plan. They include: Mozambique, Nicaragua, Zaire, Zambia, Bolivia, Cameroon, Ivory Coast, Ethiopia, Tanzania and Uganda.
To qualify for the help, these countries must undertake a three-year period of economic reform supervised by the World Bank and the I.M.F. after which they would become eligible for forgiveness of up to 67 percent of their bilateral debts to the group of donor countries known as the Paris Club.
In the second stage of the plan, these countries would continue with their economic reform programs for another three years, during which donor countries and aid institutions would provide them with additional assistance, such as free grants to reduce debt servicing costs.
At the end of this second stage, outstanding debts to Paris Club countries would be further reduced by up to 90 percent with comparable cuts in other bilateral and commercial debts. The proposed new trust fund would also pay off an undefined "portion" of their debts to multilateral development banks like the World Bank and the regional development banks.
Left unclear in the World Bank proposal is the precise role to be played by the I.M.F. The I.M.F. accounts for roughly half these countries' multilateral debts and has long resisted any debt relief on principle.
While the I.M.F. would not be expected to contribute to the World Bank trust fund, it is " expected to take action that would reduce the present value of its claims on a country participating in the initiative," the World Bank said. Any such action, officials said, would certainly involve selling some of the I.M.F.'s vast stock of gold, currently valued at $40.7 billion.
While the United States, Britain and Canada believe the most heavily indebted countries have little chance of resuming growth without debt relief, they also have reservations about whether the plan's six-year timetable is too long, as well as concern that Germany and Japan will refuse to forgive up to 90 percent of their bilateral debts through the Paris Club.
Among the less enthusiastic countries at Wednesday's meeting, Japan was said by officials to have the strongest philosophical objection to debt relief, believing it would set a dangerous precedent. Instead it thinks aid donors should continue lending to these countries at concessional rates.
Germany's top financial officials also share this view, but the country's aid officials are more sympathetic toward the plan. Although many of the most indebted developing countries are former French colonies, France appears ambiguous about debt relief.

HEADLINE: Industry Pace Rises Sharply; Inflation Low

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
Rebounding more sharply than expected, industrial output rose 1.2 percent in February, a gain three times as large as a decline in January that reflected the impact of a blizzard in the Northeast, the Federal Reserve reported today.
It was the biggest surge of activity at the nation's factories, mines and utilities -- about one-third of the economy -- in more than eight years. 
 The Government also reported today that consumer prices rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent last month, further evidence that inflation remained subdued.
But it was the University of Michigan that seemed to raise economic eyebrows the most today when it told clients that its index of consumer confidence jumped to 95.7 in mid-March, the highest level since August. February's reading was 88.5.
Taken together, analysts said the figures suggested that the economy was a bit stronger than had been believed, at least before the giant increase in payroll jobs for February that was reported last Friday, and that prospects may have brightened somewhat for coming months.
"It does not appear we have slipped into recession," said Martin A. Regalia, chief economist at the United States Chamber of Commerce. "Two weeks ago we couldn't have said that" with much assurance.
The bond market slumped after the reports' release, further dampening hopes that the Federal Reserve would soon cut short-term interest rates. [Page 45.]
Still, the data remain clouded because of the effects of the blizzard and the strike against the Boeing Company that was settled in mid-December.
Economists, who had fretted about lack of information because of the shutdown of the Government's statistical apparatus, said gauging the economy had been particularly hard this winter and that the General Motors strike would add to the confusion when figures are published for March.
Mickey D. Levy, chief financial economist at Nationsbank in New York, said today that he detected in the production figures a "modest sign of pickup" but that there was no way to be sure when there were so many seasonal and other quirks. "Every month seems very awkward," he added.
The 1.2 percent jump in output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities last month was more than rebound from the blizzard but not much higher than projections derived from the Labor Department's report a week ago that employers added a strong 705,000 jobs for the month and that the length of the workweek returned to normal.
But analysts also said that January was not as weak as previously calculated, with the Fed revising that month's decline to four-tenths of 1 percent from an initial six-tenths of 1 percent.
"You got a bounce-back -- and then some," just like the employment results, said Brian M. Jones, an economist at Salomon Brothers.
The Fed also said that industry operated at 82.9 percent of capacity, well above the 82.1 percent pace to which it had sunk in January and slightly above December's 82.7 percent. The utilization rate had reached a peak of 85.1 percent last winter.
The recent improvement in output was concentrated in business equipment and related durable-goods materials, the central bank said, with the recovery in aircraft and parts production after the Boeing strike accounting for nearly one-third of the growth in the first two months of the year.
Factory output climbed 1.4 percent last month while mining's rose 1.5 percent, nearly half of this from coal. Utility output, down 1.2 percent, has now fallen three straight months.
Motor vehicle assembly jumped to a 12 million annual pace from 11.2 million, the gain split evenly between cars and trucks, the report also showed.
As for the Consumer Price Index, which seemed to surprise no one, the deceleration to a two-tenths of 1 percent rise from January's four-tenths of 1 percent was marked by a downswing for petroleum-based energy.
Apparel fell sharply to more than erase a January increase while the heavily weighted housing component rose slightly less as prices fell for fuel oil and furniture and bedding products while cable television jumped 1.3 percent.
Transportation prices climbed five-tenths of 1 percent, their second straight hefty advance, as airline fares surged 5.9 percent and used cars increased another seven-tenths of 1 percent. On the other hand, finance charges fell 1.9 percent, the fifth straight decline.
Core inflation -- the Consumer Price Index with the wide-swinging food and energy components removed -- was up two-tenths of 1 percent in February, the same as the index as a whole and the same as the average core rate for December and January, the Labor Department's report also showed.
Divided between goods and services, the former showed no inflation in February while the latter was up four-tenths of 1 percent. Both categories, however, have risen at a 3.3 percent annual rate over the latest three months.
Prices in the New York and Philadelphia metropolitan areas climbed five-tenths of 1 percent and six-tenths of 1 percent, respectively, the highest of the five cities for which monthly figures were reported.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

'American Flyer' Trains Planned for Northeast
Moving decisively to upgrade train service in the Northeast and challenge the airlines, Amtrak chose the contractors to build a $611 million fleet of "American Flyers" that will dramatically cut train travel time between Washington and Boston. The top speed of the new trains, the first of which is to be delivered in 1999, is 150 miles an hour -- 25 miles an hour faster than trains that now travel between New York and Washington, and 50 miles an hour faster than between New York and Boston.
Amtrak is ordering 18 "train sets," each consisting of six cars and an engine at either end. Each of the 345 seats will have an electric outlet for a laptop computer. The trains will be built by Bombardier Inc., of Quebec, and GEC Alsthom, which is Franco-British. But much of the work will be done in Plattsburg, N.Y., and in Barre, Vt. [Page 1.]
 
AT&T Sees Fewer Job Cuts As More Workers Take Buyouts
AT&T, not three months after it stunned Main Street and delighted Wall Street by estimating that it would cut 40,000 jobs over two to three years -- 10,000 from voluntary buyouts and 30,000 from pink slips -- is now predicting fewer reductions. The buyouts have exceeded expectations, and internal demand in some areas has been strong enough that employees who might leave one job are finding work in another part of the company. [37.]
 
Amdahl's Chief Executive Resigns
Joseph Zemke resigned unexpectedly as president and chief executive of the Amdahl Corporation, citing personal reasons. Amdahl, which makes computers compatible with I.B.M.'s mainframes, has been hard-pressed to keep up with a revitalized I.B.M. lately and reported a loss of $38.4 million in the fourth quarter. Mr. Zemke will be succeeded by John C. Lewis, Amdahl's chairman. [39.]
 
Liggett to Settle With 5 States
The Liggett Group and its parent, Brooke Group Ltd., which stunned the tobacco industry on Wednesday by agreeing to settle a giant class action suit by smokers, announced a preliminary settlement with five states -- Florida, Massachusetts, Mississippi, Louisiana and West Virginia. The states had sued seeking reimbursement for Medicaid spending for smoke-related illnesses. [6.]
 
Dow Slips as Nasdaq Advances
Blue-chip stocks closed with small losses in heavy trading that was largely linked to the triple witching expiration of futures, index futures and stock options. The Dow Jones industrial average closed 1.09 points lower at 5,584.97 after bouncing back from an early morning loss of 35 points. For the week, the Dow was up 114.52 points. Technology stocks moved ahead, reasserting their leadership and sending the Nasdaq Composite index up 8.52 points to 1,099.59. [39.]
 
Fokker N.V. Declares Bankruptcy
Fokker N.V., the Dutch aviation company whose World War I aircraft were made famous by the German ace, Baron von Richthofen, known as the Red Baron, declared bankruptcy for three core units, putting 5,600 people out of work, the most in the history of the Netherlands. Crippled by debt and heavy losses, Fokker was unsuccessful in its frantic search for a buyer after its German parent, Daimler-Benz A.G., severed a cash lifeline in January. [36.]
 
Treasury Securities Prices Fall
Prices of Treasury securities fell on growing concern over the faster pace of economic growth. The 30-year bond dropped 18/32 to 9019/32 , sending its yield up to 6.73 percent from 6.68 percent on Thursday. It was the highest yield since Aug. 24. [45.]
 
Crude Oil at 40-Month High
Crude oil prices rallied on the New York Mercantile Exchange, capping a week of gains, reflecting concerns about supply and expectations that United Nations talks with Iraq would not soon lead to an agreement to allow limited oil sales. Crude oil for April delivery rose 83 cents, to $21.99 a barrel, the highest settling price since Oct. 19, 1992. [38.]
 
The dollar gained after seesawing on fresh economic reports and rumors related to tensions between China and Taiwan. In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 105.93 Japanese yen and at 1.4725 German marks. [38.]

HEADLINE: Pataki Reveals Surprise Funds To Ease Budget

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 15

 BODY:
After threatening repeatedly in recent weeks to slash state programs if Washington failed to provide the aid he wanted, Gov. George E. Pataki made the surprise announcement today that he had found $1.4 billion in additional money that he said would enable him to balance his 1997 budget without making painful new spending cuts.
The announcement, at a hastily called news conference this afternoon, came one day after the White House rebuffed Mr. Pataki's request for changes in welfare and Medicaid laws that could save New York State $2 billion in the coming fiscal year, which begins in just two weeks. 
 The Governor's plan predicts that the regional economy will improve so that the state will take in $483 million more in tax revenues than Mr. Pataki had originally projected. It also estimates that the state will spend $758 million less on an array of programs, mainly by reducing the welfare rolls or shifting health care costs to the Federal Government.
The plan calls for only $223 million in spending reductions -- mostly from new programs the Governor had put in his earlier budget plan -- a relatively small amount, which could make the whole plan more palatable to legislators facing re-election this fall.
But the proposal is heavy with potentially risky assumptions about declines in interests rates, drops in state health care costs and savings from refinanced state debt. As a result, legislative leaders from both parties, who have been hesitant to start budget negotiations until the Federal budget impasse is broken, reacted skeptically.
Even the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican who is Mr. Pataki's strongest ally in the Legislature, referred to Mr. Pataki's $1.4 billion in found money as "a wish list" that was not certain to come true.
"My feeling is that the final document will look quite different than what is before us now," Mr. Bruno said. "But that is the process."
And the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, said the new plan had probably arrived too late to be seriously considered in time for the new fiscal year. He accused the Governor of trying to shift blame for the state's fiscal problems onto President Clinton and the Legislature, and said he would prefer simply extending the state's fiscal year until July 1 to give Congress additional time to enact a new budget.
"The Governor had three months to fix what everyone knew was the problem in his budget," Mr. Silver said. "This is just recognizing that his original budget submission was not balanced."
Analysts with Wall Street firms that rate New York State's bonds said they had not had enough time to determine whether Mr. Pataki's proposal was realistic. They praised the plan as a good way to kick-start negotiations with the Legislature. But, they said, it seems almost certain that the budget will be late for the 12th consecutive year -- far and away a national record.
Richard J. Marino, a director at Standard & Poor's, also expressed concerns that Mr. Pataki's plan still depends too heavily on additional Federal money to address the state's recurring problem of spending more than it receives in revenues. He said the state's low bond rating -- which increases the state's borrowing costs -- would stand a better chance of improving if the state balanced its budget without relying so much on Federal aid.
Throughout his news conference today, Mr. Pataki placed the onus for solving the Federal budget impasse on President Clinton. Time and again, Mr. Pataki said that while Republican Congressional leaders had endorsed the welfare and Medicaid changes he wants, White House officials have been lukewarm to them. And he charged that the President was preventing a final Federal budget agreement because of election-year politics.
"I don't see why the President should not sign this," he said, referring to a plan endorsed by the National Governors' Association that would provide New York State the changes Mr. Pataki wants. "But it is an election year."
Asked what evidence he had that Mr. Clinton was motivated by Presidential politics, Mr. Pataki said, "I don't see any other reason why there is not an agreement."
But Democrats accused Mr. Pataki of acting as a political surrogate for Senator Bob Dole, the Republican Party's presumptive Presidential nominee, who Mr. Pataki has strongly supported throughout the primary season.
"To describe it in a word, it's Dole-ful," Mr. Silver said. "Pataki goes to Washington, talks to Newt Gingrich and comes back and says that the whole budget problem is Clinton's fault. That's what he would have you believe."
Under his plan, Mr. Pataki would close his $2 billion gap using $1.4 billion in newly found money, about $400 million in savings from shifting state costs to the Federal Government and $223 million in new spending cuts.
The plan includes many of the types of financial rejiggering that is typical of Albany budget negotiations at this time of year. For instance, it raises his projections for tax revenues by $483 million.
It also re-estimates downward the amount of money the Governor expects to spend on social programs, projecting that fewer people will be on the welfare rolls than originally expected and that health care costs will fall faster than anticipated. Both of those projections assume that the economy will not weaken and force more people to request public assistance.
The plan also calls for the state to try to maximize its Federal Medicaid reimbursements. One measure would increase a state tax on nursing homes by $76 million -- money that the owners could recoup almost entirely from Medicaid.
Mr. Pataki has criticized strategies like this in the past. But today he said, "If they won't change the rules, we'll play by the rules."
The Governor would also take $350 million from a state fund set aside to help doctors defray medical malpractice costs and use it to close the budget gap. And he projects that the state can save $197 million by refinancing its debt.
A large part of the $223 million in new cuts are to the Governor's own initiatives, including eliminating Mr. Pataki's proposal to use $100 million in state Lottery money for property tax relief.
Mr. Pataki's plan is unprecedented in that it asks the Legislature to pass a budget that includes two totally different assumptions: first, that Congress will enact major changes to welfare and Medicaid programs, and second, that it will not.
Under the first assumption, if Congress fails to make the changes Mr. Pataki wants, all the $1.4 billion in the new projections would be used to close the new $2 billion shortfall.
But if Congress does do what the Governor wants, he would use the $1.4 billion to increase spending on mental health, education and Medicaid programs. The plan would also set aside $125 million for "local economic development grants," which in Albany parlance has traditionally meant pork barrel spending for legislators.
Mr. Pataki's proposal to convert welfare and Medicaid programs into block grants would be placed on hold, pending enactment of a Federal budget. The proposal had been to give local governments less money for social programs but more freedom to decide how to spend it.


GRAPHIC: Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday that he had come up with $1.4 billion in revenues and savings that he would use to plug a hole in his proposed budget.Fiscal experts and bond rating firms often frown on budgetary maneuvers like these, saying that they are often based upon risky assumptions that do not pan out.

HEADLINE: Administration Calls for End To G.M. Strike

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio, March 15

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration called on the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers today to settle a 10-day strike that has virtually shut down the North American operations of the world's largest auto maker. The call came hours after negotiations here appeared to show the first signs of progress.
The strike at two brake factories here has forced G.M. to close 24 of its 29 assembly plants and dozens of parts factories across North America. The company announced the layoffs today of another 13,350 auto parts workers, bringing the number of idled G.M. workers to 124,700, plus another 7,300 Saturn workers who were receiving training while their factory is closed. 
 Wall Street analysts estimate that the strike is costing G.M. as much as $50 million a day.
In the Administration's first public comment on the auto industry's biggest work stoppage in a quarter century, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich in a statement this evening urged both sides to resolve their differences.
"The American public is holding its collective breath while this work stoppage idles more than 85,000 workers across the country," Mr. Reich said. "Clearly, the best way to settle this dispute is by both parties coming to the bargaining table."
While G.M. has included close to 40,000 Mexican and Canadian workers in its figures for idled workers, Mr. Reich excluded them.
Mr. Reich also appeared today to side with the U.A.W. in its fight with G.M. over whether laid-off workers were entitled to unemployment benefits. G.M. announced late Thursday that it would ask state governments across the country to deny unemployment benefits to U.A.W. workers laid off because of a brake shortage caused by the strike by close to 3,200 U.A.W. workers here.
"I would hope that workers' claims to unemployment benefits be given every consideration," Mr. Reich said. "Unemployment compensation determinations are made by states. Nothing in Federal law prohibits states from paying these workers if allowed by state statutes."
G.M. officials declined to comment on Mr. Reich's remarks, referring reporters instead to previous statements by spokesmen. "Since G.M. is assessed the cost of state unemployment compensation, we don't believe we should finance a strike against ourselves," John F. Mueller, a company spokesman, said on Thursday evening.
G.M. has tried to block unemployment benefits during long strikes in the past when a strike at one or two factories has forced layoffs elsewhere, arguing that the laid-off workers are effectively part of the strike. Most state laws limit or prohibit unemployment benefits for strikers.
James M. Hagedon Jr., a spokesman here, said this morning that the negotiations were continuing in Dayton and that "our priority remains to reach an equitable agreement as soon as possible so we can resume supply to our customers."
Leery of being labeled as traditional Democrats too close to organized labor, Clinton Administration officials have seldom commented on strikes the last several years. But the Administration has been trying to find a delicate balance in an election year between satisfying business groups while keeping labor unions happy.
Today's slap at G.M. was particularly unusual because the Big Three auto makers in Detroit have supported many of President Clinton's initiatives. They were particularly vocal in 1994 in favor of the Administration's health care plan, which would have helped them cope with the health care costs from their large and growing number of retirees.
But long before Mr. Reich issued his statement, the pace of talks here accelerated. Both sides sent senior officials from Detroit today for the first time since the early days of the strike, local officials from the union said.
The two sides agreed to stop discussing their differences in public and began talks at noon that continued until 10 P.M., the longest sustained negotiations here since the strike began. More talks were planned for the weekend.
Earlier this week, an auto company official said that the dispatch of senior officials from Detroit would signal the beginning of serious talks.
Several officials from the U.A.W.'s headquarters and one G.M. official from Detroit suddenly joined the talks today, said several local union officials who insisted on anonymity. The officials were fairly senior but did not include Richard Shoemaker, the head of the U.A.W.'s General Motors division, the local officials said.
Personal animosity between local union and factory officials has slowed the negotiations over the last week. Joe Buckley, the chairman of the bargaining committee for U.A.W. Local 696, which is on strike here, swore vociferously when asked about the brake factories' top managers on Thursday.
"One of the most difficult things after this is going to be to try to work with current management," he said. "They should consider some changes."
Scott F. Merlis, an independent auto analyst in Westport, Conn., estimated today that the strike was trimming $50 million a day from G.M.'s pretax earnings. The company can probably recover only half of the losses in later quarters with extra production, he added.
G.M. was selling its highly profitable pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles as fast as it could build them before the strike, so the lost output has a direct effect on profits.
Bob Rodriguez, the financial secretary of U.A.W. Local 696, said in an interview this afternoon that the union was willing to stay on strike "as long as it takes."

HEADLINE: SHOOTOUT IN THE BRONX: THE SUSPECTS;
3 Young Men With Violent Records Dating to Their Teens

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
Ricardo Morales was 15 when he helped hold up a Bronx bodega, a stickup that left the owner dead. Angel Diaz's start in crime came almost as early -- he was 16 when he was sent to prison for holding up a jewelry store, 19 when he was paroled and 20 when he was sent back to prison for robbery and assault. Jesus Mendez had barely turned 18 when he began a 7-year sentence for armed robberies in the Bronx.
The three men returned to the streets of the Bronx within months of each other in 1995. And on Thursday night, law enforcement officials said, the three were together at 187th Street and Arthur Avenue in the Bronx. 
 There, the police said, the three men -- all under the supervision of parole officers -- began what would become their bloodiest crime spree, one that ended with a New York City police officer dead.
The criminal records of the three men are sure to raise questions about the criminal justice system: about the state parole system, about sentencing rules, about the handling of juveniles who commit violent crimes and about a judge who Bronx prosecutors say reduced their bail demand for one of the three men after he was arrested last month.
Mr. Diaz, who investigators say fired the shot that killed Officer Kevin Gillespie, was first arrested in 1985. He was convicted of armed robbery, paroled barely two years into a 2- to 6-year sentence, and was back in prison seven months after his release, convicted of robbery and assault after a gang he was with held up a grocery store. His sentence was 3 1/2 to 7 years.
Mr. Diaz got what is known as a conditional release from prison in October and was required to report weekly to a parole officer. His most recent visit to his parole officer was last week, state parole officials said. He told the parole officer that he was unemployed and living with his mother. Ten days later, Mr. Diaz was in handcuffs and on the ground, arrested for killing a police officer after stealing a car.
At 15, Mr. Morales was too young to go to prison when he was arrested in 1988 for the deadly holdup of a bodega on Castle Hill Avenue in the Bronx. The store owner was killed, and an employee was wounded; the holdup was the second conducted by Mr. Morales in a three-day span.
Mr. Morales was sentenced as a juvenile to 5 to 10 years. On May 26, 1995, Mr. Morales, after serving less than seven years, was granted a conditional release. He made his required weekly visits to a parole officer and regularly passed his drug tests. In October, he was found to be wearing a beeper and ordered to abide by a curfew. He was to be under the supervision of a parole officer until 1998.
Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed that parole be abolished for violent criminals and that violent young criminals be treated like adults. Had such measures been in force, they might have kept Mr. Diaz and Mr. Morales in prison longer.
Mr. Mendez's trip through the criminal justice system could well prove the most troubling. Arrested in 1987 for armed robberies, Mr. Mendez served 7 1/2 years and was paroled last July. In January, Mr. Mendez, who had been meeting with a parole officer, was arrested for robbery, assault and possession of a weapon.
Instead of instantly returning Mr. Mendez to prison for a parole violation, parole officials, as is customary, deferred to prosecutors, allowing them to go ahead with their new case against him.
Steven Reed, a spokesman for District Attorney Robert T. Johnson of the Bronx, said prosecutors had asked for $100,000 bail for Mr. Mendez. Mr. Reed said Judge Ruth Sussman had instead set bail at $25,000. Mr. Mendez posted bond on Feb. 14 and was released.
"We asked for bail to be set at what we believed was appropriate," Mr. Reed said. Mr. Mendez reported for two subsequent meetings in February with his parole officer, but he failed to appear for a meeting on Feb. 28 and missed a court appearance on Feb. 29. A warrant was issued for Mr. Mendez's arrest late last month.

HEADLINE: Pataki's New Budget Proposal Puts Giuliani's Plans on Hold

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki's new budget proposal threw New York City's budget into disarray yesterday, offering a tiny flicker of hope for new state aid but raising the far more likely possibility that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will receive less than he has said he needs to close the city's $2 billion shortfall.
The most immediate effect of the Governor's proposals, however, could be to delay a full resolution of the city's budget until the state budget falls entirely into place: maybe this spring, maybe in the fall. All of it shows how the Federal budget impasse is causing ripple effects at every level of government statewide. 
 The Governor's proposal -- essentially a contingency plan of $1.4 billion in newly identified revenues that he would use if Washington does not enact the budgetary changes he hopes for -- reflected a growing recognition that the state might not receive the $2 billion in savings from Federal changes that Mr. Pataki had figured into his budget.
The Mayor's own preliminary proposal for the city's $31 billion budget in turn relied heavily on Mr. Pataki's ability to receive those savings. What's more, it assumed the state would share a larger part of the savings with New York City than the Governor proposed.
Mr. Pataki, a Republican, is still leaving open the possibility that the state will receive the savings from Washington, mostly in Medicaid and welfare. The state and city share the costs of those programs, so reductions in the state's benefits allow the city, too, to save money.
If the Governor fails to receive the savings, then the $1.4 billion in new revenues, along with other contingency plans, would plug the subsequent hole in the state's budget. If he receives the savings, which many officials from New York to Washington doubt, the new money would be used for a variety of programs, including what Mr. Pataki said was $690 million in new aid for the city.
Far from clarifying the city's budget picture, the Governor's proposal created such a muddle that the Mayor's office declined to comment until budget aides review the plan. The Mayor's press secretary, Colleen A. Roche, did say that Mr. Pataki had called Mr. Giuliani, also a Republican, and said the changes "would be helpful to the city."
But the Democrats who control the City Council criticized the Governor's proposal. Thomas L. McMahon, the Council's finance director, said the Governor was holding out the promise of new state aid that the city could desperately use, knowing there was actually little chance of getting it.
Either way, Mr. McMahon noted, even before today's modifications, the Governor's budget proposal included cuts in aid for the city and cuts in spending on education, health care and social services that will hurt many New Yorkers, particularly the poorest.
"It's a plan that continues to shortchange the taxpayers of New York City," Mr. McMahon said.
The Governor's new plan came on the day that the state's Financial Control Board issued a report strongly criticizing Mr. Giuliani's budget proposals for this fiscal year and the years ahead. Among its major criticisms, the board rebuked the Mayor for relying too heavily on state aid that was unlikely to materialize.
The board, created during the fiscal crisis to oversee the city's finances, concluded that the gap between the city's spending and its projected revenues would continue to widen to "historic highs" in the coming years: higher even than those during the recessionary years under Mr. Giuliani's Democratic predecessor, David N. Dinkins.
The board attributed some of the problem to the weak economy, but it also blamed the city for continuing to overspend, singling out the Mayor's recent labor settlements, which will add hundreds of millions of dollars in costs to the city's budgets in future years. And it criticized the Mayor's use of budget actions that provided one-time savings without addressing the city's core fiscal problems.
"In spite of the massive gap-closing efforts of the past several years," the board said, referring to the Mayor's first two years of budget cutting, "the city's finances continue to deteriorate."

HEADLINE: Prices of Treasuries Retreat for a Fourth Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday for the fourth time this week as concerns grew over the faster pace of economic growth.
Strong gains in reports on industrial production, capacity utilization and in the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index caused selling that raised bond yields to their highest level in six months. The data appeared to bury any remaining hopes of a quick interest-rate cut by the Federal Reserve. 
 The price of the 30-year bond rose on Monday but lost ground on subsequent days. Yesterday it dropped 18/32 , to 9019/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.73 percent, from 6.68 percent on Thursday. It was the highest yield since Aug. 24, 1995, when it was 6.81 percent.
Hugh Whelan, vice president and portfolio manager at Aeltus Investment Management in Hartford, said the data this week confirmed the market's view that last week's employment report pointed to a strengthening economy.
Indeed, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday that industrial production rose 1.2 percent in February. The gain was higher than expected and was a rebound from a decline of four-tenths of 1 percent in January.
The central bank also said that capacity utilization, or the amount of industrial capacity in use, rose to 82.9 percent in February from a revised 82.1 percent in January.
"Industrial production and capacity use was stronger than many had been led to believe," Mr. Whelan said. "And we know it appears to be growing at a healthy level relative to the 1995 fourth quarter G.D.P. But just as important, bullish investors have been focusing on the health of the consumer. The University of Michigan sentiment report released today says consumers do not appear to be very worried, and signals that they will be opening their wallets more."
Mr. Whelan said a further indication of consumer sentiment would come next week, when February retail sales are reported.
The University of Michigan's preliminary consumer sentiment index for early March rose to 95.7 from 88.5 in February, traders and analysts said. The index is released only to subscribers.
In another report, the Consumer Price Index for February rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent, suggesting that inflation remained subdued. But the positive implications of the report had little impact on the bearish market.
Kenneth J. McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, a research analysis firm, said, "In the past few weeks, the bond market has dropped like a rock."
The rise in yields, he said, has been prompted by "a reassessment by market participants about how strong the economy is."
"Instead of believing the economy was very weak, and the Federal Reserve will continue to lower rates," he said, "suddenly they appear to expect a surge that will ignite inflation and keep the Fed from lowering rates further and possibly push the central bank to increase rates later this year."
But Mr. McCarthy said the market was overreacting. "While the economy is certainly not as weak as it appeared in January, it is far from strong," he said. "It has picked up momentum in the past two months and is growing at a 2.5 percent annual pace, compared with 0.9 percent in the fourth quarter. That's an improvement, but it does not warrant the kinds of increases in interest rates that we have seen in recent months."

HEADLINE: TENNIS;
Haarhuis, Ranked 68th, Defeats Sampras

BYLINE: By ROBIN FINN 

DATELINE: INDIAN WELLS, Calif., March 15

 BODY:
Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi both missed a chance to grab the No. 1 ranking today when they failed to brave perfect desert conditions and bowed out in the quarterfinals of the Newsweek Champions Cup.
Sampras, the two-time defending champion, wilted in the sun this afternoon against 68th-ranked Paul Haarhuis of the Netherlands, 7-5, 6-7 (5-7), 6-1. 
 Then Agassi, featured under the spotlights tonight against fifth-seeded Michael Chang, put on an increasingly flawed performance and succumbed, 6-7 (3-7), 6-2, 6-1. Agassi, who prides himself on his accuracy and his piercing return of serve, made 44 unforced errors and found himself aced 13 times; in all, Chang had 17 service winners to 3 by Agassi. The Las Vegan would have claimed the top ranking had he won.
The loss to Haarhuis cost Sampras his title defense and his chance to regain his No. 1 ranking from Thomas Muster, the Austrian powerhouse. Sampras didn't seem unduly devastated. "C'est la vie," he said. "If you don't play well, you're not going to win. I don't care who you're playing, but if you let him dictate, he's going to dictate," Sampras said of Haarhuis, who has gotten the better of him in three of four meetings.
Sampras doesn't often find himself outserved and out-aced, but Haarhuis, better known for his doubles conquests, used the relatively passive Sampras for target practice from start to finish. Haarhuis served 11 aces, 1 more than Sampras, and unlike Sampras, who was broken three times, the 30-year-old Dutchman never lost a service game.
After claiming the opening set, Haarhuis forced the tie breaker with a pair of aces and took a 4-3 lead there with another ace. But Sampras served himself to a 5-4 lead and tied the proceedings at a set apiece when he converted his second set point with a 114-mile-an-hour ace.
But Sampras's resurgence was short-lived, as Haarhuis jumped out to a 4-1 lead in the final set. He broke the sluggish Sampras for a 5-1 lead with a down-the-line forehand return that Sampras couldn't shovel back over the net. Sampras surrendered the match by netting a forehand on Haarhuis's first match point.
Haarhuis, who earned an economics degree from Florida State University in 1988 and put himself on the tennis map a year later by defeating John McEnroe at the United States Open, captured his first career singles title just last year.
"He's always given the Top 10 players trouble, and I'm one of them," Sampras said.
Haarhuis simply played it sharp and smart, and that was enough to unsettle Sampras, who committed 38 unforced errors and was particularly inept from the backcourt. "I don't know what happened," Sampras said. "My shots from the backcourt were just flying, just spraying."

HEADLINE: On Language;
Of Mainstreams and Movements

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
"THIS IS A RACE BETWEEN THE MAINSTREAM and the extreme," declared Senator Bob Dole, drawing the battle lines after his New Hampshire defeat by Pat Buchanan. That choice of words has reverberated through recent political history.
At the 1964 Republican convention in San Francisco's Cow Palace, as I noted recently, the outnumbered and humiliated Rockefeller-Scranton "moderates" hauled a 30-foot banner emblazoned with "Stay in the Mainstream" across the floor, to the derision of the Goldwater delegates. When the nominee, Barry Goldwater, cried, "Extremism in the defense of liberty is no vice!" he stimulated a roar of enthusiastic approval from what was being called "the Goldwater movement." But observing from a box, the neutral Richard Nixon sat on his hands, telling friends later that Goldwater's choice of words guaranteed the landslide victory of Lyndon Johnson, which led to the Democrats' Great Society. 
 At the time, I thought that the political use of mainstream was a Rockefeller coinage. In fact, President Kennedy had told the Irish Parliament in 1963 that "Ireland is moving in the mainstream of current world events"; a month later, a Rockefeller speech writer, Hugh Morrow, fashioned a blast at "vociferous and well-drilled extremist elements boring within the party" that were "wholly alien to the broad middle course that accommodates the mainstream of Republican principle."
After the G.O.P. paradise was lost, it turned out that the actual coiner was John Milton: "The neather Flood," he wrote about the fall of the angels in his 1667 poem, " . . . now divided into four main Streames." Thomas Carlyle picked up the term in 1831, holding that "the Didactic Tendency . . . still forms the main stream," and in 1865 the critic Matthew Arnold hailed Byron and Shelley for their "Titanic effort to flow in the main stream of modern literature." A century later, the word was popularized by jazz writers: "Humph" -- a bandleader known by a single name -- "is authentic mainstreamer," wrote The New Left Review in 1961. "He's been influenced by everything in jazz up to the moment."
Mainstream gained a positive connotation in politics after the Goldwater debacle, though moderate, a seeming synonym, was considered by many to be a euphemism for "liberal." Extremism became pejorative again (despite its ringing defense by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.), and was embraced by President Bill Clinton to hammer at newly elected Republican Representatives in Congress who wanted a balanced budget on terms other than his.
Because of this use by Democrats, and notwithstanding the rhyming endings of mainstream and extreme, the Dole attack on Buchanan using that Goldwater-blessed word drew a tut-tut from Ralph Reed of the Christian Coalition: "It is strategically unwise and politically shortsighted to label Buchanan or his supporters as, ipso facto, extremists or intolerant," he said. "That is the language of the left." (Ipso facto is the language of Latin and means literally "by the fact itself," its extended meaning "as an inevitable result.") Dole then turned to derogating Buchanan as a fringe candidate, one that could be defined as "on the margin," but that evokes memories of Theodore Roosevelt's classic 1913 pop at ardent reformers as a lunatic fringe.
Mr. Buchanan's political language has ranged from the subtle to the mysterious. One use is, at least to me, obscure: when the candidate Steve Forbes complained of attacks by opponents he had long been lambasting in TV commercials, Buchanan said, "What's happened is the little rich kid, who's been sitting on his estate throwing rocks at all the cars passing by, finally had someone get out of the car and clock him one." Clock him one? This may be a variant of bop him one or a reference to clean his clock; elucidation is sought from Lexicographic Irregulars, timepiece-vernacular division.
In the past, I have heard my former colleague in the speech dodge refer to himself as a movement conservative, meaning the Goldwater "movement" in contrast to traditional conservatives or neoconservatives. Lately, he has applied this word to his followers: "Listen, we have a great movement here. And if you bring Pat Buchanan's movement together with the Republican Party, we have a majority." That suggests his movement is separate from, and addable to or subtractable from, the G.O.P., holding out the threat of a bolt (a horseracing term).
It also offers an example of the vogue of third-person reference now gripping the Republican field. Nobody says I or me anymore; candidates call themselves by their proper names. Walter Bingham of Truro, Mass., wrote The New York Times about third-personalities: "Imagine if our country's leaders over the years had done the same: 'Give Patrick Henry liberty or give Patrick Henry death.' Or 'Douglas MacArthur shall return.' "
The most subtle use of a Nixon-era phrase was Buchanan's "Watch what we do"; this is taken from the comment of John Mitchell, Nixon's Attorney General, who answered a question about integration policy with "Watch what we do, not what we say." This was taken at the time to be evidence of hypocrisy, but later was understood as shorthand for strictly enforcing integration while publicly expressing sympathy for those opposing it.
Meanwhile, Lamar Alexander, who rejected "the Buchanan movement" and labeled its philosophy of "the wrong ideas" Buchananism (evoking McCarthyism), turned derisive fire on the best-financed candidate: he described Steve Forbes's proposal for a flat, or nonprogressive, tax as "a nutty idea."
"Nutty it's not," editorialized The Wall Street Journal. Milton Friedman, the Nobel-winning economist, said, "Far from being a nutty idea, the flat tax has a long pedigree -- back to tithing for the church." Prof. David Bradford of Princeton weighed in with "Nutty is the word to apply to the existing income tax." Paul Craig Roberts insisted, "It is a nutty idea only to people opposed to American success." But the dismal scientists are not running for office; many political realists agreed with Alexander's use.
The human head is shaped like, and is hard as, a nut. "She meets with a spoony that's nutty," went an English ballad collected in 1799; the meaning was "crazy with love." A century later, according to Jesse Sheidlower of Random House, the spooniness gave way to plain looniness in a book about New York's Chinatown: "He was either nutty or 'off his feed.' " In the mid-1930's, the simile nutty as a fruitcake appeared, and was used by a visitor to Al Capone in prison to sadly describe the gangster's mental decline.
Today, nutty is not as wild as "crazy," not as condemnatory as "foolish," not as formal or limited to the wealthy as "eccentric." Its precise synonym, which threatened to replace it until the word was rescued by anti-flat-taxers, is wacky.
