SECTION: Section 6; Page 40; Column 2; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3239 words

HEADLINE: CLASS IS NO LONGER A FOUR-LETTER WORD

BYLINE: By Jason DeParle; Jason DeParle is a staff writer for the Magazine, based in Washington. His last article was on Newt Gingrich.

 BODY:
The class content of a Pat Buchanan rally is so thick you can smell it. It smells like motor oil. Or so it does this February afternoon on the floor of a transmission factory in Fort Dodge, Iowa, where the air tools hiss, the employees wear coveralls and Buchanan confers upon them the proud title "worker." He issues his usual condemnations of corporate greed and pokes fun at Steve Forbes, his impossibly rich rival, for cooking up his ideas with "the boys down at the yacht club." He even solicits Democratic votes by mocking his own party's plutocratic past. "You can join the party of greed for one evening!"
But when I approach Buchanan and note, perhaps with a trace of grudging admiration, that he has brought a new class sensibility to the election, he blanches. Actually, he puckers. "Class sensibility?" he says, spitting out the phrase like a bad olive. Though Buchanan is rarely at a loss for words, this stops him cold. "I don't think I want to go anywhere near that one." Instead, he climbs back into his bus and resumes his underdog campaign, on behalf of those who "work with their hands and tools and machines." 
 Call it what you will, but class anger is back. Who could have imagined that a win in New Hampshire would come to the man who called the stock market "un-American"? Or that Bob Dole would pose, even fleetingly, as a critic of corporate America? For those who like their politics leavened with a little economic envy, it has been a soap-operatic delight, this spectacle of millionaires decrying one another's ill-gotten gain. These are, after all, Republicans.
Buchanan himself may be all but vanquished as a Republican contender, but Buchananism will continue to be scrutinized, feared, mimicked -- and heard. His early success is a reminder of (among other things) the enduring, if often convoluted, ways that class grievances play out, despite the common pretense that Americans don't mess with that class warfare stuff. Indeed, a notable aspect of the current skirmishes is that they are, by American standards, astonishingly straightforward: frustrated workers are complaining about the inequities of the market. In recent years, anger, especially blue-collar anger, has tended to flow the other way. It has pointed down -- toward welfare families, immigrants and beneficiaries of affirmative action -- even as the distribution of income has been flowing steadily upward. In railing at "corporate butchers," Buchanan hasn't abandoned these other forms of class warfare; he has simply opened a second front.
On the surface, it seems a boon for the Democrats, who have been trying to make "fairness" an issue for at least 15 years. President Clinton could have been cribbing from Buchanan earlier this month when he traveled to the blue-collar precincts outside Detroit. "People my age, 50-year-old men, are being told they're not important anymore -- 'Thank you very much for the last 25 years; you figure out how to send your kids to college,' " he said. Representative Richard Gephardt, the House minority leader, goes as far as proclaiming a new era -- "the era of income politics." But an era of income politics is almost by definition an era of at least modestly assertive government. And wasn't that Bill Clinton himself claiming, in the State of the Union address, that "the era of big government is over"?
Campaign '96 promises less to inaugurate a new era than to underscore an old lesson. It shows how class sensitivity pervades American society, even as the national mythology -- and Buchanan himself -- pretends it does not. "I don't believe in class warfare," Buchanan says, while writing an instructive new manual in the art.
A WEEK AFTER HIS APPEARANCE AT THE TRANSMISSION factory, Buchanan is bouncing through a New Hampshire blizzard in a van, still contemplating the word "class." He says that when he first heard it from me in Iowa, his reaction was, "Uh-oh, this guy must be a Marxist." But returning now from an evening rally, Buchanan is warming to the term. "I mean, we win landslides among those under $30,000 and we've lost every time among those over $100,000," he says. "So there is no doubt we have great appeal to working people."
Buchanan quickly shows that he knows quite a bit about the politics of class. After all, he learned while writing speeches for two Republican Presidents, Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan, who were masterful at stripping Democrats of their working-class base. They did it not with explicit economic appeals but by talking about "values" and cracking the cultural codes. George Wallace led the way, appealing to blue-collar resentments by painting the Democrats as the party of "pseudo-intellectuals" and pampered, unshaven hippies.
A story recounted by Michael Kazin in his book "The Populist Persuasion" is telling. "You young people seem to know a lot of four-letter words," Wallace once taunted a crowd of demonstrators. "But I have two four-letter words you don't know: S-O-A-P and W-O-R-K." Seeing how Wallace had pried loose the blue-collar vote from the Democrats in 1968, Nixon captured it with appeals to the "silent majority" in speeches that Buchanan himself wrote. "We stood up for the squares of America, if you will, the Middle Americans," Buchanan says. "It had a class component."
Though Reagan grabbed the lunch-pail voter with similar appeals, Buchanan complains that "Reagan had a very difficult time being critical of big business." Buchanan talks of pressing him to add to a speech a threat to prosecute profiteering defense contractors. "He wouldn't put it in," he says. When I ask why not, Buchanan shows that he can warm to an audience quickly. He says the corporate chiefs were part of Reagan's crowd -- "that was reflecting class sensibility, if you will."
Buchanan's playfulness with the language of class is more than mere semantics. "Class" is itself a class-coded word, with an academic, upper-income lilt; in simultaneously mocking and employing it, Buchanan straddles a class divide. More broadly, his ability to embrace and eschew what he calls "class warfare" with equal conviction -- appealing to class divisions even while pretending they do not exist -- is a characteristically American trait. Didn't the founders proclaim that "all men are created equal" while themselves holding slaves?
Historians insist that for a number of reasons, class consciousness has a relatively weak hold on American life. The country has more powerful sources of identity -- ethnicity, religion and especially race. It has enjoyed a history of real economic mobility. And the civil religion insists lives should be equal, even when they are not. That's why financial extremes can be as embarrassing to the rich as they are to the poor, and why those at both ends identify themselves as "middle class." A Fort Dodge farmer with a Buchanan button seems offended when I ask whether he considers himself working class. "Everybody's working class," he insists -- even Steve Forbes. "It's just that some do more manual labor than others."
So class anger just doesn't sell -- except when it does. That is, the country remains suffused with class feeling, even if it rarely takes on enough self-awareness to be called class consciousness. "The class aspect is not the dominant aspect of American politics, but it's a lot more significant than our mythology allows," says Kevin Phillips, whose 1990 book, "The Politics of Rich and Poor," predicted the decade would see the rise of populist passions. If there is so little economic identity in American society, how does a country singer like Sammy Kershaw sell a million records complaining, "I ain't Goldfinger and I ain't Joe Fashion/And you can't buy much with the checks I'm cashin' "?
In an economy where the dollars are migrating ever upward, more voters are singing that tune. In 1994, annual household income was $1.1 trillion greater than it had been 15 years earlier. But calculations by Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution, show that the income received by those Americans in the bottom 53 percent of society actually declined. Average household incomes of the poorest fifth dropped 3 percent, to $7,800 a year. The next fifth, the blue- and pink-collar class? Down 4 percent, to $19,200. And what about the middle fifth, the bedrock of America, the true middle? Incomes dipped almost 2 percent, to $32,400, even though more families were relying on an additional wage earner. The only place the news is good is at the top, among the people whom Nashville songwriters mock for paying "their bills on home computers." The take of the top 5 percent soared to $183,000 a year -- a raise of 40 percent.
So it should come as no surprise that voters are irritable. The erratic politics of the 1990's might be thought of as a class brawl in search of a target. Playing the fairness card in 1992, Bill Clinton fingered the rich. "The rich get the gold mine and the middle class gets the shaft," he said. "It's wrong and it's going to ruin the country." Two years later, the Republicans captured Congress by insisting that the Government itself was the problem; the bureaucrat had become the boss. "We believe parents ought to have the money; they believe bureaucrats ought to have the money," said Newt Gingrich. But the Republicans played Robin Hood in reverse: taking from Medicare to finance reductions in capital gains. "The average voter read that as, 'The fat cats are back in charge,' " Kevin Phillips says. And Buchanan had an opening.
WHILE BUCHANAN TALKS OF "CORPORATE EXECUTIONERS," OTHERS find more subtle ways to advertise their class credentials. If roots were all that mattered, Dole would have it made. Coming of age in small-town Kansas during the Depression, he knew hardships not even imagined by Buchanan, who grew up as an accountant's son in a prosperous corner of Washington. "My father was a grain-elevator operator," Dole begins one evening last month in Oskaloosa, Iowa. "He wore his overalls to work every day for 42 years, and he was proud of it. Lived in a basement apartment. Rented out the upstairs to pay the bills. I grew up hardscrabble, know what it means to be at the bottom of the ladder economically."
Dole did indeed know hardscrabble, and he worked mightily to leave it behind. The symbols of his success are the very things his rivals use to raise doubts about him -- the corporate jets, the Senate pension, the apartment at the Watergate. Though he makes a wan effort to criticize corporate greed a few weeks later, Buchanan's remarks about that speech are more persuasive. "Everyone knows that one week after Bob Dole is there" -- at the White House, that is -- "he and Dwayne Andreas and Bob Strauss, they'll all go rolling over to Kay Graham's house and it'll be business as usual."
Still, Dole continues to talk on this evening in Iowa about the hardships of the past, and as he does, a new sort of double talk emerges. Suddenly Dole is saying kind things about people on welfare. "I used to sign checks for my grandparents when I was county attorney -- they were on welfare," he says. "Wasn't their fault. You can't take everything away from the poor and say, 'Oh, boy, we balanced the budget.' This is America." This is a pleasant sentiment, and Dole may even believe it. But it is wholly at odds with his recent votes to abolish Federal welfare guarantees. It is even at odds with his own campaign commercials, which label Forbes "too liberal" on welfare. Dole's ability to be on all sides of the class war may seem like a contradiction, but it's a classic American stance.
Forbes has no humble roots to market, but that doesn't leave him tone-deaf to class. Indeed, he has managed the counterintuitive feat of turning his wealth into a kind of populist credential: the people's candidate, too rich to be bought. What do strapped voters think of a man who lavishes $30 million on his own campaign? "It's better than taking PAC money," says a fellow in a billed cap, standing outside the National Sprint Car Hall of Fame in Knoxville, Iowa. Focus groups conducted by Senator Phil Gramm's campaign concluded that most voters felt the same way. Thus the presence this winter of a candidate whose momentary support seemed to defy the laws of economic envy -- an heir, seeking to abolish the progressive income tax!
Gramm dismissed him as "Richie Rich"; Lamar Alexander taunted him as "Junior." But Forbes turned his campaign into his own version of a class war, running against the despised "insiders." So it is that a man who inherited an island in Fiji and a plane called the Capitalist Tool could attack Bob Dole for having a "Versailles mentality." Or complain that Alexander's self-enrichment "beats Hillary's commodities deal hands down."
The strangest thing about Forbes's stance as an outsider is that he may actually believe it -- "rich as hell and not going to take it anymore," as one cartoonist put it, may be how he really feels. At least it sounds that way when he talks about the tax code, his own explanation for falling incomes. "Scrap it, actually kill it, drive a stake through its heart and hope it never rises again to terrorize the American people," he says. With the I.R.S. as his foil, Forbes has mastered the unimaginable. He has managed to turn class anger into an equal-opportunity emotion: even the rich can apply.
BUT NO ONE KEEPS UP WITH BUCHANAN, WHO, DRUNK ON HIS early success, turns to medieval war cries. "The peasants are coming with pitchforks!" he bellows at every stop. It's comic, captivating, viscerally appealing -- and scary. Those black-leather bikers and gun nuts turning up at his rallies may not have mastered the concept of metaphor. Urging them to "lock and load" -- and take aim at "Jose" -- is virtually a request for violence.
Buchanan might seem less offensive if he dropped his coded references to Jewish bankers and stopped saluting the Confederate flag. But he would still have no program to satisfy the class resentments he roils. His impasse is like that of the country at large. His antipathy for Wall Street steers him toward government, but his antipathy toward government pushes him back toward the market forces he decries. He careens, railing against one and then the other, seemingly unaware of the dilemma.
Buchanan believes that tariffs are the answer, but most economists think that trade makes only a modest contribution to the nation's rising inequality. When 18 prominent economists gathered at the end of 1994 at the Federal Reserve Bank in New York, they took an informal poll. On average, they attributed about 10 percent of the growing wage disparity to international trade. They gauged that another 10 percent came from declining union memberships, and 9 percent from the erosion of the minimum wage. By contrast, they attributed almost half of the increased income inequality to technological changes that benefit the better educated.
Consider General Motors, the kind of manufacturing behemoth that Buchanan wants to keep at home. Even if G.M. had not sent jobs to Mexico, it would be employing fewer blue-collar workers in Michigan. The company is painting more and more cars with robots. Or think of Microsoft, which isn't moving to Mexico but is making millionaires out of math-class nerds. Or picture, for that matter, the Buchanan campaign, where laptop computers and voice mail can do the work of dozens of clerks, who might have drawn salaries in an earlier campaign. "Buchanan's kind of like the little Dutch boy who puts his finger in the dike," says Gary Burtless, the Brookings economist. "If he puts in this tariff, he might reduce one source of downward pressure, but I and most economists don't think it's the major source of downward pressure."
In the short run, most economists argue that the inequality of the market can't be reversed, only ameliorated. "You don't want the Government saying that I.B.M. can't lay off people," says Sheldon Danziger, co-author, with Peter Gottschalk, of "America Unequal," a study of recent income trends. "I mean, you want technological change, since you need productivity. The market economy is going to generate big winners and losers, and there's not much that government can do in the short run but cushion these losses."
Cushion them, say, by insuring that those who lose their jobs can afford to buy health insurance. Or by expanding training opportunities. Or by raising the minimum wage. "The irony here is that Clinton had such a strategy," Danziger says. "And all these things were blown out of the water by the 1994 Congressional election."
But Buchanan, like his party, is locked into a reflexive hostility to government. Unless he finds a way to repeal the Information Age, strong minds will keep widening their advantage over strong backs. Yet here is Buchanan on the stump, calling the Department of Education "a $35 billion monster" and asking, "What's it doing?" In fact, it is using more than a third of its budget to help needy students attend college -- without which they would hold no passports to the new economy.
One minute, Buchanan frets that "capitalism, totally unbridled, is the law of the jungle." But ask which is causing more problems, the market or the Government, and Buchanan lurches back to Republican orthodoxy. "It's much more the Government. The American economy is an incredible machine for producing wealth, it really is. And if you get out of the way of it enough. . . ."
If you get out of the way of it enough . . . you're back to the law of the jungle. Which may explain why Buchanan makes this the rare sentence he chooses not to complete.
Can the Democrats capitalize? Unlike Buchanan, they don't choke on such modest Government endeavors as raising the minimum wage. Certainly the Labor Secretary, Robert Reich, makes that case. "I think the President and the Democrats can talk about the wage issue with a bit more confidence and authority than they talked about it before, because the Republicans will be doing the same," he says.
Gephardt is devising a strategy to make next fall's Congressional elections a referendum on issues related to income security -- like job training, portable health care and pensions, and a minimum-wage hike. He is even drafting a campaign document that seeks to unite House Democrats behind a common economic agenda. This is how he hopes to commence his "era of income politics." But if recent politics suggest anything, it should be reticence in proclaiming new eras. Still chastened by the 1994 elections, Clinton is wary of the Gephardt strategy and of anything that exposes him to more charges of being a big-spending liberal.
Clinton will continue to talk about wage stagnation as he did in Michigan, but he will do it gingerly, and without promising too much. "We've rejected a class-based argument out of here," says a White House official involved in the campaign. "Our message is going to be less divisive and more common-ground oriented."
Which means that even if Clinton wins, he won't have a mandate to do anything. Neither the Republicans' distrust of government bureaucracy nor the Democrats' distrust of the market is inherently misguided. The early primaries, in their unlikely splendor, showed the need to get beyond the ideological paralysis. By November, the talk of "peasants with pitchforks" will be gone, but class grievances will not.

HEADLINE: Putting Fabric Together, Putting Lives Back Together

BYLINE: By BESS LIEBENSON 

 BODY:
WHILE government is talking about getting people off welfare by starting training programs, Sue Westphal is doing something about it.
Her brainchild is South End Workshop, where women learn the art of sewing patchwork to create elegant, one-of-a-kind decorative accessories and has been operating at St. Luke's Community Services in the South End section of Stamford since August. 
 It started with a love of and collection of fabrics. "The germ of my idea goes back many years," said Ms. Westphal, an interior designer who has owned and operated three decorative accessory shops. "I've been exposed to beautiful fabrics from the time I was a student at the New York School of Interior Design and visited showrooms for samples of cuttings that were discarded."
Over the past 25 years, her collection and its appeal continued to grow. But only recently, when her children were grown and she felt relieved of financial pressures, was she able to develop a training program to teach women in transition from welfare to self-sufficiency to create high-quality patchwork home accessories.
"The women who come into the program have come to St. Luke's for a hand up, not a handout," said Gail Green-Singleton, director of training and employment support services at St. Luke's Community Services, a social services agency. "Our goal is to help people become as self-sufficient as they can."
St. Luke's provides two rooms in a 100-year-old building and a modest amount of support -- $1,200 for supplies.
"Right now it's a training program," said Ms. Westphal, who majored in economics at Smith College before design school and has long enjoyed sewing as a hobby. "The goal is to turn this into a for-profit business. Employment compensation will include an hourly wage with benefits, productivity incentives, profit sharing and the possibility of stock ownership. So it's more than creating jobs. It's offering an opportunity to become entrepreneurs."
In a rainbow-colored workroom where quilts decorate walls and shelves are filled with samples and yardage, Ms. Westphal is surrounded by three trainees. A work table is laid with a cutting mat and grid, one end used for ironing. In tandem, the women design, cut, piece and quilt on several donated sewing machines including a commercial machine designed for quilting.
Sandra Jerry, 36, who started here in September, described herself as formerly homeless and a crack addict. "I've been drug- and alcohol-free for four years," she said. Now, she said, "I'm on welfare and would love to get off it."
Ms. Jerry learned to sew her own clothes when she became interested in Islam 10 years ago. "I love to sew," she said, and wants "to learn everything that Sue knows."
In the long term, "I'd like to become a part-owner and manager," she said. "I have six children and have to figure out how to support them and send at least half to college."
Gloria Cuevas, 34, who came from the Dominican Republic six years ago and also receives assistance has been a trainee since October. "I love the sewing," she said. "I like everything about it, seeing the finished product and the regular work."
The group operates 9 to 5, five days a week, with Ms. Jerry working full time and the other two women part time. "From sales we had before Christmas we were able to distribute some funds without affecting their benefits," Ms. Westphal said. "We don't want to affect their benefits until this is a viable business. We want them to experience a long-term financial gain and independence but not be at any risk."
As well as quilts, they make pillow shams, table linens, place mats, napkins, runners, table squares, potholders and tea cozies. They have sold to Hoagland's in Greenwich and the Lion's Paw in Nantucket. They do custom work for clients with their own fabrics. And they display goods in space donated by Elizabeth Day Lawrence above her store on North Street in Banksville. In the space they have created sleeping and dining scenes to showcase their patchwork as well as refinished furniture.
Ms. Westphal, who studied decorative paint finishes at the Isabel O'Neil Studio in New York, said, "We're taking fabrics and recycling them and want to do the same for furniture, to do everything connected with the home -- apply paint finishes on walls and floors, and sew clothing and art pieces.
"The idea is to be a distinctive, creative task force with a reputation for creativity, style and quality workmanship. People can go on to do upholstery, slip covers and shades. There are unlimited possibilities."
Ms. Westphal said there is a new paradigm "which sees business as a force for social change and the welfare of those who work for the company as a priority along with a traditional bottom line."
